Perryville, Missouri 
____________ 
Beginning with Supp. No. 14, 
Supplemented by Municipal Code Corporation 
____________ 

> 
PREFACE 
    The Perryville, Missouri Municipal Code, originally published by Book Publishing Company, has been kept current by regular supplementation by Municipal Code Corporation, its successor in interest. 
    During original codification, the ordinances were compiled, edited and indexed by the editorial staff of Book Publishing Company under the direction of Marilyn Dobbelare, city clerk. 
    The code is organized by subject matter under an expandable three-factor decimal numbering system which is designed to facilitate supplementation without disturbing the numbering of existing provisions. Each section number designates, in sequence, the numbers of the Title, chapter, and section. Thus, Section 2.12.040 is Section .040, located in Chapter 2.12 of Title 2. In most instances, sections are numbered by tens (.010, .020, .030, etc.), leaving nine vacant positions between original sections to accommodate future provisions. Similarly, chapters and titles are numbered to provide for internal expansion. 
    In parentheses following each section is a legislative history identifying the specific sources for the provisions of that section. This legislative history is complemented by an ordinance disposition table, following the text of the code, listing by number all ordinances, their subjects, and where they appear in the codification; and beginning with Supplement No. 14, legislation can be tracked using the "Code Comparative Table and Disposition List." 
    A subject-matter index, with complete cross-referencing, locates specific code provisions by individual section numbers. 
    This supplement brings the Code up to date through Ordinance No. Ordinance No. 6141 , passed April 16, 2019. 
Municipal Code Corporation 
1700 Capital Circle SW 
Tallahassee, FL 32310 
800-262-2633 
HOW TO USE YOUR CODE 
    This code is organized to make the laws of the city as accessible as possible to city officials, city employees and private citizens. Please take a moment to familiarize yourself with some of the important elements of this code. 
Numbering System. 
    The numbering system is the backbone of a Code of Ordinances; Municipal Code Corporation uses a unique and versatile numbering structure that allows for easy expansion and amendment of this Code. It is based on three tiers, beginning with title, then chapter, and ending with section. Each part is represented in the code section number. For example, Section 2.04.010 is Section .010, in Chapter 2.04 of Title 2. 
Title. 
    A title is a broad category under which ordinances on a related subject are compiled. This code contains about 15 to 20 titles. For example, the first title is Title 1, General Provisions, which may contain ordinances about the general penalty, code adoption and definitions. The titles in this code are separated by tabbed divider pages for quick reference. Some titles are Reserved for later use. 
Chapter. 
    Chapters deal with more specific subjects, and are often derived from one ordinance. All of the chapters on a related subject are grouped in one title. The chapters are numbered so that new chapters which should logically be placed near certain existing chapters can be added at a later time without renumbering existing material. For example, Chapter 2.06, City Manager, can be added between 2.04, City Council, and Chapter 2.08, City Attorney. 
Section. 
    Each section of the code contains substantive ordinance material. The sections are numbered by "tens" to allow for expansion of the code without renumbering. 
Tables of Contents. 
    There are many tables of contents in this code to assist in locating specific information. At the beginning of the code is the main table of contents listing each title. In addition, each title and chapter has its own table of contents listing the chapters and sections, respectively. 
Ordinance History Note. 
    At the end of each code section, you will find an "ordinance history note," which lists the underlying ordinances for that section. The ordinances are listed by number, section (if applicable) and year. (Example: (Ord. 272 § 1, 1992).) 
    Beginning with Supplement No. 14, a secondary ordinance history note will be appended to affected sections. Ordinance history notes will be amended with the most recent ordinance added to the end. These history notes can be cross referenced to the code comparative table and disposition list appearing at the back of the volume preceding the index. 
Statutory References. 
    The statutory references direct the code user to those portions of the state statutes that are applicable to the laws of the municipality. As the statutes are revised, these references will be updated. 
Cross-Reference Table. 
    When a code is based on an earlier codification, the cross-reference table will help users find older or "prior" code references in the new code. The cross-reference table is located near the end of the code, under the tabbed divider "Tables." This table lists the prior code section in the column labeled "Prior Code Section" and the new code section in the column labeled "Herein." 
Ordinance List and Disposition Table. 
    To find a specific ordinance in the code, turn to the section called "Tables" for the Ordinance List and Disposition Table. This very useful table tells you the status of every ordinance reviewed for inclusion in the code. The table is organized by ordinance number and provides a brief description and the disposition of the ordinance. If the ordinance is codified, the chapter (or chapters) will be indicated. (Example: (2.04, 6.12, 9.04).) If the ordinance is of a temporary nature or deals with subjects not normally codified, such as budgets, taxes, annexations or rezones, the disposition will be "(Special)." If the ordinance is for some reason omitted from the code, usually at the direction of the municipality, the disposition will be "(Not codified)." Other dispositions sometimes used are "(Tabled)," "(Pending)," "(Number Not Used)" or "(Missing)." 
Index. 
    If you are not certain where to look for a particular subject in this code, start with the index. This is an alphabetical multi-tier subject index which uses section numbers as the reference, and cross-references where necessary. Look for the main heading of the subject you need, then the appropriate subheadings: 
BUSINESS LICENSE 
See also BUSINESS TAX 
Fee 5.04.030 
Required when 5.04.010 
    The index will be updated as necessary when the code text is amended. 
Instruction Sheet. 
    Each supplement to the new code will be accompanied by an Instruction Sheet. The Instruction Sheet will tell the code user the date of the most recent supplement and the last ordinance contained in that supplement. It will then list the pages that must be pulled from the code and the new pages that must be inserted. Following these instructions carefully will assure that the code is kept accurate and current. Removed pages should be kept for future reference. 
Page Numbers. 
    When originally published, the pages of this code were consecutively numbered. As of Supplement No. __, when new pages are inserted with amendments, the pages will follow a "Point Numbering System". (Example: 32, 32.1, 32.2, 32.2.1, 32.2.2., 33). Backs of pages that are blank (in codes that are printed double-sided) will be left unnumbered but the number will be "reserved" for later use. 
Electronic Submission. 
    In the interests of accuracy and speed, we encourage you to submit your ordinances electronically if at all possible. We can accept most any file format, including Word, WordPerfect or text files. If you have a choice, we prefer Word, any version. You can send files to us as an e-mail attachment, by FTP, on a diskette or CD-ROM. Electronic files enable us not only to get you your code more quickly but also ensure that it is error-free. Our e-mail address is: ords@municode.com. 
For hard copy, send two copies of all ordinances passed to: 
Municipal Code Corporation 
P.O. Box 2235 
Tallahassee, FL 32316 
Customer Service. 
    If you have any questions about this code or our services, please contact Municipal Code Corporation at 1-800-262-2633 or: 
Municipal Code Corporation

Tallahassee, FL 32310

Title 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Chapters: 
Chapter 1.01 - CODE ADOPTION 
Sections: 

1.01.010 - Adoption. 
    There is adopted the "Perryville Municipal Code," as compiled, edited and published by Book Publishing Company, Seattle, Washington. 
(Ord. 3841 § 1, 1999) 
1.01.020 - Title-Citation-Reference. 
    This code shall be known as the "Perryville Municipal Code" and it shall be sufficient to refer to said code as the "Perryville Municipal Code" in any prosecution for the violation of any provision of this code or in any proceeding at law or equity. It is sufficient to designate any ordinance adding to, amending, correcting or repealing all or any part or portion of this code as an addition to, amendment to, correction or repeal of the "Perryville Municipal Code." References may be made to the titles, chapters, sections and subsections of the "Perryville Municipal Code" and such references shall apply to those titles, chapters, sections or subsections as they appear in the code. 
(Ord. 3841 § 2, 1999) 
1.01.030 - Reference applies to all amendments. 
    Whenever a reference is made to this code as the "Perryville Municipal Code" or to any portion thereof, or to any ordinance of the city of Perryville, Missouri, codified herein, the reference shall apply to all amendments, corrections and additions heretofore, now or hereafter made. 
(Ord. 3841 § 3, 1999) 
1.01.040 - Title, chapter and section headings. 
    Title, chapter and section headings contained in this code shall not be deemed to govern, limit, modify or in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any title, chapter or section in this code. 
(Ord. 3841 § 4, 1999) 
1.01.050 - Reference to specific ordinances. 
    The provisions of this code shall not in any manner affect matters of record which refer to, or are otherwise connected with ordinances which are therein specifically designated by number or otherwise and which are included within the code, but such reference shall be construed to apply to the corresponding provisions contained within this code. 
(Ord. 3841 § 5, 1999) 
1.01.060 - Ordinances passed prior to adoption of the code. 
    The last ordinance included in this code was Ordinance 3669, passed August 5, 1998. The following ordinances, passed subsequent to Ordinance 3669, but prior to adoption of this code, are adopted and made a part of this code: Ordinances 3770 through 3838 passed after August 5, 1998, and prior to March 2, 1999. 
(Ord. 3841 § 6, 1999) 
1.01.070 - Effect of code on past actions and obligations. 
    The adoption of this code does not affect prosecutions for ordinance violations committed prior to the effective date of this code, does not waive any fee or penalty due and unpaid on the effective date of this code, and does not affect the validity of any bond or cash deposit posted, filed or deposited pursuant to the requirements of any ordinance. 
(Ord. 3841 § 7, 1999) 
1.01.080 - Constitutionality. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause or phrase of this code is for any reason held to be invalid or unconstitutional, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions of this code. 
(Ord. 3841 § 8, 1999) 
1.01.090 - References to prior code. 
    References in city forms, documents and regulations to the chapters and sections of the former city code shall be construed to apply to the corresponding provisions contained within this code. 
(Ord. 3841 § 9, 1999) 
Chapter 1.04 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

1.04.010 - Code title designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters shall constitute and be designated the "Perryville Municipal Code" and may be so cited. 
(Prior code § 1-1) 
1.04.020 - Rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this code, and of all ordinances, the following rules shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of aldermen: 
    "Alderman" means any person who is a member of the board of aldermen of the city of Perryville. 
    "Board of aldermen" or "board," unless the context requires otherwise, shall be construed to refer to the board of aldermen of the city of Perryville. 
    "City" means the city of Perryville in the state of Missouri. 
    "Code of ordinances," "municipal code" or "code" means the Perryville Municipal Code. 
    "Computation of time" means the time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; and if the last day is Sunday or a legal holiday, that day shall be excluded. 
    "County," "the county" or "this county" means the county of Perry in the state of Missouri. 
    Delegation of Authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department of the city to do some act or make certain inspections, it shall be construed to authorize the head of the department to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision designate otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to males. 
    Joint Authority. Words importing joint authority to three or more persons shall be construed as authority to a majority of such persons. 
    "Mayor" means the mayor of the city of Perryville. 
    "Month" means a calendar month. 
    Name of Officer. Whenever the name of an officer is given, it shall be construed as though the words "of the city of Perryville" were added. 
    Nontechnical and Technical Words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language; but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person and thing. 
    "Oath" includes an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases, the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Or, and. "Or" may be read "and," and "and" may be read "or" if the sense requires it. 
    "Owner," when applied to a building or land, includes any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership; joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    "Person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well as to individuals. 
    "Personal property" includes every species of property except real property, as herein defined. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    "Premises" means place or places. 
    "Property" includes real and personal property. 
    "Public place" means any public street, park, airport, cemetery, school yard, public library, building and area owned or used by the city, or open space adjacent thereto. 
    "Real property" includes lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    "Residence" means the place adopted by a person as his place of habitation, and to which, whenever he is absent, he has the intention of returning. When a person eats at one place and sleeps at another, the place where such person sleeps shall be deemed his residence. 
    "Seal" means the city or corporate seal. 
    Shall. The word "shall," whenever used in this code, shall be construed as being mandatory. 
    "Sidewalk" means the portion of the street between the curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    "Signature" or "subscription" of a person shall include a mark when the person cannot write. 
    "State," "the state" or "this state" means the state of Missouri. 
    "Street" includes streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the city. 
    "Tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    "Week" means seven days. 
    "Written" or "in writing" includes any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    "Year" means a calendar year. 
(Prior code § 1-2) 
1.04.030 - Catchlines. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
(Prior code § 1-3) 
1.04.040 - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
A.  The repeal of an ordinance shall not revive any ordinances in force before or at the time the ordinance repealed took effect. 
B.  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
(Prior code § 1-4) 
1.04.050 - Severability of code. 
    It is declared to be the intention of the board of aldermen that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this code, since the same would have been enacted by the board of aldermen without the incorporation in this code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
(Prior code § 1-5) 
1.04.060 - Amendments to code. 
A.  All ordinances passed subsequent to this code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this code, may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this code and printed for inclusion therein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby, and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time that this code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new code of ordinances by the board of aldermen. 
B.  Amendments to any of the provisions of this code should be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section of this code in substantially the following language: "That section _______ of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Perryville, Missouri, is hereby amended to read as follows: ...... [Set out new provisions in full] ......" 
C.  In the event a new section not heretofore existing in the code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances of the City of Perryville, Missouri, is hereby amended by adding a section (or article, chapter or other designation, as the case may be), to be numbered _______, which reads as follows:....[Set out new provisions in full]...." 
D.  In lieu of the foregoing paragraph, when the board of aldermen desires to enact an ordinance of a general and permanent nature embracing a subject not previously existing in the code, which the board of aldermen desires to incorporate into the code, a provision in substantially the following language may be made a part of the ordinance: "It is the intention of the board of aldermen, and it is hereby ordained that the provisions of this ordinance shall become and be made part of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Perryville, Missouri, and the sections of this ordinance may be renumbered to accomplish such intention." 
E.  All sections, articles, chapters or other provisions of this code desired to be repealed should be specifically repealed by section number, article number, chapter or other number, as the case may be. 
(Prior code § 1-6) 
1.04.070 - Altering code. 
    It is unlawful for any person in the city to change or amend by additions or deletions, any part or portion of this code, or to insert or delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such code in any manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the city of Perryville to be misrepresented thereby. Any person, firm or corporation violating this section shall be punished as provided in Chapter 1.16. 
(Prior code § 1-7) 
Chapter 1.08 - CITY SEAL 
Sections: 

1.08.010 - Description. 
    The seal of the city shall be as follows: In the center shall be the words "City Seal" in large letters surrounded with a circular scroll; outside of such scroll in circular form shall be the words "City of Perryville, Perry County, Mo." in Roman capitals, and outside of this shall be another circular scroll. 
(Prior code § 2-1) 
Chapter 1.12 - ELECTIONS 
Sections: 

1.12.010 - Wards of city established. 
    The city is divided into the following three wards (precincts): 
1.  Ward No. l. Ward No. 1 shall include all of the territory bound on the west by Main Street and north of Kingshighway from its intersection with Main Street northwest to the existing city limits and further bound on the north, east, and south by the existing city limits. 
2.  Ward No. 2. Ward No. 2 shall include all of the territory bound on the east by Main Street and on the north by U. S. Highway 61 (North Kingshighway) and on the west by the city limits and on the south by St. Joseph Street. Except all of the territory bound on the west by Bruce Street and on the east by School Street and on the north by Grand Avenue and on the south by St. Joseph Street. 
3.  Ward No. 3. Ward No. 3 shall include all of the territory bound on the east by Main Street and on the south by the city limits and on the west by the city limits and on the north by St. Joseph Street. Also all of the territory bound on the west by Bruce Street and on the east by School Street and on the north by Grand Avenue and on the south by St. Joseph Street. 
(Ord. 4226 § 1, 2001: Prior code § 10-1) 
(Ord. No. 5230, § 1, 6-21-11) 
1.12.020 - Date of general election. 
    A general election for the elective officers of this city shall be held on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in April of each year: 
A.  On the first Tuesday after the first Monday in April of even-numbered years, an election shall be held by the qualified voters of each ward in the city for mayor, for police judge, and for one alderman for each ward who shall hold their respective offices for the term of two years and until their successors shall be elected and qualified. 
B.  On the first Tuesday after the first Monday in April of odd-numbered years, an election shall be held by the qualified voters of each ward of this city for one alderman for each ward who shall hold their respective offices for the term of two years and until their successors shall be elected and qualified. 
C.  On the first Tuesday after the first Monday in April of even-numbered years, an election shall be held by the qualified voters of each ward of this city for the chief of police who shall hold his office for a term of four years and until his successor shall be elected and qualified. 
(Ord. 3565 § 1, 1997: prior code § 10-2) 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 1, 4-19-16) 
1.12.030 - Declaration of candidacy. 
A.  Any person desiring to seek election for any elective office at any general city election may do so by filing a declaration of candidacy with the city clerk between eight a.m. on the sixteenth Tuesday prior to the election and five p.m. on the eleventh Tuesday prior to the election. Any candidate for elective city office at any general city election must file within this time period. The city clerk shall, before the sixteenth Tuesday prior to any election at which offices are to be filed, notify the general public of the opening filing date, the office or offices to be filled, the proper place for filing, and the closing filing date of the election. Such notification shall be accomplished by a legal notice published in at least one newspaper of general circulation in the city. The city clerk shall keep a permanent record of the names of the candidates, the office for which they seek election and the dates of the filings; and their names shall appear on the ballots in said order. 
B.  The aforesaid declaration of candidacy shall contain the full name of the candidate, his address and age, the office for which he proposes to be a candidate, the date of the filing, and if nominated and elected to such office, that the candidate will qualify. Such declaration of candidacy shall be in substantially the following form: 
 I, the undersigned, a resident and qualified elector in Ward No._______ of the City of Perryville, residing at ________ Street in said city in the County of Perry and State of Missouri, do announce myself a candidate for the office of ________ to be voted for at an election to be held on the first Tuesday in April, ________, and I further declare that if nominated and elected to such office, I will qualify. 
Dated ________/s/________ 
(Ord. 4903 § 1, 2007; prior code § 10-3) 
1.12.040 - Filing fee. 
    Every candidate for the city office shall, at the time he files his declaration of candidacy, pay filing fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to the city clerk, who shall deposit the same in the general revenue fund of the city. 
(Prior code § 10-4) 
1.12.050 - Disqualification for delinquent taxes. 
A.  In addition to other qualifications for elective office set forth in this code, any person who files as a candidate for election to a municipal office shall be disqualified from participation in the election for which the candidate has filed if such person is delinquent in the payment of any state income taxes, personal property taxes, municipal taxes, real property taxes on the place of residence, as stated on the declaration of candidacy, or if the person is a past or present corporate officer of any fee office that owes any taxes to the state. 
B.  Each potential candidate for election to a municipal office shall file an affidavit with the Missouri Department of Revenue as required under Section 115.306.2 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri and include a copy of the affidavit with the declaration of candidacy required under Section 1.12.030 of this code. The city clerk shall, without further investigation, be authorized to rely on said affidavit which shall be in substantially the following form: 
AFFIRMATION OF TAX PAYMENTS AND BONDING REQUIREMENTS: 
I hereby declare under penalties of perjury that I am not currently aware of any delinquency in the filing or payment of any state income taxes, personal property taxes, municipal taxes, real property taxes on the place of residence, as stated on the declaration of candidacy, or that I am a past or present corporate officer of any fee office that owes any taxes to the state, other than those taxes which may be in dispute. I declare under penalties of perjury that I am not aware of any information that would prohibit me from fulfilling any bonding requirements for the office for which I am filing. 
___________ Candidate's Signature 
___________ Printed Name of Candidate 
C.  Complaints alleging a delinquency of the candidate in the filing or payment of any state incomes taxes, personal property taxes, municipal taxes, or real property taxes on the place of residence, as stated on the declaration of candidacy, shall be made to the Missouri Department of Revenue and shall be investigated by the Missouri Department of Revenue as set forth in Section 115.306.3 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. The city clerk shall not be required to take any action until such time as the city clerk is notified by the Missouri Department of Revenue that the candidate has failed to comply with Section 115.306.3 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(Ord. 4903 § 2, 2007; prior code § 10-5) 
(Ord. No. 5583, § 1, 11-5-14; Ord. No. 5718, § 1, 12-1-15) 
1.12.055 - Challenge to candidate's qualifications. 
    In the event that the city clerk determines that a candidate is not qualified for office as provided in this code or if a written affidavit is filed with the city clerk that a named candidate is not qualified for the office sought, then the board of aldermen shall hold a hearing to determine the candidate's qualifications except that in the event the Missouri Department of Revenue has determined that the candidate is not qualified then no hearing is necessary. If the board of aldermen determines that a candidate is not qualified for office as provided in this code, the county clerk shall be notified and the candidate's name shall be removed from the ballot unless the candidate seeks and receives an order from a court of competent jurisdiction that the decision of the board of aldermen is incorrect. 
(Ord. No. 5583, § 2, 11-5-14) 
1.12.060 - Withdrawal of candidacy-Deadline-Procedure. 
A.  Any person who has filed a declaration of candidacy for elective office and wishes to withdraw as a candidate shall at such time as may be established in Section 115.127 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri or no later than five p.m. on the sixth Tuesday before the general election for which he has filed, file a written, sworn statement of withdrawal in the presence of the city clerk. 
B.  The name of a person who has properly filed a declaration of candidacy, or who has not given notice of withdrawal as provided in subsection A of this section, shall, except in case of death or disqualification, be printed on the official general election ballot. 
(Ord. 4903 § 3, 2007; Ord. 3659 § 1, 1998; prior code § 10-6) 
1.12.070 - Conformance of city elections with state law. 
    All city elections shall be conducted and held in conformance with the provisions of a Comprehensive Election Act of 1977. 
(Prior code § 10-7) 
1.12.080 - Conduct of election by county clerk. 
    Whenever an overlapping political subdivision conducts an election on the same day as the city election, the county clerk, as the designated election authority, shall conduct the city election. 
(Prior code § 10-8) 
1.12.090 - Conduct of election by city clerk. 
A.  If there is no overlapping political subdivision conducting an election on the same day as the city election, and if directed to do so by the board of aldermen or by appropriate election ordinance passed prior to five p.m. on the tenth Tuesday prior to the city election, and if the notification is timely received by the county clerk, the city clerk shall conduct the city election in accordance with the appropriate provisions of the act. 
B.  Unless the board of aldermen, by an appropriate election ordinance, directs the city clerk to conduct an election when there is no overlapping political subdivision conducting an election on the same, the county clerk shall conduct the city election as made and provided in the act. 
(Ord. 3659 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 10-9) 
1.12.100 - Notice of city election. 
    In city elections conducted by the county clerk, the city clerk shall notify the county clerk prior to five p.m. on the tenth Tuesday prior to any city election of the forthcoming city election. The notice shall be in writing and shall specify that the city is calling the election, the purposes of the election, the date of the election, and shall include a certified copy of the legal notice to be published and the sample ballot. 
(Ord. 3659 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 10-10) 
1.12.110 - Voters' qualifications. 
    All residents of the city who are qualified, timely and properly registered voters in accordance with the Comprehensive Election Act shall be entitled to vote in the city election. In order to vote at any city election a person must be registered no later than five p.m. on the fourth Wednesday prior to the election. 
(Prior code § 10-11) 
1.12.120 - Designation of polling places and judges-Election cost. 
    The election authority shall designate the polling places in all city elections in accordance with the provisions of the Comprehensive Election Act. The election authority shall appoint all election judges in accordance with the provisions of said Act. The city shall pay all election costs, as required by said Act, to the election authority conducting its election. 
(Prior code § 10-12) 
1.12.130 - Assistance of city police officers. 
    It shall be the duty of city police officers to give any assistance or protection required by the election authority, any employee of the election authority, or any election judge and to comply with all lawful requests and directions of the election authority relating to such assistance. 
(Prior code § 10-13) 
1.12.140 - Special election dates. 
    Special election dates for the city shall be established in accordance with Chapter 115 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(Ord. 3565 § 2, 1997: prior code § 10-14) 
1.12.150 - Vacancies. 
    In the event a vacancy occurs in any elective office of the city, the vacancy shall be filled in accordance with Section 79.280 RSMo., 1978, as amended. 
(Prior code § 10-15) 
1.12.160 - Certification of election result. 
    As soon as practicable after each city election, the election authority shall convene a verification board in accordance with the Comprehensive Election Act to verify the account and certify the results of the election. Not later than the second Tuesday after the election, the verification board shall issue a statement announcing the results of each election and shall certify the returns to the city clerk. The city clerk shall issue to each person elected a certificate of election. 
(Prior code § 10-16) 
1.12.170 - Election ordinance. 
    Prior to each city election, the board of aldermen shall timely pass an election ordinance authorizing, establishing and providing the election procedure to be followed in the conduct of the city election. 
(Prior code § 10-17) 
1.12.180 - Tie vote in general and special elections. 
    If two or more persons receive an equal number of votes for election to an elective office, the board of aldermen at its next regularly scheduled meeting shall choose one of such persons for the office. 
(Prior code § 10-18) 
1.12.190 - Elected official to be installed in office. 
    Upon qualification for office and certification of the election results as provided herein, any candidate for elective office receiving the highest number of votes at any regular or special election shall be installed in said office. 
(Prior code § 10-19) 
Chapter 1.16 - GENERAL PENALTY 
Sections: 

1.16.010 - General penalty-Continuing violations. 
A.  Whenever in this code or in any ordinance or resolution of the city any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or whenever in such code, ordinance or resolution the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of this code, ordinance or resolution shall be punished by a fine of not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) and costs, or by imprisonment in the city prison not exceeding three months, or by both such fine and imprisonment; provided, however, that in any case wherein the penalty for an offense is fixed by state law or statute, the same penalty so fixed by state law or statute shall be imposed for the punishments of such offense and no other, except that imprisonments, when made under this section, may be in the city jail or the county jail. 
B.  Each day any violation of any provision of this code or of any such ordinance or resolution shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Prior code § 1-8) 
1.16.020 - Parties to an offense. 
    Every person who commits, attempts to commit, conspires to commit, or aids or abets in the commission of any act declared herein to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, whether individually or in connection with one or more other persons or as principal, agent or accessory, shall be guilty of such unlawful act or offense or misdemeanor, and every person who falsely, fraudulently, forcibly or wilfully induces, causes, coerces, requires, permits or directs another to violate any provision hereof shall likewise be guilty. 
(Prior code § 1-9) 
1.16.030 - Acts punishable under different sections. 
    In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense, provided that the revocation of a license or permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other penalty being enforced. 
(Prior code § 1-10) 
Title 2 - ADMINISTRATION AND PERSONNEL 
Chapter 2.04 - BOARD OF ALDERMEN 
Sections: 

2.04.010 - Composition. 
    The board of aldermen shall consist of six members, two of whom shall be chosen from each ward of the city, in accordance with the provisions of the laws of this state governing cities of the fourth class. 
(Prior code § 2-19) 
2.04.020 - Qualifications of members. 
A.  No person shall be an alderman unless he is at least twenty-one (21) years of age, a citizen of the United States, an inhabitant and resident of the city for one year next preceding his election, a resident of the ward from which he is elected and a qualified voter under the laws and constitution of this state and the ordinances of the city. 
B.  No person shall be an alderman who shall at the time of his election be in arrears for any unpaid city taxes, or forfeiture or defalcation in office. 
C.  No person shall be an alderman who has been found guilty of or pled guilty to a felony or misdemeanor under the federal laws of the United States or to a felony under the laws of this state or an offense committed in another state that would be considered a felony in this state. 
D.  No person shall be an alderman who has not filed a candidate's affidavit of tax payments and bonding requirements with the Missouri Department of Revenue (Form 5120) as required by Section 115.306.2, RSMo. 
(Prior code § 2-20) 
(Ord. No. 5717, § 1, 12-1-15) 
2.04.030 - Compensation. 
    Each member of the board of aldermen shall receive as compensation the sum of three thousand six hundred dollars ($3,600.00) per year, payable quarterly, for performing the duties of office. 
(Prior code § 2-21) 
2.04.040 - Resignations of members. 
    Resignations of aldermen shall be in writing and addressed to the president of the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-22) 
2.04.050 - Procedure for appointing city officers. 
    The board of aldermen shall, in electing any person to fill any office of the city vote by ayes and nays, and the result thereof shall be entered upon the journal of the proceedings of the board. In all cases, it shall require a majority vote of all the members of the board of aldermen for any person to be appointed to such office. 
(Prior code § 2-23) 
2.04.060 - Authority to fix compensation of city officers and employees. 
    The board of aldermen shall have the power, by ordinance, to fix the compensation of the officers and employees of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-24) 
2.04.070 - Changes in compensation of elected city officers. 
    The board of aldermen shall not change the salary of any city officer during the time for which he was elected. 
(Prior code § 2-25) 
2.04.080 - Authority to prescribe and enforce rules for transacting business. 
    The board of aldermen may prescribe and enforce such rules as it may find necessary for the expeditious transaction of its business. 
(Prior code § 2-26) 
2.04.090 - Power to compel attendance of witnesses and production of records-Execution of process- Fees-Oaths. 
    The board of aldermen shall have the power to compel the attendance of witnesses and the production of papers and records relating to any subject under consideration in which the interest of the city is involved, and shall have the power to call on the city marshal or any policeman of the city or the sheriff of this county to execute such process. The officer making such service shall be allowed to receive therefor such fees as are allowed by law in the circuit court for similar services to be paid by the city. The mayor or acting president of the board of aldermen shall have the power to administer oaths to such witnesses. 
(Prior code § 2-27) 
2.04.100 - Exempting persons from taxes prohibited. 
    The board of aldermen shall have no power to relieve any person from the payment of any tax, or exempt any person from any assessment or other burden imposed upon him by law. 
(Prior code § 2-28) 
2.04.110 - Semiannual financial statement. 
    The board of aldermen shall semiannually each year, at times to be set by the board of aldermen, make out and spread upon their records a full and detailed account and statement of the receipts and expenditures and indebtedness of the city for the half year ending with the last day of the month immediately preceding the date of such report, which account and statement shall be published in some newspaper in the city. 
(Prior code § 2-29) 
2.04.120 - Meetings-Time. 
    Regular meetings of the board of aldermen shall be held at six-thirty p.m. on the first and third Tuesdays of each and every month, and adjourned meetings whenever the mayor and board of aldermen shall deem the same necessary." 
(Prior code § 2-34) 
(Ord. No. 5345, § 1, 7-17-12) 
2.04.130 - Special meetings. 
    The mayor or any two members of the board of aldermen may call a special meeting of the board of aldermen at any time by causing the city marshal or other police officer to serve a notice upon members of the board of aldermen and mayor of the time fixed for such special meeting. Such notice shall be signed by those calling such special meeting and shall be served on the remaining members by delivering a copy of such notice to each of the parties to be served or by leaving a copy of such notice at his usual place of residence or business with some member of his family above the age of fifteen (15) years, or with his clerk, agent or representative in business. 
(Prior code § 2-35) 
2.04.140 - Failure to attend meetings- Fines-Loss of office. 
A.  Any aldermen failing to attend any regular meeting of the board of aldermen, or, after being duly notified shall neglect or refuse to attend an adjourned or special meeting, without having a reasonable excuse to be accepted by the board, may be fined not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than five dollars ($5.00). 
B.  Whenever any member of the board of aldermen shall absent himself from two or more successive meetings of the board of aldermen, without having a reasonable excuse for his absence, the board, by a vote of two-thirds of the members elected thereto, may expel such member and declare his office vacant. 
(Prior code § 2-36, 2-37) 
2.04.150 - Mayor to preside-Voting. 
    The mayor shall have a seat in and preside over the board of aldermen, but shall not vote on any question except in the case of a tie, nor shall he preside or vote in cases when he is an interested party. 
(Prior code § 2-38) 
2.04.160 - Election of board president. 
    At the first meeting of the board of aldermen, the board shall elect a president of the board. 
(Prior code § 2-39) 
2.04.170 - Election of acting president when mayor is absent. 
    In the absence of the mayor, the president of the board of aldermen shall preside over the board. In the absence of the mayor or president of the board of aldermen, the board shall elect one of their own number to occupy the place temporarily, who shall be styled "acting president of the board of aldermen." 
(Prior code § 2-40) 
2.04.180 - Journal of proceedings to be maintained. 
    The board of aldermen shall cause to be kept a journal of its proceedings. 
(Prior code § 2-41) 
2.04.190 - Quorum requirements- Adjournment-Summoning absent members. 
    A majority of the members of the board of aldermen shall constitute a quorum to do business; but a smaller number may adjourn from time to time and may send a special messenger for any absent member. 
(Prior code § 2-42) 
2.04.200 - Mayor to call meetings to order. 
    The mayor shall take the chair at the hour to which the board of aldermen may have previously adjourned and, on appearance of a quorum, shall call the board members to order and cause the proceedings of the previous meeting to be read. 
(Prior code § 2-43) 
2.04.210 - Order of business. 
A.  The mayor or his designate shall establish an agenda or order of business for each meeting. 
B.  Any business may be called up out of order by consent of a majority of the board members present. 
(Ord. 3658 § 4, 1998: prior code § 2-44) 
2.04.220 - Mayor to preserve order and decide questions. 
    It shall be the duty of the mayor to preserve order and decorum at all meetings of the board of aldermen and to decide all questions of order, subject to an appeal to the board. 
(Prior code § 2-45) 
2.04.230 - Members to vote when question is put. 
    When a question is put by the mayor, each member of the board of aldermen present, if not personally interested, shall vote unless the board for special reasons shall excuse him. 
(Prior code § 2-46) 
2.04.240 - Procedure when ayes and nays demanded. 
    If the ayes and nays are demanded by two members of the board of aldermen, the names of the board members shall be called alphabetically, their votes recorded in the journal, the absentees voted and the result announced by the presiding officers of the board. 
(Prior code § 2-47) 
2.04.250 - Interested members not to vote- Legal effect. 
    No member of the board of aldermen shall be permitted to vote for or against any ordinance appropriating money, or for the allowance of any account or claim, or for the award or approval of any contract in which such member is directly or indirectly interested. Any ordinance, resolution or motion having passed by the vote of such interested member shall be deemed illegal and of no effect. 
(Prior code § 2-48) 
2.04.260 - When motion to be written. 
    Every motion made at any meeting of the board of aldermen shall be reduced to writing if the presiding officer of the board or any board member shall require it. 
(Prior code § 2-49) 
2.04.270 - Motion to be seconded before debate. 
    No motion made at any meeting of the board of aldermen shall be debated unless it is seconded. 
(Prior code § 2-50) 
2.04.280 - Procedure when motion is seconded. 
    When a motion is made and seconded at any meeting of the board of aldermen, it shall be stated by the presiding officer of the board or, if in writing, it shall be read aloud by the city clerk before debate shall be in order on the same. 
(Prior code § 2-51) 
2.04.290 - Motions which can be made when question is put. 
    When a question is before the board of aldermen for consideration, no motion shall be in order except a motion for an amendment, for postponement, for commitment to lie on the table or for adjournment. 
(Prior code § 2-52) 
2.04.300 - When motion may be withdrawn. 
    Any motion made at a board meeting may be withdrawn by the mover at any time before an amendment is offered to it or a decision is made thereto; and any motion may be withdrawn by the mover at any time before final decision if the unanimous consent of the whole board is obtained therefor. 
(Prior code § 2-53) 
2.04.310 - Motion to adjourn. 
    A motion to adjourn shall always be in order at a board meeting, unless a board member is speaking, and shall be decided without debate. 
(Prior code § 2-54) 
2.04.320 - Reconsideration of motions. 
    Whenever a motion has been put and decided in the affirmative or negative, it shall be in order for any board member who voted on the side which prevailed to move for a reconsideration thereof at the same meeting or at the next meeting thereafter, but not afterwards. After a motion has once been reconsidered, it shall not be reconsidered again for six months thereafter. 
(Prior code § 2-55) 
2.04.330 - Amendments to an amendment. 
    An amendment to an amendment may be permitted at a board meeting, but no further amendments shall be allowed. 
(Prior code § 2-56) 
2.04.340 - Speaking permitted only when motion is before board. 
    No member of the board of aldermen shall speak at a board meeting unless there is a motion before the board. 
(Prior code § 2-57) 
2.04.350 - Recognition by chair. 
    When two or more persons at a board meeting rise to speak or deliver any matter to the board, the presiding officer of the board shall name the one who shall proceed. 
(Prior code § 2-58) 
2.04.360 - Members to address chair. 
    When a member of the board of aldermen rises to speak at a board meeting, he shall respectfully address the presiding officer. 
(Prior code § 2-59) 
2.04.370 - Members to be seated when another is speaking. 
    No member of the board of aldermen shall leave his seat during a board meeting while another member is speaking. 
(Prior code § 2-60) 
2.04.380 - Speaking on same subject restricted. 
    No member of the board of aldermen shall speak more than once on the same subject at a board meeting until every member choosing to speak shall have spoken. 
(Prior code § 2-61) 
2.04.390 - Members to abstain from personalities in debate. 
    Every member of the board of aldermen shall abstain from personalities in debate during any board meeting. 
(Prior code § 2-62) 
2.04.400 - Referring matters to committees. 
    Whenever it shall be necessary to refer any matter to a committee, the presiding officer of the board shall, upon motion of any member, appoint such committee. 
(Prior code § 2-63) 
2.04.410 - Disturbing members may be fined. 
    No member of the board of aldermen shall disturb any board meeting by walking across the floor, carrying on private discourse, or doing anything which might annoy the board or any member thereof. Any violator of this section may be fined at the discretion of the presiding officer. 
(Prior code § 2-64) 
2.04.420 - Ordinances-Style-Form-Synopsis-Readings-Motion for passage. 
A.  The style of the ordinances of the city shall be: 
"Be it ordained by the mayor and board of aldermen of the City of Perryville, Missouri, as follows:" 
B.  All ordinances shall be introduced to the board of aldermen in printed or electronic written form. 
C.  Upon request by any member of the board of aldermen, the city clerk shall prepare copies of all proposed ordinances for distribution to all members of the board on Tuesday before the meeting at which the ordinance is to be introduced. Upon request by any member of the board of aldermen, the city administrator shall prepare a synopsis of each ordinance to be introduced and attach said synopsis to the copies distributed to the board. 
D.  Ordinances shall be read two times. Ordinances shall be read in full, or by title only where copies are available to the board of aldermen and those in attendance on the first reading, and may not be amended. The ordinances shall be read by title only on second reading. 
E.  Except as provided in subsection F of this section, any ordinance which shall have had its first reading shall be taken up by the board of aldermen at its next session and shall be read the second time and thereupon shall be open for debate and amendment. On the close of debate, the presiding officer shall entertain a motion to place such ordinance on final passage. 
F.  First and second readings of an ordinance may occur at a single meeting of the board of aldermen only if: 
1.  The ordinance is designated in the body of the bill as an emergency ordinance "for the immediate preservation of public peace, property, health, safety, morals, or other good cause," or 
2.  The ordinance is designated in the body of the bill as a "matter related to zoning as found in Title 17 of this code which has previously been reviewed and approved by the planning and zoning commission." 
G.  The motion for final passage shall not be debatable and shall take precedence over all other motions except one for adjournment. Upon being seconded, the presiding officer shall immediately put the motion to the board of aldermen. If the motion is adopted, no further debate or amendment shall be allowed and the clerk shall immediately call the roll for its final passage. If such motion is not adopted, the ordinance shall still be open for debate and amendment until such time as a motion for final passage is adopted. 
H.  All ordinances passed by the board of aldermen as set forth in this section shall take effect immediately upon their passage unless in the body of the bill a different effective date is set forth. 
(Ord. 3658 § 2, 1998; prior code § 2-5) 
(Ord. No. 5570, § 1, 10-7-14) 
2.04.430 - Ordinances-Passage-Veto power of mayor-Overriding veto. 
A.  No ordinance shall be passed except by bill and, except where otherwise provided in this section, no bill shall become an ordinance unless on its final passage a majority of the members elected to the board of aldermen shall vote for it, and the ayes and nays be entered on the journal; all bills shall be read two times before their passage. 
B.  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no bill shall become an ordinance until it has been signed by the mayor or person exercising the duties of the mayor's office. 
C.  The mayor shall have the power to sign or veto any ordinance passed by the board of aldermen; provided, however, that if the mayor neglects or refuses to sign any ordinance and returns same without his objections, in writing, at the next regular meeting of the board of aldermen, the same shall become law without his signature. 
D.  Every bill duly passed by the board of aldermen and presented to the mayor and by him approved shall become an ordinance, and every bill presented as aforesaid, but returned with the mayor's objections thereto, shall stand reconsidered. The board of aldermen shall cause the objections of the mayor to be entered at large upon the journal, and proceed at its convenience to consider the question pending, which shall be in this form: "Shall the bill pass, the objections of the Mayor thereto notwithstanding?" The vote on this question shall be taken by ayes and nays and the names entered upon the journal. If two-thirds of all the members-elect shall vote in the affirmative, the city clerk shall certify the fact on the roll, and the bill thus certified shall be deposited with the proper officer, and shall become an ordinance in the same manner and with like effect as if it had received the approval of the mayor. 
(Ord. 3658 § 3, 1998; prior code § 2-6) 
2.04.440 - Ordinances-Revivification and reenactment. 
    No ordinance shall be revived or reenacted by mere reference to the title thereof, but the same shall be set forth at length, as if it were an original ordinance. 
(Prior code § 2-7) 
2.04.450 - Violation of rules. 
    If any member of the board of aldermen violates any rule of the board, the presiding officer shall, and any board member may, call him to order, whereupon the offending member shall take his seat, or, upon leave, may be allowed to explain. 
(Prior code § 2-65) 
2.04.460 - Authoritative sources. 
    When city ordinance, state statute or case law is not controlling concerning the interpretation of ordinances, Roberts' Rules of Order, as printed by William Morrow and Company, Inc., of New York, New York, 1979 edition, shall be considered the authoritative source and controlling. 
(Prior code § 2-66) 
Chapter 2.08 - CITY OFFICERS GENERALLY 
Sections: 

2.08.010 - Officers elected-Terms. 
A.  The mayor, board of aldermen, city collector and municipal judge shall be elected by the qualified voters of the city and shall hold office for a term of two years and until their successors are elected and qualified. 
B.  The chief of police shall be elected by the qualified voters of the city and shall hold office for a term of four years and until his successor is elected and qualified. 
C.  No person shall be an alderman unless he or she is at least twenty-one (21) years of age, a citizen of the United States, an inhabitant and resident of the city for one year next preceding his or her election, and a resident, at least at the time he or she files and during the time he or she serves, of the ward from which he or she is elected. 
(Ord. 4059 § 1, 2000: prior code § 2-76) 
2.08.020 - Qualifications. 
A.  All officers elected or appointed to offices under the city government shall be qualified voters under the laws and constitution of this state and the ordinances of the city and shall be residents of the city; provided, however, that this section shall not apply to appointed police officers, the city attorney and other employees having only ministerial duties. 
B.  No person shall be elected or appointed to any office under the city government who shall at the time be in arrears for any unpaid city taxes, or forfeiture or defalcation in office. 
(Prior code § 2-77) 
2.08.030 - Oath of office. 
    Every officer of the city, his assistants, and every alderman before entering upon the duties of his office, shall take and subscribe to an oath or affirmation before some court of record in the county or the city clerk that he possesses all the qualifications prescribed for his office by law; that he will support the Constitution of the United States and of the state of Missouri, the provisions of all laws of this state affecting cities of the fourth class, and the ordinances of the city; and that he will faithfully demean himself while in office; which official oath or affirmation shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 2-78) 
2.08.040 - Bond requirements. 
A.  All city officers who are required to give bond by this code shall be covered by a surety bond purchased by the city, with the terms and conditions of the surety bond to be determined and negotiated by the city with the bonding company or entity contracting with the city. The surety bond shall be conditioned upon the faithful performance of the duties of the city officers and shall insure that the city offiover all monies belonging to the city, as provided by law, that may come into their hands and that they will turn over to their successors in office, or to such other proper officer of the city, all books, papers and personal property of whatsoever nature in their custody belonging to the city. In the event of any breach of condition of any such bond, suit may be instituted thereon by the city or by any person in the name of the city to recover any monies, assets, books, papers or personal property of whatsoever nature belonging to the city. 
B.  City officers shall be bonded in the following amounts: 
1.  City clerk: Twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00); 
2.  Utility collection clerks: Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); 
3.  Deputy city clerk: Twelve thousand dollars ($12,000.00); 
4.  City treasurer: Twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00); 
5.  Deputy city treasurer: Fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00); 
6.  City administrator: Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); 
7.  Police officers: Two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00); 
8.  Municipal court clerk: Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); 
9.  Municipal court payment clerk: Ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00); 
10.  City hall secretary collecting funds for occupational and liquor licenses: Two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(Prior code § 2-79) 
(Ord. No. 5216, § 1, 5-3-11; Ord. No. 5748, § 2, 4-19-16) 
2.08.050 - Failure to take oath or give bond-Vacancy of office. 
    If any person elected or appointed to any city office fails to take and subscribe to the oath or affirmation prescribed in Section 2.08.030 or to give bond as required by this code, his office shall be deemed vacant. 
(Prior code § 2-80) 
2.08.060 - Filling of vacancies. 
A.  If a vacancy occurs in any elective city office, the mayor or the person exercising the duties of the mayor shall cause a special meeting of the board of aldermen to convene where a successor to the vacant office shall be selected. The successor shall serve until the next regular municipal election. 
B.  If any vacancy occurs in any office of the city not elective, the mayor shall appoint a suitable person to discharge the duties of such office until the first regular meeting of the board of aldermen thereafter, at which time such vacancy shall be permanently filled. 
(Ord. 3658 § 6, 1998; prior code § 2-81) 
2.08.070 - Books, accounts and reports to conform with fiscal year. 
    All books, accounts and reports of city officers shall be made to conform to the fiscal year designated in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 2-82) 
2.08.080 - Mayor or board may require officers to exhibit records and make reports. 
    The mayor or board of aldermen shall have the power, as often as he or it may deem it necessary, to require any officer of the city to exhibit his accounts or other papers or records and to make reports to the board of aldermen touching any matters relating to this office. 
(Prior code § 2-83) 
2.08.090 - Access of treasurer and clerk to other offices. 
    The city treasurer and city clerk shall have free access to each other's offices for the inspection of all books, accounts and papers which they respectively contain, and free access to all other offices of the city for the inspection of such books, accounts and papers as concern any of their duties. 
(Prior code § 2-84) 
2.08.100 - Mileage on trips to be compensated. 
    Whenever it shall be necessary for any alderman or other city official to make trips outside the city limits in connection with their duties, the city clerk, upon order of the board, shall pay the maximum amount allowable by the Internal Revenue Code for tax deduction purposes for each mile traveled. 
(Ord. 3658 § 5, 1998: prior code § 2-85) 
2.08.105 - Employee grievance against an elected official. 
    Any employee who feels that he or she is being subjected to harassment (as defined in Section 2.88.200 of this code) by an elected official shall immediately submit his or her complaint in writing to the personnel clerk. That complaint shall be immediately given to the city attorney who shall prepare a report to the board of aldermen concerning said complaint and that complaint shall be presented to the board of aldermen in closed session. In making such report, the city attorney shall take reasonable steps to maintain the confidentiality of the complaining employee if possible. If the mayor determines that immediate action under Section 2.08.110 is necessary, the mayor may proceed with suspension of the elected official. The city shall conduct such investigation as may be necessary and shall take such steps as are necessary to comply with applicable state and federal laws regarding harassment and discrimination, including the laws regarding retaliation. If the complaint is substantiated by the investigation, then the public process set forth in Section 2.08.110 shall be initiated. If the elected official chooses to resign rather than go through the removal process outlined in Section 2.08.110, the resignation shall be accepted and the findings of the investigation shall be made public. 
(Ord. No. 5477, § 1, 12-3-13) 
2.08.110 - Suspension or removal of elective officers. 
A.  The mayor is empowered to suspend from office any elective officer of the city for any of the following causes: 
1.  A wilful violation of any of his official obligations; 
2.  Any culpable official negligence or dereliction of duty; 
3.  Any conduct inconsistent with his official character and duty; or 
4.  For official incompetency. 
B.  Any suspension under subsection A of this section shall be effected by an order filed by the mayor in the office of the city clerk, accompanied by a statement of the charges upon which the same is founded, a copy of which shall be forthwith made by the clerk and delivered to the city marshal, who shall forthwith deliver the same to the elective officer suspended; and if any elective city officer shall, during suspension from office, attempt to perform any official duty, he shall be punished as provided in Section 1.16.010. 
C.  The mayor shall report any suspension under this section and lay the charge before the board of aldermen if in session at the time, and if not, at its next regular session thereafter. The board of aldermen shall investigate the same without unnecessary delay. 
D.  Whenever any elective city officer shall be suspended as aforesaid, or shall be charged by the mayor any member of the board of aldermen or any other city officer, or by affidavit of any reputable citizen of the city filed with the city clerk, with a wilful violation of any of his official obligations, or any culpable official negligence or dereliction of duty, or with any conduct inconsistent with his official character and duty or with official incompetency, the board of aldermen shall appoint a committee to investigate the same. Such committee, if it shall deem the charge well founded, shall frame and report to the board of aldermen charges and specifications against such officer, and the board of aldermen shall appoint a day for the hearing thereof and cause a copy of such charges and specifications with a notice of the time and place set for the hearing to be delivered to such officer at least five days before the day set for the hearing. 
E.  At the time set for the hearing under this section, the board of aldermen shall meet and proceed, according to such rules as it may adopt, to hear the evidence against and in favor of the accused, and may adjourn from time to time, if necessary, until all the evidence is heard. 
F.  The mayor, or person acting as such, shall preside at all hearings under this section, but in cases where the charges are against the mayor, the president of the board of aldermen shall preside and in case the charges are against the person acting as mayor and such person is also the president of the board of aldermen, the remaining members of the board of aldermen shall choose one of their number to preside. 
G.  Upon any hearing under this section, the accused shall be entitled to be heard by himself and his counsel in his defense, and the city attorney, or person acting as such, shall attend such hearing and prosecute on behalf of the city. 
H.  Subpoenas for witnesses to testify at any hearing under this section may be issued by the mayor, or person acting as such, or in case the charges shall be against the mayor, by the president of the board of aldermen, and shall be served and returned by any proper officer of the city. Such officer and witnesses shall be entitled to the same fees as would be allowed for like services in the police judge's court. 
I.  The mayor, or person acting as such, or in case the charges are against the mayor, the president of the board of aldermen, shall have power to administer oaths to witnesses in all proceedings before the board of aldermen under this section. 
J.  As soon as all of the evidence has been taken at any hearing under this section and the case submitted, the board of aldermen shall vote by yeas and nays upon each charge and specification separately. The question upon each charge shall be: "Is the accused guilty?" If the board of aldermen, by a majority vote of all the members elected, find the accused guilty of any of the charges and such finding is approved by the mayor, the accused shall, by resolution, be removed from office. If the board of aldermen shall, by a two-thirds vote of all its members, find the accused guilty, he shall be removed from office by resolution independent of the mayor's approval and the office thereupon shall be declared vacant. 
K.  The proceedings of the board of aldermen under this section shall be entered at large upon the journal of the proceedings of the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-86) 
2.08.120 - Removal of appointive officers. 
    The mayor may, with the consent of a majority of all the members elected to the board of aldermen, remove from office any appointive officer of the city at will, and any such appointive officer may be so removed by a two-thirds vote of all the members of the board of aldermen, independently of the mayor's approval or recommendation. In no case shall it be necessary to present charges and specifications or assign any reason for the removal of any appointive officer of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-87) 
2.08.130 - Defense of city officers. 
    The board of aldermen shall purchase such insurance as the board of aldermen in its absolute discretion deems prudent and necessary to cover any liability claims made or brought against any city officers as a result of the city officers performing their duties or responsibilities on behalf of the city. To the extent that the actions of any city officer in the performance of the city officer's duties or responsibilities to the city are not covered by a policy of liability insurance, then the city shall employ and pay for the legal representation of any city officer in the defense of the city officer's actions to carry out the city officer's duties and responsibilities on behalf of the city. If the board of aldermen deems that any payment, judgment amount or settlement amount against any city officer is the result of the performance of the city officer's duties and responsibilities to the city and if the actions of the city officer are not covered by a policy of liability insurance, then the board of aldermen may allocate such sums as are necessary to pay such payment, judgment amount or settlement amount against any city officer. City officers shall include, but not be limited to, the mayor, members of the board of aldermen, the city administrator, the city attorney, the city clerk, the city treasurer, the municipal judge, the building official, the city engineer, and the city's fire and police officers. 
(Ord. No. 5223, § 1, 5-17-11; Ord. No. 5748, § 3, 4-19-16) 
Chapter 2.12 - MAYOR 
Sections: 

2.12.010 - Office established. 
    There is established the office of mayor. 
(Prior code § 2-93) 
2.12.020 - Qualifications. 
A.  No person shall be mayor unless he is at least twenty-five (25) years of age, a citizen of the United States, a resident of the city at the time of and for at least one year next preceding his election, and a qualified voter under the laws and Constitution of this state and the ordinances of the city. 
B.  No person shall be mayor who shall at the time of his election be in arrears for any unpaid city taxes or forfeiture or defalcation in office. 
C.  No person shall be mayor who has been found guilty of or pled guilty to a felony or misdemeanor under the federal laws of the United States or to a felony under the laws of this state or an offense committed in another state that would be considered a felony in this state. 
D.  No person shall be mayor who has not filed a candidate's affidavit of tax payments and bonding requirements with the Missouri Department of Revenue (Form 5120) as required by Section 115.306.2, RSMo. 
(Ord. 4058 § 1, 2000: prior code § 2-94) 
(Ord. No. 5717, § 2, 12-1-15) 
2.12.030 - Compensation. 
    The mayor shall receive as compensation the sum of four thousand nine hundred dollars ($4,900.00) per annum, payable quarterly, and shall also be entitled to reasonable expenses for mileage and incidental expenses as determined by the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-95) 
2.12.040 - Communications to board. 
    The mayor shall, from time to time, communicate to the board of aldermen such measures as may, in his opinion, tend to the improvement of the finances, the police, health, security, ornament, comfort and general prosperity of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-96) 
2.12.050 - Supervision of officers and city affairs. 
    The mayor shall exercise a general supervision over all the officers and affairs of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-97) 
2.12.060 - Handling of violations by officers. 
    The mayor shall cause all subordinate city officers to be dealt with promptly for any neglect or violation of duty. 
(Prior code § 2-98) 
2.12.070 - Enforcement of ordinances and laws. 
    The mayor shall be active and vigilant in enforcing all state laws and city ordinances for the government of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-99) 
2.12.080 - Authority to summon aid. 
    The mayor is authorized to call on every inhabitant of the city over eighteen (18) years of age and under fifty (50) to aid in enforcing the laws. 
(Ord. 3658 § 7, 1998: prior code § 2-100) 
2.12.090 - Remittance of fines and forfeitures-Granting of reprieves and pardons. 
    The mayor shall have the power to remit fines and forfeitures and to grant reprieves and pardons for offenses arising under the ordinances of the city; but this section shall not be so construed as to authorize the mayor to remit any costs which may have accrued to any officer of the city by reason of any prosecution under the laws or ordinances of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-101) 
2.12.100 - Signing of commissions and appointments. 
    The mayor shall sign the commissions and appointments of all city officers elected or appointed in the city. 
(Prior code § 2-102) 
2.12.110 - Approval of bonds. 
    The mayor shall approve all official bonds unless otherwise prescribed by ordinance. 
(Prior code § 2-103) 
2.12.120 - Signing of orders, drafts and warrants-Attesting and affixing city seal by clerk-Records. 
    The mayor shall sign all orders, drafts and warrants drawn on the city treasurer for money, and cause the city clerk to attest the same and to keep an accurate record thereof in a book to be provided for that purpose. 
(Prior code § 2-104) 
2.12.130 - Vacancy in office. 
    When a vacancy occurs in the office of mayor by death, resignation, removal from the city, removal from office, refusal to qualify, or from any other cause whatever, the acting president of the board of aldermen shall, for the time being, perform the duties of mayor, with all the rights, privileges, powers and jurisdiction of the mayor, until such vacancy is filled or such disability is removed, or, in case of temporary absence, until the mayor returns. 
(Prior code § 2-105) 
Chapter 2.16 - CITY CLERK 
Sections: 

2.16.010 - Office established. 
    There is established the office of city clerk. 
(Prior code § 2-111) 
2.16.020 - Appointment. 
    The city clerk shall be appointed by the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-112) 
2.16.030 - Bond. 
    The city clerk shall be covered by a surety bond supplied by the city in the amount and manner as provided in Section 2.08.040 of this code. 
(Prior code § 2-113) 
(Ord. No. 5216, § 2, 5-3-11) 
2.16.040 - Compensation. 
    The compensation of the city clerk shall be established in accordance with Section 2.92.010. 
(Prior code § 2-114) 
2.16.050 - Designated general accountant. 
    The city clerk shall be the general accountant of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-115) 
2.16.060 - Execution of duties. 
    The city clerk shall carefully and promptly execute every official duty that may be required of him by the laws of this state and the ordinances of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-116) 
2.16.070 - Attendance of board meetings- Journal of proceedings. 
    The city clerk shall attend all meetings of the board of aldermen and keep a correct journal of its proceedings. 
(Prior code § 2-117) 
2.16.080 - Custodian of certain property. 
A.  The city clerk shall have the custody of and safely keep the seal of the city, the public records, the original rolls of ordinances and resolutions of the board of aldermen, and such other records, documents and papers of public nature as may be delivered into his custody. 
B.  The city clerk shall have the custody of all public account books, accounts, vouchers, documents, bonds and coupons paid or redeemed, all papers relating to accounts and contracts of the city, and its revenue, debt and fiscal affairs, not required by law or ordinance to be placed in some other office or kept by some other person. 
(Prior code § 2-118) 
2.16.090 - Labeling, recording and filing duties. 
    The city clerk shall neatly label, record and file for safekeeping the original roll of all ordinances and resolutions of the board of aldermen, and such other vouchers, papers, records and documents as may be delivered into his custody. 
(Prior code § 2-119) 
2.16.100 - Furnishing date to mayor and board. 
    The city clerk shall give information in writing to the mayor and board of aldermen, whenever required, upon any subject relating to the fiscal affairs of the city or touching any duties of his office. 
(Prior code § 2-120) 
2.16.110 - Records and documents to be furnished to city attorney. 
    The city clerk shall furnish to the city attorney any record or document in his office necessary to be used in any proceedings in court to which the city is a party. 
(Prior code § 2-121) 
2.16.120 - Preparation and record of documents. 
    The city clerk shall prepare all certificates of election, commissions, appointments and other official documents required by ordinance to be issued, or which the mayor in the discharge of his duty is required to issue, and shall keep a record of the same. 
(Prior code § 2-122) 
2.16.130 - Affixing city seal to documents. 
A.  The city clerk shall affix the seal of the city to all public instruments and documents and official acts of the mayor which by law or ordinance are required to be so attested, and countersign the same. 
B.  The city clerk shall affix the seal of the city to and certify any record, document, copies of papers or ordinances that may be required for evidence in any court of this state or of the United States by any individual, or that may be required for the use of any officer in the city. 
(Prior code § 2-123) 
2.16.140 - Recording of revenue.
