    The city clerk shall keep a complete record of all branches of the city revenue, opening an account with every appropriation or fund which, by law or ordinance, is made a separate fund, crediting the same with all moneys paid into the city treasury on account thereof, and charging said appropriation or fund with all warrants drawn thereon. 
(Prior code § 2-124) 
2.16.150 - Recording of liabilities. 
    The city clerk shall keep a record of all obligations of the city, specifying the date of issuance, for what purpose issued, the rate of interest, the time when principal and interest become due, the amount of principal, to whom payable, and the registered number of each bond and coupon. 
(Prior code § 2-125) 
2.16.160 - Drawing of warrants. 
A.  In all cases of accounts audited and allowed against the city and for the payment of which the mayor and board of aldermen, by ordinance, shall have made the necessary appropriation, it shall be the duty of the city clerk to draw a warrant on the city treasury for the amount due. 
B.  The city clerk shall express in the body of every warrant drawn upon the treasurer, the particular fund out of which the same is to be paid. 
(Prior code § 2-126) 
2.16.170 - Register of warrants to be maintained. 
    The city clerk shall keep a register of all warrants drawn upon the city treasurer, specifying the number, date, to whom payable, on what fund or appropriation drawn, and the amount of each warrant. 
(Prior code § 2-127) 
2.16.180 - Accounting of officers handling money. 
    The city clerk shall keep in a set of books, provided for that purpose, accurate accounts between the city and all city officers charged with the collection, custody or disbursement of public moneys, and shall enter thereupon all receipts and payments, from what source derived and on what account paid. 
(Prior code § 2-128) 
2.16.185 - Bonding of utility collection clerks. 
    The utility collection clerks shall be covered by a surety bond supplied by the city in the amount and manner as provided in Section 2.08.040 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 5216, § 3, 5-3-11) 
2.16.190 - Licenses-Preparation, issuance and record. 
    The city clerk shall prepare blank licenses for all purposes for which licenses are required to be issued and, when required, shall cause the same to be issued, signing his name and affixing the seal of the city thereto, and shall keep an account for such licenses and the amount of license tax thereon. 
(Prior code § 2-129) 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 4, 4-19-16) 
2.16.200 - Recording of bonds. 
    The city clerk shall record the official bonds of all city officers and the bonds of all other persons executed to the city and placed in his custody. 
(Prior code § 2-130) 
2.16.210 - Additional duties. 
    In addition to the duties prescribed in this chapter, the city clerk shall perform such other duties as may be required of him by the laws of this state. 
(Prior code § 2-131) 
2.16.220 - Deputy city clerk. 
A.  Office established. There is established the office of deputy city clerk. 
B.  Appointment. The board of aldermen may, by resolution or ordinance, and at its discretion elect a deputy city clerk. 
C.  Powers and Duties. The deputy city clerk shall have all the powers and perform all the duties of the city clerk as designated in this chapter and in Section 79.320 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
D.  Bond. The deputy city clerk shall be covered by a surety bond supplied by the city in the amount and manner as provided in Section 2.08.040 of this code. 
E.  Compensation. The compensation of the deputy city clerk shall be established in accordance with Section 2.92.010. 
(Prior code § 2-132) 
(Ord. No. 5216, § 4, 5-3-11) 
2.16.230 - Violations-Penalties. 
    For the wilful violation of any provision of this chapter, in addition to other penalties provided by law, the city clerk shall be punished as provided in Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 2-133) 
Chapter 2.20 - CITY TREASURER 
Sections: 

2.20.010 - Office established. 
    There is established the office of city treasurer. 
(Prior code § 2-139) 
2.20.020 - Bond. 
    The city treasurer and the deputy city treasurer shall be covered by a surety bond supplied by the city in the amount and manner as provided in Section 2.08.040 of this code. 
(Prior code § 2-140) 
(Ord. No. 5216, § 5, 5-3-11) 
2.20.030 - Compensation. 
    The city treasurer shall receive such compensation as may be determined from time to time by the board of aldermen, and such compensation shall be made payable monthly. 
(Prior code § 2-141) 
2.20.040 - Receipt and custody of funds. 
    The city treasurer shall receive and safely keep all moneys of the city which may come into his hands by virtue of office. 
(Prior code § 2-143) 
2.20.050 - Disbursal of funds. 
    The city treasurer shall not disburse any city funds except upon warrants properly drawn and which are signed by the mayor and attested by the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 2-144) 
2.20.060 - Warrants, bonds and obligations. 
    The city treasurer shall receive and safely keep all warrants, bonds and obligations of the city entrusted to his care, and shall dispose of the same only upon proper authority from the board of aldermen or as provided by this code. 
(Prior code § 2-145) 
2.20.070 - Accounts to be maintained. 
    The city treasurer shall keep, in a set of books provided for that purpose, a full and accurate account of all moneys received and disbursed by him on behalf of the city, specifying the date of receipt or disbursement, from whom received, to whom disbursed, and on what account received and disbursed. 
(Prior code § 2-146) 
2.20.080 - Money paid into treasury- Disposition. 
    The city treasurer shall issue duplicate receipts for all sums of money which may be paid into the city treasury, specifying in the receipts the date of payment and upon what account paid. One of these receipts shall be given to the person making the payment and the other he shall file with the city clerk, who thereupon shall credit the person named in the receipt with the amount of his payment and charge the treasurer with the same. 
(Prior code § 2-147) 
2.20.090 - Warrants to be paid only when presented by proper person. 
    The city treasurer shall not pay any warrant drawn on him unless such warrant is presented by the person in whose favor the same is drawn or by his assignee, executor or administrator. 
(Prior code § 2-148) 
2.20.100 - Register of warrants to be maintained. 
    The city treasurer shall keep a register of all warrants paid into the treasury, describing such warrants by their date, number, name of payee and amount, specifying the time of receipt thereof, from whom received and on what account. 
(Prior code § 2-149) 
2.20.110 - Manner of canceling debts. 
    The city treasurer shall cancel all bonds, coupons, warrants and other evidences of debt against the city, whenever paid by him, by writing or stamping across the face thereof the words "Paid by the City Treasurer," with the date of payment written or stamped thereon. 
(Prior code § 2-150) 
2.20.120 - Furnishing fiscal information to mayor and board. 
    The city treasurer shall give information in writing to the mayor and board of aldermen, whenever required, upon any subject relating to his office or the fiscal affairs of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-151) 
2.20.130 - Financial statements. 
    The city treasurer shall prepare a financial statement for the board of aldermen and the various board and department heads of the city as requested by them. 
(Prior code § 2-152) 
2.20.140 - Preparation of annual budget. 
    The city treasurer shall assist in the preparation of the annual budget of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-155) 
2.20.150 - Maintenance of books and records. 
    The city treasurer shall assist the city clerk in maintaining the financial books and records of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-156) 
2.20.160 - Monthly reports to board. 
    The city treasurer shall make a monthly report to the board of aldermen, not later than the second regular meeting, which report shall show the balance in the city treasury at the beginning of the month, the amount received during the month and credited to the various funds, the amount disbursed during the month, and the balance remaining to the credit of each fund and constituting the general balance in the treasury at the close of business on the day when such statement is made as aforesaid. 
(Prior code § 2-157) 
2.20.170 - Annual report to board. 
    The city treasurer shall report to the board of aldermen, at its first regular meeting held in April of each year, the amount of receipts and disbursements of the city treasury during the preceding year, the balance remaining to the credit of each fund and constituting the general balance in the treasury on the first day of April, the amount of bonds maturing in the succeeding year, if any, for the redemption of which provision must be made, and the amount of money required to pay interest falling due on the indebtedness of the city during the next fiscal year. 
(Prior code § 2-158) 
2.20.180 - Final settlement. 
    At the first regular meeting of the board of aldermen held in April of each year, the city treasurer shall, if demanded by the board of aldermen, present the mayor and board of aldermen, for final settlement, a general statement of his accounts for the past fiscal year. Such statement shall show the amount of all receipts into the city treasury and of all payments made by him during such term, the condition of the treasury on the first day of April, the balance remaining on that day to the credit of each fund, and such settlement, when made and approved by the mayor and board of aldermen, shall be entered of record in the office of the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 2-159) 
2.20.190 - Additional duties. 
    In addition to the duties prescribed in this chapter, the city treasurer shall perform all other duties as may be required of him by state law. 
(Prior code § 2-160) 
2.20.200 - Misuse of funds. 
    The city treasurer is expressly prohibited from using, either directly or indirectly, for his own benefit or that of any other person, any money, warrant or other obligation of the city in his custody. 
(Prior code § 2-161) 
2.20.210 - Violations-Penalties. 
    If the city treasurer wilfully neglects or refuses to perform any of the duties enjoined upon him by ordinance or by resolution of the mayor and board of aldermen, or if he is guilty of any oppression or extortion in the discharge of his official duties, or if by color of his office he knowingly does any act not authorized by ordinance, he shall be punished as provided in Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 2-162) 
Chapter 2.28 - CITY ATTORNEY 
Sections: 

2.28.010 - Office established. 
    There is established the office of city attorney. 
(Prior code § 2-186) 
2.28.020 - Qualifications. 
    No person shall be appointed city attorney who is not a licensed attorney under the laws of the state. 
(Prior code § 2-187) 
2.28.030 - Compensation. 
    The city attorney shall receive compensation as established by Section 2.92.010, by the annual budget ordinance, or by other ordinance officially passed and approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-188) 
2.28.040 - Attendance of board meetings. 
    The city attorney shall attend all meetings of the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-189) 
2.28.050 - Drawing up ordinances. 
    The city attorney shall draw up any ordinance requested by any member of the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-190) 
2.28.060 - Preparation of documents and notices. 
    In all proceedings connected with the affairs of the city, the city attorney shall prepare all legal documents connected therewith, and see that all documents and notices are properly made out, served and properly returned. 
(Prior code § 2-191) 
2.28.070 - Adviser of commissions and boards. 
    The city attorney shall be the legal adviser of the airport commission, park board, planning and zoning board, and such other boards as may be appointed by the mayor. 
(Prior code § 2-192) 
2.28.080 - Advising board, committees and officers. 
    The city attorney shall advise the board of aldermen or its committees, or any city officer, on such legal questions as may arise in relation to the affairs of the city. 
(Prior code § 2-193) 
2.28.090 - Furnishing written opinions. 
    The city attorney shall furnish written opinions on legal questions whenever the same shall be required by the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-194) 
2.28.100 - Preparation of charges and complaints against violators-Prosecution-Affidavits. 
    The city attorney shall prepare all charges and complaints against parties charged with a violation of the city ordinances, shall prosecute the same on behalf of the city and shall make all affidavits on behalf of the city necessary in procuring changes of venue or taking appeals. 
(Prior code § 2-195) 
2.28.110 - Prosecution and defense of suits. 
    It shall be the duty of the city attorney to prosecute or defend all suits in any court in which the city may be a party and all suits in which any officer of the city may be a party, arising out of said officer's legal acts. 
(Prior code § 2-196) 
2.28.120 - Additional duties. 
    In addition to the duties prescribed in this chapter, the city attorney shall perform any and all other duties required of him by the laws of this state. 
(Prior code § 2-197) 
2.28.130 - Employment of counsel when no person is appointed to office. 
    In case no city attorney is appointed, the mayor or board of aldermen may, by resolution, employ an attorney or attorneys to perform any legal services required by the city and pay him or them a reasonable fee or compensation therefor. 
(Prior code § 2-198) 
2.28.140 - Employment of additional counsel. 
    In case a city attorney has been appointed, the mayor and board of aldermen may, if they deem it necessary, employ additional counsel and pay them reasonable compensation for any legal services demanded by the city. 
(Prior code § 2-199) 
2.28.150 - Appointment of substitute during temporary disability. 
    In case of sickness, absence from the city or other temporary inability of the city attorney to discharge the duties of his office, he may, with the approbation of the mayor and at his own expense, appoint some competent attorney to act in his stead during such sickness, absence from the city or other temporary inability. If such appointment is not made as aforesaid, then it shall be the duty of the police judge to appoint some competent attorney to represent the city in all cases before his court, pending such temporary inability of the city attorney to perform the duties of his office, and the person so appointed shall possess the same powers and receive the same fees as the regular city attorney would if he were present. 
(Prior code § 2-200) 
Chapter 2.32 - CITY ENGINEER 
Sections: 

2.32.010 - Office established. 
    There is established the office of city engineer. 
(Prior code § 2-206) 
2.32.020 - Qualifications. 
    The city engineer shall have a knowledge of surveying and civil engineering. 
(Prior code § 2-207) 
2.32.030 - Compensation. 
    The city engineer shall receive compensation as established by Section 2.92.010, by the annual budget ordinance, or by other ordinance officially passed and approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-208) 
2.32.040 - General duties. 
    The city engineer shall perform such duties as the board of aldermen shall require from time to time. 
(Prior code § 2-209) 
Chapter 2.36 - CITY ADMINISTRATOR 
Sections: 

2.36.010 - Office created. 
    The office of city administrator is created. 
(Prior code § 2-219) 
2.36.020 - Appointment. 
    The city administrator shall be appointed by the mayor with approval of a majority of elected members of the board of aldermen for an indefinite term. He shall be at least twenty-one (21) years of age and shall be chosen solely on the basis of his executive and administrative qualifications. The choice of the city administrator shall not be limited by residence qualifications; however, he shall reside within the city limits while in office and shall devote his full time to the performance of the duties of his office. 
(Prior code § 2-220) 
2.36.025 - City administrator serves at the pleasure of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
    The city administrator serves at the pleasure of the mayor and board of aldermen and may be removed at any time as set forth in Section 2.36.060 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 5050, § 1, 9-15-09) 
2.36.030 - Oath of office. 
    Before entering upon the duties of his office, the city administrator shall take and subscribe to an oath or affirmation before the city clerk or someone authorized to administer oaths, that he possesses all the qualifications prescribed for his office by law; that he will support the constitution of the United States and the state of Missouri; the provisions of all laws of the state of Missouri and the ordinances of the city; and that he will faithfully demean himself while in office. 
(Prior code § 2-221) 
2.36.040 - Bond. 
    The city administrator shall be covered by a surety bond supplied by the city in the amount and manner as provided in Section 2.08.040 of this code. 
(Prior code § 2-222) 
(Ord. No. 5216, § 7, 5-3-11) 
2.36.050 - Compensation. 
    The compensation of the city administrator shall be established in accordance with the annual budget ordinance or ordinance approving the annual pay plan. 
(Prior code § 2-223) 
2.36.060 - Removal from office. 
    The city administrator shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority as set forth in Section 2.36.025 of this code. The mayor, with consent of a majority of all members of the board of aldermen, may remove the city administrator from office at will, and such city administrator may also be removed by a three-fourths vote of all members elected to the board of aldermen independently of the mayor's approval or recommendations. The city administrator shall request a public hearing within five days of removal. If requested, the mayor and board of aldermen shall grant the city administrator a public hearing within thirty (30) days following notice of removal. During the interim, the city administrator shall be suspended from duty but shall continue his salary and if, after a hearing, removal becomes final the city administrator shall only be entitled to compensation if it is required in the existing employment agreement with the city administrator. 
(Prior code § 2-224) 
(Ord. No. 5050, § 2, 9-15-09; Ord. No. 6100 , § 1, 12-18-18) 
2.36.065 - Evaluations. 
    It is the policy of the city administrator that all employees as defined in Section 2.88.200 of the code of ordinances shall receive regular evaluations as follows: 
A.  City Administrator. The city administrator will be evaluated by the mayor and board of aldermen with said evaluation process to begin September 1st of each year and to be conducted by such person as the board of aldermen may direct with said evaluation designed in such a manner as to fully inform the board of aldermen as to the city administrator's job performance. 
B.  All Other Employees. The city administrator shall conduct an evaluation process whereby all employees are evaluated by their immediate supervisor under the direction of their respective department head. Department heads shall be evaluated by the city administrator. The city administrator shall institute a system of job targets to be met by employees who receive substandard evaluations; employee job targets shall be for the purpose of improving employee performance. 
(Ord. No. 5050, § 3, 9-15-09) 
2.36.070 - Powers and duties. 
A.  The city administrator shall be the chief administrative assistant to the mayor and as such shall be the administrative officer of the city government. He may head one or more departments and shall be responsible to the mayor and board of aldermen for proper administration and management of the government business, officers and employees of the city. To that end, he shall have power and shall be required to: 
1.  Appoint and, when necessary for the good of the service, suspend or remove all employees of the city except as otherwise provided for by law or city ordinance. However, when it is necessary to fill vacancies in the office of city attorney, assistant city attorney, public works director, city clerk or city treasurer, or fire chief, the city administrator shall submit the names of individuals for approval by the mayor and board of aldermen. The city administrator may recommend removal or suspension of any such appointee when it would be in the best interest of the city, and the governing body shall give due consideration to such recommendations. If any appointment made by the mayor is rejected by the board of aldermen, the administrator shall, within twenty (20) days after the rejection of such permanent nominee, submit to the board of aldermen the name of some person other than such rejected nominee for permanent appointment to such office, job, board or commission. All direct appointments, removals or suspensions made by the city administrator, and all recommendations made to thesuspensions shall be based solely on merit, qualifications or disqualifications of the officers or employees concerned without regard to his political beliefs or affiliations; 
2.  Recommend for adoption by the governing body standard personnel procedures to include position classifications and pay schedules for all employees covered in the city's personnel program and shall cause to be prepared written job descriptions for all regularly employed city personnel; 
3.  Prepare the proposed budget annually and submit it to the board of aldermen together with a message describing important features; the budget to be supported by appropriate schedules and analysis; and he shall be designated the budget officer of the city; 
4.  Keep the governing body advised of the financial condition and future needs of the city, and make such recommendations as he may deem desirable; 
5.  Prescribe such rules and regulations as are necessary or expedient for conduct of administrative department or agencies subject to his authority, and he shall have the power to revoke, suspend or amend any rule or regulation of the administrative service prescribed by himself or any subordinate; 
6.  Investigate, examine or inquire into the affairs or operation of any department, and when so authorized by the board of aldermen, he shall have power to employ consultants and professional counsel to aid in such investigations, examinations or inquiries; 
7.  Coordinate and control the activities of administrative, police, fire, street, water, sewer and gas departments, and shall have the power to alter, amend and set aside orders, rules and policies issued and set by department heads. Such coordination and control shall be exercised through department heads or foremen of the respective departments, if any, and if none, then directly subject to the rules and regulations that may be prescribed from time to time by the board of aldermen; 
8.  Meet with standing committees appointed by the mayor on matters concerning general and special administrative problems, who shall consult with and render advice to city administrator on such matters; 
9.  Attend all meetings of the board of aldermen and have the right to appear before and address the board of aldermen at any meeting; 
10.  Have responsibility for all real and personal property of the city. He shall have responsibility for all inventories of such property and for the upkeep of all such property. Personal property may be sold by the administrator only with approval of the board of aldermen. Real property may be sold only with the approval of the board of aldermen by resolution or ordinance; 
11.  Supervise the purchase of all materials, supplies and equipment for which funds are provided in the budget. He shall have the power to purchase materials, supplies and equipment in amounts up to and including seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00), amounts over seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) shall be subject to approval of the respective committees, unless the health or safety of the citizens of the city are involved then this limit shall not apply. Contracts for services, construction and items of equipment purchased by sealed bids must be approved by the board of aldermen; 
12.  Supervise the preparation of all bid specifications for services, construction, and equipment and supervise all design-build projects as may be authorized by the statutes of the State of Missouri. 
13.  Perform other such duties as may be required by the board of aldermen, not inconsistent with the state statutes, laws or ordinances; 
14.  Account to the mayor and board of aldermen for any actions taken when requested to do so, and at all times shall be subject to supervision, control and direction of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
B.  The city administrator's further powers and duties shall be as follows: 
1.  He shall be in charge of and held responsible for the proper operation of the water plant and water distribution system, the gas distribution system, the sewer plants and sewer distribution system, and the maintenance and repair of streets. 
2.  He or his delegates shall supervise all assistants, laborers or helpers who shall be responsible to him and who may be discharged by him for cause deemed sufficient. Any assistant, laborer or helper who has been discharged by the administrator shall have the right to appeal to the board of aldermen his dismissal if the appeal or complaint is filed in writing with the board of aldermen within fifteen (15) days after the date of dismissal. 
3.  He or his delegates shall be responsible for the inspection of all water and gas meter installations and sewer connections to see that same conform to the rules and regulations of the city. 
4.  He or his delegates shall approve the location of water and gas meters. 
5.  He or his delegates shall have the right of free access to the property of the consumer during all reasonable hours of the day for the purpose of examining pipes, connections and meters. 
6.  He shall be subject to the orders of the board and shall perform such services as may be assigned to him by them. 
(Prior code § 2-225) 
(Ord. No. 5050, §s; 4-7, 9-15-09; Ord. No. 6136 , § 1, 3-19-19) 
2.36.080 - Interference by members of the board of aldermen. 
    No member of the board of aldermen shall directly interfere with the conduct of any department or duties of employees subordinate to the city administrator, except at the express direction of the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-226) 
2.36.090 - Vacancy in the office of city administrator. 
    In the event of a vacancy in the office of city administrator due to death, resignation or removal of the city administrator, the mayor, with approval of the board of aldermen, may designate such person or persons as the mayor may deem appropriate to carry out the various duties of the office of city administrator on an interim basis. The designation of powers hereunder shall include, but not be limited to, the power to conduct hearings under Title 8 of this code, or to conduct such other duties as the mayor, with the approval of the board of alderman, deems necessary on an interim basis. 
(Ord. 4401 § 1, 2003) 
Chapter 2.40 - CHIEF OF POLICE 
Sections: 

2.40.010 - Designated-Qualifications for office. 
A.  The marshal shall be the chief of police. 
B.  No person shall be the chief of police unless he is at least twenty-one (21) years of age, a citizen of the United States, an inhabitant and resident of the city for at least one year next preceding his election, and a qualified voter under the laws and the Constitution of this state and ordinances of the city. 
C.  No person shall be the chief of police who shall, at the time of his election, be in arrears for any unpaid city taxes or forfeiture or defalcation in office. 
D.  No person shall be the chief of police who has been found guilty of or pled guilty to a felony or misdemeanor under the federal laws of the United States or to a felony under the laws of this state or an offense committed in another state that would be considered a felony in this state. 
E.  No person shall be the chief of police who has not filed a candidate's affidavit of tax payments and bonding requirements with the Missouri Department of Revenue (Form 5120) as required by Section 115.306.2, RSMo. 
F.  Training for the chief of police shall be as set forth in Section 79.055, RSMo, and any amendments thereto. 
G.  The eligibility of a 'first responder' (as defined in Section 192.800, RSMo) who is an employee of the city to be a candidate for chief of police shall be governed by Section 67.145, RSMo, other provisions of this code notwithstanding. 
(Ord. 4320 § 1, 2002; prior code § 22-21) 
(Ord. No. 5478, §§ 1, 2, 12-3-13; Ord. No. 5717, § 3, 12-1-15) 
2.40.020 - Authority-Responsibilities and duties. 
A.  The chief of police shall be the executive head of the police force. All orders and directives to the police force will be directed through the chief of police. 
B.  The chief of police shall be responsible for the proper and efficient enforcement of all laws and ordinances, as well as departmental policies, rules and regulations. He shall discharge the responsibilities and duties imposed on his office and he shall perform any task that may be assigned him from time to time by the city administrator. He shall require employees in his force to do likewise. 
C.  He shall have the authority to promulgate such orders to the employees of the police force as he may deem proper, but the orders shall conform to state statute, city ordinance and departmental policies and rules and regulations. 
(Prior code § 22-22) 
2.40.030 - Compensation. 
    The chief of police shall receive as compensation the sum hereinafter indicated per year in lieu of all fees provided by city ordinance or state law: for the 2018-2022 term of office, sixty-eight thousand four hundred eighty dollars and no cents ($68,480.00). 
(Ord. 4713 § 2, 2005: Ord. 4225 § 2, 2001: Ord. 3570 § 2, 1997: prior code § 22-23) 
(Ord. No. 5067, § 2, 12-1-09; Ord. No. 5475, § 2, 12-3-13; Ord. No. 5981 , § 1, 11-21-17) 
2.40.040 - Attendance of board meetings. 
    The chief of police shall, upon request of the board of aldermen, attend the meetings of the board. 
(Prior code § 22-25) 
2.40.050 - Execution of board orders-Service of notices and processes. 
    The chief of police shall execute the orders and mandates of the board of aldermen and serve all notices and processes issued to him by the board, the mayor or other officers of the city. 
(Prior code § 22-26) 
2.40.060 - Attendance at police court sessions-Preservation of order. 
    The chief of police shall, upon request of the municipal judge, attend sessions of the police court and preserve order in the courtroom. 
(Prior code § 22-27) 
2.40.070 - Authority to make arrests and detain prisoners. 
    The chief of police shall have the power at all times to make or order an arrest, with proper process, for any offense against the city or state, and to keep the offender in the city prison or other proper place to prevent his escape until a trial can be had before the proper officer, unless such offender shall give a good and sufficient bond for his appearance at such trial. In all cases in which any offense against the city or state is committed in the presence of the chief of police, he shall have the power to make arrests without process. 
(Prior code § 22-28) 
2.40.080 - Authority to designate member to perform duties when disabled. 
    In case of sickness, absence from the city or other temporary disability, the chief of police shall have authority to designate some member of the police force to act in his stead and perform the duties required of him, until such disability is removed. 
(Prior code § 22-29) 
Chapter 2.44 - BUILDING OFFICIAL 
Sections: 

2.44.010 - Office established-Powers generally-Powers of other offices enumerated. 
    There is established the office building official. The office of building official shall include the power, authority and responsibility of the following offices: zoning administrator, building commissioner, mobilehome inspector, building official, building inspector, plumbing official, plumbing inspector, mechanical official, electrical official, electrical inspector. The building official shall be appointed by the city administrator. 
(Prior code § 8-6) 
2.44.020 - Qualifications. 
    No person shall be appointed to the office building official who is not at least twenty-five (25) years of age and a registered voter in the state of Missouri. The building official shall comply with the qualifications for officials and inspectors under the city's basic plumbing, building, mechanical and electrical codes; provided, however, that the city administrator may, waive these qualifications. 
(Prior code § 8-7) 
2.44.030 - Compensation. 
    The compensation of the building official shall be established in accordance with Section 2.92.010. 
(Prior code § 8-8) 
2.44.040 - Duties. 
    The duties of the building official shall be as set forth in the city's basic building, plumbing, mechanical and electrical codes. The building official shall also perform the duties of those offices set forth in Section 2.44.010. 
(Prior code § 8-9) 
Chapter 2.48 - ETHICS CODE 
Sections: 

2.48.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    "Commission" means the Missouri Ethics Commission. 
    "Dependent child" or "dependent child in his custody" means all children, stepchildren, foster children and wards under the age of eighteen (18) residing in his household and who receive in excess of fifty (50) percent of their support from him. 
    "Public document" means a state tax return or a document or other record maintained for public inspection without limitation of the right of access to it and a document filed in juvenile court proceeding. 
    "Substantial interest" means ownership by the individual, his spouse or his dependent children, whether singularly or collectively, directly or indirectly of ten percent or more of any business entity, or of an interest having a value of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) or more, or the receipt by an individual, his spouse or his dependent children, whether singularly or collectively, or a salary, gratuity or other compensation or remuneration of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), or more, per year from individual, partnership, organization or association within any calendar year. 
    "Substantial personal or private interest in any measure, bill, order or ordinance" means any interest in a measure, bill, order or ordinance which results from a substantial interest in a business entity. 
(Ord. 4970 § 1 (part), 2008; Ord. 4864 § 1 (part), 2007; Ord. 4791 § 1 (part), 2006; Ord. 4545 § 1 (part), 2004: Ord. 4317 § 1 (part), 2002: Ord. 3607 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 2-300) 
2.48.020 - Substantial personal or private interest-Report required. 
    Any member of the governing body of the city who has a substantial personal or private interest in any measure, bill, order or ordinance proposed or pending before such governing body shall, before he passes on the measure, bill, order or ordinance, file a written report of the nature of the interest with the city clerk and such statement shall be recorded in the appropriate journal or other record of proceedings of the city. 
(Ord. 4970 § 1 (part), 2008; Ord. 4864 § 1 (part), 2007; Ord. 4791 § 1 (part), 2006; Ord. 4545 § 1 (part), 2004: Ord. 4317 § 1 (part), 2002: Ord. 3607 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 2-301) 
2.48.030 - Compliance. 
    Any member of the governing body of the city shall be deemed to have complied with the requirements of Section 2.48.020 if he has filed, at any time before he passes on such measure, bill, order or ordinance, a financial interest statement pursuant to Section 2.48.060 which discloses the basis for his substantial personal or private interest or interests that he may have therein. Any such person may amend his financial interest statement to disclose any subsequently acquired substantial interest at any time before he passes on any measure, bill, order or ordinance and shall be relieved of the provisions of Section 2.48.020. 
(Ord. 4970 § 1 (part), 2008; Ord. 4864 § 1 (part), 2007; Ord. 4791 § 1 (part), 2006; Ord. 4545 § 1 (part), 2004: Ord. 4317 § 1 (part), 2002: Ord. 3607 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 2-302) 
2.48.040 - Effect on other laws. 
    Nothing in Sections 2.48.010 through 2.48.070 shall be interpreted as exempting any individual from applicable provisions of any other laws of this state or the provisions of any charter or ordinance of other political subdivisions in the state. 
(Ord. 4970 § 1 (part), 2008; Ord. 4864 § 1 (part), 2007; Ord. 4791 § 1 (part), 2006; Ord. 4545 § 1 (part), 2004: Ord. 4317 § 1 (part), 2002: Ord. 3607 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 2-303) 
2.48.050 - Persons required to file a financial interest statement. 
    Each elected official, the chief administrative officer and the chief purchasing officer of the city, and each official or employee of the city who is authorized by the governing body of the city to promulgate rules and regulations with the force of law or to vote on the adoption of rules and regulations with the force of law shall be required to file a financial interest statement as required by Section 2.48.060. 
(Ord. 4970 § 1 (part), 2008; Ord. 4864 § 1 (part), 2007; Ord. 4791 § 1 (part), 2006; Ord. 4545 § 1 (part), 2004: Ord. 4317 § 1 (part), 2002: Ord. 3607 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 2-304) 
2.48.060 - Financial interest statement requirements. 
    The following requirements with respect to disclosure of substantial interests must be met: 
A.  Disclosure in writing of the following described transactions, if any such transactions were engaged in during the calendar year: 
1.  For such person, and all persons within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity of such person, the date and the identities of the parties to each transaction with a total value in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), if any, that such person had with the city other than compensation received as an employee or payment of any tax, fee or penalty due to the city and other than transfers for no consideration to the city; 
2.  The date and the identities of the parties to each transaction known to the person with a total value in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), if any, that any business entity in which such person had a substantial interest had with the city, other than payment of any tax, fee or penalty due to the city or transactions involving payment for providing utility service to the city, and other than transfer for no consideration to the city. 
B.  The chief administrative officer and chief purchasing officer of the city shall disclose in writing the following information: 
1.  The name and address of each of the employers of such person from whom income of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more was received during the year covered by the statement; 
2.  The name and address of each sole proprietorship which he owned; the name, address and the general nature of the business conducted of each general partnership and joint venture in which he was a partner or participant; the name and address of each partner or co-participant for each partnership or joint venture unless such names and addresses are filed by the partnership or joint venture with the secretary of state; the name, address and general nature of the business conducted of any closely held corporation or limited partnership in which the person owned ten percent or more of any class of the outstanding stock or limited partners' units; and the name of any publicly traded corporation or limited partnership which is listed on a regulated stock exchange or automated quotation system in which the person owned two percent or more of any class of outstanding stock, limited partnership units or other equity interests; 
3.  The name and address of each corporation for which such person served in the capacity of a director, officer or receiver. 
C.  Duplicate disclosure reports made pursuant to this section shall be filed with the commission and the city clerk. The city clerk shall maintain such disclosure reports available for public inspection and copying during normal business hours. 
(Ord. 4970 § 1 (part), 2008; Ord. 4864 § 1 (part), 2007; Ord. 4791 § 1 (part), 2006; Ord. 4545 § 1 (part), 2004: Ord. 4317 § 1 (part), 2002: Ord. 3607 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 2-305) 
2.48.070 - Time for filing. 
    The financial interest statements shall be filed at the following times, but no person is required to file more than one financial interest statement in any calendar year: 
A.  Each candidate for elective office shall file a financial interest statement no later than the forty-fifth day after the last day for firing for the election at which he seeks nomination or election, and the statement shall be for the twelve (12) months prior to the closing date, except that in the event an individual does not become a candidate until later than the forty-fifth day after the last day for filing for the election, the statement shall be filed within ten days of his becoming a candidate. An individual required to file a financial interest statement because of his candidacy for office prior to a primary election in accordance with this section is also required to amend such statement within seven days prior to the following general election to reflect any changes in financial interest during the interim. The appropriate elections authority shall provide to the candidate at the time of filing for election written notice of the candidates' obligation to file under this article and the candidate shall sign a statement acknowledging receipt of such notice. 
B.  Each person appointed to office and each official or employee described in Section 2.48.050 who is not otherwise covered in this section shall file the statement within thirty (30) days of such appointment or employment. 
C.  Every other person required by this chapter to file a financial interest statement shall file the statement annually not later than the first day of May and the statement shall cover the calendar year ending the immediately preceding December 31st; provided that any member of the governing body of the city may supplement his financial interest statement to report additional interests acquired after December 31st of the covered year until the date of filing of the financial interest statement. 
D.  The deadline for filing any statement required by this chapter shall be five p.m. of the last day designated for filing the statement. When the last day of filing falls on a Saturday or Sunday or on an official state holiday, the deadline for filing is extended to five p.m. on the next day which is not a Saturday or Sunday or official holiday. Any statement required within specified time shall be deemed to be timely filed if it is postmarked not later than midnight of the day previous to the date designated for filing the statement. 
(Ord. 4970 § 1 (part), 2008; Ord. 4864 § 1 (part), 2007; Ord. 4791 § 1 (part), 2006; Ord. 4545 § 1 (part), 2004: Ord. 4317 § 1 (part), 2002: Ord. 3607 § 1 (part), 1998: prior code § 2-306) 
Chapter 2.52 - LOBBYING 
Sections: 

2.52.010 - Federal-appropriated funds prohibited. 
    No federal-appropriated funds shall be paid, by or on behalf of the city, to any person for influencing or attempting to influence an officer or employee of any agency, a member of Congress, an officer or employee of Congress, or any employee of a member of Congress in connection with the awarding of any federal contract, the making of any federal grant, the making of any federal loan, the entering into of any cooperative agreement, and the extension, continuation, renewal, amendment or modification of any federal contract, grant, loan or cooperative agreement. 
(Prior code § 2-350) 
2.52.020 - Disclosure form. 
    If any funds other than federal-appropriated funds have been or will be paid to any person for influencing or attempting to influence an officer or employee of any agency, a member of Congress, an officer or employee of Congress, or an employee of a member of Congress in connection with a federal contract, grant, loan, or cooperative agreement, the city shall complete and submit Standard Form-LLL, "Disclosure Form to Report Lobbying," in accordance with its instructions. 
(Prior code § 2-351) 
2.52.030 - Inclusion in all subaward documents. 
    The city shall require that the language of this chapter be included in the award documents for all subaward at all tiers (including subcontract, subgrants and contracts under grants, loans and cooperative agreements) over one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) and that all subrecipients shall disclose accordingly. 
(Prior code § 2-352) 
Chapter 2.56 - POLICE DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

2.56.010 - Purpose. 
    This chapter is established in order to establish the lines of authority and responsibility as between the mayor and the board of aldermen and the elected chief of police and his department. 
(Prior code § 22-1) 
2.56.020 - Police force positions-Rules and regulations-Filling vacancies. 
A.  Police Force Positions. The police force of the city, in addition to the chief of police, shall consist of those positions as established in the budget ordinance of the city. The police force shall include all dispatchers and reference in this chapter to 'policemen' or the like shall include dispatchers. 
B.  Rules and Regulations. Chapter 2.88 of this code shall apply to the police officers of the city. However, recognizing the special nature of the police force, the chief of police, with the approval of the board of aldermen, may establish such additional rules and regulations as the chief of police deems necessary for the efficient administration, management, and control of the police force. These additional rules and regulations and any amendments thereto shall be kept on file both in the office of the city clerk and in the office of the chief of police. In the event of a conflict, Chapter 2.88 shall control unless specifically approved and noted by action of the board of aldermen. 
C.  Filling Vacancies. When a vacancy arises in the police department, the following procedure shall apply: 
1.  The personnel clerk, with direction from the chief of police, shall solicit applications from qualified candidates for vacancies in the department by advertising in professional journals, local newspapers, and other generally accepted sources. 
2.  The chief of police, assistant chief of police, personnel clerk, and such other police department personnel as the chief of police deems appropriate and necessary shall screen the applications and candidates and select no less than three to present for employment to the interview board. 
3.  The interview board shall consist of the following: the president of the board of aldermen, chairman of the public safety committee, chief of police, assistant chief of police, and personnel clerk. 
4.  The interview board shall conduct the final interview with the prospective candidates, rate the candidates, and make its selection to fill the vacancy. 
5.  In the case of an emergency, the chief of police may, with the approval of the board of aldermen, fill vacancies within the police department without a final interview by the full interview board. The authorization provided in this subsection may be revoked and rescinded by the board of aldermen at any time, and in such event the hiring procedure set forth in subsections (C)(1) through (4), of this section shall be followed. 
6.  The process for promotions within the police department shall follow a similar process utilizing a three-person interview board. The board shall consist of the city's personnel clerk, the supervisor of the position to be filled, and the chief of police and/or his designee. Exceptions to this process shall be approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. 4714 § 1, 2005; prior code § 22-2) 
(Ord. No. 5523, § 1, 5-20-14; Ord. No. 5730, § 1, 2-2-16) 
2.56.030 - Salary-Restrictions on compensation. 
A.  The salary of the police officers of the city shall be established in the annual city pay plan or other action approved by the board of aldermen in the same manner as other city employees. 
B.  The personnel rules and regulations of the city as set forth in Chapter 2.88 of this code and the rules and regulations established under Section 2.56.020(B) of this code shall apply to police officers. 
(Prior code § 22-3) 
(Ord. No. 5730, § 2, 2-2-16) 
2.56.040 - Bond. 
    All appointed police officers of the city shall be covered by a surety bond supplied by the city in the amount and manner as provided in Section 2.08.040 of this code. 
(Prior code § 22-4) 
(Ord. No. 5216, § 8, 5-3-11) 
2.56.050 - Summoning assistance. 
    The chief of police or any policeman is authorized, whenever he deems it necessary, to call to his assistance any person or number of persons needed to aid him in making arrests. 
(Prior code § 22-5) 
2.56.060 - Intoxication-Accepting gratuities-Failure to discharge duties. 
    The chief of police or any policeman who becomes intoxicated while in the discharge of his duties, or accepts from any person arrested any present or gratuity of any character or description, or refuses, neglects or fails to discharge any duty enjoined upon him by virtue of this code shall be deemed guilty of misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 22-6) 
2.56.070 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5730, § 3, adopted February 2, 2016, repealed § 2.56.070, which pertained to special policemen and derived from prior code § 22-7. 
2.56.080 - Excessive force. 
A.  The city adopts, and will enforce the policy prohibiting the use of excessive force by law enforcement agencies within its jurisdiction against any individuals engaged in nonviolent civil rights demonstrations. 
B.  Any person found to be violating any provisions of this section shall be served by the city with a written notice stating the nature of the violation. 
C.  Any person guilty of this violation shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and on conviction thereof shall be fined in accordance with the provisions of Section 1.16.010. Each day in which such violation shall continue shall be deemed a separate offense. 
D.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall become liable to the city for any expense, loss, or damage occasioned by the city by reason of such violation. 
(Prior code § 22-8) 
2.56.090 - Emergency response by city officials in county. 
A.  The mayor and board of aldermen of the city exercise the authority established by the general legislature of the state of Missouri to allow response by city police officials in emergency situations with the county of Perry. 
B.  The city does through this section adopt all of the provisions set forth in Section 70.820 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri as the official policy of the city and does authorize the chief of police to authorize response to emergency situations as defined in said statute within the confines of the county of Perry, state of Missouri, and under the specific provisions of Section 70.820, Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1978, as amended in 1977. 
C.  This section shall be effective upon the passage of a similar resolution by the county commissioners of Perry County, Missouri. 
D.  The chief of police of the city is authorized to authorize the response by any peace officer of the city who has completed the police basic training program as promulgated by Chapter 590, Revised Statutes of the state of Missouri, to emergency situations within the county of Perry. 
E.  No police officer shall respond to any situation, whether emergency or otherwise, outside of the confines of the city limits without the permission of the chief of police or his designate. 
(Prior code § 22-30) 
2.56.100 - Fresh pursuit-Defined. 
    As used in Sections 2.56.110 through 2.56.150, "fresh pursuit" means the pursuit of a person who has committed a felony or is reasonably suspected of having committed a felony in the state of Missouri, or who has committed or attempted to commit in the state of Missouri a criminal offense or violation of municipal or county ordinance in the presence of a city police officer or for whom such officer holds a warrant of arrest for a criminal offense. It shall also include the pursuit of a person suspected of having committed a supposed felony in the state of Missouri, though no felony has actually been committed, if there is reasonable ground for so believing. "Fresh pursuit" shall imply instant pursuit. 
(Prior code § 22-70) 
2.56.110 - Fresh pursuit-Authority to conduct. 
    Every city police officer certified by the Missouri Director of the Department of Public Safety as a peace officer as provided by Mo. Rev. Stat., Chapter 590 (1986, as amended), is authorized to arrest and hold in custody any person apprehended as the result of fresh pursuit as defined herein subject to the rules and procedures adopted by the city. 
(Prior code § 22-71) 
2.56.120 - Initiation of fresh pursuit. 
    Fresh pursuit may only be initiated from within the city limits and shall be terminated once the pursuing officer is outside of his jurisdiction and has lost contact with the person being pursued. 
(Prior code § 22-72) 
2.56.130 - Fresh pursuit-Traffic violations. 
    If the offense is a traffic violation, the uniform traffic ticket shall be used as if the violator had been apprehended in the city and a summons shall be issued by the arresting officer. 
(Prior code § 22-73) 
2.56.140 - Fresh pursuit-Warrant arrests. 
    If an arrest is made in obedience to a warrant, the disposition of the prisoner shall be made as in other cases of arrest under a warrant. 
(Prior code § 22-74) 
2.56.150 - Policies and procedures. 
    All incidents of fresh pursuit shall be conducted pursuant to the policies and procedures adopted by the city marshal of the city police department and approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 22-75) 
Chapter 2.60 - POLICE RESERVE UNIT 
Sections: 

2.60.010 - Created. 
    There is created a police reserve unit, the membership of which shall consist of not more than six members or one-half of the full strength of the regular police department officers, whichever is greater. Each member shall be in good physical condition, of good character and not less than twenty-one (21) years of age. Appointments to the police reserve unit shall be made by the chief of police with the approval of the board of aldermen for two years, providing that any member may be discharged at any time with or without cause and without a hearing by the chief of police or internal review board or the mayor and the board of aldermen. Regular police officers shall be eligible for membership in the police reserve unit. 
(Prior code § 22-50) 
2.60.020 - Oath-Commission-Powers-Duties-Service. 
    The police reserve unit shall function under the immediate direction of the chief of police or his designate. Oath, powers and duties will be the same as required of a regular police officer. Except during probation periods, members of the police reserve unit shall have all the powers and authority and shall be subject to all of the duties of members of the regularly constituted police department and shall be subject to the rules and regulations governing the police department; provided, however, that the membership in the police reserve unit shall not constitute members in the regularly constituted police department nor shall any member of the police reserve unit be entitled to any right or privilege of compensation, pension or any other similar right or privilege of members of the regular police department, nor any prerequisite or emolument attaching to membership in the regularly constituted police department. All members of the police reserve unit will be required to work a minimum number of hours per year as established by the chief of police. 
(Prior code § 22-51) 
2.60.030 - Training. 
    The chief of police shall determine the program for training members of the police reserve unit in police work. Reserve officers will work within the command structure of the present police department. 
(Prior code § 22-52) 
2.60.040 - Compensation. 
A.  No member of the police reserve shall receive any compensation from the city for his services as a member of the police reserve unit except as may be provided from time to time by the board of aldermen. 
B.  The police reserve unit may not accept donations for their services. 
(Prior code § 22-53) 
2.60.050 - Uniforms, equipment and vehicles. 
A.  The members of the police reserve unit shall furnish their own uniforms and other necessary equipment without reimbursement from the city except as otherwise provided by ordinance. 
B.  The police reserve unit shall own no equipment other than their personal uniforms and equipment approved by the chief of police. They shall use the existing equipment of the regular police department as designated. 
(Prior code § 22-54) 
2.60.060 - Selection. 
    The chief of police, with the approval of the board of aldermen, shall appoint reserve personnel. 
(Prior code § 22-55) 
Chapter 2.64 - FIRE DEPARTMENT 
Sections: 

2.64.010 - Established. 
    There is established a fire department in the city. 
(Prior code § 12-15) 
2.64.020 - Composition. 
    The fire department shall consist of a fire chief, deputy fire chief, and two assistant fire chiefs and other such officers and members as determined is necessary and approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-16) 
2.64.030 - Meetings. 
    The fire department shall meet at regular monthly meetings and the December meeting shall be the annual meeting of the department. 
(Prior code § 12-17) 
2.64.040 - Appointment of chief. 
    The fire chief shall be appointed in April of each even-numbered year by the mayor with the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 12-18) 
(Ord. No. 5236, § 1, 7-5-11) 
2.64.050 - Oath of chief. 
    The fire chief shall, before entering upon the discharge of his duties, be sworn to faithfully perform the duties of office. 
(Prior code § 12-19) 
2.64.060 - Term of chief. 
    The fire chief shall serve in office for the term of two years and until his successor is appointed and qualified, unless sooner removed for cause. 
(Prior code § 12-20) 
(Ord. No. 5236, § 2, 7-5-11) 
2.64.070 - Removal of chief. 
    The fire chief may be removed from office by resolution of the board of aldermen at any time for incompetency, inefficiency, neglect of duty or when it may appear to the board to be in the best interest of the fire department. 
(Prior code § 12-21) 
2.64.080 - Appointment of deputy chief, assistant chiefs, and members. 
    The deputy fire chief, assistant fire chiefs, other officers and members of the fire department shall be appointed by the fire chief. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-22) 
2.64.090 - Dismissal of deputy chief, assistant chiefs, other officers, or members. 
    The deputy fire chief, assistant fire chiefs, other officers, or any or all members of the fire department may be summarily dismissed by the fire chief at any time when in his opinion the same will be to the best interest of the fire department. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-23) 
2.64.100 - Filling of vacancies. 
    Upon the dismissal or resignation of the deputy fire chief, assistant fire chiefs, or any or all members of the fire department, the fire chief shall immediately proceed to fill such vacancy or vacancies. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-24) 
2.64.110 - Compensation of members. 
    Each member of the fire department shall receive such compensation as determined by the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 12-25) 
2.64.120 - Adoption of constitution, bylaws and regulations. 
    The fire department shall have the authority to adopt a constitution, bylaws and regulations for the government of the same. 
(Prior code § 12-26) 
2.64.130 - General authority of chief. 
    The fire chief shall be commander of the fire department subject only to the orders of the mayor. 
(Prior code § 12-27) 
2.64.140 - Members to obey orders of chief. 
    The deputy fire chief, assistant fire chiefs, all other officers and members of the fire department shall strictly obey all lawful orders of the fire chief. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-28) 
2.64.150 - Deputy chief/assistant chiefs-Duties. 
    The deputy chief and the assistant fire chiefs shall assist the fire chief and, in the absence of the fire chief, act in his stead. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-29) 
2.64.160 - Members to respond to alarms. 
    Whenever there is a fire alarm, the firefighters shall, under the direction of the fire chief, deputy fire chief, or assistant fire chief, proceed as rapidly as possible to the scene of the fire with the fire apparatus and equipment, and there work and manage the same under the direction of the fire chief, deputy fire chief or the assistant fire chief until the fire is extinguished. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-30) 
2.64.170 - Departure from fire by members. 
    It is unlawful for any member of the department once on the scene to leave task without the permission of the fire chief, deputy fire chief, assistant fire chief or other fire officer in command at said location. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-31) 
2.64.180 - Destruction of structures to arrest progress of fire. 
    The fire chief or other officer in command at any fire may order the removal of any building or erection for the purpose of arresting the progress of any fire and, with the advice of the mayor and two members of the board of aldermen, shall have the power to blow up any building or structure for the purpose of arresting the progress of a fire. 
(Prior code § 12-32) 
2.64.190 - Summoning aid at fire. 
    The fire chief, deputy fire chief, or assistant fire chief shall have the authority to summon any person present to aid in extinguishing any fire or protecting property thereat and it shall be unlawful for any person to refuse to assist when summoned. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-33) 
2.64.200 - Arrest authority of chief, deputy chief, and assistant chiefs. 
    The fire chief, deputy fire chief, or the assistant fire chiefs shall have the power to arrest any person refusing to assist the fire department in extinguishing any fire or protecting property thereat when summoned or any person who steals or attempts to steal any property during the progress of the fire and hold such person in custody until he can be dealt with according to law. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 12-34) 
2.64.210 - Mutual aid agreements. 
A.  The fire department shall not answer any fire calls and/or use public safety equipment outside the city limits, except as hereinafter provided. 
B.  The city fire department, with the approval of the mayor and the board of aldermen, may enter into mutual aid agreements with rural fire protection associations, municipalities and counties as authorized by state statute. Such mutual aid agreements shall be entered into only by official action of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 12-35) 
2.64.220 - Equipment and apparatus- Custody and maintenance. 
    The fire chief shall have the custody of the fire engines, hose carts, trucks, hooks, ladders and other equipment or apparatus of the fire department and it shall be his duty to look after and carefully preserve such equipment or apparatus. 
(Prior code § 12-36) 
2.64.230 - Equipment and apparatus- Repair. 
    Whenever any of the fire engines, hose carts, trucks, hooks, ladders and other equipment or apparatus of the fire department need to be repaired, the fire chief shall, with the advice and consent of the mayor, cause such repairs to be made. 
(Prior code § 12-37) 
2.64.240 - Use of intoxicating liquor by members. 
A.  It is unlawful for any member of the fire department to be found in a state of intoxication at any fire or to use any intoxicating liquor in or about any fire station. 
B.  Any member of the fire department convicted of violating any provision of subsection A of this section shall, after dismissal, be ineligible to be a member of the fire department. 
(Prior code § 12-38) 
2.64.250 - Annual inspection. 
    There shall be a general review of the fire department during the month of November of each year. 
(Prior code § 12-39) 
2.64.260 - Intentional or negligent acts and false alarms-Fees and charges. 
A.  Intent. The board of aldermen, after making a study of the matter, finds that the city fire department occasionally must respond to emergency situations, both inside and outside the city limits, that are the result of intentional or negligent acts and false alarms. There should be a means for the city to receive reimbursement for extraordinary expenditures of funds in providing fire suppression services in such instances. 
B.  When Charges Incurred. Fees and charges as set forth in the fee schedule in this section may be imposed for reimbursement of services rendered by the city fire department in the following cases: 
1.  For responses made to a fire or accident which occurred as a result of a negligent or intentional act, the fee shall be imposed against the individual or individuals responsible for the act; and 
2.  For responses made as a result of a maliciously set false alarm or repeated nonmaliciously set false alarms, the fee shall be imposed against the individual or individuals responsible for the false alarm. 
C.  Fee Schedule. The following fee schedule shall apply: 
1.  Minimum initial service charge-two hundred dollars ($200.00) per fire truck used. 
2.  Special equipment fees and substantial personnel hours costs as determined by the fire chief. 
3.  For equipment destroyed or lost while combatting fire and not replaced by proceeds from insurance, replacement costs shall be charged. Consumable items used shall be refunded at replacement cost, i.e., foam, air or oxygen. 
D.  Determination of Charges. The fire chief shall make the determination as to when the fees set forth in this section shall be assessed and which individual or individuals shall be responsible for payment of the fees. 
(Prior code § 12-8) 
2.64.270 - Hazardous materials incidents- Fees and charges. 
    In incidents involving hazardous materials including but not limited to leaks, spills or releases of such hazardous materials, the person having control over the hazardous substance shall be liable for such reasonable cleanup and containment costs incurred by the city. Such liability includes the cost of materials, supplies and contractual services actually used to secure an emergency situation. The liability may also include the cost for third party contractual services, third party services, equipment, material of any kind or type necessary or desirable for cleanup and containment cost, which are not routinely provided by the department or the city. 
(Ord. 4069 § 1 (part), 2000) 
Chapter 2.68 - MUNICIPAL COURT 
Sections: 

2.68.010 - Court established. 
    There is established in this city a police court, to be known as the "Perryville Municipal Court, a Division of the 32nd Judicial Circuit Court of the State of Missouri." This court is a continuation of the police court of the city as previously established, and is termed herein "the municipal court." 
(Prior code § 23-1) 
2.68.020 - Jurisdiction. 
    The jurisdiction of the municipal court shall extend to all cases involving alleged violations of the ordinances of the city. 
(Prior code § 23-2) 
2.68.030 - Selection of judge-Compensation. 
A.  The judge of the city's municipal court shall be known as the 'Municipal Judge of the 32nd Judicial Circuit Court' and shall be elected to the position by the qualified voters of this city for a term as specified in Section 2.68.040. 
B.  The municipal judge shall receive the sum of one thousand ninety-two dollars ($1,092.00) per month for the 2018-2020 term of office in lieu of all other fees. 
(Ord. 4891 § 2, 2007: Ord. 4713 § 3, 2005: Ord. 4502 § 2, 2004: Ord. 4225 § 3, 2001: Ord. 3940 § 2, 1999: Ord. 3570 § 3, 1997: prior code § 23-3) 
(Ord. No. 5067, § 3, 12-1-09; Ord. No. 5282, § 2, 12-6-11; Ord. No. 5475, § 3, 12-3-13; Ord. No. 5716, § 1, 12-1-15; Ord. No. 5981 , § 2, 11-21-17) 
2.68.040 - Judge-Term of office. 
    The municipal judge shall hold his office for a period of two years and shall take office biannually from the date for an elected official to take office. If for any reason a municipal judge vacates his office, his successor shall complete that term of office even if the same is for less than two years. 
(Prior code § 23-4) 
2.68.050 - Judge-Vacation of office. 
    The municipal judge shall vacate his office under the following circumstances: 
A.  Upon removal from office by the state commission on the retirement, removal and discipline of judges, as provided in Missouri Supreme Court Rule 12; 
B.  Upon attaining his seventy-fifth birthday; or 
C.  Should he fail within six months of his election to satisfactorily complete course of instruction for municipal judge as prescribed by the state supreme court. 
(Prior code § 23-5) 
2.68.060 - Judge-Qualifications for office. 
    The municipal judge shall possess the following qualifications before he shall take office: 
A.  He shall be licensed to practice law within the state of Missouri. 
B.  He must reside within Perry County, Missouri. 
C.  He must be a resident of the state of Missouri. 
D.  He must be between the ages of twenty-one (21) and seventy-five (75) years. 
E.  He may not hold any other office within the city government. 
F.  The municipal judge shall be considered holding a part-time position and as such may accept (within the requirements of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Missouri Supreme Court Rule 2) other employment. 
G.  He shall be a qualified voter under the laws and the Constitution of this state and ordinances of the city. 
H.  No person shall be judge who shall at the time of his election be in arrears for any unpaid city taxes or forfeiture or defalcation in office. 
I.  No person shall be judge who has been found guilty of or pled guilty to a felony or misdemeanor under the federal laws of the United States or to a felony under the laws of this state or an offense committed in another state that would be considered a felony in this state. 
J.  No person shall be judge who has not filed a candidate's affidavit of tax payments and bonding requirements with the Missouri Department of Revenue (Form 5120) as required by Section 115.306.2, RSMo. 
(Ord. 4231 § 1, 2001: prior code § 23-6) 
(Ord. No. 5717, § 4, 12-1-15; Ord. No. 5895, § 1, 5-16-17) 
2.68.070 - Superintending authority. 
    The municipal court of the city shall be subject to the rules of the circuit court of which it is a part, and to the rules of the State Supreme Court. The municipal court shall be subject to the general administrative authority of the presiding judge of the circuit court, and the judge and court personnel of the court shall obey his directives. 
(Prior code § 23-7) 
2.68.080 - Report to board of aldermen. 
    The municipal judge shall cause to be prepared within the first ten days of every month a report indicating the following: 
    A list of all cases heard and tried before the court during the preceding month, giving in each case the name of the defendant, the fine imposed if any, the amount of cost, the names of the defendants committed and the cases where there was an application for trial de novo, respectively. The same shall be prepared under oath by the municipal court clerk or the municipal judge. This report will be filed with the city clerk, who shall thereafter forward the same to the board of aldermen of the city for examination of its first session thereafter. The municipal court shall, within the ten days after the first of the month, pay to the municipal treasurer the full amount of all fines collected during the preceding months, if they have not previously been paid. 
(Prior code § 23-8) 
2.68.090 - Docket and court records. 
    The municipal judge shall be a conservator of the peace. He shall keep a docket in which he shall enter every case commenced before him and the proceedings therein and he shall keep such other records as may be required. Such docket and records shall be records of the circuit court of Perry County. The municipal judge shall deliver the docket and records of the municipal court, and all books and papers pertaining to his office, to his successor in office or to the preceding judge of the circuit. 
(Prior code § 23-9) 
2.68.100 - Municipal judge-Powers and duties generally. 
    The municipal judge is authorized to: 
A.  Establish a traffic violations bureau as provided for in the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts and Section 479.050 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri; 
B.  Commute the term of any sentence, stay execution of any fine or sentence, suspend any fine or sentence, and make such other orders as the municipal judge deems necessary relative to any matter that may be pending in the municipal court; 
C.  Make and adopt such rules of practice and procedure as are necessary to implement and carry out the provisions of this chapter, and to make and adopt such rules of practice and procedure as are necessary to hear and decide matters pending before the municipal court and to implement and carry out the provisions of the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts. Any and all rules made or adopted hereunder may be annulled or amended by an ordinance limited to such purpose; provided that such ordinance does not violate, or conflict with, the provisions of the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts, or state statutes; 
D.  The municipal judge shall have power to enforce due obedience to all orders, rules and judgments made by him, or may fine or imprison for contempt offered to him while holding court and as to process issued by him, in the same manner and to the same extent as circuit judges. 
1.  It is declared to be an act of contempt of the municipal court for any person or group of persons to, while the court is in session in a regular or special session, do or accomplish or encourage or aid or abet in the accomplishments of any of the following: 
a.  The use of loud or unusual language or discussion in the courtroom after the person or persons have been warned to cease and refrain from committing acts that they were doing; 
b.  Unruly, unsavory, unseemly or uncooperative conduct, behavior and mannerisms in the courtroom in the presence of the court or public officials of the city, designated to intimidate, harass, heckle or otherwise obstruct, delay, hinder or disrupt court proceedings. 
2.  The punishment for acts committed within the presence of the municipal judge of the city or other public official of the city shall be punished summarily as the judge may deem expedient, in order to punish and otherwise correct bad behavior and set examples for persons who might otherwise be inclined to carry on similar behavior in the future by assessing a fine not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) or by a jail sentence not to exceed ninety (90) days. 
3.  After due notice and hearing thereon, the same punishment shall likewise be had for acts committed without the presence of the municipal judge, including but not limited to failure to obey court orders, process, judgments, summonses or warrants; 
E.  The municipal judge shall have such other powers, duties and privileges as are or may be prescribed by the laws of this state, this code or other ordinances of this city. 
(Ord. 3980 § 1 (part), 2000; prior code § 23-10) 
2.68.110 - Violations bureau. 
    There is established a violations bureau and the city shall provide all expenses incident to the operation of the same. The city clerk or her designate is designated as the violations clerk for the bureau, if established. The city clerk or her designate shall accept the appearance, waiver of trial and plea of guilty and payment of fine and costs in violations bureau cases or as directed by the municipal judge; generally act as violation clerk of the violations bureau. (See Rule 37.49 V.A.M.R.) 
(Ord. 3980 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 23-11) 
2.68.120 - Issuance and execution of warrants. 
    All warrants issued by a municipal judge shall be directed to the city marshal, chief of police, or any other police officer of the municipality or to the sheriff of the county. The warrant shall be executed by the marshall, chief of police, police officer, or sheriff any place within the limits of the county and not elsewhere unless the warrants are endorsed in the manner provided for warrants in criminal cases, and, when so endorsed, shall be served in other counties, as provided for in warrants in criminal cases. 
(Prior code § 23-12) 
2.68.130 - Arrests without warrants. 
    The city marshal, chief of police, or other police officer of the city may, without a warrant, make arrest of any person who commits an offense in his presence. 
(Prior code § 23-13) 
2.68.140 - Jury trials. 
    Any person charged with a violation of a municipal ordinance of this city shall be entitled to a trial by jury, as in prosecutions for misdemeanors before an associate circuit judge. Whenever a defendant accused of a violation of a municipal ordinance demands trial by jury, the municipal court shall certify the case to the presiding judge of the circuit court for reassignment, as provided by Missouri law. 
(Ord. 3658 § 8, 1998: prior code § 23-14) 
2.68.150 - Duties of city's prosecuting attorney. 
    It shall be the duty of an attorney designated by the municipality to prosecute the violations of the city's ordinances before the municipal judge or before any circuit judge hearing violations of the city's ordinances. The salary or fees of the attorney and his necessary expenses incurred in such prosecutions shall be paid by the city. The compensation of such attorney shall not be contingent upon the result in any case. 
(Prior code § 23-15) 
2.68.160 - Prosecutions based on information only-Proceedings. 
    All prosecutions for the violation of municipal ordinances shall be instituted by information and may be based upon a complaint. Proceedings shall be in accordance with the supreme court rules governing practice and procedure in proceedings before municipal judges. 
(Prior code § 23-16) 
2.68.170 - Summoning of witnesses.
