    It shall be the duty of the municipal judge to summon all persons whose testimony may be deemed essential as witnesses at the trial, and to enforce their attendance by attachment, if necessary. The fees of witnesses shall be the same as those fixed for witnesses in trials before associate circuit judges and shall be taxed as other costs in the case. When a trial shall be continued by a municipal judge it shall not be necessary to summon any witnesses who may be present at the continuance; but the municipal, judge shall orally notify such witnesses as either party may require to attend before him on the day set for trial to testify in the case, and enter the names of such witnesses on his docket, which oral notice shall be valid as a summons. 
(Prior code § 23-17) 
2.68.180 - Transfer of complaint to associate circuit judge. 
    If, in the progress of any trial before a municipal judge, it shall appear to the judge that the accused ought to be put upon trial for an offense against the criminal laws of the state and not cognizable before him as municipal judge, he shall immediately stop all further proceedings before him as municipal judge and cause the complaint to be made before some associate circuit judge within the county. 
(Prior code § 23-18) 
2.68.190 - Jailing of defendants. 
    If in the opinion of the municipal judge the city has no suitable and safe place of confinement, the municipal judge may commit the defendant to the county jail, and it shall be the duty of the sheriff, if space for the prisoner is available in the county jail, upon receipt of a warrant of commitment from the judge to receive and safely keep such prisoner until discharged by due process of law. The municipality shall pay the board of such prisoner at the same rate as may now or hereafter be allowed to such sheriff for the keeping of such prisoner in his custody. The same shall be taxed as cost. 
(Prior code § 23-19) 
2.68.200 - Parole and probation. 
    Any judge hearing violations of municipal ordinances may, when in his judgment it may seem advisable, grant a parole or probation to any person who shall plead guilty or who shall be convicted after a trial before such judge. The court is authorized to use circuit approved private probation services to supervise requirements of probation. 
(Ord. 3980 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 23-20) 
2.68.210 - Right of appeal. 
    The defendant shall have a right to a trial de novo, even from a plea of a guilty, before a circuit judge or an associate circuit judge. Such application for a trial de novo shall be filed within ten days after the judgment and shall be in the form as provided by supreme court rules. 
(Prior code § 23-21) 
2.68.220 - Appeal from jury verdicts. 
    In all cases in which a jury trial has been demanded, a record of the proceedings shall be made, and appeals may be had upon that record to the appropriate appellate court. 
(Prior code § 23-22) 
2.68.230 - Breach of recognizance. 
    In the case of a breach of any recognizance entered into before a municipal judge or an associate circuit judge hearing a municipal ordinance violation case, the same shall be deemed forfeited and the judge shall cause the same to be prosecuted against the principal and surety, or either of them, in the name of the municipality as plaintiff. Such action shall be prosecuted before a circuit judge or associate circuit judge, and in the event of cases caused to be prosecuted by a municipal judge, such shall be on the transcript of the proceedings before the municipal judge. All moneys recovered in such actions shall be paid over to the municipal treasury to the general revenue fund of the municipality. 
(Prior code § 23-23) 
2.68.240 - Interest or prejudice of judge-Disqualification from hearing particular case. 
    A municipal judge shall be disqualified to hear any case in which he is in anywise interested, or, if before the trial is commenced, the defendant or the prosecutor files an affidavit that the defendant or the municipality, as the case may be, cannot have a fair and impartial trial by reason of the interest or prejudice of the judge. Neither the defendant nor the municipality shall be entitled to file more than one affidavit or disqualification in the same case. 
(Prior code § 23-24) 
2.68.250 - Temporary municipal judge. 
    If a municipal judge be absent, sick or disqualified from acting, the mayor may designate some competent, eligible person to act as municipal judge until such absence or disqualification shall cease; provided, however, that should a vacancy occur in the office of an elected municipal judge more than six months before a general municipal election, then a special election shall be held to fill such vacancy; and in case of vacancy in the office of an elected municipal judge within less than six months of a general municipal election, the office may be filled by a competent, eligible person designated by the mayor. The board of aldermen shall provide by ordinance for the compensation of any person designated to act as municipal judge under the provisions of this section. 
(Prior code § 23-25) 
2.68.260 - Clerk of municipal court. 
    The city clerk is designated as the clerk of the municipal court. The city clerk may appoint an assistant city clerk to perform the hereinafter set forth duties, provided the city clerk shall be responsible for the performance thereof. The duties of the clerk shall be as follows: 
A.  To collect such fines for violations of such offenses as may be described, and the court costs thereof; 
B.  To take oaths and affirmations; 
C.  To accept signed complaints, and allow the same to be signed and sworn to or affirmed before him; 
D.  Sign and issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of witnesses and sign and issue subpoenas duces tecum; 
E.  Perform all other duties as provided for by ordinance, by rules of practice and procedure adopted by the municipal judge and by the Missouri Rules and Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts and by statute; 
F.  Maintain, properly certified by the city clerk, a complete copy of the ordinances of the city of the municipality which shall constitute prima facie evidence of such ordinances before the court. Further, to maintain a similar certified copy on file with the clerk servicing the circuit court of this county. 
(Prior code § 23-26) 
2.68.265 - Bond. 
    Any person appointed as municipal court clerk or municipal court payment clerk in accordance with Section 2.68.260 of this code shall be covered by a surety bond supplied by the city in the amount and manner as provided in Section 2.08.040 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 5216, § 1, 5-3-11) 
2.68.270 - Court costs. 
A.  In addition to any fine that may be imposed by the municipal judge, there shall be assessed as costs in all cases the following amounts: 
1.  Costs of court in the amount of twelve dollars ($12.00); 
2.  Other costs shall include the following: 
a.  Issuance of warrants: Four dollars ($4.00); 
b.  Witnesses who are served with a subpoena and who actually attend court proceedings: 
i.  For attending court within the county where the witness resides, each day: Three dollars ($3.00), 
ii.  For attending court out of the county where the witness resides, each day: Four dollars ($4.00); 
c.  Out of pocket expenses incurred by the city for extra postal services; 
3.  Actual costs assessed against the city by the county sheriff for apprehension or confinement in the county jail; 
4.  Mileage, in the same amount as provided to the sheriff in criminal violations, for each mile and fraction thereof the officer must travel (both directions) in order to serve any warrant or commitment or order of this court; 
5.  In all cases where there is a plea of guilty, finding of guilt or conviction for violation of the provision of Section 10.12.070 or 10.12.090 of this code, the court may assess an amount in additional costs, up to the maximum amount of fifty dollars ($50.00), to defray the expenses of the city incurred in enforcing these sections. Both the city and the defendant shall have the right to present evidence to the court before the amount of the assessment is determined. 
B.  In accordance with the provisions of Section 479.260, Revised Statutes of Missouri, there is created the judicial education fund. The purpose of this fund is to pay for continuing education and certification required of municipal judges by law or Supreme Court rule, and for education and training for the administrator of the municipal court, and the clerks of municipal court. The judicial education fund shall be funded as follows: In each case where the twelve-dollar ($12.00) costs of court are collected, as provided for in subsection (A)(1) of this section, one dollar ($1.00) of that amount shall be retained by the court in the judicial education fund. This fund shall be administered by the municipal court, and the balance in this fund shall not exceed one thousand five hundred dollars ($1,500.00) for each court employee (judges, administrators and clerks). Any balance exceeding the maximum amount herein specified shall be turned over to the municipal general revenue fund. Disbursements from the judicial education fund shall only be made upon order of the municipal court, upon application by an eligible participant setting forth the amount of the disbursement, the payee and the purpose for such disbursement. 
(Ord. 3538 § 1, 1997: prior code § 23-27) 
(Ord. No. 5447, § 1, 8-6-13) 
2.68.280 - Additional court costs and surcharges. 
    In addition to any fine that may be imposed by the municipal judge and costs set forth in Section 2.68.270 hereof, there shall be additional court costs assessed in the following amounts and for the offenses and circumstances as set forth hereinafter: 
A.  Training of Law Enforcement Officers. 
1.  The municipal judge shall assess as court costs the sum of three dollars for each violation of the ordinances of the city, provided that no such fee shall be collected in any proceeding when the proceeding or the defendant has been dismissed by the court, or when the defendant is found to be indigent. 
2.  Two dollars of such fee collected shall be transmitted monthly to the treasurer of the city, to be used locally for training law enforcement officers. One dollar of such fee collected shall be deposited in the peace officer standards and training commission fund, to be used state wide for training law enforcement officers. The checks transmitting such funds shall be made payable by the clerk to the "Treasurer, State of Missouri," and shall be mailed on or before the fifteenth day of each month to Budget Director, Department of Public Safety, P.O. Box 749, Jefferson City, Missouri, 65102. 
B.  Crime Victims Compensation Fund. 
1.  In all cases in which the proceeding or the defendant has been dismissed by the court, or when costs are to be paid by the city on behalf of an indigent defendant, an additional amount of seven dollars and fifty ($7.50) cents surcharge shall be assessed for the crime victims compensation fund. 
C.  Motorcycle Safety Trust Fund. 
1.  There shall be additional court costs assessed for any person who violates a municipal ordinance as an operator of a motorcycle or motor-tricycle in the amount of five dollars ($5.00). 
2.  There shall be additional court costs in the amount of five dollars ($5.00) assessed on any motor vehicle operator who violates a municipal ordinance where a violation involves a motorcycle or motor-tricycle or whether the operator causes an accident involving a motorcycle or motor-tricycle. 
3.  Court costs assessed under this subsection shall be doubled if the operator at fault violated any local ordinance relating to consumption of alcohol. 
4.  Court costs under this subsection by the municipal court clerk shall be paid into the State Treasury to the credit of the motorcycle safety trust fund created by Section 302.137 RSMo. 1994. 
D.  Domestic Violence Shelter Fund. 
1.  In all cases an amount of four dollars ($4.00) additional court costs shall be assessed for purposes of the domestic violence shelter fund (Section 488.607 RSMo). 
2.  The court shall not assess the costs specified in this subsection in any case when the proceeding has been dismissed by the city or when costs are paid by the city on behalf of an indigent defendant. 
3.  Costs collected for the aforesaid fund shall be collected by the clerk and disbursed to the county clerk at least monthly. 
E.  Spinal Cord Injury Fund. 
1.  There shall be additional court costs assessed for any person convicted of an intoxication-related offense under Section 10.12.090 of this code in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) (Section 304.027 RSMo.) 
2.  The court shall not assess the costs specified in this subsection in any case when the proceeding has been dismissed by the city or when costs are paid by the city on behalf of an indigent defendant. 
3.  Costs collected under this section shall be remitted to Missouri Department of Revenue, County Tax Section, Spinal Cord Injury Fund, P.O. Box 453, Jefferson City, Missouri 65105-0453. 
F.  Inmate Security Fund. 
1.  In all cases an amount of two dollars ($2.00) additional court costs shall be assessed for purposes of the inmate security fund (Section 488.5026, RSMo). 
2.  The court shall not assess the costs specified in this subsection in any case when the proceeding has been dismissed by the city or when costs are paid by the city on behalf of an indigent defendant. 
3.  The city treasurer shall deposit funds generated into the "Inmate Security Fund." Funds deposited shall be utilized to develop biometric verification systems to ensure that inmates can be properly identified and tracked within the local jail system. Upon the installation of the biometric verification system, funds in the inmate security fund may be used for the maintenance of the biometric verification system and to pay for any expenses related to custody and housing and other expenses for prisoners. 
G.  Sheriffs' Retirement Fund. 
1.  In all cases an amount of three dollars ($3.00) additional court costs shall be assessed for purposes of the sheriffs' retirement fund (Section 57.955.1, RSMo). 
2.  The court shall not assess the costs specified in this subsection in any case when the proceeding has been dismissed by the city or when costs are paid by the city on behalf of an indigent defendant. 
3.  The city treasurer shall deposit the funds generated into the sheriffs' retirement fund. Funds shall be used only for the purposes provided in Sections 57.949-57.997, RSMo, and for no other purpose. 
(Ord. 4879 § 1, 2007; Ord. 4203 § 1, 2001: Ord. 3977 § 4 (part), 2000; Ord. 3943 § 1, 1999; Ord. 3532 §§ 1, 2, 1997; prior code § 23-28) 
(Ord. No. 5597, § 1, 12-16-14; Ord. No. 5766, § 1, 6-7-16) 
2.68.290 - Assessment against prosecuting witness. 
    The costs of any action may be assessed against the prosecuting witness and judgment be rendered against him that he pay the same and stand committed until paid in any case where it appears to the satisfaction of the municipal judge that the prosecution was commenced without probable cause and from malicious motives. 
(Prior code § 23-29) 
2.68.300 - Installment payment of fines. 
    When a fine is assessed for violating an ordinance, it should be within the discretion of the judge assessing the fine to provide for the payment of a fine on an installment basis under such terms and conditions as he may deem appropriate. 
(Prior code § 23-30) 
2.68.310 - Committal to jail-Working out fine. 
    It shall be a part of the judgment permitted by this chapter that the defendant stand committed to jail until the judgment is complied with; provided, that any person so committed may be allowed to labor upon the streets, alleys or roads of the city, or at such other labor as the board of aldermen may provide in such manner and under such rules and regulations as they may prescribe, until the whole amount of such fine, penalty and costs is worked out as provided in this chapter. For a refusal to work when so commanded, such prisoner may be punished in such manner as this code or the board of aldermen may by ordinance prescribe; provided, that such punishment shall not be cruel or excessive. 
(Prior code § 23-31) 
2.68.320 - Failure to pay fines. 
    When any person has been fined for the violation of this code or any ordinance of this city and shall fail or refuse to pay the fine and all costs, such person shall be imprisoned in the county jail or in a jail of this city or any suitable jail or place of confinement for a period of not more than ninety (90) days or may be required to work at such labor as the municipal court may provide in such manner and under such rules and regulations it may prescribe under the direction of a person, firm or corporation appointed and approved by the court at the rate prescribed by the court until the fine and all costs have been paid, including board of the prisoner until the date of discharge. 
(Ord. 3980 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 23-32) 
2.68.330 - Discharge of defendant. 
    Any defendant committed under the provisions of Section 2.68.320 may be discharged upon the payment of the fine and costs, or upon perfecting his appeal as provided in the ordinances of the city or other applicable statutes or laws. 
(Prior code § 23-33) 
2.68.340 - Officers authorized to have prisoners perform work. 
    The municipal judge shall have power and be authorized and required to have all prisoners work out the full number of days for which they have been sentenced at a job as directed by the municipal court under the supervision of a person, firm or corporation ordered by the court. 
(Ord. 3980 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 23-34) 
2.68.350 - Failure to appear. 
    Any person who has been: 
A.  Ordered, either orally or in writing, or who has received written notice of an order by the judge or court clerk of the municipal court to appear in court on a date certain; or 
B.  Personally served with a summons duly issued by the municipal court directing such person to appear in court on a date certain; or 
C.  Served with a uniform complaint and summons by a police officer of the city directing such person to appear in the municipal court on a date certain. 
and who shall fail to appear in person in the municipal court on the date certain as referred to hereinabove shall be guilty of failure to appear and shall be subject to punishment as provided in this code under Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 23-35) 
Chapter 2.72 - PLANNING COMMISSION AND ZONING COMMISSION 
Sections: 

2.72.010 - Established. 
    There is established by the city a planning commission and a zoning commission. 
(Prior code § 2-255) 
2.72.020 - Composition. 
A.  Planning Commission. The planning commission shall consist of ten members, including the mayor, a member of the board of aldermen selected by the board annually at its first organizational meeting, the city engineer or similar city official, and seven citizens appointed by the mayor and approved by the board. 
B.  Zoning Commission. The zoning commission shall consist of the planning commission as set forth hereinabove; provided, however, the zoning commission shall in addition be composed of up to three alternate members to be appointed in the same manner as citizen planning commission members. The alternate citizen members of the zoning commission shall serve for a four-year term, except that the terms of the alternates first appointed shall be for varying periods so that succeeding terms will be staggered. The alternate members shall serve in the absence or disqualification of any of the regular zoning commission members at any regular or special zoning commission meeting. Alternates may be removed as provided in Section 2.72.080. 
C.  Designation. The planning commission and the zoning commission shall be collectively known as the planning and zoning commission. 
(Prior code § 2-256; Ord. No. 6108 , § 1, 1-8-19) 
2.72.025 - Employees not to serve on planning commission or zoning commission. 
    No person who is a non-elected full-time or part-time employee of the city shall be appointed to or serve on the planning commission or the zoning commission. 
(Ord. No. 6054 , § 1, 7-3-18) 
2.72.030 - Term of citizen members. 
    The term of each citizen member of the planning commission shall be for four years, except that the terms of the citizen members first appointed shall be for varying periods, so that the succeeding terms will be staggered. 
(Prior code § 2-257) 
2.72.040 - Compensation of citizen members. 
    All citizen members of the planning commission shall serve without compensation. 
(Prior code § 2-258) 
2.72.050 - Election of chairman and secretary. 
    The planning commission shall elect a chairman and secretary from among the citizen members thereof. 
(Prior code § 2-259) 
2.72.060 - Term of chairman and secretary. 
    The term of the chairman and secretary of the planning commission shall be for one year, with eligibility for reelection. 
(Prior code § 2-260) 
2.72.070 - Vacancies in citizen membership. 
    Any vacancy in a citizen membership of the planning commission shall be filled for the unexpired term by appointment by the mayor with the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-261) 
2.72.080 - Removal of citizen members. 
    The board of aldermen may remove any citizen member of the planning commission for cause, stated in writing, after a public hearing thereon. 
(Prior code § 2-262) 
2.72.090 - General authority. 
    The planning commission shall have the authority necessary to enable it to perform its functions and promote municipal planning. 
(Prior code § 2-263) 
2.72.100 - Functions generally. 
    The planning commission shall perform all of the functions of a planning commission and a zoning commission, as provided for in Chapter 89 of the Revised Statutes of the state of Missouri. 
(Prior code § 2-264) 
2.72.110 - Meetings. 
    The planning commission shall hold regular and special meetings as it provides by rule. A quorum of the planning commission shall consist of four members. 
(Prior code § 2-265; Ord. No. 6108 , § 2, 1-8-19) 
2.72.120 - Rules and records. 
    The planning commission shall have the authority to adopt rules for the transaction of business and shall keep records of its proceedings, which records shall be available for public inspection. 
(Prior code § 2-266) 
2.72.130 - Appointment of staff- Contracting for services. 
    The planning commission shall, subject to the limitations prescribed in this chapter, appoint the employees and staff necessary for its work and may contract with city planners and other professional persons for the services that it requires. 
(Prior code § 2-267) 
2.72.140 - Expenditures. 
    The expenditures of the planning commission, exclusive of grants and gifts, shall be within the amount appropriated for such purpose by the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 2-268) 
2.72.150 - Furnishing of information by public officials. 
    All public officials shall, upon request of the planning commission, furnish it within a reasonable time all available information it requires for its work. 
(Prior code § 2-269) 
2.72.160 - Right of entry. 
    The members and employees of the planning commission, in the performance of the functions of the planning commission, may enter upon any land to make examinations and surveys. 
(Prior code § 2-270) 
2.72.170 - Commission to make and adopt city plan. 
    The planning commission shall make and adopt a city plan for the physical development of the city, which plan, with the accompanying maps, plats, charts and descriptive and explanatory matter, shall show the planning commission's recommendations for the physical development and uses of land, and may include, among other things: 
A.  The general location, character and extent of streets and other public ways, grounds, places and spaces; 
B.  The general location and extent of public utilities and terminals, whether publicly or privately owned; 
C.  The acceptance, widening, removal, extension, relocation, narrowing, vacation, abandonment or change of use of any of the foregoing; 
D.  The general character, extent and layout of the replanning of blighted districts and slum areas. 
(Prior code § 2-271) 
2.72.180 - Preparation of city plan- Purpose. 
    In the preparation of a city plan, the planning commission shall make careful and comprehensive surveys and studies of the existing conditions and probable future growth of the city. Such plan shall be made with the purpose of guiding and accomplishing a coordinated development of the city which will, in accordance with existing and future needs, best promote the general welfare, as well as efficiency and economy in the process of development. 
(Prior code § 2-272) 
2.72.190 - Preparation of zoning plan. 
    The planning commission shall prepare a zoning plan for the regulation of the height, area, bulk, location and use of private, nonprofit and public structures and premises, and of population density. 
(Prior code § 2-273) 
2.72.200 - Procedure for adoption of city plan. 
    The planning commission may adopt a city plan as a whole by a single resolution or, as the work of making the city plan progresses, may from time to time adopt a part thereof, any such part to correspond generally with one or more of the functional subdivisions of the subject matter of the plan. Before the adoption, amendment or extension of the plan or portion thereof, the planning commission shall hold at least one public hearing thereon. Fifteen (15) days' notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be published in at least one newspaper having general circulation within the city. Such hearing may be adjourned from time to time. The adoption of the plan requires a majority vote of the full membership of the planning commission. The resolution shall refer expressly to the maps, descriptive matter and other matters intended by the planning commission to form the whole or part of the plan and the action taken shall be recorded on the adopted city plan, or part thereof, by the identifying signature of the secretary of the planning commission and filed in the office of the planning commission, identified properly by file number. A copy of the plan, or part thereof, shall be certified to the board of aldermen and the city clerk, and a copy thereof shall be recorded in the office of the county recorder of deeds and shall be available at the city clerk's office for public inspection during normal office hours. 
(Ord. 3658 § 9, 1998: prior code § 2-274) 
2.72.210 - Approval of improvements by commission-Overruling disapproval. 
    Whenever the planning commission adopts the plan of the city, or any part thereof, no street or other public facilities, nor public utility, whether publicly or privately owned, the location, extent and character thereof having been included in the recommendations and proposals of the plan, or portions thereof, shall be constructed or authorized in the city until the location, extent and character thereof has been submitted to and approved by the planning commission. In case of disapproval, the planning commission shall communicate its reasons to the board of aldermen and the board, by vote of not less than two-thirds of its entire membership, may overrule the disapproval and, upon the overruling, the board of aldermen or the appropriate board or officer may proceed, except that if the public facility or utility is one the authorization or financing of which does not fall within the province of the board of aldermen, then the submission to the planning commission shall be by the board having jurisdiction, and the planning commission's disapproval may be overruled by that board by a vote of not less than two-thirds of its entire membership. The acceptance, widening, removal, extension, relocation, narrowing, vacation, abandonment, change of use, acquisition of land for, sale or lease of any street or other public facility is subject to similar submission and approval, and the failure to approve may be similarly overruled. The failure of the planning commission to act within sixty (60) days after the date of official submission to it shall be deemed approval. 
(Prior code § 2-275) 
2.72.220 - Prerequisites to making public improvements. 
    Upon adoption of a major street plan and subdivision regulations, the city shall not accept, lay out, open, improve, grade, pave or light any street, lay or authorize the laying of water mains, sewers, connections or other utilities in any street within the city unless the street has received the legal status of a public street prior to the adoption of a city plan; or unless the street corresponds in its location and lines with a street shown on a subdivision plat approved by the board of aldermen or the planning commission or on a street plan made by and adopted by the planning commission. The board of aldermen may locate and construct or may accept any other street if the ordinance or other measure for the location and construction or for the acceptance is first submitted to the planning commission for its approval, and approved by the planning commission or, if disapproved by the planning commission, is passed by the affirmative vote of not less than two-thirds of the entire membership of the board. 
(Prior code § 2-281) 
2.72.230 - Prerequisites for issuance of building permit or erection of building. 
    After the adoption of a major street plan, no building permit shall be issued for and no building shall be erected on any lot within the territorial jurisdiction of the planning commission unless the street giving access to the lot upon which the building is proposed to be placed conforms to the requirements of Section 2.72.220. 
(Prior code § 2-282) 
2.72.240 - Building lines. 
    Whenever a plan for major streets has been adopted, the board of aldermen, upon recommendation of the planning commission, is authorized and empowered to establish, regulate, limit and amend, by ordinance, building or setback lines on major streets, and to prohibit any new building being located within the building or setback lines. When a plan for proposed major streets or other public improvements has been adopted, the board of aldermen may prohibit any new building being located within the proposed site or right-of-way when the center line of the proposed street or the limits of the proposed sites have been carefully determined and are accurately delineated on maps approved by the planning commission and adopted by the board. 
(Prior code § 2-283) 
Chapter 2.76 - PARK AND RECREATION BOARD 
Sections: 

2.76.010 - Created-Composition- Appointment and qualifications of members. 
    Under authority of Sections 67.750 through 67.780, Revised Statutes of the State of Missouri, 1969, there is created a park and recreation board in the city, the members of which shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the board of aldermen. The park and recreation board shall consist of seven members. Members appointed to the park and recreation board must be citizens and shall have been residents of the city for at least two years immediately prior to their appointment. No member of the municipal government shall be a member of the park and recreation board. 
(Prior code § 21-1) 
2.76.015 - Employees not to serve on park and recreation board. 
    No person who is a non-elected full-time or part-time employee of the city shall be appointed to or serve on the park and recreation board. 
(Ord. No. 6054 , § 2, 7-3-18) 
2.76.020 - Terms of members-Removal- Filling of vacancies- Compensation. 
A.  Members of the park and recreation board shall hold their respective office from the first of July following their appointment. They shall be appointed for a term of five years, or until their successors are appointed and qualified, except that members first appointed shall be appointed for such terms that the terms of not more than two of the members shall expire annually thereafter. Those appointed at the first meeting shall cast lots for their respective terms; one member to serve five years, two members to serve four years, two members to serve three years, and two members to serve two years. All initial terms of office shall be retroactive to June 1, 1977. Annually and thereafter, on or before the first meeting in June, the mayor shall, by and with the approval of the board of aldermen, appoint members to fill expired terms on the park and recreation board and the so appointed members shall hold office for five years. 
B.  The mayor may, by and with the consent of the board of aldermen, remove any member of the park and recreation board for misconduct or neglect of duty. 
C.  Vacancies occasioned by removal, resignation or otherwise, shall be reported to the board of aldermen, and shall be filled in like manner as original appointments, except that the term of office is restricted to the unexpired term of office. All members of the park and recreation board shall serve without pay or other compensation. 
(Prior code § 21-2) 
2.76.030 - Election of officers-Rules, regulations and bylaws. 
    The park and recreation board shall, within fifteen (15) days of the appointment of members, meet and organize by the election of one member as president, a vice-president, secretary and treasurer. Officers shall serve one-year renewable terms. The parks and recreation director and staff shall serve this body by providing necessary staff support and clerical functions. Subject to the approval of the board of aldermen, the park and recreation board shall make and adopt bylaws, rules and regulations for the conduct, administration and management of the city park and recreation system not inconsistent with this chapter and with Sections 67.750 through 67.780 of the Revised Statutes of the state of Missouri. 
(Prior code § 21-3) 
(Ord. No. 5150, § 1, 9-21-10) 
2.76.040 - Duties and responsibilities. 
A.  The park and recreation board, in general, shall assist the board of aldermen to carry out the spirit and intent of Sections 67.750 through 67.780 of the Revised Statutes of the state of Missouri in establishing and maintaining public parks. 
B.  The park and recreation board shall meet regularly, as determined by the president of the board, but no less than quarterly. 
C.  The park and recreation board shall have the general authority to advise the park and recreation director, the board of aldermen and the general public on all matters pertaining to the supervision, improvement, care, acquisition and custody of the parks. 
D.  The park and recreation board shall survey and propose plans for the development and maintenance of facilities and activities for a quality municipal park system. 
E.  The board of aldermen may request the park and recreation board participate in the selection of a suitable person to administer the parks and make recommendations for necessary assistants. With just cause the park and recreation board may request personnel action be taken against said staff. The board of aldermen shall have the power to remove such appointees for misconduct or neglect of duty. 
(Prior code § 21-4) 
(Ord. No. 5150, § 2, 9-21-10) 
2.76.050 - Annual reports. 
    The president of the park and recreation board shall present to the board of aldermen an annual report. Such report shall be presented at the first meeting of the board of aldermen in November of each year and shall consist of: 
A.  Statistics, information and details of operation the park and recreation board may deem to be of general interest. 
B.  Recommendations for improving the park and recreation program and facilities. 
C.  Recommendations and suggestions for the park and recreation budget for the coming year. 
D.  Recommendations for longer term capital improvements. 
(Prior code § 21-5) 
(Ord. No. 5150, § 3, 9-21-10) 
2.76.060 - Private donations. 
    The park and recreation board is encouraged to make plans for the benefit of the community's park and recreation programs and facilities. After a plan has been approved by the board of aldermen, the park and recreation board may solicit or seek private donations for the project. The park and recreation board shall determine the appropriate use of said donation. Substantial expenditures or permanent improvements that exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) shall require the specific approval of the board of aldermen. An accurate accounting of any donations received or expended shall be maintained by the city treasurer's office. 
(Prior code § 21-6) 
(Ord. No. 5150, § 4, 9-21-10) 
Chapter 2.78 - AIRPORT BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5744, § 1, adopted April 19, 2016, amended Chapter 2.78 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Chapter 2.78, §§ 2.78.010-2.78.050, pertained to the airport advisory board, and derived from Ord. No. 5353, adopted August 21, 2012 and Ord. No. 5376, adopted October 2, 2012. 

2.78.010 - Created-Composition-Appointment and qualification of members. 
A.  There is hereby created an airport board in the city, the members of which shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the board of aldermen. 
B.  The airport board shall consist of no less than five members and no more than nine members. Members appointed to the airport board must be United States citizens. Preference for appointment to the airport board shall be given first to city residents, second to residents of Perry County, Missouri, and third to residents of Ste. Genevieve County, Missouri, Cape Girardeau County, Missouri, or Randolph County, Illinois, if, in the judgment of the mayor and board of aldermen, their knowledge of airport facilities is beneficial to the city. 
C.  One member of the airport board shall be a member of the board of aldermen, and no less than three members shall be individuals who have had experience or knowledge of aviation or economic development. The executive director of the Perry County Economic Development Authority and the city administrator, or his designee, shall serve as ex-officio, nonvoting members and assist the airport board members in all areas of responsibility. Business tenants of the airport shall be invited to attend the public portion of airport board meetings as ex-officio members. 
(Ord. No. 5744, § 1, 4-19-16; Ord. No. 5816, § 1, 11-1-16; Ord. No. 6050 , § 1, 6-19-18) 
2.78.015 - Employees not to serve on airport board. 
    No person who is a non-elected full-time or part-time employee of the city shall be appointed to or serve on the airport board. 
(Ord. No. 6054 , § 3, 7-3-18) 
2.78.020 - Terms of members-Removal-Filling of vacancies-Compensation. 
A.  Members of the airport board shall hold their respective office beginning the first of July following their appointment. They shall be appointed for a term of three years, or until their successors are appointed and qualified, except that the terms of members first appointed shall be staggered so that not more than two of the members shall expire in a given year. Members of the airport board shall be eligible to succeed themselves. 
B.  The mayor may, by and with the consent of the board of aldermen, remove any member of the airport board for misconduct or neglect of duty. 
C.  Vacancies occasioned by removal, resignation, or otherwise shall be reported to the board of aldermen and shall be filled in like manner as original appointments, except that the term of office is restricted to the unexpired term of office. 
D.  All members of the airport board shall serve without pay or other compensation. 
(Ord. No. 5744, § 1, 4-19-16) 
2.78.030 - Election of officers. 
    The airport board shall, within thirty (30) days of the appointment of members, meet and organize by the election of one voting member as chairman, one voting member as secretary, and such other voting members as officers as the board may determine necessary. The officers of the board shall perform those functions normally performed by persons in the specified offices, and such other duties as the board may assign from time to time. If an officer shall die, resign or be removed by the board of aldermen, or if an officer shall resign his office but remain a member of the board, the board shall elect a successor at its first regular or special meeting after the vacancy shall occur. 
(Ord. No. 5744, § 1, 4-19-16) 
2.78.040 - Meetings. 
    The chairman shall preside at all meetings. The secretary shall keep the minutes and records thereof and duly transmit same to the board of aldermen for their review. The board shall, by resolution, set a date, time, and place for regular meetings and no notice of a regular meeting need be given to the members. Regular meetings shall be scheduled to occur no less than quarterly. A special meeting of the board may be called by the chairman, any three voting members of the board, or upon the resolution of the board of aldermen. Notice of a special meeting shall state the purpose or purposes for which the meeting is called and shall be mailed by ordinary mail at least three days before the meeting or delivered electronically at least twenty-four (24) hours prior to the date of the meeting to each of the board members. 
(Ord. No. 5744, § 1, 4-19-16) 
2.78.050 - Advisory duties generally. 
    The airport board shall serve in an advisory capacity to the board of aldermen in addition to its financial and managerial duties. The airport board shall be responsible for making recommendations to the mayor, board of aldermen, and the city administrator relating to the management, control, and operation of the Perryville Municipal Airport, hereafter referred to as K02. This may include, by way of example but not of limitation: 
A.  Recommendations regarding priorities for annual entitlement grant funding; 
B.  Recommendations relative to fixed base operators and to the terms of a fixed base operation agreement; 
C.  Recommendations on policies, procedures, and/or regulations for the approval of other persons or firms authorized to conduct businesses from K02; 
D.  Recommendations as to the approval or denial of applications of other persons or firms seeking approval to conduct business at K02; 
E.  Recommendations relating to the terms, provisions, conditions, and/or contracts with those providing or proposing to provide aviation services of any type at K02; 
F.  Recommendations relative to services that should be considered for addition and for contracts with a fixed base operator or by a person or firm that proposes to be authorized to conduct such additional services; 
G.  To consider and make recommendations relative to the reasonableness and necessity of costs of operations, of facilities, or other aspects of the operations of K02; and 
H.  In general, to act as an advisory board with special knowledge and expertise to maximize the financial feasibility, economic development, safety, growth, and services provided or proposed to be provided at K02. 
(Ord. No. 5744, § 1, 4-19-16) 
2.78.060 - Financial and management duties generally. 
A.  Any income deriving to the airport, including, but not limited to, farm rental payments, fuel farm sales, hangar rental, and other airport income shall be maintained in a separate city account similar to accounts maintained for natural gas and transportation. 
B.  The airport board shall recommend to the city a yearly budget utilizing the airport funds. Said yearly budget shall be approved in the same manner at the same time as the general city budget. 
C.  The airport board shall operate all aspects of the airport under and in accordance with said budget and may seek amendments to the budget by submitting said amendments to the board of aldermen. The airport board shall not maintain its own checking or bank account. All checking and banking transactions shall be maintained by the city treasurer in the same manner as are maintained for other funds of the city and checks shall be written in the same manner. 
D.  Expenditures of the airport board shall be reviewed monthly in the same manner as the finance committee of the board of aldermen reviews the monthly bills of the city. All contracts with the airport may be negotiated and approved preliminarily by the airport board, but transactions outside of the authorization of the approved airport budget shall be approved by the mayor and board of aldermen in the same manner as other contracts with the city. 
(Ord. No. 5744, § 1, 4-19-16) 
2.78.070 - Accountability to board of aldermen. 
    The airport board shall make all reports necessary to the city administrator and board of aldermen as may be necessary for formulating the annual airport budget at the same time as the city budget is prepared. In addition, the chairman of the airport board or his designee shall submit a report in writing and in person to the board of aldermen at the first July meeting of the board of aldermen or as soon thereafter as is reasonably possible. 
(Ord. No. 5744, § 1, 4-19-16) 
Chapter 2.80 - CIVIL DEFENSE 
Sections: 

2.80.010 - Organization created-Purpose. 
    There is created a local municipal civil defense organization to minimize and repair injury and damage resulting from disasters caused by enemy attack. 
(Prior code § 9-1) 
2.80.020 - Composition of organization. 
    The local municipal civil defense organization shall consist of a director and other additional members to be selected by the coordinator in the state survival plan and program. 
(Prior code § 9-2) 
2.80.030 - Appointment of Coordinator- Term. 
    The coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization shall be appointed by the mayor and shall serve until removed by the mayor. 
(Prior code § 9-3) 
2.80.040 - General authority of coordinator. 
A.  The coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization shall have direct responsibility for the organization, administration and operation of such organization subject to the direction and control of the mayor. 
B.  The coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization shall have the authority to appoint, without compensation, or remove any member of such organization.eol; 
(Prior code § 9-4) 
2.80.050 - General authority of organization. 
    The local municipal civil defense organization shall be responsible for the performance of civil defense functions within the territorial limits of the city and may conduct such functions outside of the limits as may be required pursuant to state law. 
(Prior code § 9-5) 
2.80.060 - Oath. 
    Every person appointed to serve in any capacity in the local municipal civil defense organization shall, before entering upon his duties, subscribe to the following oath, which shall be filed with the coordinator: 
I,___________, do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support and defend and bear true faith and allegiance to the Constitution of the United States and the Constitution of the State of Missouri, and the territory, institutions and facilities thereof, both public and private, against all enemies, foreign and domestic; that I take this obligation freely, without any mental reservations or purpose of evasion; and that I will well and faithfully discharge the duties upon which I am about to enter. And I do further swear (or affirm) that I do not advocate, nor am I, nor have I been, a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the Government of the United States or this state by force or violence; and that during such time as I am affiliated with the local municipal civil defense organization, I will not advocate nor become a member of any political party or organization that advocates the overthrow of the Government of the United States or of this state by force or violence. 
(Prior code § 9-6) 
2.80.070 - Mobile support teams. 
A.  The coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization shall form mobile support teams as authorized by Section 44.080 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1969, and the state survival plan and program, and shall designate the leaders thereof. 
B.  Any member of a mobile support team who is a city employee or officer shall receive the compensation and have the powers, duties, rights and immunities incident to such employment or office while serving on call to duty by the governor or adjutant general of this state.eol; 
(Prior code § 9-7) 
2.80.080 - Mutual aid agreements. 
A.  The mayor, with the approval of the governor of this state, may enter into mutual aid agreements or arrangements with other public and private agencies within and without the state for reciprocal civil defense aid. Such arrangements or agreements shall be consistent with the state disaster plan and program. In time of emergency, it shall be the duty of the local municipal civil defense organization to render assistance in accordance with the provisions of such mutual aid arrangements or agreements. 
B.  The coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization may assist in the negotiation for reciprocal mutual aid agreements between said organization and other public and private agencies and between the governor of this state and the adjoining states or political subdivisions thereof, and shall carry out arrangements or agreements relating to the local unit. 
(Prior code § 9-8) 
2.80.090 - Cooperation between state and city in emergency. 
    In carrying out the emergency powers under the provisions of Chapter 44 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1969, the governor of this state and the mayor or board of aldermen are directed to utilize the services, equipment, supplies and facilities of existing departments, offices and agencies of the state and political subdivisions thereof to the maximum extent practicable, and the officers and personnel of all such departments, offices and agencies are directed to cooperate with and extend such services and facilities to the governor and to the disaster organizations of this state upon request. 
(Prior code § 9-9) 
2.80.100 - Acceptance of federal gifts and loans. 
    Whenever the federal government or any officer or agency thereof shall offer to the city, through the state, services, equipment, supplies, material or funds by way of gift, grant or loan, for the purpose of civil defense, the city, through the mayor and the governor of this state, may accept such offer and receive such services, equipment, supplies, materials or funds on behalf of the city subject to the terms of the offer. 
(Prior code § 9-10) 
2.80.110 - Procurement of services, supplies or equipment during emergency. 
    In the event of an emergency, as defined by Section 44.010(4) of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1969, the coordinator of the local municipal civil defense organization is authorized on behalf of the city to procure services, supplies, equipment or material as may be necessary for such purposes, in view of the exigency, without regard to the statutory procedures or formalities normally prescribed by law pertaining to municipal contracts or obligations; provided, however, that if the board of aldermen meets at such time, the coordinator shall act subject to the directions and restrictions imposed by the board. 
(Prior code § 9-11) 
2.80.120 - Contract bids to be waived when. 
    In the event of enemy attack, the mayor may waive the provisions of statutes requiring advertisement for bids for the performance of public work or entering into contracts. 
(Prior code § 9-12) 
2.80.130 - Office space. 
    The mayor or board of aldermen is authorized to designate space in any municipally owned or leased building for the local municipal civil defense organization as its office. 
(Prior code § 9-13) 
Chapter 2.84 - MISCELLANEOUS ADMINISTRATIVE REGULATIONS 
Sections: 

2.84.010 - Public policy on open meetings. 
A.  The city adopts Sections 610.010 through 610.028 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1978, as amended, as the official governmental policy of this city, subject to the requirements of Section 610.028 of RSMo., 1978, as amended. 
B.  In accordance with Section 610.023 of RSMo., as amended, the city clerk is appointed as the official custodian of the governmental records of this municipality. 
C.  Complying with the provisions of the above-cited state statute, the city clerk is given discretion as to procedural implementation of the directives of such statute. 
(Prior code § 1-11) 
2.84.020 - City library merged with county library district. 
    The municipal tax-supported library of the city shall be merged and become a part of the county library district. 
(Prior code § 2-8) 
Chapter 2.88 - PERSONNEL RULES AND REGULATIONS 
Article 1. - Basic Objectives 

2.88.100 - Basic objectives. 
    The purpose of these policies is to provide a uniform set of rules governing city/employee relations with all the benefits such a program insures. The fundamental objectives of good personnel administration sought to be achieved by these policies include: 
A.  To promote and increase efficiency and economy in the service of the city; 
B.  To provide fair and equal employment opportunities to all qualified applicants to enter and advance in city employment on the basis of demonstrated merit and fitness as ascertained through fair and practical methods of selection and promotion without regard to gender, race, color, creed, handicap, or national origin; 
C.  To develop a program of recruitment, advancement and tenure which will make the service of the city attractive as a career and encourage each employee to render their best services to the city; 
D.  To establish and maintain a uniform plan of evaluation and pay based upon the relative duties and responsibilities of position in the service of the city; 
E.  To promote high morale among city employees by providing good working relationships, uniform personnel policies, opportunity for advancement and consideration for employee welfare. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.105 - Applicability. 
    These policies shall apply to all employees in the service of the city. These policies shall not apply to elected officials in that elected officials are governed by Section 2.08.105 of this code. Individual departments may establish internal rules and regulations not governed by this manual with the approval of the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5479, § 1, 12-3-13) 
2.88.110 - Affirmative action policy. 
    It is the city's policy to take affirmative action to insure that applicants are employed, and that employees are treated during employment without regard to their race, color, religion, gender, handicap, veteran status, or national origin. Such action shall include, but not be limited to, the following: employment, upgrading, demotion or transfer; recruitment and advertising; layoff or termination; rates of pay or other forms of compensation; selection for training, including apprenticeships; and participation in recreational and educational activities. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.115 - Americans with disabilities. 
    It is the city's policy to avoid discrimination against a qualified individual with a disability because of the disability of the individual in regard to job application procedure, the hiring, advancement or discharge of employees, employee compensation, job training and other terms, conditions and privileges of employment. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.120 - Harassment policy and procedure. 
    The city will not tolerate the harassment of any of its employees and will take immediate, positive steps to stop it when it occurs. 
    Any employee who feels he or she is being subjected to harassment shall immediately contact their immediate supervisor, or the next level supervisor if their immediate supervisor is not appropriate. Complaints may be made orally or in writing. The city will immediately conduct an investigation into the allegations of harassment and take corrective action if warranted. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.125 - Personnel records. 
    Personnel history records of each employee are available for inspection by the employee and his supervisory officials. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.126 - Reference policy on current or former employees. 
    In order to promote fair and equal consideration, protect privacy, and prevent legal liabilities, the city hereby establishes the following personnel policy on reference requests. It is the policy and practice of the city to provide all prospective employers with references or recommendations per authorized requests. All requests must be directed to the personnel clerk. At no time is any supervisor, superintendent, or department head (referred to as 'supervisor') authorized to give references or recommendations without the consent of the personnel clerk or city administrator. 
    Unauthorized references or recommendations may result in disciplinary action. Supervisors can provide a personal reference for employees not under their supervision. Personal references cannot be written on city letterhead or through city e-mail. Supervisors assume all legal liabilities when a personal or unauthorized reference or recommendation is given. 
    The city will release employment information pertaining to: Name of employee, dates of employment, position(s) held, and rate of pay. All references and recommendations will contain the information listed above. All other information related to performance, re-hire status, or other specific employment information of current or past employees will require a written request from the prospective employer and signed by the current or former employee. A copy of any written response or completed form will be placed in the referenced employee's personnel file. 
(Ord. No. 5372, § 1, 9-20-12) 
2.88.130 - Personnel policy publication. 
    Within ten days from the date of adoption of these policies, they shall be furnished to each employee who shall acknowledge in writing the receipt of such copy. The policies shall be reviewed periodically by the city administrator and may be changed by the board of aldermen, but no such change will divest any employee of rights accrued under these policies at the time of such change. A copy of each change in these policies will be furnished to each employee. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
Article 2. - Definitions 

2.88.200 - Definitions. 
    As used in these rules, unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    "Call back" means an unscheduled or emergency return to work outside of normal hours or on a holiday or day off at the request of the supervisor. It does not mean overtime or holiday work scheduled in advance. 
    "Classification" means the assignment of an individual position to an appropriate grade on the basis of kind, difficulty, and responsibility of the work actually performed in the position. 
    "Compensatory time (comp time)" means that amount of authorized time worked by an employee during the employee's pay period, which exceeds the total time such employee was regularly scheduled to be on duty, vacation, sick time or injury leave, for which time off from work shall be allowed as regular pay. 
    "Crew leader" is a person who is directly in charge of a group of nonsupervisory employees. 
    "Day" means any regularly scheduled or specially scheduled work period as designated by the board of aldermen, city administrator or department head. 
    "Demotion" means an assignment of an employee from a position in one pay grade to a position in another pay grade having a lower maximum salary rate. 
    "Department" means a major functional unit of the city government. 
    "Department head" means a person appointed by the city administrator and responsible to him for the administration of a department. 
    "Discrimination" means any unfair treatment based on race, color, religion, national origin, ancestry, gender, age or handicapping condition as it relates to employment. 
    "Division" means a major functional unit of a department. 
    "Division head" means a person responsible for administration of the work of a division. 
    "Employee" includes all regular, part-time, and probationary employee and means any person working in the service of the city in an official paid capacity, exclusive of temporary employees. 
    "Exempt employee" means any employee determined by city policy to be exempted from the requirements of overtime pay as established by the laws of the United States and the rules and regulations of the United States Department of Labor. 
    Foreman. (See "Supervisor"). 
    "Grade" is a level on the pay scale to which classified positions are assigned based on the duties, responsibilities and qualifications required by the job itself. 
    "Handicap" means a physical or mental impairment which substantially limits one or more of the person's major life activities, or a condition perceived as such, which with or without reasonable accommodation does not interfere with performing the job, utilizing the place of accommodation, or occupying the dwelling in question. 
    "Harassment" means any conduct which may create a hostile environment including, but not limited to, making slurs, using offensive terms, telling jokes or creating any work consequences based on another's race, color, religion, ancestry, national origin, age, gender, veteran status, disability, or handicap. 
    "Immediate family" means mother, father, sister, brother, spouse, son, daughter, father-in-law, mother-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, grandmother, grandfather, son-in-law, daughter-in-law, grandchild, stepchild, or any relative living in the same household. 
    Job. (See "Position"). 
    "Layoff" means a separation from employment because of the city's shortage of funds or materials, abolishment of positions or other reasons beyond the control of an employee and not reflecting a discredit to him. 
    "Military leave" means the leave of absence granted to employees entering the armed forces of the United States during a national emergency or in response to draft or call to duty from the ready reserve of the armed services. 
    "Month" means one calendar month. 
    "Nonexempt employee" means any employee determined by city policy not to be exempted from the requirements of overtime pay as established by the laws of the United States and the rules and regulations of the United States Department of Labor. 
    "On call" means being available for work at a designated place for a designated period of time. 
    "Overtime" means any hours over forty (40) in a Sunday-Saturday work week that are worked by a non-exempt employee. Any overtime hours worked must be authorized by a supervisor in advance, except for emergency situations. Supervisors may arrange for the employee to take time off in the same work week in lieu of overtime pay whenever possible. 
    "Part-time employee" means any employee that works under one thousand five hundred (1,500) hours per year for the city. 
    "Performance increase" means an advancement to a higher classification. 
    "Physicians" means medical or osteopathic doctors licensed by the Missouri State Board of Medical Examiners. 
    "Position" or "job" means a group of current duties and responsibilities legally assigned or delegated by an appointing authority requiring the full-time or temporary employment of one person. 
    "Probationary employee" means a working test period of one hundred eighty (180) days during which an employee is required to demonstrate the employee's fitness for a position by actual performance of the duties of the position. 
    "Promotion" means an assignment of an employee from a position in one grade to a position in another grade having a higher maximum salary rate. 
    "Qualified individual with a disability" means an individual with a disability who, with or without reasonable accommodation, can perform the essential functions of the employment position that such individual holds or desires. 
    "Range" is a series of steps on the pay scale assigned to each grade. 
    "Reasonable accommodation" means and includes making existing facilities used by employees readily accessible to and usable by individuals with disabilities and job restructuring, modifying work schedules, acquisition or modification of equipment and/or training materials, and the like. 
    "Reevaluation" means a change in classification of an individual position on the basis of a review of the kind, difficulty or responsibility of work performed in such position. 
    "Regular employee" means an employee intended by the city to work forty (40) hours per week or two thousand eighty (2,080) hours per year. 
    "Residency" shall, for the purpose of this provision, be defined as the actual living quarters of the employee and his/her family, if any, and this requirement shall not be met by maintenance of an address, room or rooms by the employee solely for the purpose of giving the appearance of compliance herewith, when the actual facts demonstrate employee's intent to remain outside the geographical area permitted in this chapter. Residency shall mean residence within the corporate limits of the city. 
    "Service credit" means the credit allowed for an employee's length of service when completing certain benefits such as vacation, sick time and retirement. 
    "Sexual harassment" means unwelcome conduct in the form of pinching, grabbing, patting, propositioning; making either explicit or implied job threats or promises in return for submission to sexual favors; making inappropriate sex-oriented comments on appearance, including dress or physical features; telling embarrassing sex-oriented stories; displaying sexually explicit or pornographic material, no matter how it is displayed; or sexual assaults on the job by supervisors, fellow employees or nonemployees. Sexual harassment includes conduct directed by men toward women, by men toward men, by women toward men and by women toward women. 
    "Superintendent" means the member of management who has responsibility for a functional area, including supervising the nonexempt employees assigned to that area. 
    "Supervisor" means any person designated and responsible for directing the work of others. 
    "Temporary employee" is an employee who has been appointed for a period of time normally not to exceed twelve (12) months. 
    "Transfer" means any change of an employee from one position to another position, having the same salary range. (See also "Promotion" and "Demotion"). 
    "Undue hardship" is an action requiring significant difficulty or expense when considered in light of: (1) the nature and cost of the accommodation; (2) the overall financial resource of the city; (3) the number of persons employed; (4) the effect such an expense would have on the city; or (5) other impact. 
    "Workday" or "working day" means any one shift during which a department is open for business or on which an employee is scheduled to work. 
    "Workweek" means no more than forty (40) hours regularly to be worked by an employee during any seven consecutive days unless overtime hours are paid at a premium rate or unless compensatory time is allowed, all pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act or as may be varied for police or fire work pursuant to the Fair Labor Standards Act which act is cited as 29 USC Section 207. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5306, § 1, 2-21-12; Ord. No. 5462, § 1, 10-1-13; Ord. No. 5730, § 4, 2-2-16) 
Article 3. - Appointments/Separation 

2.88.300 - Residence. 
A.  The city administrator, shall maintain his or her primary residence within the city limits of the city of Perryville. 
B.  The residency requirement for the city marshal or chief of police shall be controlled by Chapter 2.40 of the Code of Ordinances of the city of Perryville. Police officers and communications officers within the city of Perryville police department shall reside within sixty (60) miles of the city of Perryville. 
C.  If all other considerations are equal, persons residing within the city limits of the city of Perryville will be given preference in all appointments of employment. General employees of the city of Perryville shall not have a residency requirement. However, any prospective on-call employee who does not reside within the city limits of the city of Perryville shall reside within fifteen (15) miles of his or her workstation as designated by the city administrator. Active employees who are transferred to other positions will not be disqualified from that transfer or from employment because of distance. Any on-call employee who moves to a new residence more than fifteen (15) miles from his or her workstation will be placed on probation and granted the opportunity to correct the residency defect in the manner set forth in this section. 
D.  Any employee who fails to satisfy the residency requirements of this section during their initial probation period shall be discharged. However, upon the written request of an otherwise successful employee, the city administrator may in the city administrator's absolute discretion determine that reasonable efforts to relocate have been made and there exists an employee hardship. If the city administrator so determines, the city administrator may extend the probationary period for one or more additional period(s) not to exceed one hundred eighty (180) days in total. At the end of this period, the employee shall be discharged if the employee does not comply with this section. 
E.  In the event that any city employee resides outside of the city limits of the city of Perryville, then that city employee shall not be allowed to use a city vehicle as transportation to and from his or her residence. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5215, § 1, 4-19-11; Ord. No. 5462, § 2, 10-1-13; Ord. No. 5609, § 1, 2-3-15; Ord. No. 6024 , § 1, 4-17-18) 
2.88.305 - Pre-employment medical examinations. 
    Before commencement of employment, each prospective employee must undergo a thorough medical and work fitness examination by a physician and/or program designated by the city administration, the cost to be borne by the city. The type and extent of examination shall be at the sole discretion of the city based on the type of work the prospective employee is expected to perform. The examination for safety sensitive employees shall include a urine test to determine the presence of unauthorized or illegal substances pursuant to the city's substance abuse policy. No one who is given a medical examination shall be employed unless the examining physician certifies that he or she meets the minimum standards of physical fitness required for his or her position. A prospective employee must be reexamined if three or more months intervene between his or her medical examination and the day of his or her appointment. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 6046 , § 1, 6-19-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6046 , § 1, adopted June 19, 2018, amended § 2.88.305 and in so doing changed the title of said section from "Medical examination, drug and alcohol testing and examinations relating to rehabilitation" to "Pre-employment medical examinations," as set out herein. 
2.88.310 - Appointment. 
A.  New employees shall be selected upon the basis of their qualifications for the job including their physical condition to the extent allowed by law. All offers of employment shall be conditional on certification by examining physician and/or program of physical fitness required for the position, except those exempted by the city administrator. Preference shall be given to former employees with a good record of service with the city. 
B.  When minors are employed, they shall furnish the city with a minor's release. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.315 - Transfer. 
A.  At the beginning of a pay period, employees may be transferred between departments or other units of the city government. An employee may be transferred upon their own request when approved by the department heads concerned and upon approval of the city administrator. 
B.  When necessary, an employee may be required to transfer to a different department, position, or unit. Whenever possible, the employee will be given a two-week notice of the transfer, with the transfer taking effect at the beginning of a pay period. An employee who does not want to transfer to the position suggested may request consideration for transfer to another open position, or he/she may resign. 
C.  Any employee transferred to a different department, position, or unit shall be placed on "probationary employee" status and shall be notified of the probationary status upon transfer. 
D.  If a transferred employee fails to pass their probationary period, the employee may be transferred to a different position if one is available and the city administrator deems the transfer to be in the best interest of the city. If a position is unavailable or if the transfer is not in the best interest of the city, the employee may be laid off or terminated. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.320 - Layoff. 
A.  Department heads may lay off employees when necessary due to changes in duties or lack of work or funds upon approval of the city administrator. When possible, employees who are to be laid off in one department will be transferred into other departments. 
B.  When layoffs are required, they will be based on length of service with the city and relative to efficiency as demonstrated on the job. Layoffs will not be considered to be disciplinary action. (See Section 2.88.555). 
C.  Whenever possible, a two-week written notice of layoff will be given by the department head to the employee; however, persons employed on temporary work may at the time they are employed be given a statement as to when the employment is expected to end. This notice will meet the requirements for notification. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
Article 4. - Probation Period 

2.88.400 - Probation period. 
    Every person appointed to a position in the service of the city shall be required to successfully complete a probation period of one hundred eighty (180) calendar days. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5462, § 3, 10-1-13) 
2.88.405 - Purpose. 
    The department head shall use the probation period to closely observe and evaluate the work of newly appointed employees and to encourage their effective adjustment to the job and to the service of the city. Department heads shall retain only those employees who meet an acceptable standard during the probation period. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.410 - Confirmation or termination. 
    Within ten days prior to the end of the probation period, if action has not been taken previously, the personnel clerk shall cause to be prepared a notice of regular status or of termination of employment for each probationary employee for the department head's consideration. It is provided, however, that following the end of the one hundred eighty (180) day probation period, if the department head determines that the goals of Section 2.88.405 can still be obtained and with the approval of the city administrator, an employee may be placed on an additional period of probation, but in no case shall that additional period exceed one hundred eighty (180) days No employee shall continue after expiration of the probation period unless the employee's status has been evaluated and adjusted as set forth herein. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5462, § 4, 10-1-13) 
2.88.415 - Discretionary termination of probationary employee. 
    A new employee may be dismissed at any time during the probation period when, in the judgment of the department head or supervisor, the quality of his work, demeanor or attitude does not merit continuation in the service (pay upon termination shall be in accordance with Section 2.88.575 of this chapter). 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.420 - Mandatory termination of probationary employee. 
    The department head shall recommend termination of a probationary employee immediately upon finding the employee: 
A.  Physically unfit for performing the duties of the position which he or she seeks to hold unless reasonable accommodation is required by law; 
B.  Is impaired in their performance by the use of drugs or alcohol; 
C.  Has unsatisfactory character on previous employment records; 
D.  Has failed to submit pertinent information requested by the department head; 
E.  Has practiced fraud or deception or made false statements in his application; or 
F.  Has performed acts of insubordination or has failed to perform required duties. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
Article 5. - Wage/Salary Administration 

2.88.500 - Adopting the plan. 
    The wage and salary administration plan set forth in the wage and salary ordinance of the city shall be a part of these policies. Copies of the plan, individual job specifications and wage schedules are available in the city clerk's office for review by an employee. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.505 - Contents of the plan. 
    The wage and salary administration plan consists of city wage schedules and a grouping of city positions according to type of work, difficulty and responsibility. The wage schedule consists of a listing of all job titles and their corresponding rates of pay. Each job shall be distinguished by written specification including job title, a list of duties and responsibilities, and a statement of the minimum qualifications necessary for satisfactory performance of the duties of the job. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.510 - Maintaining the plan. 
    The city administrator shall be responsible for continuous maintenance and administration of the plan. In consultation with the department concerned, he shall classify each new position in the service of the city into a temporary grade or range until specifications can be prepared and approved. He shall revise existing specifications as the need arises. 
    Department heads will notify the city administrator when they desire to establish a new position or to modify an existing one, and the city administrator will keep them informed of all classification changes. 
A.  When a new position is created or an existing position is changed by adding, modifying or taking away assignments, that position will be evaluated and properly classified. 
B.  The city administrator will make periodic reviews of all positions in a single department or of all the positions in a particular range. As a result of his study, he may submit to a job evaluation committee a recommendation to reevaluate individual positions; or he himself may recommend a reevaluation subject to the approval of the board of alderman. 
C.  An employee may submit to his department head a written request for reevaluation of his position. This request shall set forth reasons justifying reevaluation. The department head will study each request and forward it with his recommendations to the city administrator.
