The city administrator will study the position in question, revise the job specifications if necessary and submit his findings and recommendations in writing to the department head. Written notice of the final determination will be furnished to the employee within sixty (60) days of the request for reevaluation. 
D.  An employee who occupies a position which is reevaluated shall continue in that position in the new range only if he or she possesses the minimum requirements and is appointed in accordance with the rules governing transfer, promotion or demotion. 
1.  When a position is reevaluated to a lower range, the employee may continue in his position in the new range (see Section 2.88.550) or he or she may apply for transfer to a position in the original range. If the employee continues in his/her position in the new range, the employee shall receive no raise in pay until such time as the new range reaches his/her pay amount. 
2.  When a position is reevaluated to a higher range, the incumbent employee, if he or she has the minimum qualification, may continue in the position. 
E.  Reasonable accommodations for the known physical or mental limitations or disability of an employee or applicant who is otherwise qualified to perform the essential functions of the position shall be made by the city unless the requisite accommodations would impose an undue hardship on the city. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.515 - Use of job title. 
    All jobs are designated by job titles on all official records, payrolls and communications. No job will carry an official title which has not been approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.520 - Certification, license or education. 
    If the city administrator determines that a certification, license, or education is necessary or essential to provide better service to the city, then the city administrator may, with approval of the board of aldermen, establish a compensation schedule providing for compensation to employees who obtain the certification, license or education set forth in the schedule. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.525 - Continuous study of salary rates. 
    Prior to the preparation of each annual budget, the city administrator shall prepare an analysis of prevailing rates of pay for similar public and private employment in the area and at large taking into consideration cost of living factors, budget effects of various alternative pay plans, and other factors which may be pertinent in recommending changes in the plan. On the basis of this information, he shall recommend to the board of aldermen changes in pay policy or in individual pay rates necessary to keep the pay plan current, uniform and equitable. Recommended changes in pay policy shall become effective when approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.530 - Pay increases. 
A.  The pay plan is designed to provide for pay increases to employees to compensate the employee's increased value to the city through length of service with consideration given for the employee's performance and efficiency. 
B.  Eligibility for step increases within the classification grade of a position in the pay plan shall be based on the length of service of the employee; however, any employee who received an overall performance evaluation below successful shall not be eligible for a step increase. In such cases, the employee, the employee's supervisor, and the employee's department head shall set out a program designed to help the employee attain the successful level in the employee's evaluation. The employee shall reach the successful level in the employee's evaluation within six months or be subject to dismissal. If the employee reaches the successful level anytime within the six month period, the employee's step increase shall be restored. 
C.  Each January all supervisors shall complete an informal supplementary assessment of all employees under their supervision to determine if any employee is in jeopardy of falling below an overall evaluation score of successful. In such cases the employee shall receive a written employee evaluation and, for those scoring below successful, any cost of living adjustment (COLA) shall be withheld beginning in April of that year. At that same time, the employee, the employee's supervisor, and the employee's department head shall set out a program designed to help the employee attain the successful level in the employee's evaluation. The employee shall reach the successful level in the employee's evaluation within six months or be subject to dismissal. If the employee reaches the successful level anytime within the six month probation period, the employee's COLA shall be restored. 
D.  Performance increases and promotions shall take effect at the beginning of a pay period and shall be approved by the city administrator before becoming effective. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5610, § 1, 2-3-15) 
2.88.535 - Total remuneration. 
    No employee shall be paid at a rate more than the maximum for his range unless he or she was drawing that salary prior to the adoption of these policies or the adoption of any new classification plans. (See Section 2.88.550(A)(2).) 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.540 - Original appointment. 
    Upon appointment, a new employee normally shall be paid the minimum rate for the employee's salary range. However, when diligent search reveals that it is impossible to obtain qualified persons at such rate, or when a new employee possesses exceptional qualifications, the city may make an original appointment at a higher starting salary within the following parameters: 
A.  The city administrator may appoint employees in job classifications at or above Grade 11 to a level within the first five steps of the pay plan. 
B.  The chief of police may appoint employees in job classifications at or above Grade P-8 to a level within the first five steps of the pay plan. 
C.  Any exception to this shall be approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5610, § 2, 2-3-15) 
2.88.545 - Employees in training. 
    When it is not possible to obtain an employee who meets all the qualifications set forth in the specifications for a given position, the department head, with the approval of the city administrator, may appoint an employee who meets the educational requirements but does not meet all the other qualifications; the employee will then undergo a period of training which will prepare the employee for the position. In such cases, the employee will be placed in the classification designated for the position, but the employee's starting pay will be at a lower level. Such starting pay will be determined by the department head and the city administrator on the basis of the employee's education and experience. An employee will be expected to be proficient in this position after a period of one hundred eighty (180) days and during that time is on probation. See Article 4 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5462, § 5, 10-1-13) 
2.88.550 - Change in position. 
A.  When an employee's position is reevaluated, or he or she is appointed to a new position in another classification, and his current rate of pay is: 
1.  Less than the minimum rate of the new position, his rate of pay shall be increased to the new minimum rate; 
2.  More than the maximum rate for the new position, his rate of pay shall be maintained at the current rate. 
B.  Except that a demotion for just cause under Section 2.88.830 shall result in a reduction in pay to the level in the pay plan to which the employee is demoted. 
C.  All adjustments of pay due to changes in position shall be recommended by the department head and approved by the city administrator. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.555 - Reemployment. 
    An employee who is reemployed in a position which he or she previously held with the city shall be paid at the same range at which the employee was previously paid if the employee had been laid off, had a good performance record, and is re-employed within one year of lay off. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.560 - Part-time and temporary employee pay rate. 
    Rate of pay shall be established at the discretion of the department head with the approval of the city administrator. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.565 - Overtime. 
A.  All nonexempt employees who work overtime will be paid for all additional time worked to the nearest quarter hour. All overtime will be at the rate of time and one-half of the regular hourly rate, except that overtime on Sundays and holidays will be at the rate of double time of the regular hourly rate. It is generally the policy of the city that employees work a forty (40) hour work week; therefore, compensatory time should be scheduled in the same week in which the overtime is worked. If overtime is necessary, the department head will determine if compensatory time will be used or overtime will be paid. 
B.  All nonexempt employees working within the police department will receive compensatory time in lieu of overtime pay as directed by the chief of police or will be paid at the overtime rate set forth in subsection A of this section except as specifically modified in this subsection, all at the discretion of the chief of police with the approval of the city administrator. All compensatory time will be computed at one and one-half times the overtime worked. (Example: An employee works one hour overtime, he or she receives compensatory time of one and one-half hours.) Nonexempt employees working within the police department shall not be entitled to double time for Sundays and holidays if those days are regularly scheduled duty. However, nonexempt employees working within the police department who are called out on Sundays and holidays that are not their regularly scheduled duty will receive compensatory time computed at double the time of overtime worked. 
C.  Nonexempt employees called back shall be paid the applicable overtime rate for the time worked with a minimum of two hours pay. A day off shall be considered to begin and end at the same time as a regular workday, and work continuing into a day off from a previous call back shall not be entitled to the two-hour premium. 
D.  Any employee who works overtime that has not been certified by a department head as necessary and approved by the city administrator may be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including discharge. 
E.  Nonexempt employees shall work overtime when necessary, and overtime on any job shall be allocated as evenly as possible among all nonexempt employees qualified to do the work. Payment shall be as provided in this section. Departments shall keep complete records of overtime and will furnish periodic reports to the city administrator. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5730, § 5, 2-2-16) 
2.88.570 - Method of payment. 
    Pay periods and dates of payment shall be set by the board of aldermen. All nonexempt employees are paid for the actual number of hours worked during each pay period. When absent on authorized sick time or on vacation, each employee shall be paid at this regular rate according to vacation and sick time pay policies. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.575 - Terminal pay. 
    All employees who leave the service of the city for any reason shall receive all pay which may be due them with the following qualification: Regular employees who have completed at least six months' service shall be paid for all unused vacation and personal time accumulated. Employees who leave before completing their six months' service shall not be entitled to any vacation or personal time pay. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.580 - Payroll deductions. 
    Each employee has the right to request the personnel clerk to make regular deductions from their paycheck for city-sponsored insurance premiums. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.585 - Assignment of wages. 
    No assignment of an employee's wages, earned or unearned, used as a transfer, or as a security for a debt, shall be binding on the city. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.590 - Wages and salaries-Grade levels. 
A.  The grades of the various officers and employees of the city in the various departments shall be as set forth in the annual ordinance establishing pay rate, classifications and grades for all city employees. A copy of same may be obtained from the city clerk during regular business hours. 
B.  This division implements the city's wages and salary administration plan, which plan is hereby adopted by reference. The plan, which includes individual job specifications and classifications, and which is established in accordance with the personnel rules and regulations of the city, shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. 
C.  The grade of each classification of city officers and employees represents the officers' and employees' salary levels. The rate of pay for each grade shall be established by the approved budget for the current fiscal year and shall be administered in accordance with, and as made and provided in, the personnel rules and regulations as codified in this code under this chapter. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.595 - Travel work days/travel time. 
    Attendance at professional conferences, seminars, conventions, schools or visits to other cities in the interest of the city shall be considered to be part of the normal work day when authorized by the city administrator. Travel time shall be governed as follows: 
A.  Ordinary travel time between home and work is not considered hours of work; 
B.  On-call time is not considered hours worked. However, when an employee "on-call" gets a call, they are "on the clock" from the time they get the call, travel to where they are needed, perform the required services, and travel back to where they received the call. 
C.  Home to work travel on a special one-day assignment in another city must be counted as hours of work; however, the employee's normal commute is subtracted. On a one-day assignment, both the driver and the passenger is "on the clock" for the duration of the travel time. 
D.  Travel away from home that involves overnight travel is considered work time when it coincides with the employee's normal work day. On overnight travel, both the driver and the passenger is "on the clock" for any travel time that is over and above the normal work day. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
Article 6. - Attendance/Accrual of Benefits 

2.88.600 - Accrual of benefits. 
A.  Temporary employees do not accrue any benefits. 
B.  Employees sharing a job position may be entitled to benefits on a pro rata basis as determined by the city administrator. 
C.  All regular employees working full-time (forty (40) hours per week) shall be entitled to all benefits of the city. Those benefits, including but not limited to sick time and vacation time, shall accrue based on hours worked for time when an employee is actually paid. However, see Section 2.88.725 regarding workmen's compensation. 
D.  Medical insurance, life insurance, retirement and any other benefits obtained through a company or government agency not managed or controlled by the city shall be governed and determined by the contract or benefit provisions existing at the time. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.605 - Hours of work. 
    The hours during which city offices and departments are open for business shall be determined by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.610 - Attendance. 
    Employees shall be required to be at their place of work in accordance with these rules and general or departmental regulation. All departments shall maintain daily attendance records of employees. 
    Excessive absenteeism and/or tardiness may subject employees to disciplinary action, up to and including termination. Unexcused absences are defined as any occurrence of absence or lost time from work (consecutive missed days) that is not planned and approved by the supervisor in advance. Tardiness is defined as arriving late or leaving early without prior approval. Absenteeism and/or tardiness that is excessive or habitual in pattern may lead to disciplinary action up to and including termination. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.615 - Holidays. 
    The following holidays are declared official holidays for all city employees. If the holiday falls on Saturday, it will be observed on the preceding Friday; if it falls on Sunday, it will be observed on the following Monday. 
    New Year's Day, January 1; 
    Martin Luther King's Birthday, third Monday in January; 
    President's Day, third Monday in February; 
    Good Friday, 1/2 work day on Friday before Easter; 
    Memorial Day, last Monday in May; 
    Independence Day, July 4; 
    Labor Day, first Monday in September; 
    Veteran's Day, November 11; 
    Thanksgiving, fourth Thursday in November; 
    Day after Thanksgiving, fourth Friday in November; 
    Christmas Eve, December 24; 
    Christmas, December 25; 
    New Year's Eve, December 31; 
    Two days of personal leave. 
A.  As many employees as possible will be given each holiday off without loss of pay. All regular employees who are required to work on holidays shall be given an alternate day off or shall be paid double time for the time worked in addition to the holiday pay. When the holiday and regular day off occur on the same day, those employees who are scheduled off duty on that day will be entitled to holiday pay or another day off. 
B.  Temporary employees will be paid their regular rates on a holiday, only if required to work. No employee shall be allowed to work on a holiday unless specifically authorized by the department head. 
C.  An employee who is absent without approved leave on the scheduled work day immediately preceding or following a holiday shall lose pay for the holiday as well as pay for the missed day. 
D.  When the board of aldermen declares a special holiday, it shall be observed as provided in this section. 
E.  If Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve fall on a Friday, Saturday, or Sunday, then Christmas Eve and New Year's Eve will be observed on the last full work day before the Christmas or New Year's holidays are observed. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.620 - Vacation. 
A.  All regular employees shall be entitled to four hours of vacation at their regular rate of pay for each month of their first two years of continuous service. Upon completion of two years of continuous service, each regular employee will accrue eight hours of vacation at his regular rate of pay for each month of service. Upon completion of ten years of continuous service, each regular employee will accrue twelve (12) hours of vacation at his regular rate of pay for each month of service. Upon completion of twenty (20) years of continuous service, each regular employee will accrue sixteen (16) hours of vacation at his regular rate of pay for each month of service. An employee who enters the service to the city before the sixteenth day of the month, or who terminates after the fifteenth day of any month, will earn accrued hours of vacation for that month. 
B.  Official holidays occurring during an employee's vacation shall not be deducted from accrued vacation. 
C.  The maximum allowed accrual of vacation time is two hundred forty (240) hours; however, the city administrator may waive this limitation if the needs of the city preclude the taking of any excess vacation which would otherwise be lost because of this limitation. The amount of continuous vacation time which can be granted to an employee in excess of eighteen (18) days must be approved by the city administrator. 
D.  After an employee's accrued sick time has been exhausted, when requested, vacation may be used as sick time. To receive paid vacation an employee shall communicate with department head or designate and obtain prior approval from his department head or designate. (See Section 2.88.570). 
E.  Accrual of vacation time begins immediately upon employment with the city in a regular position. 
F.  Upon leaving employment, the employee shall be entitled to any pay for unused vacation time. Regular employees who leave the city before completing six months' service are not entitled to vacation or vacation pay upon separation. (See Section 2.88.575). Temporary employees shall not earn or accrue vacation, nor be entitled to vacation pay upon separation. 
G.  No accrued vacation time can be taken until a regular employee has completed six months of service with the city in a permanent position. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.625 - Sick time. 
    All regular employees are entitled to ninety-six (96) hours of sick time per year. Sick time credit accrues at the rate of eight hours each calendar month. Unused sick time may be accrued up to nine hundred sixty (960) hours. 
A.  Sick time shall accrue but shall not be granted to any employee during his probationary period unless specifically approved by his department head. 
B.  An employee who enters the service of the city before the sixteenth shall earn eight hours of sick time for that month. (See Section 2.88.735, Effect of leave). 
C.  Official holidays and regular days off shall not be counted against sick time. 
D.  After an employee's accrued sick time has been exhausted, when requested, vacation may be used as sick time. When absence due to illness exceeds the amount of paid time earned and authorized, the pay of an employee shall be discontinued until he or she returns to work. (See Section 2.88.570). 
E.  Sick time may only be allowed in case of illness or physical incapacity of an employee or their child, spouse, or parent. In addition, sick time may be granted for medical appointments as follows: (1) within the city of Perryville area - exact hours needed for the appointment; (2) within a forty (40) mile radius of Perryville (i.e., Cape Girardeau) - four hours; over a forty (40) mile radius of Perryville - eight hours. 
However, if the medical appointment includes tests or necessitates preparation, recovery or recuperation, the employee may be allowed additional sick time off at the discretion of the department head. 
F.  To receive paid sick time, an employee shall communicate with his department head or designate before the time set for beginning work on that day (unless the situation deems it impossible). 
G.  Department heads may require satisfactory proof of illness and may disallow sick time in the absence of such proof. Employees who consistently use their sick time as it is earned, or who fail to accrue it, may be subject to disciplinary action up to and including dismissal. 
H.  Employees shall not be paid, at any time, for unused accrued sick time. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5121, § 1, 6-8-10) 
2.88.630 - Personal time. 
    All regular employees receive two personal days (sixteen (16) hours) at the beginning of each calendar year and may use these days upon the approval of their department head. Personal time must be used in the calendar year received and shall not accrue. Any new regular employee who begins their employment before July 1st shall be granted two personal days (sixteen (16) hours) for the year; however, if a new regular employee begins employment on or after July 1st, they shall receive one personal day (eight hours) for that year. Upon leaving employment, the employee shall be entitled to any pay for unused personal time. However, regular employees who leave the city before completing six months' service are not entitled to personal pay upon separation. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.635 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5392, § 1, adopted December 18, 2012, repealed § 2.88.635, which pertained to a health care fund and derived from Ord. No. 4866, 2007. 
2.88.640 - Retirement system. 
A.  All regular employees are required, as a condition of their employment, to participate in the Missouri Local Government Employee Retirement System (LAGERS). Employee and employer contributions to the retirement system do not start until the employee has completed six full months of employment. Employees working less than one thousand five hundred (1,500) hours annually are not eligible to enroll in the retirement system. 
B.  Deposits. The city will contribute an actuarially computed amount determined by LAGERS. 
C.  Retirement Date. An individual employee may retire any time after attaining early service retirement age with reduced benefits at age fifty-five (55) if he or she is a general employee or age fifty (50) if he or she is a policeman. To retire and receive full benefits an employee must have reached the minimum service retirement age which is sixty (60) for a general employee or fifty-five (55) for a policeman. 
To be eligible for retirement an employee must have five years or more of credited service and have worked for the city for one calendar year after March 1, 1969. 
Mandatory retirement age is subject to any applicable federal or state law. 
D.  Vested Interest. Credit for membership in LAGERS is based on service with the city before and after March 1, 1969. One hundred (100) percent credit for prior service will be granted to those employees eligible for membership in the system who are employed by the city before March 1, 1969. Service credit will be given for employment until date of retirement. 
E.  Further Information. Additional information on the benefits provided through LAGERS may be obtained by acquiring a copy of "A Summary of Lagers" from the city clerk or by writing Missouri LAGERS, P.O. Box 1665, Jefferson City, Missouri 65101. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
Article 7. - Leave 

2.88.700 - Funeral leave. 
    All regular employees may be granted emergency leave with pay for a period not to exceed three days in case of death in their immediate family. This leave will not be charged against sick time or vacation. Temporary employees may be granted leave of absence without pay in such cases. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.705 - Family and Medical Leave Act (1993). 
A.  Purpose of Policy. To define city of Perryville's policy and procedure with regard to family and medical leave, in accordance with the Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993. 
B.  Scope. This policy covers all employees of city of Perryville. 
C.  Policy and Procedures. 
1.  Eligibility. 
a.  Employees who have been employed as a full-time employee for at least twelve (12) months (continuous or noncontinuous), and have worked for at least one thousand two hundred fifty (1,250) hours in the twelve (12) month period preceding the start of the leave, shall be eligible for up to twelve (12) weeks of leave (family and/or medical) in a twelve (12) month period. The twelve (12) month period is measured as a "rolling" twelve (12) month period; measured backward from the date an employee uses any FMLA leave. Each time an employee takes FMLA leave, the remaining leave entitlement would be any balance of the twelve (12) weeks which have not been used during the immediately preceding twelve (12) months. The following reasons qualify for FMLA leave: 
b.  i.  The birth of an employee's child and/or to care for the newborn child; 
ii.  The placement of a child with the employee for adoption or foster care or any necessary activities related thereto; 
iii.  Where the employee is needed to care for a child, spouse, or parent of the employee who has a serious health condition; and/or 
iv.  Inability of the employee to perform the essential functions of his or her position due to a serious health condition of the employee, including prenatal care or the inability to work due to pregnancy. 
c.  Any employee requesting family and/or medical leave must explain the reasons for the needed leave so as to allow the city of Perryville time to determine whether the leave qualifies as FMLA leave. Only leave taken for the above conditions will count against the twelve (12) weeks of FMLA entitlement, so long as the employee is eligible. 
2.  Notice. 
a.  Where the need for family and/or medical leave is foreseeable, the employee must provide the city of Perryville with at least thirty (30) days' notice. If unforeseeable, as much notice as practicable should be given. If an employee fails to give thirty (30) days' notice for a medical or family leave that was clearly foreseeable, and the employee has no reasonable excuse for the delay, the city of Perryville may deny the taking of leave until at least thirty (30) days after the employee provides notice to the city. 
b.  Employees are expected to consult with their supervisor or department head prior to scheduling medical treatment in order to work out a treatment schedule that best suits the needs of both the city and the employee. Management may, for justifiable cause, require an employee to reschedule treatment subject to the availability and approval of the health care provider. The city will at no time render any medical opinion, but will rely on the opinion of the qualified health care professional as to the reasonableness of rescheduling. 
3.  Pregnancy, Related Medical Condition, or Placement of Child. 
a.  In some cases, leave for birth or placement for adoption or foster care can be taken prior to the actual birth or placement. 
b.  An employee's right to family and/or medical leave for the birth or placement expires at the end of the twelve (12) month period beginning on the date of birth or placement. Any leave must be concluded within this one year. 
4.  Serious Health Condition. 
a.  A serious health condition means an illness, injury, impairment, or physical or mental condition involving: (i) inpatient care in a hospital, hospice, or residential medical care facility; (ii) any incapacity requiring absence from work, school, or other regular daily activities of more than three calendar days that also involves continuing treatment by or under the supervision of a health care provider; (iii) continuing treatment by or under the supervision of a health care provider for a chronic or long-term health condition that is incurable or so serious that, if not treated, would likely result in a period of incapacity of more than three calendar days; and (iv) prenatal care. 
(A)  Whenever more than three consecutive work days are missed due to qualified reasons as defined by the Family Medical Leave Act of 1993, then this leave time shall be designated as FMLA leave. When more than three consecutive days are missed, the FMLA leave will be retroactive to the first day missed. 
b.  City of Perryville may require medical certification: form (http://dol.gov/esa/ regs/compliance/whd/fmla/wh380.pdf) where leave is sought to care for the serious health condition of child, spouse, parent, or due to a serious health condition of the employee. The employee must provide the requested certification within fifteen (15) days after the family or medical leave absence commences, or after the city requests the certification, whichever occurs first unless it is not practicable under the particular circumstances to do so despite the employee's diligent good-faith efforts. If an employee does not provide timely certification within fifteen (15) days, and the leave was foreseeable, city of Perryville may deny leave until the required certification is provided. If the leave was unforeseeable, the employee must try to provide the certification as soon as practicable and may be denied continuance of leave if the medical certification is not provided within a reasonable time. 
i.  The medical certification form sets forth the date the serious health condition commenced, the nature of the condition, and the probable duration of the condition. When an employee takes leave for his own medical condition, city of Perryville will require that the certification state that the employee is unable to perform his or her essential job functions. If needed, city of Perryville will provide a statement of the essential functions of the employee's position for the health care provider to review. 
ii.  When the leave is taken to care for a family member, city of Perryville will require a statement from a health care provider that the employee is needed to care for the family member and an estimate of the time required for that care. 
iii.  In its discretion and at its own expense, city of Perryville may request that a second medical opinion be secured from a health care provider. If the second opinion differs from the first opinion, city of Perryville reserves the right to require a third opinion at city of Perryville's expense. The third opinion will be provided by a health care provider approved jointly by the city and the employee. This third opinion will be final and binding. Subsequent medical re-certification may also be required by city of Perryville if the city has reason to question the appropriateness of the leave or its duration or whenever circumstances described by the original certification have changed significantly. 
c.  Employees may take twelve (12) weeks worth of leave on an intermittent or reduced work week basis for a serious health condition of the child, spouse, or parent of the employee or the employee, but such leave will be allowed only if medically necessary, and medical need can be best accommodated through an intermittent leave or reduced work schedule. The same requirements for medical certification apply for intermittent or reduced work week leave. The statement from a health care provider must state that the employee is needed to care for the family member and the reasons why intermittent or reduced work week leave can best accommodate the medical need. Intermittent leave may occur where the family member's condition itself is intermittent, or the employee is only needed intermittently. Examples of intermittent leave would include leave taken on an occasional basis for medical appointments or leave taken several days at a time. 
i.  The city of Perryville reserves the option to transfer the employee temporarily to an available alternative position with equivalent pay and benefits for which the employee is qualified and which better accommodates recurring periods of leave than does the employee's regular position. The alternative position will have equivalent pay and benefits. 
ii.  The employee must attempt to work out a schedule that meets the employee's needs without unduly disrupting the city's operations. 
5.  Benefits. 
a.  An employee on family and/or medical leave will be required to use all accrued paid time off, in the order designated by the employee, for any circumstances for which they may be eligible for FMLA leave. This paid leave shall run concurrently with FMLA leave. Employees utilizing paid time off in conjunction with FMLA leave will continue to accrue paid time off during the leave and will receive any holiday pay. After the employee has exhausted all paid days off, the remainder of the leave will be unpaid. 
b.  The personnel clerk will inform the employee, prior to the leave, whether it considers the leave to qualify for FMLA leave and what portion, if any, will be paid leave. (See form http://www.dol.gov/esa/forms/whd/wh-381.pdf, "Employer Response to Employee Request for FMLA.") In cases where notification to the city occurs after the absence has begun, the city will communicate this information as soon as possible. 
c.  Group health coverage will be maintained until the end of the FMLA leave of absence, or for twelve (12) weeks, whichever is shorter. During the duration of an employee's leave, coverage by the health plan will remain at the level the coverage would be if the employee were still on the job. An employee who wishes to maintain dependent group health coverage during the leave must continue to pay the employee's portion of the premium for coverage, if any, that he or she paid prior to the FMLA leave. If an employee chooses to retain coverage during FMLA leave, the employee, upon reinstatement, will be entitled to the same terms as prior to taking the leave. 
i.  If allowable, the employee must notify the city of any change in coverage desired during leave. The employee will also be notified of any opportunity to change plans or benefits. The employee will bear all additional costs that would have been incurred by the employee had he or she been on the job. If premiums are raised during the time an employee is on leave, the employee will be required to pay the additional premium rates that would have been incurred while on the job. Also, the employee will be subject to new or changed plan benefits to the same extent as if the employee were not on leave. 
ii.  During paid leave, if any, premiums will be made by payroll deduction. During unpaid leave, the employee is to send the premium payment to the personnel clerk on the date on which the payroll deduction would normally be made for the premium. No additional charges will be added. Health insurance coverage will cease if an employee's premium payment is more than thirty (30) days late. If coverage lapses because an employee has not made the required premium payment, if allowable the employee will be restored to the previous coverage upon return from leave without incurring a waiting period. 
iii.  In the event that an employee fails to return to work upon completion of an approved family or medical leave for a reason other than the continuation, recurrence, or onset of a serious health condition, or other circumstances beyond the employee's control, the employee must reimburse the city for the cost of any premium payments made by the city to maintain the employee's group health coverage while the employee was on leave. This does not include premiums for a period of FMLA leave covered by paid leave where premium payments were deducted from payroll checks. If and when the employee informs the city of his or her intent not to return to work, the right to health benefit privileges ends (except for COBRA privileges). Where feasible, city of Perryville will recover its share of health insurance premiums through deduction of any sums due to the employee. The city's payment of the employee's portion of any other benefits, such as life insurance will be recovered from the employee whether or not the employee returns from leave. 
iv.  If the employee fails to return due to the continuation, recurrence or onset of a serious health condition, the city may require medical certification of the employee's or family member's serious condition. The employee is required to provide the medical certification within thirty (30) days from the date of the city's request. If the city requests the medical certification and the employee does not provide such certification within thirty (30) days, the city can recover the health benefit premiums it paid during the period of leave. An employee who returns to work for less than thirty (30) days is not considered to have "returned" to work. 
6.  Return from Leave. 
a.  Any employee on FMLA leave must periodically, but at least every thirty (30) days, report to their immediate supervisor on his or her status and intent to return to work. 
b.  Employees returning from leave under this subsection will be allowed to return to their same or equivalent position upon completion of the authorized leave, assuming the employee would otherwise have been employed in that position at the time reinstatement is requested. If an employee is no longer qualified for the position because of lack of training, testing, etc., the employee will be given a reasonable opportunity to fulfill those conditions upon return to work. An employee will be able to receive any unconditional pay increases that may have occurred during the leave period. 
c.  Any employee wishing to return from leave must obtain and present certification from a qualified health care provider that the employee is able to resume work. This fitness-for-duty certification should only address the particular health condition that caused the employee's need for FMLA leave. The certification must state whether the employee is able to return to work and perform the essential functions of his or her job as well as clearly identify any medical restrictions. 
d.  If leave was due to a serious health condition of the employee, Work STEPS fit-for-duty testing will be required prior to returning to work on a full-duty status. The Work STEPS policy is on file at City Hall. 
e.  Employees who fail to report to work when released to do so by their physician, who fail to accept an available position upon release by their physician, or do not return to work for any reason within twelve (12) weeks after going on family or medical leave of absence, or their date of release whichever is sooner, lose their right to reinstatement and employment will be terminated. 
f.  Should an employee fail to return to work at the end of their FMLA leave, retirement benefits shall be based on the last day worked or of paid time off taken by employee. 
g.  In the event a health care provider's restrictions prevent an employee from performing the essential functions of his or her original position, the employee will be assigned to an available equivalent position with essential functions the employee can perform where possible. If no such positions are available, the employee may, at the city's discretion, remain on an extended medical leave of absence for as long as feasible. If the city administrator determines it is in the city's best interest, the employment may be terminated. 
7.  General. 
a.  A husband and wife both working for the city of Perryville are each entitled to the full twelve (12) week allotment of leave for their own health condition or because of the serious health condition of their spouse, son, or daughter. However, if the leave is used for the birth of a child, adoption of a child, or to care for a sick parent, the combination of husband and wife is entitled to twelve (12) weeks of leave. 
b.  Any employee who fraudulently obtains leave under this policy will be immediately terminated. 
c.  Where the cause of a serious health condition initially occurred as a result of a work-related injury or illness covered by workers compensation law, such time off as it applies to work-related illness or injury shall not be counted as family medical leave. 
d.  Step increase dates and annual across-the-board increases shall not be affected by an employee utilizing FMLA leave. 
8.  Responsibilities. In addition to the obligations of the city and the employee outlined above, all managers, supervisors, and human resources representatives of the city of Perryville are responsible for ensuring that FMLA absences are administered in accordance with this policy. Proper collection and retention of applicable documents is required. Data and documents with regard to family and medical leaves will be kept in accordance with all applicable HIPAA requirements. Supervisor and department heads, along with the personnel clerk are to ensure that state specific regulations are taken into account when making leave of absence decisions. 
9.  Complaints. If an employee believes their rights under FMLA have been violated, the employee has the choice of: 
a.  Filing, or having another person file on his or her behalf, a complaint with the Secretary of Labor; or 
b.  Filing a private lawsuit pursuant to Section 107 of FMLA.eol; 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5121, § 2, 6-8-10) 
2.88.710 - Leave of absence (non-FMLA). 
    Leaves of absence may be granted by the city administrator. Leaves of absence may not exceed ninety (90) days in duration and may not be renewed without board approval. Employees shall request leaves of absence in writing well in advance of the date desired. Leave may be requested for any legitimate purpose, but employees shall be obligated to show that granting such leaves is in the interest of the city. No leave shall be granted before an employee has completed his probation period. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.715 - Failure to return for work. 
    If an employee fails to return to work at the time specified in his application for leave, and does not provide a reasonable excuse and notice to his department head, he or she shall be considered to have resigned, effective the date he or she should have returned. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.720 - Absence without leave. 
    No employee may be absent from duty without permission of his immediate supervisor. Absence without leave shall be sufficient cause for dismissal. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.725 - Workmen's compensation leave. 
    If it is determined that an employee has been injured while on duty, the following factors should be considered for administering workmen's comp leave. (Also see Section 2.88.705 re Family and Medical Leave Act - General (3)). 
A.  Employee Choices. The employee may choose to be: (1) compensated by the city's workers compensation plan at loss of time benefit rate; or (2) compensated by the city's workers compensation plan at loss of time benefit rate and use a portion of their accrued sick, personal, and vacation time (in that order) at their normal rate of pay. 
B.  Accrual of Benefits. The employee will continue to accrue their benefits while on worker's compensation leave. 
C.  Doctor Visits. Once an employee has returned to work, any follow-up worker's compensation doctor visits will not be charged against their accrued time. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.730 - Military leave. 
    The city of Perryville complies with the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994 with regard to employees serving in the armed forces. An employee who serves in the uniformed services of the United States for training or service shall be granted a leave of absence without pay for the duration of such time required for such purpose, and for a period of ninety (90) calendar days following the period of actual service. The employee may utilize accrued vacation pay during the leave, at his/her discretion. Upon termination of such service, the employee will be returned to the position he/she would have held had the interruption in employment not occurred. Vacancies resulting from leave granted under this section shall be filled only on a temporary basis. One voluntary enlistment shall be considered the same as induction for the purpose of this section, but reenlistment shall not. 
    "Service in the uniformed services" means the performance of duty on a voluntary or involuntary basis in a uniformed service under competent authority. Service in the uniformed services includes active duty, active and inactive duty for training, national guard duty under federal statute, and a period for which a person is absent from a position of employment for an examination to determine the fitness of the person to perform such duty. (See Section 105.270 of RSMo. Laws 1985). 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.735 - Effect of leave. 
    When any leave of absence without pay exceeds thirty (30) days: 
A.  Any earned service credit is retained and will be reinstated upon the employee's return to work; 
B.  The employee and the employee's family may remain in the city's health insurance program at the employee's expense; 
C.  No vacation or sick time is accrued during the leave; and 
D.  Retirement benefits will be governed by the rules of the retirement program. (See Sections 2.88.530, 2.88.620 and 2.88.625). 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.740 - Jury duty. 
    Regular employees receive regular pay for any time they are actively serving on a jury or on the jury selection process. The employee must notify his/her supervisor as far in advance as possible when summoned to jury duty. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.745 - Voting privileges. 
    All employees entitled to vote in national, state, county or municipal elections shall, when necessary, be allowed sufficient time off with pay to exercise this privilege in accordance with federal and state statutes. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
Article 8. - Discipline/Grievance Procedures 

2.88.800 - Progressive discipline procedure. 
A.  It shall be the duty of each employee to maintain high standards of cooperation, efficiency, and economy in the employee's work for the city. Department heads and supervisors shall organize and direct the work of their units to achieve these objectives. 
B.  Employees may be evaluated annually, or more frequently as necessary, by their department head or designated supervisor as set forth in Section 2.88.530. 
C.  The city utilizes the following progressive approach to disciplinary actions: 
1.  Coaching. When work habits, attitude, production, or personal conduct of an employee falls below desirable standards, supervisors should point out the deficiencies at the time they are observed. 
2.  Verbal. If an employee fails to correct the deficiencies, the supervisor will provide a documented verbal warning indicating to the employee that this verbal warning is intended to correct the deficiencies within a specific timeline before a written warning must be issued. 
3.  Written. If an employee fails to correct the deficiencies after the verbal warning, the supervisor will provide a written warning, including steps for the employee to improve behavior and a timeline for reassessment to ensure improvement. 
4.  Suspension/Probation. If the first written warning does not produce improvement, then the supervisor will provide a second warning, which may include a disciplinary suspension without pay and corrective probation, informing the employee that failure to improve may result in discharge. 
    A written warning and sufficient time for improvement should typically precede formal discipline, but nothing in this section shall prevent an immediate formal action whenever the interest of the city requires it. The employee shall be given a copy of the warnings issued to the employee and a copy provided to the employee's personnel file. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5610, § 3, 2-3-15) 
2.88.805 - Grounds for demotion, suspension, or dismissal. 
    The following are declared to be examples of grounds for demotion, suspension or dismissal of any regular employee: 
A.  Conviction of a felony or other crime involving moral turpitude; 
B.  Acts of incompetence; 
C.  Absence without leave; 
D.  Intentional failure or refusal to carry out instructions; 
E.  Misappropriation, destruction, theft or conversion of city property; 
F.  Acts of insubordination; 
G.  Refusal or neglect to pay just debts. Maintenance of effort to pay debts must be shown to clear employee of neglect charges; 
H.  Employee subsequently becomes physically or mentally unfit for the performance of his duties. In such cases, the employee shall be entitled to accrued sick leave; 
I.  Acts of misconduct while on duty; 
J.  Disregard of orders; 
K.  Intentional disregard of standard safety precautions; 
L.  Habitual tardiness and/or absenteeism; 
M.  Falsification of any information required by the city; 
N.  Failure to properly report accidents or personal injuries; 
O.  Neglect or carelessness resulting in damage to city or private property or equipment; 
P.  Repeated conviction during employment on misdemeanor and/or traffic charges; 
Q.  Introduction, possession or use on city property or in city equipment of intoxicating liquors or illegal drugs, or proceeding to or from work under the influence of liquor or illegal drugs; 
R.  Conviction of a misdemeanor involving alcohol or drugs. The first conviction may result in suspension and any subsequent conviction may result in dismissal (see Section 2.88.820 re Disciplinary action); 
S.  Failure of a random, post-accident, reasonable cause, return to duty or follow-up drug test after successfully completing a rehabilitation program will result in immediate dismissal; 
T.  Harassing another employee of the city. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.810 - Employment at will. 
    Nothing in this code shall limit the right of the city regarding each employee's status as an "employee at will" under Missouri law. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.815 - Suspension pending investigation. 
    If an employee is the subject of an investigation concerning the employee's work-related wrongdoing for any reason, then the department head, with the approval of the city administrator, may suspend the employee with or without pay pending the completion of the investigation. An employee who is suspended shall be given written notice of the reasons for the action and a copy forwarded to the city administrator to be made part of the regular employee's personal history record. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.820 - Disciplinary action. 
    When an employee has been convicted of an alcohol or drug-related driving violation, and when driving is a major component of the employee's job, he or she may be subject to the following disciplinary action. The disciplinary action will vary depending on the situation but may include: 
A.  Administrative leave as deemed appropriate by the administration pending satisfactory completion of an approved drug and alcohol rehabilitation program. Employee will be required to use accrued sick leave and vacation time for the period of drug and alcohol evaluation and rehabilitation. Thereafter, employee's leave will be without pay. 
B.  For a period of six months, employee may be deemed a probationary employee as defined in Article 4 of these rules and regulations. 
C.  Employee will be subject to unannounced drug or alcohol testing at any time. 
D.  In the event the employee's license is revoked and the employee's job requires that they have a valid driver's license, the employee may be dismissed or placed on leave without pay if no other position is available or accommodations are unreasonable until the license is reinstated. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.825 - Disciplinary suspension. 
A.  In the interest of good discipline, a department head may for just cause suspend an employee without pay for any length of time up to thirty (30) days in a single year. An employee who is suspended shall be given written notice of the reasons for the action and a copy forwarded to the city administrator to be made part of the regular employee's personal history record. 
B.  During investigation, hearing or trial of a regular employee on any civil cause or criminal charge, when suspension would be in the interest of the city, a regular employee may be suspended for the duration of the proceedings. This suspension shall terminate within five days after completion of the case for which he or she was suspended by resignation or dismissal of the employee, by reinstatement with full recovery of all pay and other benefits lost during the period of suspension or by other appropriate action. Approval of the city administrator shall be required in all cases involving suspension of regular employees. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.830 - Demotion. 
A.  A regular employee may be demoted for just cause. A demotion may be accomplished by assigning him to a position of lower classification. An employee who is demoted must be given written notice by his department head or supervisor of the reasons for the action. Reduction in pay as set forth in Section 2.88.550 shall be effective at the beginning of a pay period following demotion. 
B.  A regular employee may request or accept voluntary demotion when assignment of less difficult or responsible work would be to his advantage and in the interest of the city. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.835 - Termination. 
A.  Employment with the city is considered to be "at will." An employee may resign at any time and the city may terminate employment, with or without cause, at any time for any reason not prohibited by law. 
B.  All regular employees terminated by the city administrator shall have the right to appeal the discharge to the board of aldermen provided such appeal is filed in writing with the city clerk within fifteen (15) days after the date of dismissal. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.840 - Grievance. 
    When any question arises concerning the validity of an order of a supervisor, employees shall complete the task assigned. If they then have any complaint, they will settle it with their supervisor, if possible. If they are unable to get satisfaction from their supervisor, they have the right to use appeal procedures as described below. 
A.  Regular employees who have any complaints regarding the application or policy to themselves have the right to appeal to their immediate supervisor or to their department head in the order named until the complaint is settled. Appeal may be made in writing within five days of the incident. 
B.  The complaint procedure shall be simple and informal. Department heads or supervisors may require signed complaint notices at their discretion, but all discussions shall be conducted in a manner most conducive to quick and satisfactory solution of the problems involved. 
C.  Any complaint not settled in a department within five days may be carried to the city administrator for settlement. The city administrator shall hear or investigate all sides of the case and shall render a decision. The decision will be provided in writing within five days of the rendering of the department head's settlement recommendation. 
D.  When a grievance involves an elected official, then the employee shall follow the procedure set forth in Section 2.08.105 of this code. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5479, § 2, 12-3-13) 
2.88.845 - Resignation. 
    To resign in good standing, an employee shall submit their resignation in writing to their department head at least two weeks before the effective date of their resignation. After approval by the department head, the resignation shall be forwarded to the city administrator with a final evaluation of performance. When the employee submits their resignation, their department head shall contact the personnel clerk to arrange an exit interview for the employee. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
Article 9. - Employee Standards 

2.88.900 - Appearance. 
    While on duty for the city of Perryville, employees shall maintain an appearance that projects a positive image for the city of Perryville. If uniforms are provided by the city of Perryville, the employees shall wear the shirts and/or uniforms designated. If an employee wears their uniform while off-duty, they shall continue to maintain an appearance that projects a positive image for the city of Perryville. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.905 - Nepotism. 
    The city administrator shall not approve the appointment of any member of the immediate family of a supervisor to that supervisor's work group, nor shall the appointment of any member of the immediate family of any department head be approved unless the city administrator shall determine the necessity therefor because of the lack of qualified applicants for such position. No member of the immediate family of any board member, the mayor or the city administrator can be considered for employment. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.908 - Employees not to serve on any appointed city board. 
    No person who is a non-elected full-time or part-time employee of the city shall be appointed to or serve on any appointed city board. 
(Ord. No. 6054 , § 4, 7-3-18) 
2.88.910 - Relationship between co-workers. 
A.  From and after December 1, 2001, it shall be a violation of the personnel rules and regulations for a husband and wife (or individuals cohabitating) to work in the same department of the government of the city of Perryville. Any married couple employed in the same department prior to December 1, 2001, may continue their current employment. 
B.  Nothing in this section shall prohibit a husband and wife (or individuals cohabitating) from working in separate departments of the government of the city of Perryville. 
C.  If any party works in the same department of the government of the city of Perryville and chooses to marry (or cohabitate with) another person employed in the same department, then the employees shall notify their department head and request a transfer to another department. If no opportunity for transfer to another department exists, then one of the two employees shall immediately upon marriage (or cohabitation) terminate their employment with the city of Perryville. 
D.  Dating and romantic or sexual relationships between superior and subordinate are expressly prohibited and the superior found to be engaging, or attempting to engage, in such activity will be disciplined up to and including dismissal. 
E.  Peer dating and romantic or sexual relationships between employees not in a superior/subordinate position are generally discouraged. Employees electing to engage in such relationships shall report said relationship to the personnel clerk immediately. The department head will make every effort to schedule employees in such a manner as to minimize workplace distractions. 
F.  Employees involved in such personal relationships shall not engage in public displays of affection while at the workplace. 
G.  For purposes of this section, a department is defined as a division of the government of the city of Perryville under the supervision of a department head. Such department shall include, but not be limited to, city hall administration, police, fire, public works, parks and recreation. 
H.  This section shall apply to both full-time and part-time employees. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5423, § 1, 5-21-13) 
2.88.915 - Outside employment. 
A.  Outside employment is defined to include any work activity that is designed to generate income including working for an employer, independent contracting, and self-employment. 
B.  The city administration generally discourages employees from engaging in outside employment. An employee who desires outside employment shall submit his/her written request to do so to his/her department head. The department head shall review said request and forward it to the city administrator with a recommendation for approval or denial. The city administrator shall respond to the request in writing within five days of receipt thereof. With respect to the police department, it is provided that the decision of the city marshal regarding outside employment is final and without recourse. For all other departments, the city administrator's decision is final and without recourse. 
C.  No request for outside employment shall be considered until after an employee's successful completion of his/her probationary period. 
D.  Any approval of outside employment is contingent on an employee remaining successful in the performance of his/her normal duties. 
E.  Any approval of outside employment is contingent on the employee complying with all applicable business license requirements of Chapter 5.04 of this code. 
F.  An employee's current city employment must take precedence over his/her outside employment. Outside employment shall not interfere with one's city employment. At the point this occurs, the employee may be directed to discontinue either employment. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5423, § 2, 5-21-13; Ord. No. 5524, § 1, 5-20-14) 
2.88.920 - Political activity. 
A.  Employees shall not circulate petitions or campaign literature for elective city officials or be in any way concerned with soliciting or receiving any subscription, contribution or political service from any person for any such elective official. 
B.  All employees of the city may become candidates for city elective offices upon compliance with the following conditions: 
1.  Affirmatively request and accept an unpaid leave of absence from the date of filing for candidate for city office until election date; and 
2.  Acknowledge in writing that fringe benefits shall be suspended during the leave of absence, except for those benefits which the employee-candidate chooses to maintain at his expense; and 
3.  Acknowledge in writing that the employee-candidate's election to a municipal office shall constitute resignation from the employee-candidate's previous city position. 
C.  All employees of the city shall resign from their city position on or before the assumption of duties of a partisan public or political office that is incompatible with their city position. For purposes of this section, "incompatible" shall mean functions and duties that conflict, clash or are at variance with one another. 
D.  In accordance with Section 67.145, RSMo., nothing herein shall prohibit any first responder, as the term first responder is defined in Section 192.800, RSMo., from engaging in any political activity while off duty and not in uniform, being a candidate for elected or appointed public office, or holding such office unless such political activity or candidacy is otherwise prohibited by state or federal law. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 5492, § 1, 2-18-14) 
2.88.925 - Solicitations. 
    No solicitation of funds of any character or for any purpose whatsoever shall be permitted among city employees on the job without the express approval of the department head and the city administrator. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.930 - Drug-free workplace policy. 
    The city of Perryville strictly prohibits the illicit use, possession, dispensation, distribution, or manufacture of controlled substances in the workplace. Being under the influence of alcoholic beverages or non-prescription drugs is prohibited in the workplace or while on duty. 
    The city may require an employee to undergo testing for drugs or alcohol if his or her supervisor has a reasonable suspicion that he or she has drugs or alcohol in his or her system. Any employee found to be under the influence of intoxicants or controlled substances, not specifically prescribed by a licensed physician, will be immediately removed from duty and subject to federal regulations, if applicable, disciplinary action, up to and including termination, as well as other legal action as appropriate. Individuals who engage in conduct prohibited by the drug-free workplace policy or who fail to cooperate with any investigation or testing will be subject to disciplinary action, up to and including discharge, as well as other legal action as appropriate. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
(Ord. No. 6046 , § 2, 6-19-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6046 , § 2, adopted June 19, 2018, amended § 2.88.930 and in so doing changed the title of said section from "Use of intoxicants or controlled substances. (Drug-free workplace)" to "Drug-free workplace policy," as set out herein. 
2.88.931 - Adoption of provisions of Code of Federal Regulations. 
    The city hereby adopts 49 CFR Part 40; 49 CFR Part 199; and 49 CFR Parts 192, 193, and 195 of the Code of Federal Regulations 2017 for all safety sensitive employees working for the city. All drug testing procedures contained in these federal regulations shall control in dealing with employee accidents by safety sensitive employees or drug or alcohol use by safety sensitive employees. 
(Ord. No. 6046 , § 3, 6-19-18) 
2.88.932 - Safety sensitive employees. 
    A safety sensitive employee is any employee who spends a considerable portion of his or her day driving a vehicle of or for the city, carries a firearm, or operates equipment of the city that could affect the safety of said employee or other employees or members of the public at large as further defined by Chapter 49 CFR of the Code of Federal Regulations. Examples of safety sensitive employees would be, but not be limited to: 
A.  Employees who perform covered functions under 49 CFR Part 40 (DOT regulations). 
B.  Employees who perform covered functions under 49 CFR Part 199 (PHMSA regulations). 
C.  Employees who are commissioned or non-commissioned law enforcement. 
D.  City lifeguards or pool safety personnel within the park and recreation department. 
E.  Employees in other departments or job descriptions as deemed appropriate by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 6046 , § 4, 6-19-18) 
2.88.933 - Drug/Alcohol testing. 
A.  Pre-Employment. The examination of safety sensitive employees as defined in Section 2.88.932 shall include a urine test to determine the presence of unauthorized or illegal substances pursuant to federal regulations. A negative test will be a condition of employment. The city will not hire any applicant who refuses to undergo said drug testing or whose drug test is confirmed to be positive. 
B.  Random. Safety sensitive employees as defined in Section 2.88.932 are subject to unannounced testing based on a random, scientifically based selection as defined by federal regulations. Employees who test positive will be subject to federal regulation requirements and disciplinary procedures. 
C.  Post-Accident or On-The-Job Injury. Post-accident or on-the-job injury drug and/or alcohol testing for safety sensitive employees as defined in Section 2.88.932 will be governed by federal regulations. Post-accident or on-the-job injury for non-safety sensitive employees will be based upon supervisor and/or department head discretion as defined in Section 2.88.935 workplace accidents/injuries. 
D.  Reasonable Suspicion or For Cause. The city will require any employee reasonably suspected of being under the influence of alcohol and/or drugs, and so documented, to be tested by qualified personnel for the use of drugs and/or alcohol based upon federal regulation requirements and disciplinary procedures. 
E.  Return-to-Duty. Return-to-duty testing will be based upon federal regulation requirements. 
F.  Follow-Up. Follow-up testing will be based upon federal regulation requirements. 
G.  Refusal to Test. A refusal to comply with a directive to undergo a drug or alcohol test will be treated in the same manner as a positive screen. Discipline, up to and including termination, is the penalty for failing a drug or alcohol screen. 
H.  Violations. Any drug and/or alcohol violation will be considered misconduct and will be subject to federal regulation requirements and disciplinary procedures, up to and including, termination. 
I.  Employees not Covered by Federal Regulations. Employees who test positive for drugs or alcohol but are not subject to specific federal regulations shall be subject to the city progressive discipline procedure, shall be required to successfully complete a prescribed program through EAP, and shall be subject to one year of random drug or alcohol testing. 
(Ord. No. 6046 , § 5, 6-19-18) 
2.88.935 - Workplace accidents/injuries. 
    In the event of an injury or accident at the workplace, the employee(s) shall immediately report the incident to his or her department head. The department head must follow the necessary guidelines as set forth in the city's worker's compensation injuries/illnesses instructions. This section shall apply equally to both the driver/operator and the passenger, spotter, or co-worker involved in the incident. 
A.  Any work-related accident or injury may be determined to be cause for the employee to submit to a drug and/or alcohol test. All employees shall comply with the drug and/or testing policies of the city. 
B.  In the event any employee is involved in an accident in a city vehicle at any time or in any other vehicle while conducting city business, the employee shall immediately report such accident to his or her department head and may be required to submit to any drug and/or alcohol test required by the department head. If the supervisor or department head deems it necessary for the safety of the employee or other individuals, that employee shall not be allowed to drive but shall be driven to and from the appropriate testing facility and in the sole discretion of the supervisor or department head may not be allowed to return to work. 
C.  All other work-related accidents (non-vehicular) must be reported to the employee's supervisor. At the discretion of the supervisor, a drug test may be required. 
D.  In the event any employee sustains an injury or develops a disability, the city may require that employee to undergo a physical and/or mental examination to determine what, if any, accommodations need to be made for the employee under existing law and to determine the employee's ability to safely and effectively complete the requirements of employment with the city. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007; Ord. No. 6046 , § 6, 6-19-18) 
2.88.940 - Employee use and operation of city vehicles or equipment. 
A.  City employees are not automatically entitled to use city vehicles or equipment. Where an employee is given the responsibility of operating city vehicles or equipment and caring for it, the employee's continued access and privilege to use the vehicle or equipment will depend on the employee's responsible operation, care, and use of the vehicle or equipment. 
B.  City vehicles are to be used strictly for city business, and any personal errands must be approved by the city administrator. Minimum reasonable stops at stores or other places of business which do not interfere with the performance of an employee's duties do not require prior approval. However, this privilege should not be abused. After normal working hours an employee shall only use a city vehicle if on official city business. 
C.  Employees are not permitted to transport family members using city vehicles, apart from exceptional cases approved by the city administrator. No employee residing outside the corporate limits of the city of Perryville shall be permitted to take a city vehicle home. 
D.  It is the responsibility of the employee assigned the vehicle or equipment to keep the vehicle or equipment clean, in good repair, and to follow a regular maintenance schedule. An employee must immediately report any loss, damage, or malfunction of a city vehicle or equipment. In the event that the damage, destruction, or loss to the vehicle or equipment is due to an employee's negligence, the employee understands that restitution may be required in addition to appropriate disciplinary action being taken. The city is not responsible for any lost or damaged personal property of the employee stored or located in city-owned vehicles or equipment. 
E.  It is a condition of employment with the city of Perryville that all employees who drive city vehicles or operate motorized equipment maintain a valid driver's license at all times appropriate for the type of vehicle or equipment being operated. 
F.  Employees shall drive in a safe and prudent manner and obey all applicable federal, state, and local traffic laws and regulations while driving or operating city-owned vehicles or equipment. Employees shall wear seatbelts or other safety restraint devices properly when operating or riding in city-owned vehicles or equipment. In the event of an accident or collision, whether resulting in injury to any person or property damage of any kind, the employee shall immediately report the accident to the appropriate law enforcement agency, as well as the employee's supervisor. Employees involved in an accident or collision may be required to submit to a drug and/or alcohol test as required by the department head. 
G.  Employees shall under no circumstances use or be under the influence of alcohol or drugs while driving or operating city-owned vehicles or equipment. Employees shall not use tobacco products while driving or riding in city-owned vehicles or equipment. 
H.  Immediately upon termination or separation of employment, city employees who are assigned city vehicles and equipment shall promptly return city property to the appropriate personnel. 
I.  No employee may use any city-owned vehicle, equipment, or property either in support of or in opposition to the nomination or election of any candidate for public office, or for any other political purpose. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007; Ord. No. 6046 , § 7, 6-19-18) 
2.88.945 - Misuse of electronic communications. 
A.  Telephonic and electronic communication systems and all information transmitted by, received from, or stored in these systems including city-owned mobile phones is the property of the city of Perryville. City premises and any work area provided by the city, including desks, computers, files, or lockers, are city property and may be accessed or inspected at any time without prior notice by authority of supervisory personnel. Any personal belongings or information which the employee intends to keep private should not be brought to or kept on city property. 
B.  Internet, e-mail or phone mail shall not be used to transmit or receive vulgar, profane, insulting, pornographic, or offensive messages or material, such as racial or sexual slurs. Prohibited uses of internet, e-mail and phone mail include, but are not limited to, soliciting outside business ventures, advertising for personal enterprises, soliciting for noncity-related purposes, gambling, or viewing pornographic sites or material. 
Employees are not permitted to use passwords, access a file, or retrieve any stored communication unless authorized to do so, or unless they have received prior clearance from an authorized management representative. All passwords are the property of the city. 
C.  Authorized representatives of the city, from time to time, may monitor the use of such equipment. Such monitoring may include accessing recorded messages, printing or reading data files by city employees who are authorized to do so by management. 
    Employees who violate this policy are subject to disciplinary action, up to, and including termination. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
2.88.950 - Labor organizations. 
A.  Supervisory Employees. Supervisory employees are required to conduct themselves in a manner that benefits the interests of the city of Perryville and to carry out policies established by the mayor and board of aldermen or the designees of the mayor and board of aldermen of the city of Perryville. Supervisory employees shall at all times be cognizant of the statutory obligations of the city of Perryville relative to any labor organization certified by the Missouri Labor and Industrial Relations Commission and shall not engage in any activity that interferes with or adversely affects the rights of the city of Perryville relative to any labor organization representing employees of the city of Perryville. No supervisory employee shall participate in organizing activities for any labor organization desiring to represent employees of the city of Perryville. 
B.  Union Activity During Working Time. No employee shall use any work time paid by the city of Perryville for union organizing, union grievance processing or meet and confer activity. All union-related activity shall be conducted at a location away from the employee's normal work areas. 
C.  Statutory Requirements. In accordance with Section 105.520, RSMo., the city of Perryville shall appoint one or more representatives to meet, confer and discuss with representatives of any labor organization certified by the Missouri Labor and Industrial Relations Commission. 
D.  Employee Correction or Discipline.
