From time to time the department head or other supervisory employees will meet with employees for the purpose of explaining or correcting work performance or activity. Those meetings shall be conducted in a manner established by the department head. No person shall be present at those meetings except as authorized by the department head. Employee discipline shall be conducted as set forth in the ordinances of the city of Perryville. 
E.  Appearance. Political, fraternal, organizational or membership items of any type or kind shall not be worn or displayed while on duty. 
F.  Posting Notices or Advertisements. No advertisements or notices of any type concerning labor organizations shall be posted on city property unless required by the Missouri Labor and Industrial Relations Commission or unless approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. 4866 § 2 (part), 2007) 
Title 3 - REVENUE AND FINANCE 
Chapters: 
Chapter 3.04 - FISCAL PROVISIONS GENERALLY 

3.04.010 - Fiscal year designated. 
    The fiscal year of the city shall commence on the first day of April and terminate on the thirty-first (31st) day of March of each year. 
(Prior code § 2-2) 
3.04.020 - City depositories. 
A.  The banking institutions located within the city shall from time to time be selected and designated the official depositories of the funds of the city. 
B.  Each of the banking institutions designated as a depository shall post bonds of the United States, the state of Missouri, or other securities of like character, for the faithful performance of all obligations and duties devolving upon them under and by virtue of the laws of this state in order to qualify as a depository. The value of the securities deposited in and maintained by any such banking institution shall at all times be not less than one hundred (100) percent of the actual amount of the funds on deposit with the depository, less the amount, if any, insured by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. 
C.  Depositories shall be designated by the board of aldermen under the terms and conditions stated herein in intervals of not less than three years. 
(Ord. 3658 § 1, 1998: prior code § 2-3) 
3.04.030 - Disbursement of funds. 
A.  No money shall be paid out of the city treasury except upon a warrant signed by the mayor and attested to by the city clerk. 
B.  No appropriation of money shall be made by the mayor and board of aldermen, and no warrant shall be drawn by the city clerk or paid by the city treasurer, unless the amount of money remaining in the city treasury to the credit of the fund or appropriation upon which the warrant is to be drawn shall be sufficient to pay the same. 
C.  No warrant shall be drawn on the city treasury in favor of any officer who is in arrears to the city, nor in favor of any person indebted to the city, except for the amount due such officer or person in excess of such arrears or indebtedness. 
(Prior code § 2-4) 
3.04.035 - Reserve fund policy. 
A.  Capital Reserve Balances. In addition to meeting its bonding requirements, the city will annually budget to maintain an unrestricted capital reserve equal to twenty-five (25) percent of its annual operating expenses in the general revenue and enterprise funds. Utilization of cash reserves shall require the approval of the board of aldermen. Revenues earned in these accounts may be transferred among the other accounts as allowable by law in an effort to promote efficient operations and maintain reasonable user rates. 
B.  Working Capital Balances. The city shall annually budget to maintain a working capital balance equal to three months of operating expenses in the general revenue, enterprise, and transportation trust funds. These balances may fluctuate over the course of operations but shall not be an amount less than two months of operating expenses or an amount greater than four months of operating expenses without the city administrator advising the board of aldermen. In addition, revenues earned in these same accounts may be transferred among the other accounts as allowable by law in an effort to promote efficient operations and maintain reasonable user rates. 
(Ord. No. 5534, § 1, 7-1-14) 
3.04.040 - Policy for contracts, purchases, specifications, contract requirements-Contracting for capital improvements, equipment, services, materials and repairs. 
    The city administrator or his designate, after approval by the board of aldermen of the city of Perryville, is authorized and directed to establish a policy for contracts, purchases, specifications, contract requirements, (and other matters relating to) contracting for capital improvements, equipment, services, materials and repairs, which policy is adopted by reference and incorporated in this chapter as if fully set forth. A copy of the policy shall remain on file in the office of the city clerk for public reference. 
(Ord. 4523 § 1, 2004) 
3.04.050 - Policy for the development of subdivisions and construction of water, sewer and gas utility lines. 
A.  It is the policy of the city that it is in the best interest of the residents of the city that development within the city limits of Perryville be encouraged and advanced. 
B.  The board of aldermen is authorized to provide a separate fund as part of the budgeting process each fiscal year which fund is to be known as the "Utility Expansion Fund" and the board may consider each fiscal year the recommendation of the city administrator or his designate concerning the amount to be budgeted to said fund. 
C.  Any "subdivider" as defined in Section 16.04.020 of the code may apply to the city for the city to install water, sewer and gas utility lines with the costs of the installation of water, sewer and gas utility lines to be paid from the "Utility Expansion Fund" provided that: 
1.  A first lien is imposed on each lot served in an amount equal to the amount expended by the city divided by the number of lots served. 
2.  The amount due shall bear interest at an amount equal to the highest amount received by the city for city funds under Section 3.04.020 of the code at the time the "Utility Expansion Fund" is accessed for the project. 
3.  The amount due on each subdivision lot plus interest shall be paid at the time each lot is sold and no clear title shall be granted to any lot until and unless said amount is paid. 
4.  Any amount and accrued interest not paid within ten (10) years of the date that the "Utility Expansion Fund" is accessed for the project will be due and payable on the first day of the one hundred and twentieth (120th) month following the date that the "Utility Expansion Fund" is accessed, provided, however, that the board of aldermen may authorize such partial payments or extensions as it deems fit and proper. 
(Ord. 4938 § 1, 2008) 
3.04.060 - Required protest of any tax, fee or other payment to the city. 
    Any person, group, firm, corporation or any other entity disputing or objecting to any tax, fee or other payment to the city must file a written protest with the city clerk within thirty (30) days of payment of the tax, fee or other payment to the city. The protest shall contain the specific reasons for the protest and the mailing address to which any decision shall be mailed. A hearing before the board of aldermen shall be set within ninety (90) days of the filing of the written protest and the complainant shall be notified by mail of the hearing date. At said hearing the complainant and the city may present evidence. Thereafter, the board of aldermen shall render a written decision on the protest within ninety (90) days of the hearing and the complainant shall be notified of the decision by mail. The complainant aggrieved by the decision of the board of aldermen may appeal the decision to the circuit court within thirty (30) days of the mailing date of the decision. Any tax, fee or other payment to the city made prior to November 1, 2010, shall be protested by December 1, 2010. Any claim, suit or action concerning any tax, fee or other payment to the city is barred if protest is not timely filed as required in this section. 
(Ord. No. 5165, § 1, 11-1-10) 
Chapter 3.08 - PROPERTY TAXES 

3.08.010 - Property taxable. 
    For the support of the city government, the payment of the outstanding indebtedness and for the advancement of the public interest and improvement of the city, taxes shall be levied on all property, real and personal, subject to taxation for state, county and city purposes. 
(Prior code § 25-1) 
3.08.015 - Contract with county collector for collection of city property taxes. 
A.  The city shall contract with the county of Perry and the Perry County collector for the billing and collection of the city's personal and real estate property taxes as provided under Article VI, Section 16, of the Missouri Constitution; Section 70.220, et seq., RSMo; and Section 140.670, et seq., RSMo. 
B.  The county of Perry and the Perry County collector shall be responsible for maintaining and operating the tax collection system for the city. 
C.  The city shall pay to the county of Perry for the collection of the city's personal and real estate property taxes an amount equal to three percent of all taxes collected by the county of Perry in any year. 
D.  The agreement among the city, the county of Perry, and the Perry County collector shall be known as the "Agreement for the Collection of Taxes for the City of Perryville, Missouri," and shall govern the terms and conditions of the agreement among the parties. 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 6, 4-19-16) 
3.08.020 - Abstract of assessor's books to be obtained by clerk and delivered to board. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to procure from the county clerk, on or before the first day of July of each year, a certified abstract from his assessment books of all properties within the city made taxable for state purposes, and the assessed value thereof, as agreed upon by the board of equalization, which abstract shall be immediately transmitted to the board of aldermen." 
(Prior code § 25-2) 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 7, 4-19-16) 
3.08.030 - Board to fix rate of levy. 
    The board of aldermen shall, within a reasonable time after the certified abstract of the county clerk's assessment books have been transmitted to it for each year, ascertain the amount of money to be raised thereon for general and other purposes, and fix the annual rate of levy therefor by ordinance. 
(Prior code § 25-3) 
3.08.040 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5748, § 8, adopted April 19, 2016, repealed § 3.08.040, which pertained to tax books-tax and license charges-clerk's authority and derived from prior code § 25-4. 
3.08.050 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5748, § 9, adopted April 19, 2016, repealed § 3.08.050, which pertained to tax book-copy to collector and derived from prior code § 25-6. 
3.08.060 - Taxes payable when. 
    All taxes under this chapter for each year shall become due and payable at the same time and in the same manner as county taxes. 
(Prior code § 25-7) 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 10, 4-19-16) 
3.08.070 - Failure to pay taxes-Penalty. 
    If any taxpayer shall fail or refuse to pay his city taxes at the time and in the manner required by the general laws of this state in relation to the collection of state and county taxes, he shall be liable to the same penalties for such failure or refusal to so pay such taxes as are now or may hereafter be in force in this state for failure or refusal to pay state and county taxes under like conditions. 
(Prior code § 25-8) 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 11, 4-19-16) 
3.08.080 - Enforcement of payment of taxes. 
    The enforcement of all taxes authorized by this chapter shall be made in the same manner as is provided by the laws of this state for the collection and enforcement of the payment of state and county taxes, including the seizure and sale of goods and chattels after the taxes become delinquent; provided, however, that all suits for the collection of city taxes shall be brought in the name of the state, at the relation and to the use of the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 25-9) 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 12, 4-19-16) 
3.08.090 - Property liable for taxation. 
    Every person owning or holding property on January 1, including all such property purchased on that day, shall be liable for taxes thereon for the ensuing year. 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 13, 4-19-16) 
3.08.100 - When taxes become delinquent. 
    City taxes shall become delinquent on January 1 for the preceding year. 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 14, 4-19-16) 
3.08.110 - Back taxes to be lien in favor of city. 
    Real property shall in all cases be liable for taxes thereon to the city and the lien created in favor of the city by virtue of state law for delinquent and back taxes due upon real estate shall be enforced as provided by Missouri state statutes. 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 15, 4-19-16) 
Chapter 3.12 - ELECTRICITY COMPANY TAX 
Sections: 

3.12.010 - Levied. 
    Every person engaged in the business of supplying electricity for any purpose in the city for compensation shall pay to the city a tax in the amount of five percent of the gross receipts from such business. 
(Prior code § 25-20) 
3.12.020 - Statement to be filed. 
    Every person engaged in business of supplying electricity for any purpose in the city for compensation shall file with the city clerk, on the tenth day of each month, a sworn statement of the gross receipts from such business for the month immediately preceding the filing of such statement. 
(Prior code § 25-21) 
3.12.030 - Examination of statement. 
    The city clerk, or his duly authorized deputy, is authorized to investigate the accuracy of the statement required to be filed by this chapter and, for such purpose, he shall have access at all reasonable times to the books, documents, papers and records of any person making the statement in order to ascertain the accuracy thereof. 
(Prior code § 25-22) 
3.12.040 - Payment. 
    Every person engaged in the business of supplying electricity for any purpose in the city for compensation shall pay to the city, on or before the fifteenth day of each month, an amount equal to five percent of the gross receipts from such business for the preceding month. 
(Prior code § 25-23) 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 16, 4-19-16) 
3.12.050 - Construction of provisions. 
    The tax required to be paid by this chapter shall be in lieu of any other occupation tax required of any person engaged in the business of supplying electricity for any purpose in the city for compensation; but nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as to exempt such person from the payment to the city of the tax which the city levies upon the real or personal property belonging to such person; nor from the tax required of merchants or manufacturers for the sale of anything other than electricity; nor from the payment of any other tax of such business. 
(Prior code § 25-24) 
Chapter 3.16 - TELEPHONE COMPANY TAX 
Sections: 

3.16.010 - Levied. 
    Every person engaged in the business of supplying telephone service for any purpose in the city for compensation shall pay to the city a tax in the amount of five percent of the gross receipts from such business. "Telephone service" for the purpose of this chapter shall mean any service providing person-to-person communication services which is offered to the public for a fee, including, but not limited to, telephone, wire, cellular, digital and electronic. 
(Ord. 4136 § 1, 2001: prior code § 25-35) 
3.16.020 - Statement to be filed. 
    Every person engaged in the business of supplying telephone service for any purpose in the city for compensation shall file with the city clerk, on the tenth day of January and on the tenth day of July of each year, a sworn statement of the gross receipts from such business for the six months immediately preceding the filing of such statement. 
(Prior code § 25-36) 
3.16.030 - Examination of statement. 
    The city clerk, or his duly authorized deputy, is authorized to investigate the accuracy of the statement required to be filed by this chapter and, for such purpose, he shall have access at all reasonable times to the books, documents, papers and records of any person making the statement in order to ascertain the accuracy thereof. 
(Prior code § 25-37) 
3.16.040 - Payment. 
    Every person engaged in the business of supplying telephone service for any purpose in the city for compensation shall pay to the city, on or before the fifth day of January and on or before the fifth day of July of each year, an amount equal to five percent of the gross receipts from such business for the preceding six months. 
(Prior code § 25-38) 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 17, 4-19-16) 
3.16.050 - Construction of provisions. 
    The tax required to be paid by this chapter shall be in lieu of any other occupation tax required of any person engaged in the business of supplying telephone service for any purpose in the city for compensation; but nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed as to exempt such person from the payment to the city of the tax which the city levies upon real or personal property belonging to the person; nor from the tax required of merchants or manufacturers for the sale of anything other than telephone service; nor from the payment of any other tax of such business. 
(Prior code § 25-39) 
3.16.060 - Municipal Telecommunications Business License Tax Simplification Act-Compliance under Sections 92.074, et seq., RSMo. 
A.  Construction. To the extent required by law, in all respects, this chapter shall be interpreted, construed and applied consistent with the requirements of Sections 92.074 through 92.098 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. In the event that Sections 92.074, et seq., RSMo, are found to be inapplicable or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction, then this section shall be deemed to be null and void and the code of the city as it existed prior to the passage of this section shall be deemed to control. 
B.  Definitions. All terms used in Title 3, Chapter 3.16, of this code shall be deemed to be as set forth in Sections 92.077 and 92.083 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
C.  Tax Levied. 
1.  Every person now or hereafter engaged in the business of selling telephone or telegraph service for compensation for any purpose in the city shall pay to the city, as a license or occupation tax, five percent of the gross receipts from such business in the city. 
2.  To the extent required by law, the city administrator of the city is authorized and directed to promulgate and publish the revenue neutral rates to be applied in the city for bills to be rendered on or after July 1, 2006, based on the rate information supplied by the director of revenue of the state of Missouri. 
3.  Effective July 1, 2006, to the extent required by law, notwithstanding the provisions of any municipal business license tax ordinance (as defined in Section 92.077, RSMo), this tax shall be based solely and exclusively on those gross receipts of telecommunications companies (being any company doing business in the state of Missouri that provides telecommunications services) for the retail sale of telecommunications services which are subject to taxation under Sections 144.010 and 144.020 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
4.  To the extent required or permitted by law, for bills rendered on and after July 1, 2006, the tax rate shall be five percent or the revenue neutral rates as promulgated and published, with the highest rate being applicable so long as it is in compliance with the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
5.  To the extent required by law, for bills rendered on and after July 1, 2007, the tax rate shall be adjusted as promulgated and published by the director of the department of revenue for the state of Missouri pursuant to Section 92.086, RSMo. The city shall notify the director of the department of revenue in writing within thirty (30) days of any change in the tax rate to the extent required by Section 92.086, RSMo. 
D.  Violations-Penalties. 
1.  Any person engaged in any of the businesses described in Title 3, Chapter 3.16, of this code who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be subject to punishment as provided in Section 1.16.010 of this code. 
2.  Delinquent taxes under this chapter shall be subject to the penalties as provided for by other ordinances of the city, now or hereafter enacted, relating to penalties upon delinquent taxes. 
3.  To the extent required by law, unless specifically stated otherwise in Sections 92.074 through 92.098 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, taxpayer remedies, enforcement mechanisms, tax refunds, tax protests, assessments and all other procedures regarding the tax imposed by this chapter shall be the same as those provided in Chapter 144, RSMo. 
(Ord. 4748 § 1, 2006) 
Chapter 3.20 - TRANSPORTATION SALES TAX 
Sections: 

3.20.010 - Imposed. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted by and subject to the provisions of Sections 94.600 through 94.650, Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1978, as amended, a tax for transportation purposes is imposed on all sellers for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling tangible personal property or rendering taxable services at retail to the extent and in the manner provided in Chapter 144 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1978, and the rules and regulations of the director of revenue issued pursuant thereto. The rate of tax shall be one-half of one percent on the receipts from sale at retail of all tangible personal property or taxable services at retail within the city limits, if such property and taxable services are subject to taxation by the state of Missouri under the provisions of Chapter 144, Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1978, as amended. The tax shall become effective as provided in subsection 5 of Section 94.605, Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1978, as amended, and shall be collected pursuant to the provisions of Sections 94.600 through 94.650, Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1978, as amended. 
(Prior code § 25-51) 
Title 5 - BUSINESS LICENSES AND REGULATIONS 
Chapter 5.04 - BUSINESS LICENSES GENERALLY 

5.04.010 - Scope-Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all corporations, companies, associations, joint stock associations, partnerships, co-partnerships and persons and their lessees, duly constituted trustees or receivers, heirs, administrators or assigns, who shall engage in any business, trade, vocation, profession or occupation including manufacturing, within the city limits; specifically excepting those professions or callings exempted from license requirements by virtue of RSMo. 71.620, which are as follows: minister of the gospel, duly accredited Christian Science practitioner, teacher, professor in a college, priest, lawyer, certified public accountant, dentist, chiropractor, optometrist, chiropodist or physician or surgeon in the state; and also specifically exempting farmers or producers, for the sale of produce raised by them when sold from their wagon, cart or vehicle or from any person in the employ of such farmers or producers in the city, as provided in RSMo. 71.630. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to any persons following for a livelihood the profession of veterinarian, architect, professional engineer, land surveyor, auctioneer, or real estate broker or salesman in this state unless that person maintains a business office within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Prior code §§ 16-11, 16-12) 
5.04.020 - Definitions. 
    Terms used in this chapter shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    "Appliance dealers" means any person who shall buy, manufacture or assemble and sell or offer for sale any televisions, radios, washers, dryers, cooking stoves, dishwashers or other appliances for use in the home. 
    "Architect" means any person who plans or designs buildings or ground for others, or who supervises and oversees the construction, alteration, repair or remodeling of the same. 
    "Auctioneer" means any person who shall sell or offer to sell any goods, wares or merchandise, or any real or personal property, or any interest therein, at public outcry to the highest bidder, for a fee or commission. 
    "Auto accessory dealer" means any person who shall buy, manufacture or assemble and sell or offer for sale any tires or other fixtures, appliances or accessories to or for automobiles, trucks or trailers except persons, etc., who are licensed as merchants. 
    "Automobile dealer" means any person who shall buy, for the purpose of sale or trade, or who shall sell, trade or offer to sell or trade automobiles or motor vehicles. 
    "Bakery" means any shop, stand, store or place where bread, cakes, cupcakes, doughnuts, pies, pastries and/or similar products are manufactured, prepared, sold or offered for sale, except a person licensed to do business as a merchant who sells but does not manufacture such products. 
    "Bank" means any place of business or establishment where money and/or valuables are deposited, kept, issued, loaned and/or exchanged. 
    "Barber" means any person who for a consideration cuts or trims the hair or beard, or performs any of the other services commonly offered in barbershops, or offers to do so. 
    "Beauty parlor" means any shop, room, stand or place where for a consideration service, substances, services or things designed or intended to improve or enhance the appearance are sold or dispensed. 
    "Billiard table" or "pool table" means any table, platform, or devise designed and used for playing the game of pool or pocket billiards. 
    "Billposter" means any person who shall tack, nail, paste or otherwise attach to billboards, fences, buildings or other structures, any bills, notices, posters, signs or other advertising material, except legal notices issued by or under the direction of the court. 
    "Blacksmith shop" means any shop, stand or place where horses are shod, and/or metal is worked or fashioned or metal objects are made, altered or repaired. 
    "Bottling works" means any place or establishment where soft drinks or other liquids are prepared and bottled. 
    "Bowling alley" means any room, stand or place equipped and used for bowling or playing the game of tenpins where an admission or fee is charged. 
    "Broker" means any person who acts or offers to act as the agent or representative of others in matters of trade, commerce or navigation, and receives or charges a fee or commission for such a service. 
    Butcher, Retail. "Retail butcher" means any person who shall kill, cut, prepare and/or sell or offer to sell any fresh meat in quantities less than one-quarter of a carcass. 
    "Canvasser" means any person who shall go from place to place or from person to person and solicit or accept orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise or similarly solicits money, influence, signatures or information. 
    "Cleaning and dyeing establishments" means any shop, stand or place of business where clothing or other articles are washed, cleaned, dyed or renovated. 
    "Cobbler and shoe repairer" means any shop, stand or place where boots, shoes or other footwear are repaired, amended or rebuilt for others for a consideration. 
    "Collection agency" means any person who for a fee or commission collects or attempts to collect notes, accounts or obligations for others. 
    "Commission merchant" means any person who buys, sells or deals in any goods, wares or merchandise in exchange for payment of a percentage of the business transacted. 
    "Confectioner" means any person who shall sell, deal in or offer for sale any candies, nuts, popcorn, chewing gum, fruits, ice cream, sweetmeats, cold drinks, light lunches or other confections, except a person duly licensed as a druggist or merchant. 
    "Contractor" means any person who contracts or undertakes to build, erect, construct, raze, remodel, lay, install, remove or repair any building, object, structure, walk, pavement or sidewalk except a person who contracts or undertakes thereby to furnish nothing except his own labor. 
    "Corn doctor" means any person who shall treat or offer to treat corns, bunions or diseases or malformations of the feet. 
    "Dance hall" means any place where public dances or balls are held or conducted where an admission of charge for dancing is made. 
    "Drugstore" means any place that compounds and sells or offers for sale any drugs or medicines, or any of the other articles or things commonly found in drugstores. 
    "Express company" means any company or organization engaged in the business of providing a fast service for transporting goods or delivering money. 
    "Florist and seed stores" means any person who sells or offers for sale flowers or flowering or decorative plants. 
    "Grocer" means any person who sells or offers for sale foods or food products other than a butcher. 
    "Hairdresser" means any person who does or offers to cut, trim, curl, dye, dress or arrange the hair of other persons for a consideration. 
    "Hawker" means any person who goes from place to place selling or offering for sale by public outcry on the streets any goods or articles except farmers or producers selling produce raised by themselves. 
    "Hotel" means any place or establishment where rooms and meals are regularly offered to the public. 
    "Huckster" means any person who deals at retail in vegetables or provisions, particularly one who deals therein from a wagon or open stand. 
    "Ice cream parlor" means any store, shop or place where ice cream, ices, sherbets or soft drinks are sold or served for consumption on the premises. 
    "Ice cream stand" means any booth or stand not provided with chairs and tables, where ice cream or other products mentioned in the preceding definition are sold or served. 
    "Ice plant" means any plant or factory which manufactures ice for sale or distribution. 
    "Insurance agent" means any person who solicits or accepts applications for insurance, or writes, sells, delivers or offers to write, sell or deliver policies of insurance, or who collects or receives premises or charges for insurance as the employee, agent or representative of an insurance company. 
    "Intelligence agency" means any person who for a consideration offers or undertakes to investigate any matter or to assemble information for others. 
    "Junk dealer" means any person who buys and/or sells old metals, rags, bottles, bones or second-hand machinery or similar articles or substances. 
    "Laundry" means any person who washes or irons or offers to wash or iron clothing or fabrics for others, except such person who performs such service in his own or his customer's private residence and who operates not more than one washing machine an two hand irons in so doing. 
    "Loan company" means any company or organization engaged in the business of lending money or which offers to lend money to others for a consideration either in the way of interest or commission. 
    "Lumber dealer" means any person who buys, sells or deals in lumber or wood products. 
    "Lunchstand" means any open stand, booth or place where sandwiches, lunches and/or drinks are sold other than regular meals, and where tables and chairs are not provided for the customers. 
    "Machine shop" means any shop, stand or establishment maintaining or operating machines for making or repairing articles of wood or metal, tools or equipment for others for a consideration. 
    "Mercantile company" means any company that makes a business of collecting information relating to the credit, character, responsibility or reputation of merchants, for the purpose of furnishing such information to others for a consideration. 
    "Merchant" means any person who buys, sells or deals in any goods, wares or merchandise at any store, stand or place of business within this city. 
    "Monument dealer" means any person who buys for sale, sells, manufactures or deals in monuments or markers. 
    "Newspaper office" means any shop, plant, office or establishment where newspapers are regularly printed, prepared, sold or distributed. 
    "Nursery stock agent" means any person who sells or distributes or solicits or accepts orders for trees, shrubs, plants or other nursery products. 
    "Office building" means any building, rooms or portions of which are leased, rented or used for offices. 
    "Oil station" means any shop, stand or place of business where gasoline, oils and/or petroleum products are sold or distributed, either at wholesale or retail, except where such sale or distribution is purely an incidental part of the business of a duly licensed merchant. 
    "Patent right dealer" means any person who buys, sells or deals in patents or rights therein, or rights to use or sell patented articles or substances. 
    "Pawnbroker" means any person who lends or offers to lend money upon the security of articles of personal property deposited with such lender, or who deals in the purchase of personal property on condition that the seller may repurchase the same at a stipulated price, or who displays the sign or insignia of pawnbrokers. 
    "Peddler" means any person who sells or offers to sell at retail any goods, wares or merchandise except newspapers, Bibles or religious tracts by carrying the same for sale from place to place and excluding farmers and producers selling produce raised by themselves. 
    "Photographer" means any person who makes for sale or for a consideration, any photographs or pictures made by the motion of light. 
    "Piano, victrola or radio agent" means any person who acts as the employee, agent or representative within this city of a nonresident piano, victrola or radio dealer. 
    "Picture show" means any show, entertainment, display or exhibition of or by means of pictures of any sort. 
    "Poultry dealer" means any person who buys, sells or deals in domestic fowl or the meat or eggs thereof. 
    "Printing plant" means any plant, shop or establishment, which does or offers to do printing for others for a consideration. 
    "Produce dealer" means any person who buys, sells or deals in agricultural farm products. 
    "Ready-to-wear clothing store" means any place that solicits or accepts orders for, delivers, collects or receives money for ready-made clothing as the agent, employee or representative of a nonresident maker or owner. 
    "Real estate agent" means any person who sells, trades, rents, leases or manages, or offers to sell, trade, rent, lease or manage any real estate for others for a fee or commission. 
    "Restaurant" means any inn or establishment engaged solely or chiefly in the sale and serving of meals or lunches, where tables and chairs are provided for the customers. 
    "Sewing machine agent" means any person who buys, sells or deals in or offers to buy, sell or deal in sewing machines as the employee, agent or representative of a nonresident person or firm. 
    "Skating rink" means any place where persons are invited to skate, to which admission is charged. 
    "Soft drink parlors" means any place where soft drinks or nonalcoholic beverages are sold or served. 
    "Stockyard" means any yard, pen or enclosure where livestock is held pending sale, slaughter or shipment, or is boarded, for compensation. 
    "Storage warehouse" means any building, structure or place where for a consideration personal property of others of any sort or kind is stored or kept. 
    "Subcontractor" means any person who contracts or undertakes at the instance of another, any work which such other person has previously contracted or agreed to do or procure. 
    "Tailor shops" means any shop, stand or establishment that cuts, sews, makes or repairs clothing to fit the customer. 
    "Tavern" means any hotel, public house or similar place for the accommodation or entertainment of strangers. 
    "Tinner" means any person who works with tin or other sheet metal, or who builds, installs, makes, removes or repairs objects composed solely or chiefly of sheet metal. 
    "Traveling store" means any stock of goods, wares or merchandise offered for sale which is moved about from place to place within the city. 
    "Undertaker" means any person who undertakes to conduct funerals or care for bodies of the dead. 
    "Wholesale merchant" means any person who sells or offers to sell any goods, wares or merchandise to retailers or to other persons for resale by such purchasers. 
    "Wood and coal dealer" means any person who buys, sells or deals in wood, kindling or coal. 
    The specification of meanings of this section shall not be exclusive and shall not be construed to exclude other matters not herein specified which are usually and ordinarily included within the various terms here defined. 
    Any business, employment, occupation, agency, amusement or exhibition not specifically enumerated hereinabove, or excluded by state statute or other provisions of this chapter, will be classified under the classification, "miscellaneous" and charged a fee as hereinafter set forth. 
(Prior code § 16-1) 
5.04.030 - License required. 
    No person shall engage in any business, employment, occupation, agency, amusement or exhibition enumerated in Section 5.04.040 or own, manage, operate or control any public building, vehicle or other thing enumerated in Section 5.04.040 unless a license is first obtained therefor from the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 16-2) 
5.04.035 - State automobile dealer license required. 
    No person shall conduct business in the city as an automobile dealer unless that business is licensed as an automobile dealer under the laws of the State of Missouri and no business license shall be issued to an automobile dealer unless that automobile dealer is licensed by and is in good standing with the State of Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 5970 , § 1, 10-17-2017)

5.04.050 - License issuance. 
    If the city clerk is convinced that the applicant for a license required by Section 5.04.030 has complied with all of the provisions of this code, and the other ordinances of the city relating to the license, he shall issue to such applicant a license upon presentation of the following: 
A.  A receipt for the amount of the respective license fee required by Section 5.04.040; 
B.  If a business involved retail sales, the applicant must furnish a copy of the state sales tax license; and 
C.  If the applicant employs five or more persons, or in the event it is a construction company, employs one or more persons, a copy of its workmen's compensation certificate of insurance. 
D.  If the applicant is an automobile dealer, a copy of a current automobile dealer license with the State of Missouri. 
    All such licenses shall be issued under the seal of the city and shall be signed by the mayor and attested to by the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 16-4) 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 19, 4-19-16; Ord. No. 5970 , § 2, 10-17-2017)

5.04.090 - License display. 
    Every person doing business under a license granted pursuant to this chapter shall keep such license in a conspicuous place in his place of business so that it may be readily seen by any official of the city. 
(Prior code § 16-8)

    No license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be assigned or transferred. 
(Prior code § 16-9) 
5.04.110 - License revocation. 
    The board of aldermen may revoke any license granted to any person pursuant to this chapter if such person has been convicted of violating any criminal law of this state or any provision of this code or any other ordinance of the city. 
(Prior code § 16-10) 
5.04.120 - Penalties for operating without an occupational license. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to obtain and/or maintain an occupational license as required under Section 5.04.030 of this chapter. Any person, firm or corporation found in violation of the chapter shall be subject to the penalties set forth in Section 1.16.010 of this code. In addition to any other penalty and/or remedy available under this code, the city may petition any circuit court to issue injunctive relief against any person found to be in violation of this section. 
(Ord. 3833 § 1, 1999) 
Chapter 5.08 - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENTS 
Article 1. - General Provisions 

5.08.010 - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall govern the interpretations of this chapter: 
    "Adult" refers to persons who have attained the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
    "Adult book store" means an establishment having as a significant portion of its stock in trade, books, magazines and other periodicals which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this section, or an establishment or section thereof devoted to the sale or display of such material. 
    "Adult entertainment establishment" means any establishment, including, but not limited to adult book stores, adult stores, adult motion picture theaters, adult mini motion picture theaters, or establishments providing live dancers or models, having as a material portion of its business the offering of entertainment, stock in trade or materials, scenes or other presentations characterized by emphasis on depiction or descriptions of specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this section. 
    "Adult motion picture theater" means an enclosed building with a capacity of twenty (20) or more persons used for presenting or showing, for money consideration, movie or video films or pictures or other material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas as defined in this section, for observation by patrons therein. 
    "Employee" means any clerk, entertainer, server, manager, cashier, bouncer, bartender or other persons hired by owners or their agents, to perform services at an adult entertainment establishment during business hours. 
    "Manager" means any person who manages, directs, administrates or is in charge of the affairs and/or conduct of any portion of any activity at an adult entertainment establishment. 
    "Nudity" means the showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, or buttocks with less than a fully opaque covering, the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering below a point immediately below the top of the areola, or the showing of the covered male genitals in a discernable turgid state. 
    "Specified sexual activities." is defined as: 
1.  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; 
2.  Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; 
3.  Fondling or other erotic touching of the human genitals, pubic region, buttock or the female breast. 
    "Specified anatomical areas" is defined as those areas of the human body specified in the definition of "nudity" above. 
(Prior code § 16-200) 
5.08.020 - Regulations and requirements. 
A.  Age Restriction. Only adults as defined in this chapter shall be permitted on the premises of any adult entertainment establishment as defined in this chapter. 
B.  Exterior Display. No establishment, including an adult entertainment establishment, shall be conducted in any manner that permits the observation of live performers engaged in an erotic depiction or dance, or any material or persons depicting, describing or relating to specified sexual activities or specified anatomical areas, as defined in this chapter, from any exterior source by display, decoration, sign, show window or other opening. 
C.  Live Nudity Prohibited. No person shall be permitted to appear live in any establishment, including an adult entertainment establishment, in a state of nudity as defined in this chapter. 
D.  Protective Barrier Required. Any establishment including an adult entertainment establishment, engaging in the display or performance of live models or dancers in an erotic manner shall not permit patrons within ten feet of the performance, and shall in addition erect a barrier from floor to ceiling, of sufficient strength to prevent patrons from entering the performance area or touching the performers in any manner. No establishment including an adult entertainment establishment shall permit a live erotic performance in an area not isolated by the barrier described above. 
E.  Erotic Touching Prohibited. No person in an adult entertainment establishment shall be permitted to place his or her hand or hands upon, touch with any part of his or her body, fondle in any manner, or massage the breast, buttocks, genitals or pubic area of any other person, whether or not such sexual or genital part of such other person is covered or clothed, and whether such person is employed by the establishment or is a patron thereof. 
F.  Tipping Prohibited. No person in an adult entertainment establishment shall be permitted to tip any entertainer, performer, dancer or model. 
G.  Signs Required. All adult entertainment establishments providing live dancers or models shall have conspicuously displayed in the common area at the principal entrance to the premises a sign, on which upper case letters shall be at least two inches high, and lower case letters at least one inch high, which shall read as follows: 
THIS ADULT ENTERTAINMENT 
ESTABLISHMENT IS REGULATED 
AND LICENSED BY THE CITY 
OF PERRYVILLE, MISSOURI. 
ENTERTAINERS ARE: 
(1)  Not permitted to engage in any type of sexual conduct or prostitution on the premises or to fondle, caress or touch the breasts, pubic region, buttocks or genitals of any employee, patron or other entertainer or to permit any employee, patron or other entertainer to fondle, caress or touch the breasts, pubic region, buttocks or genitals of said entertainer. 
(2)  Not permitted to be nude, unclothed or in less than opaque attire, costume or clothing so as to expose to view any portion of the breasts below the top of the areola or any portion of the pubic region, buttocks and/or genitals. 
(3)  Not permitted to demand or collect any payment or gratuity from any customer for entertainment. 
CUSTOMERS ARE: 
(1)  Not permitted to be upon the stage at any time. 
(2)  Not permitted to touch, caress or fondle the breasts, pubic region, buttocks or genitals of any employee, server or entertainer or engage in solicitation for prostitution. 
(3)  Not permitted to offer or pay any gratuity or tip to any entertainer, performer, dancer or model. 
H.  Hours of Operation. No adult entertainment establishment may be open or in use between the hours of one a.m. and nine a.m. on any day other than Sunday when the business may not be open between the hours of one a.m. and twelve noon. 
I.  Manager on Premises. A manager shall be on duty at any adult entertainment establishment at all times the premises are open for business. The name of the manager on duty shall be prominently posted during business hours. The manager shall have the following duties: 
1.  To verify that all employees possess a current and valid adult entertainment employee license; 
2.  To insure that persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years do not enter upon the premises. 
(Prior code § 16-201) 
Article 2. - Location and Distance Requirements 

5.08.030 - Intent of article. 
    The special provisions of this article are intended to regulate the location of adult entertainment establishments as defined in this chapter, by specifying districts in which such uses may be permitted and requirements for spatial separation of such uses. Nothing in this article shall be construed or interpreted to permit adult entertainment establishments in areas other than those set forth herein. 
    Adult entertainment establishments are acknowledged to have special characteristics and impacts upon their surroundings, and upon the use and enjoyment of adjacent property. It is the intent of these regulations to provide for the confinement of adult entertainment establishments to those industrial areas in which these special impacts are judged to be least disruptive to the use and enjoyment of adjacent properties. These regulations are further intended to require that adult entertainment establishments shall not be permitted to locate in such concentration that their operational features may establish the dominant character of any industrial area. 
    These regulations are further intended to protect and balance lawful rights of expression with other lawful rights to the enjoyment and use of property, and are made with full consideration of legal and constitutional issues heretofore adjudicated. 
    The provisions of this article shall govern the location and spatial separation of adult entertainment establishments in industrial ditricts, and no such regulated use, as defined, may be permitted except in conformance with these provisions. 
(Prior code § 16-210) 
5.08.040 - Location and spatial separation regulations. 
    Adult entertainment establishments, including but not limited to adult book stores, adult motion picture theaters, adult mini-motion picture theaters and establishments providing live dancers or models, as defined in this chapter, are declared to be regulated uses according to this article and their location and spatial separation shall be governed by rules as follows: 
A.  Adult entertainment establishments may be located upon any industrially zoned property, but not within one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet of any residentially zoned property; 
B.  No adult entertainment establishment shall be allowed to locate or expand within one thousand (1,000) feet of any other adult entertainment establishment or of any business licensed to sell or serve alcoholic beverages as defined by this code whether or not the business is also an adult entertainment establishment as defined in this chapter; and 
C.  No adult entertainment establishment shall be allowed to locate or expand within one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet of any school, religious institution or public park within the city. 
(Prior code § 16-211) 
5.08.050 - Measurement of distance. 
A.  The distance between any two adult entertainment establishments or between any adult entertainment establishment and a business selling or serving alcoholic beverages shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures, from the closed exterior structural wall of each business. 
B.  The distance between any adult entertainment establishment and any religious institution, school or public park, or any property zoned for residential use, shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures, from the closest exterior structural wall of the adult entertainment establishment to the closest property line of the religious institution, school or public park or the property zoned for residential use. 
(Prior code § 16-212) 
Article 3. - Adult Picture Theaters 

5.08.060 - Regulations and requirements. 
A.  Areas to be Open to View. The premises of any building used as an adult motion picture theater or an adult mini motion picture theater shall be constructed, located and maintained so that the entire interior portions of any booths, cubicles, rooms or stalls are visible from a common area of the premises. Visibility shall not be blocked or obscured by doors, curtains, drapes or any other obstruction whatsoever. 
B.  Lighting Required. The premises of such theaters shall be so lighted at all times with illumination of not less than one foot candle as measured at the floor level. 
C.  Occupancy by More Than One Person Prohibited. No cubicle, room or booth used for the purpose of private viewing of movies, or video films or pictures of specified sexual activity or of specified anatomical areas shall be occupied at any time by more than one person. 
(Prior code § 16-220) 
5.08.070 - Duties of owners or operators. 
A.  The owner or operator of any adult motion picture theater or adult mini motion picture theater shall cause to be posted in a conspicuous place at the entrance to each room, booth or cubicle used for the purpose of private viewing in such theater a legible written notice of the provisions of this article prohibiting more than one person from occupying such room, booth or cubicle at any one time and in addition, stating that sexual activity, homosexual activity or any deviant sexual intercourse is prohibited in such theater. 
B.  No owner or operator of any adult motion picture theater or adult mini motion picture theater, nor any person employed by such owner or operator in such theater shall knowingly allow or permit any person to solicit for or engage in any form of sexual behavior on the premises of such theater. 
(Prior code § 16-221) 
Article 4. - Licenses and Permits 

5.08.080 - Business permit required. 
    No person, firm, partnership, association or corporation shall operate an adult entertainment establishment, as defined in this chapter, without first having obtained a permit pursuant to this chapter. A separate permit shall be required for each and every separate place of business conducted by any one permittee. Such permit shall be valid only from July 1st to June 30th of the following year. 
(Prior code § 16-230) 
5.08.090 - Employee permit required. 
    No person shall be employed as an employee of any kind in an adult entertainment establishment, as defined in this chapter, unless he or she has a valid employee's permit issued by the city pursuant to the provisions of this article. 
(Prior code § 16-231) 
5.08.100 - Business permit application-Fees. 
A.  Every applicant for a permit to maintain, operate or conduct an adult entertainment establishment shall file an application with the city clerk and pay an annual fee to the city clerk of three hundred dollars ($300.00) which shall not be refundable or prorated and which shall be in addition to any other applicable tax, license or fee. 
B.  The applicant for a permit to operate an adult entertainment establishment shall set forth the exact nature of the establishment, the proposed place of business and facilities therefor, and the name, residence address, telephone number, date of birth and social security number of each applicant including any stockholder holding more than ten percent of the stock of the corporation, any partner and/or proprietor, and any manager. Each such person shall provide written proof that he or she is an adult, as defined in this chapter. Each such person shall further provide a statement: 
1.  Whether he or she has previously operated in this or another city, county or state, and if so, where and whether any business license has been revoked or suspended including the reason(s) therefor; 
2.  That he or she has not been convicted of a felony criminal act within five years prior to the application; 
3.  That he or she has not been convicted of a misdemeanor criminal act or a municipal ordinance violation within two years prior to the application, where such criminal act involved sexual offenses, prostitution, promotion of prostitution, sexual abuse, pornography or related offenses, or that involved controlled substances, illegal drugs or narcotic offenses. 
C.  All applications shall be verified by notarized statement under oath that the applicant has personal knowledge of the information contained in the application, that all information is true and correct and further state the applicant has read this chapter regulating adult entertainment establishments. 
(Prior code § 16-232) 
5.08.110 - Employee permit application-Fees. 
A.  Any person employed by an adult entertainment establishment shall file a written application with the city clerk and pay an annual fee to the city clerk of one hundred dollars ($100.00) which shall not be refundable or prorated and which shall be in addition to any other applicable tax, license or fee. 
B.  The application for any employee permit shall contain the full name, age, sex, telephone number and present address of the applicant, and written proof that he or she is an adult, as defined in this chapter. Each such person shall further provide a statement: 
1.  Whether he or she has previously been employed by an adult entertainment establishment in this or another city, county, or state, and if so, where and whether any employee license has been revoked or suspended including the reason(s) therefor; 
2.  That he or she has not been convicted of a felony criminal act within five years prior to the application; 
3.  That he or she has not been convicted of a misdemeanor criminal act or a municipal ordinance violation within two years prior to the application, where such criminal act involved sexual offenses, prostitution, promotion of prostitution, sexual abuse, pornography or related offenses, or that involved controlled substances, illegal drugs or narcotic offenses. 
C.  All applications shall be verified by notarized statement under oath that the applicant has personal knowledge of the information contained in the application, that all information is true and correct and further state the applicant has read this chapter regarding adult entertainment establishments. 
(Prior code § 16-233) 
5.08.120 - Identification cards. 
    Permitted employees shall be issued an identification card by the city clerk which shall be in the possession of the employee at all times when working in an establishment subject to the provision of this chapter. No person shall alter an identification card. 
(Prior code § 16-234) 
5.08.130 - Permit issuance. 
    After the filing of an application in proper form for a business permit or an employee permit, the city clerk shall issue such permit within twenty-one (21) days following the application, unless the city clerk finds that the applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading or fraudulent statement of fact in the application, has failed or refused to pay the required fee or has failed or refused to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 16-235) 
5.08.140 - Inspections. 
    Any duly authorized officer of the city, including without limitation employees of the police, health and public works departments, may from time to time make an inspection of each adult entertainment establishment for the purpose of determining that the provisions of this chapter are complied with. Such inspections shall be at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner. It is unlawful for any permittee to fail to allow such officer immediate access to the premises or to hinder such officer in any manner. 
(Prior code § 16-236) 
5.08.150 - Supervision. 
    A business permittee shall have the premises supervised at all times when open for business. The permittee shall personally supervise the business, and shall not violate or permit others to violate, any applicable provision of this chapter. The violation of any such provision by any agent or employee of the permittee shall constitute a violation by the permittee. 
(Prior code § 16-237) 
5.08.160 - Duties of business permittee. 
    All business permittees under the provisions of this chapter shall keep and maintain on their premises a current register of all their employees showing such employee's name, address, age, sex, duties and permit number. Such register shall be open to inspection at all reasonable times by any duly authorized officer of the city. 
(Prior code § 16-238) 
5.08.170 - Permit transfer-Other licenses and fees. 
A.  Business and employee permits are not transferrable, and such authority as a permit confers shall be conferred only to the permittee named therein. 
B.  Any applications made, fees paid, and permits obtained under the provisions of this chapter shall be in addition to and not in lieu of any other fees, permits or licenses, required to be paid or obtained under any other ordinances of this city. 
(Prior code § 16-239) 
Article 5. - Violations 

5.08.180 - Violations-Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished in accordance with the provisions of Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 16-250) 
Chapter 5.12 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 

5.12.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the respective meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    "Beer" means any beer manufactured from pure hops or pure extract of hops and pure barley malt or other wholesome grains or cereals, and wholesome yeast and pure water, and free from all harmful substances, preservatives and adulterants, having an alcoholic content of not more than five percent by weight. 
    "Club" means a corporation organized under the laws of this state or an association not formed for pecuniary profit solely for promoting some common object other than the sale and consumption of alcoholic liquors. 
    "Hotel" means every building or other structure kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public to be a place where food is actually served and consumed and where sleeping accommodations are offered for adequate pay to travelers and guests. 
    "Intoxicating liquor" means and includes alcohol for beverage purposes, alcoholic, spirituous, vinous, fermented, malt or other liquors, or combination of liquors, a part of which is spirituous, vinous or fermented, and all preparations or mixtures for beverage purposes, containing in excess of one-half of one percent by volume except for nonintoxicating beer as defined herein. All beverages having an alcoholic content of less than one-half of one percent by volume shall be exempt from the provisions of this chapter, but subject to inspection as provided by Missouri law. 
    "Nonintoxicating beer" means any beer manufactured from pure hops or pure extract of hops, pure barley malt or other wholesome grains or cereals, wholesome yeast, pure water, and free from all harmful substances, preservatives and adulterants, having an alcoholic content of more than one-half of one (0.5) percent by volume and not exceeding three and two-tenths (3.2) percent by weight. 
    "Original package" is defined as three or more cans or bottles of nonintoxicating beer or intoxicating liquor sold in sealed containers. 
    "Person" means and includes an individual, association, joint stock company, syndicate, copartnership, corporation, receiver, trustee, conservator or other officer appointed by any state or federal court. 
    "Restaurant" means any public place kept, used, maintained, advertised and held out to the public as a place where meals are actually served and regularly served. 
(Ord. 3658 § 10, 1998; prior code § 4-1) 
5.12.020 - Sale or disposal to minors. 
    No person shall sell, give away or otherwise dispose of or suffer the same to be done, any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer in any quantity to any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(Prior code § 4-2) 
5.12.030 - Purchase or possession by minor. 
A.  Any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years who purchases or attempts to purchase, or has in his or her possession, any intoxicating liquor as defined in Section 311.020, RSMo, or who is visibly intoxicated as defined in Section 577.001, RSMo, or has a detectable blood alcohol content of more than two-hundredths of one percent or more by weight of alcohol in such person's blood is guilty of violating this section. For purposes of prosecution under this section, a manufacturer-sealed container describing that there is intoxicating liquor therein need not be opened or the contents therein tested to verify that there is intoxicating liquor in such container. The alleged violator may allege that there was not intoxicating liquor in such container, but the burden of proof of such allegation is on such person as it shall be presumed that such a sealed container describing that there is intoxicating liquor therein contains intoxicating liquor. 
B.  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section, or any lawful rules or regulations promulgated pursuant thereto, upon conviction, shall be punished for a first violation by a fine not to exceed three hundred dollars ($300.00). A second or subsequent violation of said section shall be punishable by imprisonment for a term not to exceed ninety (90) days and/or a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). 
(Ord. 4877 § 1, 2007: prior code § 4-3) 
(Ord. No. 5271, § 1, 11-1-11) 
5.12.040 - Sale or disposal to drunkards. 
    No person shall sell, give away or otherwise dispose of or suffer the same to be done, any intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer to any intoxicated person or habitual drunkard. 
(Prior code § 4-4) 
5.12.050 - Intoxicated persons-Officer granted immunity. 
A.  A person who appears to be incapacitated or intoxicated may be taken by a police officer to the person's residence, to any available treatment service, or to any other appropriate local facility, which may, if necessary, include jail for custody not exceeding twelve (12) hours. 
B.  Any officer detaining such person shall be immune from prosecution for false arrest and shall not be responsible for damages for taking action pursuant to subsection A of this section if the officer has reasonable grounds to believe the person is incapacitated or intoxicated by alcohol, and he does not use unreasonable excessive force to detain such person. 
C.  Such immunity from prosecution includes the taking of reasonable action to protect himself or herself from harm by the intoxicated or incapacitated person. 
(Prior code § 4-7) 
5.12.060 - Public assemblies. 
    It is unlawful for any person in the city to enter any schoolhouse or church house in which there is an assemblage of people, met for a lawful purpose, or any courthouse, in a drunken or intoxicated condition, or to attend any other assemblage of people met for a lawful purpose at any other public place, in a drunken or intoxicated condition, or to drink or offer to drink any intoxicating liquor in the presence of any such assembly of people. 
(Prior code § 4-8) 
5.12.070 - Consumption of alcoholic beverages in public places. 
    It is unlawful for any person to drink intoxicating liquor or nonintoxicating beer upon the public streets, parking lots, alleys, highways, thoroughfares or sidewalks within the city. 
(Prior code § 4-9) 
5.12.080 - License-Required. 
    No person shall, either by himself or through the use of agents or servants, engage in the manufacture, brewing, sale or distribution of intoxicating liquors or nonintoxicating beer within the city, without first having taken out and obtained a license authorizing such manufacture, brewing, sale or distribution in compliance with the terms of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 4-20) 
5.12.090 - License-Duration. 
    A license issued under this chapter shall be issued for a period of one year from June 30th of each year, and persons desiring to secure licenses after June 30th shall pay for such portion of the license year remaining at the time such license is issued. Thereafter, all renewals of licenses shall be made on June 30th of each year. 
(Prior code § 4-21) 
5.12.100 - License-Applications and content. 
A.  Submittal to City Clerk. All applications for licenses under the provisions of this chapter shall be made in writing on the proper form to the city clerk and shall state specifically whether the license is for a distiller, brewer or wholesale distributor, and in the case of a retailer's license shall state the alcoholic content of the intoxicating liquor to be sold under the license, and whether the license is issued for consumption on the premises, not for consumption on the premises, or for both sale in the original package and for consumption on the premises where sold. 
B.  Contents. All such applications shall state the name and address of the applicant, or if the applicant is a firm, partnership or association, the names and addresses of each member of the firm, partnership or association, or if the applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses of all officers, the board of directors, and all stockholders of the corporation, and shall describe the premises which the license applied for shall cover. The application shall be completed under oath and shall contain any information reasonably required to administer this chapter. 
(Prior code § 4-22) 
(Ord. No. 5841, § 1, 2-7-17) 
5.12.110 - Application investigation. 
    Upon the receipt by the city clerk of an application and completed Missouri State Highway Patrol background check, the city clerk shall determine if the applicant is qualified and has complied with all applicable provisions of this code of ordinances and the state law. 
(Prior code § 4-23) 
(Ord. No. 5421, § 1, 5-21-13; Ord. No. 5841, § 2, 2-7-17) 
5.12.120 - Action on application. 
    Upon verification by the city clerk that the applicant for a liquor license has complied with all applicable provisions of this code of ordinances and the state law, the city clerk shall issue a license as provided by this chapter. 
    Any applicant who is denied a license by the city clerk may appeal that decision to the board of aldermen. Upon finding by a majority of the members of the board of aldermen that the applicant is qualified and has complied with all applicable provisions of this code of ordinances and the state law, the board of aldermen shall direct the issuance to such applicant. 
(Prior code § 4-24) 
(Ord. No. 5421, § 2, 5-21-13; Ord. No. 5841, § 3, 2-7-17) 
5.12.130 - Qualifications of applicant. 
    No person shall be granted a license or permit under this chapter unless such person is of good moral character, and no person shall be granted a license whose license has previously been revoked or who has been convicted of a violation of the provisions of any law applicable to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor, or any employees in his business or any person whose license has been revoked or who has been convicted of violating the provisions of any such law; nor shall any corporation be granted a license or permit hereunder unless the managing officer of such corporation qualifies as would an individual under the above applicable requirements. 
    No license shall be issued to a person who, while in the operation of a business holding a license under this chapter, has violated city zoning, nuisance or criminal ordinances relating to the conduct of the business if the board of aldermen deems it to be in the best interest of the city to deny said license. No license shall be issued to a person who has operated a business licensed under this chapter if the chief of police reports to the board of aldermen that the business is the source of repeated or regular disturbances and if the board of aldermen deems it to be in the best interest of the city to deny said license. No license shall issue to a person who is not a resident of the state of Missouri, who is not a citizen of the United States, who has been convicted of a felony, who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or misdemeanor opposed to decency or morality, whose license under this chapter has been revoked for cause, or any law enforcement officer. Any mayor, or member of the board of aldermen, either directly or indirectly involved in the manufacture, sale or distribution of intoxicating liquor shall not vote or participate in the debate on the issuance, denial or transfer of the licenses. 
(Prior code § 4-25) 
(Ord. No. 5421, § 3, 5-21-13; Ord. No. 5841, § 4, 2-7-17) 
5.12.140 - Examination of applicant. 
    The mayor and board of aldermen shall have the right to examine, or cause to be examined, under oath, any applicant for a license hereunder or any licensee upon whom notice of revocation or suspension has been served as herein after provided. The mayor and board of aldermen may examine, or cause to be examined, the books and records of such applicant or licensee. 
(Prior code § 4-26) 
5.12.150 - License-Issuance-Requirement-Contents. 
A.  Issuance. On approval of the application by the city clerk and the payment of the license taxes herein provided, the city clerk shall grant the applicant a license to conduct business at the specified location in the city for a period set forth in Section 5.12.090. 
B.  Content. Every license issued under this chapter shall set forth the type of license granted and shall particularly describe the premises. 
C.  Requirements and Restrictions. 
1.  No licensee shall be deemed to be authorized or permitted to sell intoxicating liquor at any place other than described in the license. 
2.  No licensee under this chapter shall be permitted to move the location of his establishment as pertains to the sale of intoxicating liquor without express approval of the board of aldermen. 
3.  No license shall be issued unless the licensee is in present possession of the premises described in his application. 
4.  No license shall be issued unless the location of the applicant's proposed establishment wherein he will sell intoxicating liquor has been issued an occupancy permit; except, however, a license may be issued pending said permit. 
(Prior code § 4-27) 
(Ord. No. 5421, § 4, 5-21-13; Ord. No. 5841, § 5, 2-7-17) 
5.12.160 - License not transferable-Termination. 
A.  License Not Transferable. No license under this chapter shall be transferable from one person to another, nor shall the license be used at any place except the premises for which the license is issued; and proper license shall be procured for each place of business for which a state license is required. 
B.  Cause for Termination-Notice Required. Whenever a license holder under this chapter shall be closed for business for over thirty (30) consecutive calendar days, the license holder's license shall be subject to termination upon notification by the city administrator or his designee that the license shall be voided and the licensee ordered to turn in his license unless the licensee, within fifteen (15) days of the notification by the city, shall, in writing, state the reasons why this should not be done. If the licensee makes the written return within fifteen (15) days, his license shall not be terminated or voided unless upon action by the board of aldermen. The board of aldermen shall make its decision on the basis of the qualifications, duties and obligations of the license holder listed in this chapter, and the reasons for which operation ceased. 
(Prior code § 4-28) 
5.12.170 - Fees. 
    A separate license is required for each place of business, and the following license fees shall be paid annually: 
A.  Retail Liquor by the Drink (RBD). Retailers selling intoxicating liquors with an alcoholic content of more than five percent by weight for consumption on the premises where sold, three hundred dollars ($300.00). The license issued under this subsection includes the right of sale in original package, provided such original package shall not be opened and the contents thereof consumed on the premises where sold and shall include the right to sell beer with an alcoholic content of five percent or less by weight, by the drink or in the original package. 
B.  Sunday by Drink (SBD). A retailer, in addition to other licenses permitted by this chapter, may secure a license to sell intoxicating liquor between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and midnight on Sundays by paying, in addition to all other fees required by law of such retailer, an additional fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year payable at the same time and in the same manner as its other license fees. 
C.  Sunday Original Package (SOP). Retailers selling intoxicating liquor in the original package, not to be consumed upon the premises where sold, in addition to other licenses permitted by this chapter, may secure a license to sell intoxicating liquor between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and midnight on Sundays by paying, in addition to all other fees required by law of such retailers, an additional fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year, payable at the same time and in the same manner as its other license fees. 
D.  Original Package Liquor (OPL). Retailers selling intoxicating liquors containing alcohol in excess of five percent by weight, in the original package, not to be opened or consumed on the premises where sold, one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
E.  Original Package Tasting (OPT). Retailers conducting wine, malt beverage, beer and distilled spirit tastings of the product in its original package on the licensed premises, twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
F.  Retail Liquor by Drink-Exempt (RBDE). Any charitable, fraternal, religious, service or veterans' organization which has obtained an exemption from the payment of federal income taxes as provided in section 501(c)(3), 501(c)(4), 501(c)(5), 501(c)(7), 501(c)(8), 501(c)(10), 501(c)(19) or 501(d) of the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1954, as amended, selling intoxicating liquors with an alcoholic content of more than five percent by weight for consumption on the premises where sold, three hundred dollars ($300.00). The license issued under this subsection includes the right of sale in original package, provided such original package shall not be opened and the contents thereof consumed on the premises where sold and shall include the right to sell beer with an alcoholic content of five percent or less by weight, by the drink or in the original package. 
G.  Retail Liquor by Drink-Picnic (RBDP). Any person selling intoxicating liquor or beer by the drink at a temporary location for a picnic or gathering conducted by any charitable, fraternal, religious, service or veterans' organization, twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each stand for which the permit is issued. 
H.  Retail Liquor by Drink-Caterers (RBDC). Any person with an appropriate liquor license at a permanent location providing intoxicating liquor or beer by the drink at a temporary location at which the food and drinks are catered, ten dollars ($10.00) for each calendar day, or fraction thereof, for which the permit is issued. 
I.  Five Percent Beer by Drink-Wine-No Sunday (5BDW). Retailers selling beer containing not in excess of five percent of alcohol by weight and wines containing not in excess of fourteen percent of alcohol by weight by the drink for consumption on the premises where sold, fifty dollars ($50.00). 
J.  Five Percent Sunday by Drink (5SBD). A retailer, in addition to other licenses permitted by this chapter, may secure a license to sell beer containing not in excess of five percent of alcohol by weight and wines containing not in excess of fourteen percent of alcohol by weight between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and midnight on Sundays by paying, in addition to all other fees required by law of such retailer, an additional fee of two hundred dollars ($200.00) per year payable at the same time and in the same manner as its other license fees.
