Such signaling device shall be used for warning purposes only and shall not be used for making unnecessary noise, and no other sound-producing signaling device shall be used at any time. 
(Prior code § 19-113) 
10.16.070 - Mirrors. 
    All motor vehicles which are so constructed or loaded that the operator cannot see the road behind such vehicle by looking back or around the side of such vehicle shall be equipped with a mirror so adjusted as to reveal the road behind and be visible from the operator's seat. 
(Prior code § 19-114) 
10.16.080 - Vision-reducing material applied to vehicle windshield or windows without permit prohibited. 
    Except to the extent permitted by Section 307.173, RSMo, and in compliance with the technical specifications and requirements of said section, no person shall operate a motor vehicle on any public highway or street of this city with any vision-reducing material applied to any portion of the motor vehicle's windshield, sidewings or windows. 
(Ord. 4878 § 1, 2007: prior code § 19-115) 
10.16.090 - Altering passenger motor vehicle by raising front or rear of vehicle prohibited, when-Bumpers front and rear required, when-Certain vehicles exempt. 
A.  No person shall operate any passenger motor vehicle upon the public streets or roadways of this city, the body of which has been altered in such a manner that the front or rear of the vehicle is raised at such an angle as to obstruct the vision of the operator of the street or roadway in front or to the rear of the vehicle. 
B.  Every motor vehicle which is licensed in this state and operated upon the public streets or highways of this city shall be equipped with front and rear bumpers if such vehicle was equipped with bumpers as standard equipment. This subsection shall not apply to motor vehicles designed or modified primarily for off-highway purposes while such vehicles are in tow or to motorcycles or motor driven cycles, or to motor vehicles registered as historic motor vehicles when the original design of such vehicles did not include bumpers nor shall the provisions of this subsection prohibit the use of drop bumpers. Rules and regulations relating to bumper standards adopted by the superintendent of the Missouri State Highway Patrol are incorporated in this chapter by reference and shall be authoritative in the enforcement and construction of this section. Maximum bumper heights of both the front and rear bumpers of motor vehicles shall be determined by weight category of gross vehicle weight rating (GVWR) measured from a level surface to the highest point of the bottom of the bumper when the vehicle is unloaded and the tires are inflated to the manufacturer's recommended pressure. Maximum bumper heights are as follows: 
Maximum front 
bumper height Maximum rear 
bumper height Motor vehicles except commercial motor vehicles 22 inches 22 inches Commercial motor vehicles (GVWR) 4,500 lbs and 
under 24 inches 26 inches 4,501 lbs through 7,500 lbs 27 inches 29 inches 7,501 lbs through 9,000 lbs 28 inches 30 inches 9,001 lbs through 11,500 lbs 29 inches 31 inches  
(State law reference Section 307.172, RSMo.) 
(Ord. 4590 § 2, 2004: prior code § 19-116) 
10.16.100 - Headgear. 
    Every person operating or riding as a passenger on any motorcycle, as defined in RSMo Section 301.010, upon any highway of this city shall wear protective headgear at all times the vehicle is in motion. The protective headgear shall meet reasonable standards and specifications as may be established by the Director of the Missouri Department of Revenue. 
(Prior code § 19-117) 
10.16.130 - Loads which might become dislodged to be secured. 
    All motor vehicles, and every trailer and semitrailer operating upon the public streets and roadways of this city and carrying goods or material or farm products which may reasonably be expected to become dislodged and fall from the vehicle, trailer or semitrailer as a result of wind pressure or air pressure and/or by the movement of the vehicle, trailer or semitrailer shall have a protective cover or be sufficiently secured so that no portion of such goods or material can become dislodged and fall from the vehicle, trailer or semitrailer while being transported or carried. 
    (State law reference Section 307.010, RSMo.) 
(Ord. 4590 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.16.140 - Sirens and flashing lights, emergency use, persons authorized. 
    Motor vehicles and equipment which are operated by any member of an organized fire department, ambulance association, or rescue squad, whether paid or volunteer, may be operated on streets and roadways in this city as an emergency vehicle under the provisions of Section 304.022, RSMo, while responding to a fire call or ambulance call or at the scene of a fire call or ambulance call and while using or sounding a warning siren and using or displaying thereon fixed, flashing or rotating blue lights, but sirens and blue lights shall be used only in bona fide emergencies. Permits for the operation of such vehicles equipped with sirens or blue lights shall be in writing and shall be issued and may be revoked by the chief of an organized fire department, organized ambulance association, or rescue squad and no person shall use or display a siren or blue lights on a motor vehicle, fire, ambulance or rescue equipment without a valid permit authorizing the use. Permit to use a siren or lights as heretofore set out does not relieve the operator of the vehicle so equipped with complying with all other traffic laws and regulations. 
    (State law reference Section 307.175, RSMo.) 
(Ord. 4590 § 1 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 10.20 - STOPPING, STANDING AND PARKING 
Sections: 

10.20.010 - Public square defined. 
    As used in this chapter, the term "public square" includes both sides of the streets bordering the county courthouse, being Jackson Street, St. Joseph Street, Main Street and Ste. Maries Street. 
(Prior code § 19-180) 
10.20.020 - Prohibited parking places enumerated. 
A.  Whenever a prohibited parking place is designated and clearly marked by a sign, symbol or method set out in the Model Traffic Ordinance as being a prohibited parking area, it shall be unlawful to park or stand any motor vehicle in such space. 
B.  The city administrator or his designate is authorized and directed to cause signs or other markings indicating prohibited parking area to be placed at certain locations described and set forth in the Prohibited Parking Places Schedule (Ordinance No. 3618, passed and approved on April 21, 1998). That schedule is adopted by reference and incorporated in this chapter as if fully set forth. A copy of the schedule, as well as any amendments thereto, shall remain on file in the office of the city clerk for public reference. 
C.  Any violation of subsection A of this section shall be punishable as set forth in Section 1.16.010. 
(Ord. 3618 § 1, 1998: prior code § 19-181) 
10.20.025 - School related parking; tow-away zone. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be parked within five feet of a driveway entrance or either side of South Walnut Street south of Hart Street or on the south side of College Street east of Spring Street and west of Campus Drive. The city administrator or the city administrator's designate shall cause signs to be placed in these locations stating that parking is prohibited within five feet of a driveway and that this area is a tow-away zone. 
B.  Any vehicle found to be in violation of this section may be ordered towed by authority of a police officer and such vehicle shall be impounded until all costs of towing have been paid on such vehicle. 
(Ord. 4434 § 1, 2003) 
10.20.030 - Fifteen-minute parking limit areas designated. 
A.  Whenever a parking space is clearly marked by a sign or symbol by a method set forth in the model traffic code as having a fifteen (15) minute parking limit, it shall be unlawful to park or stand any motor vehicle in such space for a period of more than fifteen (15) minutes. 
B.  The city administrator or his designate is authorized and directed to cause signs or other markings indicating a fifteen-minute parking limit at certain locations described and set forth in the Fifteen-Minute Parking Limit Schedule (Ordinance No. 3618, passed and approved on April 21, 1998). Said schedule is adopted by reference and incorporated herein as if fully set forth. A copy of said schedule, as well as any amendments thereto, shall remain on file in the office of the city clerk for public reference. Any violation of subsection A of this section shall be punishable as set forth in Section 1.16.010. 
(Ord. 3618 § 2, 1998: prior code § 19-182) 
10.20.040 - Two-hour parking limit areas designated. 
A.  Whenever a parking space is clearly marked by a sign or symbol or method as prescribed in the model traffic ordinance as being a two-hour parking limit area, it is unlawful to park or stand any motor vehicle in such space. 
B.  The city administrator or his designate is authorized and directed to cause signs or other markings indicating a two-hour parking limit area to be placed at certain locations described and set forth in the two-hour parking limit schedule. (Ordinance No. 3618, passed and approved on April 21, 1998). Such schedule is adopted by reference and incorporated herein as if fully set forth. A copy of such schedule, as well as any amendments thereto, shall remain on file in the office of the city clerk for public reference. 
C.  Any violation of subsection A of this section shall be punishable as set forth in Section 1.16.010. 
(Ord. 3618 § 3, 1998: prior code § 19-183) 
10.20.050 - Standing or parking of peddler's vehicles. 
    No person engaged in selling melons, fruit, produce or goods, wares or merchandise at retail from any vehicle shall stand or park such vehicle on any street within the city, except in case of emergency, for more than five minutes. 
(Prior code § 19-184) 
10.20.060 - Granting of taxicab stands-Fee. 
    Upon written application by the operator of a taxicab stating the name of the cab company, the owner thereof and the location of the proposed cabstand, the board of aldermen, considering the safety and convenience to the public, may grant the operator a specified number of parking spaces to be used exclusively as a taxicab stand upon payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each parking space allotted for a taxicab stand. 
(Prior code § 19-185) 
10.20.070 - Truck, large vehicle, and trailer parking. 
A.  Definitions. 
1.  For the purpose of this section, "residential area" means any area in the city within an "R" zoning classification. 
2.  For the purpose of this section, 'length of a trailer or vehicle' means the length measured from the farthest point at the front of the vehicle or trailer to the farthest point at the back of the vehicle or trailer. In the event that a trailer is attached to any truck, tractor, or other pulling device, then the length shall be measured from the farthest point at the front of the truck, tractor, or other pulling device to the farthest point at the end of the trailer. 
3.  For the purpose of this section, the term "dropping trailers" means using any city street within the city as a place to park any trailer with a length of over sixteen (16) feet used or designed to be used for the carrying of merchandise or freight and designed to be pulled by a truck or tractor unless such trailer is in the continuous process of being loaded or unloaded in conjunction with an adjacent business. 
B.  Restricted. 
1.  No bus, truck, tractor, trailer, or other vehicle used or designed to be used for the carrying of passengers, merchandise, or freight, or to be let for hire or commercial use of any kind whatsoever, weighing or licensed to or capable of carrying or pulling over twelve thousand (12,000) pounds or more shall be parked on any street in any residential area of the city, except for the actual and continuous process of being loaded and unloaded. It is provided, however, that this paragraph does not apply to pickup trucks unless said pickup truck is a dual-wheeled vehicle. 
2.  No person shall park a trailer or other vehicle exceeding sixteen (16) feet in length or eight feet in width on any street in any residential area of the city except that: 
a.  Such trailers or other vehicles may be parked up to two (2) hours for the purpose of making a delivery to a destination immediately adjacent to the location where the trailer or vehicle is parked; or 
b.  A person may park a noncommercial recreational vehicle on the city street immediately adjacent to the person's residence for a period not to exceed seventy-two (72) hours; or 
c.  A person may park a construction trailer for such periods as may be necessary for a construction project on an adjacent residence. 
3.  If the chief of police or his designee determines that parking any trailer or other vehicle [including those less than sixteen (16) feet in length or eight feet in width] creates a hazardous situation, then the trailer or vehicle must be moved or be subject to a violation of this code. 
4.  All trailers parked after dusk or before dawn on any street in any residential area of the city shall display red and white department of transportation reflective striping on both the front and the rear of the trailer. 
5.  No person shall park a dual-wheeled vehicle on any street in the city in such a manner that it impedes the natural flow of traffic or creates a hazard by protrusion into an active traffic lane. 
C.  Dropping Trailers Prohibited. 
1.  The practice of "dropping trailers" is prohibited on any city street within the city. 
2.  Any trailer found to be in violation of this section may be towed and stored at the owner's expense. Said trailer may be reclaimed by the owner only upon payment of all towing and storage expenses and payment of any fines and court costs. 
(Ord. 4857 § 1, 2007: Ord. 4787 § 1, 2006: Ord. 4412 § 1, 2003; Ord. 3579 § 1, 1998; prior code § 19-186) 
(Ord. No. 5326, § 1, 5-1-12) 
10.20.080 - Disabled parking. 
A.  Parking in spaces designated for the exclusive use of vehicles which display a distinguishing license plate or card issued pursuant to the laws of any state is prohibited under the following terms and conditions: 
1.  If a private property owner has designated disabled parking spaces on property owned by it and if said disabled parking spaces are clearly marked by a sign or symbol as being reserved for parking by the physically disabled and if a driver parks a vehicle in said disabled parking space without displaying the required license plate or card, then the property owner or its designee may make a written complaint to the chief of police of the city and the driver of said vehicle shall be guilty of violating this section. 
2.  Any driver parking in a parking space set forth in the disabled parking schedule established in subsection B of this section who does not display on their vehicle a distinguishing license plate or card issued pursuant to the laws of any state for a disabled driver shall be guilty of violating this section. 
B.  The city administrator or his designee is authorized and directed to cause signs or other marking indicating a parking space for the physically disabled to be placed at certain locations described and set forth in the disabled parking schedule (Ordinance No. 3069 passed and approved on March 17, 1993). Such schedule is adopted by reference and incorporated herein as if fully set forth. A copy of such schedule, as well as any amendments thereto, shall remain on file in the office of the city clerk for public reference. Any reference to the term "handicapped parking" shall now be referred to as "disabled parking." 
C.  Any violation of subsection A of this section shall be punishable as set forth in Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 19-187) 
(Ord. No. 5686, § 1, 9-1-15) 
10.20.090 - Reserved parking. 
A.  Three parking spaces are established and designated as reserved for sheriff department vehicles on the south side of West Ste. Marie Street between Jackson Street and Main Street; such spaces shall be clearly marked by a sign or symbol as being reserved for sheriff department vehicles' use only. 
B.  One parking space is established and designated as reserved for sheriff department vehicles on the east side of Jackson Street between Ste. Marie Street and St. Joseph Street; such space shall be clearly marked by a sign or symbol as being reserved for sheriff department vehicles' use only. 
C.  Two parking spaces are established and designated as reserved for judges vehicles on the west side of Main Street between St. Joseph Street and Ste. Marie Street; such spaces shall be clearly marked by a sign or symbol as being reserved for judges vehicles' use only. 
D.  Whenever a parking space in a parking area or facility that is available for public use is clearly marked by a sign or symbol as being reserved for sheriff department parking or judges parking, it is unlawful for any other persons to park or stand any motor vehicle in such spaces. 
(Prior code § 19-188) 
(Ord. No. 5004, § 1, 1-20-09) 
10.20.100 - Parking in private and public parking areas. 
    It is unlawful for the operator of any motor vehicle to park such vehicle on any public or privately owned parking lot or parking facility generally open for use by the public, either: 
A.  In such a manner as to block any entrance to or exit from such parking area or facility; or 
B.  In such a manner as to block or unreasonably impede or obstruct the free flow of vehicular traffic within such parking area or facility; or 
C.  With any part of the vehicle outside of the designated parking spaces when such facility is marked with separate parking spaces. 
(Prior code § 19-189) 
10.20.110 - Traffic citations for parking violations. 
    Any police officer who finds a motor vehicle parked in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or any other portion of this code relating to proper parking, shall issue a parking ticket/citation and place the parking ticket/citation on such vehicle. 
(Prior code § 19-195) 
10.20.120 - Ticket/citation stub-Filing and contents. 
    It shall be the duty of every police officer to deposit with the city clerk, the stub of each parking ticket/citation issued by him pursuant to this chapter, which stub shall contain: 
A.  The state license number of the vehicle parked in violation of this chapter or any other part of this code related to parking violations; 
B.  The day and hour at which the vehicle was parked in violation of this chapter or any other part of this code related to parking violations; 
C.  Any other facts which the officer deems necessary to properly understand the circumstances of the violation. 
(Prior code § 19-196) 
10.20.130 - Payment of fines-Expedited resolution. 
A.  Any person accused of violation of any portion of this chapter or any ordinance prohibiting parking of a vehicle in a designated area or restricting the length of time a vehicle may be there parked, may settle and compromise the claim against him or her for such illegal parking by paying to the city the sum of money indicated hereinbelow within five working days of the time such alleged offense was committed. Receipts shall be issued for all money so received, and such money shall be promptly turned over to the city clerk to be deposited and used in the manner provided for disposition of fines for traffic violations. 
B.  Members of the police department are authorized to refrain from instituting a prosecution for the alleged offense involved, provided, however, that this resolution shall not apply to persons parking a vehicle so as to obstruct the entrance or exit of any place where police or fire department apparatus or other emergency equipment is kept or housed, or so as to block an emergency entrance to a hospital. Nor shall this resolution apply to any person charged with parking a vehicle so as to entirely obstruct traffic in any street or alley, or parking in such a way as to reduce traffic on an arterial street to one-way traffic only; nor to any person who refuses to move a vehicle illegally parked at the request of any member of the police department. 
(Prior code § 19-197) 
10.20.140 - Form of traffic ticket-Amount of parking fine. 
    The following form of ticket may be used and the following fines shall apply: 
FORM 
No.___________ 
Date: _________ Time: _____ 
License No.: ________ State: _____ 
Make of vehicle: _____________ 
Officer: __________________ 
You are charged with the violation marked below: 
1. No parking zone (10.20.020) ..... $10.00 ? 
2. Overparked 15 minutes (10.20.030) ..... 10.00 ? 
3. Overparked 2 hours (10.20.040) ..... 10.00 ? 
4. Peddling from vehicle (10.20.050) ..... 10.00 ? 
5. No truck parking (10.20.070) ..... 10.00 ? 
6. Other parking violations ..... 10.00 ? 
The fine for this violation is indicated above. If you wish to dispose of this matter by settlement please attach your ticket stub, place the fine in the envelope and mail or deliver to: City Clerk, City Hall, 215 North West Street, Perryville, Missouri 63775, or deposit in the city's night depository. Failure to remit in five (5) working days shall result in issuance of a summons and added penalty. 
;adv=7;(Prior code § 19-198) 
(Ord. No. 5435, § 1, 6-25-13) 
10.20.150 - Parking ticket/citation-Failure to comply. 
    Any owner or operator of any motor vehicle who fails to comply with the directions written on any parking ticket/citation attached to such vehicle pursuant to this chapter or this code shall be punished as provided in Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 19-199) 
Chapter 10.24 - MOTOR VEHICLE LICENSE TAX 

10.24.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section: 
    "Motor vehicle" means any self-propelled vehicle not operated exclusively upon tracks except motorized bicycles as defined in Section 307.180 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri and motorcycles and motortricycles as defined in this section. 
    "Motorcycle" means a motor vehicle operated on two wheels. 
    "Motortricycle" means a motor vehicle operated on three wheels. 
    "Operator" means any person who operates or drives a motor vehicle. 
    "Owner" includes any person, firm, corporation or association owning or renting a motor vehicle or having the exclusive use under lease or otherwise for a period greater than ten days successively. 
(Prior code § 19-130) 
(Ord. No. 5541, § 1, 7-15-14; Ord. No. 5739, § 1, 3-15-16) 
10.24.020 - Motor vehicle registration fees-Expiration date. 
    All motor vehicle registration fees shall be due on the thirty-first (31st) day of December of each year. 
(Prior code § 19-132) 
(Ord. No. 5541, § 2, 7-15-14) 
10.24.030 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5739, § 1, adopted March 15, 2016, repealed § 10.24.030, which pertained to collector compensation and derived from prior code § 19-133. 
10.24.040 - Registration fees-Required. 
    Every owner of a motor vehicle living, residing, or operating a primary business location within the city who drives or operates the same upon the streets or highways of the city or who permits the same to be driven or operated upon the streets or highways of the city shall provide to the county assessor the make, model, and year of the motor vehicle and such other information as may be required by the county assessor in January of each year. 
(Prior code § 19-140) 
(Ord. No. 5739, § 3, 3-15-16) 
10.24.050 - Registration fees-Collection annually. 
    From the information provided the county assessor as herein set forth, the collector shall cause the annual motor vehicle registration fees (heretofore 'automobile city stickers') to be levied and indicated on each motor vehicle owner's personal property tax bill. The annual motor vehicle registration fee shall be due and payable on December 31st of each year and shall be determined and calculated upon the number and types of motor vehicles the owner owned on the preceding January 1st. The annual motor vehicle registration fee shall be delinquent on January 1st following billing. 
(Prior code § 19-141) 
(Ord. No. 5739, § 4, 3-15-16) 
10.24.060 - Registration fees prescribed. 
    Each owner of a motor vehicle shall pay three dollars ($3.00) to the collector as an annual registration fee upon the filing of the application for registration required by this chapter. 
(Prior code § 19-142) 
(Ord. No. 5739, § 3, 3-15-16) 
10.24.070-10.24.110 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5541, §§ 3-7, adopted July 15, 2014, repealed §§ 10.24.070-10.24.110, which pertained to dealers-application for registration; dealers-registration fee for tabs; dealers-fee for additional registrations; dealers-contents of tabs and dealers-display of tabs; respectively, and derived from prior code §§ 19-150-19-154. 
Chapter 10.28 - ABANDONED VEHICLES 

10.28.010 - Abandonment of motor vehicles prohibited. 
A.  It is unlawful for any person to abandon any vehicle upon any public way or other public place in the city. 
B.  It is unlawful to store in public view an automobile which is old, unused, stripped and junked, and which is no longer safely usable for the purpose for which it was manufactured. 
C.  When a vehicle is abandoned upon any public way or other public place for seventy-two (72) hours or more, its removal by a towing service may be authorized by the chief of police. 
D.  When an abandoned, unattended, wrecked, or burned or partially dismantled, or illegally parked vehicle is creating a traffic hazard because of its position in relation to the public way, its immediate removal from the public way by a towing service may be authorized by the chief of the police department. 
(Prior code § 19-160) 
10.28.020 - Impoundment-Redemption- Disposal. 
    Any motor vehicle which congests, obstructs or unduly restricts a free, clear and unimpeded movement of traffic or which has been abandoned shall be removed and impounded until such time as the registered owner thereof claims the same by the full payment of costs accrued for towing and storage while so impounded, and court costs and fines assessed, or upon posting of a bond or bonds. If such motor vehicle is not reclaimed and all of the costs of impoundment paid within ninety (90) days after the same has been impounded and stored, then the motor vehicle shall be presumed to have been completely abandoned and the city may dispose of such vehicle in the same manner as other trash or refuse is disposed of by the city. 
(Prior code § 19-161) 
10.28.030 - Violation-Responsibility. 
    If any vehicle is found within the city limits in violation of any provision of this chapter and the identity of the operator cannot be determined, the owner or person in whose name such vehicle is registered shall be held prima facie responsible for such violation. 
(Prior code § 19-162) 
10.28.040 - Sale of impounded vehicles by city. 
    In the event the city removes a motor vehicle pursuant to this chapter and the motor vehicle has been stored for a period of not less than sixty (60) days, and the owner or person having the right to possession of the vehicle has not claimed same during the sixty (60) day period, then the city shall be authorized to remove said motor vehicle and dispose of same in any manner. If the motor vehicle has a pecuniary marketable value, then said vehicle may be sold at public auction after not less than ten days' notice has been given in at least one newspaper published in the city, the first publication to be not less than ten days prior to the auction. The expense of the towing and other related expenses in connection with the motor vehicle, including the storage charges, in an amount not to exceed sixty dollars ($60.00), shall be considered an expense of sale and the balance, if any, shall be paid into the general revenue fund of the city. The time and place of the auction shall be clearly stated in the notice. 
(Prior code § 19-163) 
10.28.050 - Towing. 
A.  Any vehicle abandoned under the provisions of this chapter or any other ordinance of the city of Perryville, Missouri, relating to motor vehicles which are derelict, junked, scrapped, disassembled, or otherwise harmful to the public health under the terms of the ordinances as made and provided, may be towed by the city. The city department providing for the towing shall report the tow to the Perryville police department within two hours with a crime inquiry and inspection report as made and provided in Section 304.155 RSMo (1994) as amended. The report shall include the following: 
1.  Year, model, make and abandoned property identification number of the property; 
2.  A description of any damage to the property noted by owner or lessee in possession of the real property; 
3.  License plate and registration number and the state of issuance if available; 
4.  Physical location of the property and the reason for requesting property to be towed; 
5.  The date the report is completed; 
6.  Signature and printed name of the owner or lessee in possession of the real property; 
7.  Name of law enforcement agency notified of abandoned property. 
B.  Upon receipt of the aforesaid report or compilation of the report by the police department, the police department shall within five days make inquiry into the National Crime Information Center and any statewide Missouri law enforcement computer system to determine if the abandoned property has been reported stolen. The police department shall enter the information pertaining to the towed property in the statewide enforcement computer system. 
C.  Neither the law enforcement officer, local government agency, nor anyone having custody of abandoned property under his or her direction shall be liable for any damage to such abandoned property occasioned by a removal authorized by this section other than damages occasioned by negligence or by willful or wanton acts or omissions. 
State law reference: 304.157 laws 1999; 304.155 RSMo 1994. 
(Ord. 3982 § 1, 2000) 
Chapter 10.32 - ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.32.010 - Definitions. 
    "ATV," "ATC," "four-wheeler," "three-wheeler" and "all-terrain vehicle" means any motorized vehicle manufactured exclusively for off-highway use, which is fifty (50) inches or less in width, with an unladen dry weight of six hundred (600) pounds or less, traveling on three, four or more low-pressure tires, with a seat designed to be straddled by the operator and handlebars for steering control. 
(Prior code § 19-210) 
10.32.020 - Prohibition-Exception. 
    No person shall operate an all-terrain vehicle, as defined in this chapter, and in Section 301.010 RSMo. Laws 1990, upon the streets of this city except as follows: 
A.  All-terrain vehicles owned and operated by a governmental entity for official use; and 
B.  All-terrain vehicles operated for agricultural purposes or industrial on-premise purposes between the official sunrise and sunset of the day of operation. 
(Prior code § 19-211) 
10.32.030 - Operation in stream or watercourse. 
    No person shall operate an off-road vehicle within any stream or watercourse of this city, except that off-road vehicles may be operated within streams or watercourses which flow within the boundaries which an off-road vehicle operator owns; or for agricultural purposes within the boundaries which an off-road operator owns or has permission to be upon; or for the purpose of fording such stream or watercourse at such road crossings as are customary or part of the street system. 
(Prior code § 19-212) 
10.32.040 - Operation prohibitions. 
    No person shall operate an all-terrain vehicle: 
A.  In any careless way so as to endanger the person or property of another; 
B.  While under the influence of alcohol or any controlled substance; 
C.  Without securely fastened safety helmet on the head of an individual who operates an all-terrain vehicle or who is being towed or otherwise propelled by an all-terrain vehicle unless the individual is at least eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Prior code § 19-213) 
10.32.050 - Passengers. 
    No operator of an all-terrain vehicle shall carry a passenger, except for agricultural purposes. 
(Prior code § 19-214) 
10.32.060 - Violation-Penalty. 
    The violation of any of the provisions of this chapter will be punishable as a misdemeanor under the provisions of Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 19-215) 
Chapter 10.36 - BICYCLES 
Sections: 

10.36.010 - Bicycle and motorized bicycle, defined. 
    As used in this chapter: 
A.  The word "bicycle" means every vehicle propelled solely by human power upon which any person may ride, having two tandem wheels, except scooters and similar devices; 
B.  The term "motorized bicycle" means any two- or three-wheeled device having an automatic transmission and a motor with a cylinder capacity of not more than fifty (50) cubic centimeters, which produces less than three gross brake horsepower, and is capable of propelling the device at a maximum speed of not more than thirty (30) miles per hour on level ground. 
(State law reference Section 307.180, RSMo.) 
(Ord. 4589 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.36.020 - Brakes required. 
    Every bicycle and motorized bicycle shall be equipped with a brake or brakes which will enable its driver to stop the bicycle or motorized bicycle within twenty-five (25) feet from a speed of ten miles per hour on dry, level, clean pavement. 
    (State law reference Section 307.183, RSMo.) 
(Ord. 4589 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.36.030 - Lights and reflectors, when required-Standards to be met. 
    Every bicycle and motorized bicycle when in use on a street or highway during the period from one-half hour after sunset to one-half hour before sunrise shall be equipped with the following: 
A.  A front-facing lamp on the front or carried by the rider which shall emit a white light visible at night under normal atmospheric conditions on a straight, level, unlighted roadway at five hundred (500) feet; 
B.  A rear-facing red reflector, at least two square inches in reflective surface area, or a rear-facing red lamp, on the rear which shall be visible at night under normal atmospheric conditions on a straight, level, unlighted roadway when viewed by a vehicle driver under the lower beams of vehicle headlights at six hundred (600) feet; 
C.  Reflective material and/or lights on any part of the bicyclist's pedals, crank arms, shoes or lower leg, visible from the front and the rear at night under normal atmospheric conditions on a straight, level, unlighted roadway when viewed by a vehicle driver under the lawful lower beams of vehicle headlights at two hundred (200) feet; and 
D.  Reflective material and/or lights visible on each side of the bicycle or bicyclist and visible at night under normal atmospheric conditions on a straight, level, unlighted roadway when viewed by a vehicle driver under the lawful lower beams of vehicle headlights at three hundred (300) feet. The provisions of this subdivision shall not apply to motorized bicycles which comply with National Highway Traffic and Safety Administration regulations relating to reflectors on motorized bicycles. 
    (State law reference Section 307.185, RSMo.) 
(Ord. 4589 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.36.040 - Rights and duties of bicycle and motorized bicycle riders. 
    Every person riding a bicycle or motorized bicycle upon a street or highway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle as provided by Chapters 10.04, 10.12 and 10.20, except as to special regulations in this chapter and except as to those provisions of Chapters 10.04, 10.12 and 10.20 which by their nature can have no application. 
    (State law reference Section 307.188, RSMo.) 
(Ord. 4589 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.36.050 - Riding to right, required for bicycles and motorized bicycles, exception, bicyclists may ride abreast. 
    Every person operating a bicycle or motorized bicycle at less than the posted speed or slower than the flow of traffic upon a street or highway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as safe, exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction, except when making a left turn, when avoiding hazardous conditions, when the lane is too narrow to share with another vehicle, or when on a one-way street. Bicyclists may ride abreast when not impeding other vehicles. 
    (State law reference Section 307.190, RSMo.) 
(Ord. 4589 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.36.060 - Operating on sidewalks prohibited. 
    No person shall operate a bicycle on any sidewalks within the city. 
(Ord. 4589 § 1 (part), 2004) 
10.36.070 - Penalty for violation. 
    Any person seventeen (17) years of age or older who violates any provision of this chapter is guilty of an infraction and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of not less than five dollars nor more than twenty-five dollars ($25.00). Such an infraction does not constitute a crime and conviction shall not give rise to any disability or legal disadvantage based on conviction of a criminal offense. If any person under seventeen (17) years of age violates any provision of sections of this chapter in the presence of a peace officer possessing the duty and power of arrest for violation of the general criminal laws of the state or for violation of ordinances of counties or municipalities of the state, such officer may impound the bicycle or motorized bicycle involved for a period not to exceed five days upon issuance of a receipt to the child riding it or to its owner. 
    (State law reference Section 307.193, RSMo.) 
(Ord. 4589 § 1 (part), 2004) 
Chapter 10.38 - MOTORIZED PLAY VEHICLES 
Sections: 

10.38.010 - Definition. 
    "Motorized play vehicle" means any mini-motorcycle, pocket bike, pocket motorcycle or any other vehicle that is capable of transporting a person or persons at a speed in excess of five miles per hour which is self-propelled by a motor or engine and that is not otherwise defined by the Missouri statutes or the code of ordinances of the city of Perryville as a motor vehicle, motorcycle, bicycle or motorized bicycle. 
(Ord. 4785 § 1 (part), 2006) 
10.38.020 - Prohibition. 
    No person shall ride on or operate a motorized play vehicle upon any street, highway, roadway or sidewalk within the city or within the boundaries of any city park. 
(Ord. 4785 § 1 (part), 2006) 
10.38.030 - Violation-Penalty. 
    The violation of any of the provisions of this chapter will be punishable as a misdemeanor under the provisions of Section 1.16.010 of this code. 
(Ord. 4785 § 1 (part), 2006) 
Chapter 10.39 - ALL-TERRAIN VEHICLES, GOLF CARTS, AND UTILITY VEHICLES[1] 
Sections 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5592, § 1, adopted December 2, 2014, amended Chapter 10.39 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Chapter 10.39, §§ 10.39.010-10.39.060, pertained to utility vehicles and golf carts, and derived from Ord. No. 4990, adopted October 21, 2008. 

10.39.010 - Definitions. 
    "All-terrain vehicle" means any motorized vehicle manufactured and used exclusively for off-highway use which is fifty (50) inches or less in width, with an unladen dry weight of one thousand five hundred (1,500) pounds or less, traveling on three, four, or more non-highway tires. 
    "Golf cart" means any motorized vehicle powered electrically or by any other means designed and manufactured for operation on a golf course for sporting and recreational purposes. 
    "Utility vehicle" means any motorized vehicle manufactured and used exclusively for off-highway use which is more than fifty (50) inches but no more than sixty-seven (67) inches in width, with an unladen dry weight of two thousand (2,000) pounds or less, traveling on four or six wheels, to be used primarily for landscaping, lawn care, or maintenance purposes. 
(Ord. No. 5592, § 1, 12-2-14) 
State Law reference- Section 301.010, RSMo. 
10.39.020 - All-terrain vehicle operation on streets or roadways prohibited. 
    All-terrain vehicles as defined herein shall not be operated upon the streets or roadways of the city except when properly equipped and used exclusively in the performance of maintenance work such as snow removal or as otherwise authorized by state law to operate on the highways of the state or as authorized in Chapter 10.32 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 5592, § 1, 12-2-14) 
State Law reference- Section 304.032, RSMo. 
10.39.030 - Golf cart or utility vehicle prohibition. 
    No person shall operate a golf cart or utility vehicle as defined herein upon the streets or roadways of the city: 
A.  In a careless manner so as to endanger the life or property of another; 
B.  While under the influence of alcohol or any controlled substance; 
C.  With a passenger unless the golf cart or utility vehicle is being operated for agricultural purposes or the seat is designed to carry more than one person; 
D.  At a speed in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 5592, § 1, 12-2-14) 
State Law reference- Section 304.032, RSMo. 
10.39.040 - Golf cart or utility vehicle operation. 
    A golf cart or utility vehicle: 
A.  May only be operated on the streets or roadways of the city by an operator who possesses a valid driver's license unless exempt under the laws of the state of Missouri; 
B.  May only be operated between the hours of official sunrise and sunset; 
C.  Must be operated in accordance with all traffic regulations and must not obstruct or interfere with normal traffic flow; 
D.  Must be equipped with adequate brakes, reliable steering, safe tires, a rearview mirror, and reflectorized warning devices; 
E.  Shall not be operated with more occupants than the number for which it was designed; 
F.  Must not be operated at speeds in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour. 
(Ord. No. 5592, § 1, 12-2-14) 
10.39.050 - Violation-Penalty. 
    The violation of any of the provisions of this chapter will be punishable as a misdemeanor under the provisions of Section 1.16.010. 
(Ord. No. 5592, § 1, 12-2-14) 
Title 12 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC PLACES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 12.04 - STREETS AND SIDEWALKS GENERALLY 

12.04.010 - Obstructions. 
A.  Any person who shall place or cause to be placed in or upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city any structure or article whatsoever, so as to obstruct or hinder the free passage of persons or vehicles over or along such street, sidewalk or other public place, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
B.  Every person who employs any device, noise or performance tending to collect a crowd and obstruct travel on any street, sidewalk or other public place, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
C.  Any person who sets up, or causes to be set up, any awning post or other post on any street or sidewalk of the city without first obtaining the consent of the board of aldermen therefor, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
D.  Any two or more persons who assemble upon any street or sidewalk and there remain loafing or spending their time in idleness so as to obstruct such street or sidewalk shall each be deemed guilty of misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 24-1) 
12.04.020 - Endangering safety of other persons. 
    Any person who conducts himself upon any street, sidewalk or other public place within the city so as to endanger the safety of other persons shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 24-2) 
12.04.030 - Street standards. 
    All streets constructed in the city shall conform to street standards contained in the subdivision regulations of the city; provided, however, that variance may be granted by the board of aldermen of the city upon the recommendation of the city engineer. 
(Ord. 3663 § 1, 1998: prior code § 24-3) 
12.04.040 - Sidewalk used as crossing-Maintenance. 
    Any person who uses a part of any sidewalk in the city for a crossing and fails to keep such part of such sidewalk in good repair and on established grade shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 24-4) 
12.04.050 - Clean sidewalks and gutters-Property owner and occupant responsibility. 
    Whoever shall, in the city, fail, neglect or refuse to keep any sidewalk or gutter in front of any property owned, occupied or under his management or control swept clean and clear of dirt, mud, filth or other substances, excluding snow and ice, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 24-5) 
(Ord. No. 5835, § 1, 1-10-17) 
12.04.060 - Cellar door and grating-Unlawful to leave open. 
    It is unlawful for any person to permit any cellar door or grating on any sidewalk, or adjacent thereto, to remain open or in a dangerous condition. 
(Prior code § 24-6) 
12.04.065 - Sidewalk restaurants. 
A.  Definitions as used in this section: 
 "Adjacent to a restaurant" means an area lying between the two property lines of the restaurant when the property lines are extended to the city street. 
 "Sidewalk" means that portion of the street between the curb lines or the lateral lines of a roadway and the adjacent property lines and which is intended for use of pedestrians. 
 "Sidewalk restaurant" means a use located on a sidewalk that is associated with the adjacent restaurant where food and beverages are prepared, served, sold, and/or delivered for consumption on the sidewalk. A sidewalk restaurant is characterized by tables and chairs and may be shaded by awnings, canopies, or umbrellas otherwise complying with city ordinances. 
 "Sidewalk restaurant items" means tables, chairs, umbrellas, planters, trash receptacles, portable railings, lights, and other items associated with the operation of a sidewalk restaurant. 
B.  A sidewalk restaurant may be operated adjacent to a restaurant and incident to the operation of a restaurant. Sidewalk restaurant items must be arranged in such a manner that an unobstructed path of not less than forty-eight (48) inches, exclusive of the width of the curb, is maintained at all times on the sidewalk or shall comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act requirements and/or United States Access Board guidelines for public rights-of-way, whichever is greater. Awnings, canopies, or umbrellas that extend into the walking area shall be eighty (80) inches in height above the walking area at its lowest point or shall comply with the Americans with Disabilities Act requirements, whichever is greater. 
C.  Sidewalk restaurant items shall be arranged so that no item is within forty-eight (48) inches of a fire hydrant, non-pedestrian alleyway, pedestrian crosswalk, or accessible curb cut. 
D.  Sidewalk restaurant items shall be maintained with a clean appearance and shall be in good repair at all times. Each day the owners, managers, or employees of the restaurant shall pick up and collect all trash, debris, and refuse that results from the use of the sidewalk restaurant and said trash, debris, and refuse shall be deposited in the regular solid waste system of the restaurant and shall not be deposited in any public waste can or other public receptacle. 
E.  If additional liquor licensing is required by law, then the owner of the restaurant adjacent to a sidewalk restaurant shall apply for and obtain appropriate licensing to extend its right to serve or sell alcoholic beverages to the area of the sidewalk restaurant prior to serving or selling any alcoholic beverages. 
F.  Section 5.12.070 of this code shall not apply to patrons of sidewalk restaurants who are seated at the tables provided and who are not otherwise creating a disturbance. 
G.  Any person violating this section shall be punished under Section 1.16.010 of this code. The conviction of any owner, agent, or employee of any restaurant for a violation of this section shall also result in the offending restaurant losing the right to operate a sidewalk restaurant for a period of six months and all sidewalk restaurant items shall be removed from the sidewalk during that period of time. 
(Ord. No. 5558, § 1, 8-19-14) 
12.04.070 - Excavations to be protected. 
    Any person who makes any excavation to the depth of one foot or more on or adjoining any street, sidewalk or other public place, or any person having charge or control of such excavation, who shall leave such excavation open or unguarded shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 24-7) 
12.04.080 - Street cuts. 
A.  No person shall cut into or dig into any city street except a licensed plumber, or other qualified person, and such person shall not do so until he shall have obtained a permit as provided herein. 
B.  No person shall cut into or dig into any city street except in the manner provided in this section. 
C.  A licensed plumber, or other qualified person, desiring to cut into or dig into a city street shall file with the city clerk a written or printed application requesting a permit to cut into or dig into such street. The application shall include the following: 
1.  The location of the proposed excavation; 
2.  The purpose for the proposed excavation; 
3.  The proposed date of opening and closing same. 
D.  The city clerk may, after the receipt of the aforesaid application, issue a permit. A fee for the permit shall be established by the street superintendent based upon the actual cost to city for the repaving or resurfacing of the excavation in question. The permittee shall pay the fee within thirty (30) days of receipt of the billing. 
E.  All streets shall be cut in a manner prescribed by the street superintendent, which shall be the least destructive to the street. A ditch or other excavation in the city streets shall be excavated and backfilled in accordance with the provisions of Title 13 of this code. 
F.  A ditch or other excavation in a city street shall be guarded and protected by permittee as directed by the street superintendent for fifteen (15) days after same is closed unless the condition of the closed ditch or excavation has been sooner accepted and approved by the street superintendent or his designate. The permittee shall indemnify and hold city harmless from and against any and all liability or causes of action arising from or out of the failure of permittee to comply with this section or any other ordinance until acceptance of the ditch or excavation by the street superintendent or his designate. 
G.  Any person violating the provisions of this section shall, upon conviction, be adjudged guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 24-8) 
12.04.090 - Street names-Authority of board to change. 
A.  Whenever it is deemed necessary by the board of aldermen to change the name of any street or avenue, the board shall, by resolution, declare such proposed change of name necessary to be made. 
B.  In the event the board of aldermen receives a written request from any resident property owner(s) desiring to change the name of the street or avenue upon which they reside, together with a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) publication fee, the board may, by resolution, declare such change of name necessary to be made. 
C.  In either case, the board shall cause such resolution to be published at least one week in some newspaper published in the city. If, within four weeks after such publication, a majority of the resident property owners along the line of such street or avenue do not file with the city clerk their written protest against such proposed change of name, then the board shall have the power, by ordinance, to change the name of such street or avenue in accordance with the terms of the resolution. 
D.  Upon passage and approval of such ordinances, the city clerk shall file with the recorder of deeds of Perry County a certified copy of the ordinance, and the recorder shall enter the same upon the records of the county. 
(Prior code § 24-9) 
Chapter 12.08 - STREET CONSTRUCTION AND REPAIR 
Sections: 

12.08.010 - Opening and vacating streets-Board authority. 
    The board of aldermen shall have power to create, open and improve any public square, public park, street, avenue, alley or other highway, old or new, and also to vacate or discontinue the same whenever deemed necessary or expedient; provided, that all damages sustained by the citizens of the city or the owners of the property therein shall be ascertained as prescribed in that portion of this chapter relating to the condemnation of private property for public use; and provided further, that whenever any public square, street, avenue or alley, or other highway, shall be vacated, the same shall revert to the owners of the adjacent lots in proportion as it was taken from them; and when the grade of any street or alley shall have been once established by ordinance, it shall not be lawful to change such grade without making compensation to all persons owning real estate on such street or square, avenue, alley or other highway, who may be damaged by such change of grade, to be determined and governed in all respects, with reference to benefit and damages, as is provided herein. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-18) 
12.08.020 - Street improvements-Cost. 
    The cost of paving, macadamizing, guttering and curbing (where such curb is set out into the street beyond the sidewalks) all streets, avenues, alleys and other highways, or any part thereof or any connection therewith, and repairing the same, and for doing all excavating and grading necessary for the same, after such streets, avenues, alleys and other highways or parts thereof or connections therewith, have been first brought to grade, as provided herein, shall be levied as a special assessment upon all lots and pieces of ground upon either side of such street, avenue, alley or other highway, or part thereof or connection therewith, abutting thereon, along the distance improved, in proportion to the front foot; provided, that the cost of paving, macadamizing, curbing and guttering any street, avenue, alley or highway, or any part thereof, and the cost of repairing and cleaning of the same and of making and repairing sidewalks may be paid out of the general revenue fund of the city or other funds which the city may have for such purposes, if the board of aldermen so desires, in which case the proceedings of the city for such improvements shall specify that payment will be made out of the general revenue funds or other funds in whole or in part. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-19) 
12.08.030 - Street crossing improvements-Special assessment. 
    The cost of paving or macadamizing the squares and areas as formed by the crossing or meeting of streets and other highways, or parts thereof or connections therewith, shall be levied as a special assessment, and paid for as follows: 
    Such area shall be divided into parts or portions by lines drawn lengthwise along the middle of each of the streets or highways so intersecting or meeting, and the cost of the parts or portion shall be levied as a special assessment against the block or square contiguous to each, and prorated against the lots or pieces of ground in such block or square abutting on the street improved. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-20) 
12.08.040 - Street improvements-Declaration of necessity-Taxpayer protests. 
    When the board of aldermen shall deem it necessary to pave, macadamize, gutter, curb (when such is set out in the street beyond the sidewalk) or otherwise improve any street, avenue, alley or other highway, or any part thereof, within the limits of the city for which a special tax is to be levied as herein provided, the board of aldermen shall, by resolution, declare the work or improvements necessary to be done, and cause the resolutions to be published in some newspaper published in the city for seven consecutive insertions in a daily paper or two consecutive insertions in a weekly paper. If a majority of the owners of the property liable to taxation therefor, residing in the city at the date of the passage of such resolution, shall not, within ten days from the date of the last insertion of the resolution, file with the city clerk their protest against, then the board of aldermen may cause the improvements to be made, and to contract therefor, and to levy the tax as herein provided. The findings of the board that a majority of such owners have not filed protest shall be conclusive and final. No publication shall be necessary for the making of any sidewalks, but on the petition of any ten citizens of the city the board of aldermen may make contracts for the construction of sidewalks, including grading therefor, with or without curbing, along any street, avenue or other public highway, or any part thereof whatever. The contract shall be let to the lowest and best bidder, upon plans and specifications filed therefor by the city engineer or other officer designated by the board of aldermen, with the city clerk, not less than one week's advertisement for bids thereupon being made in some newspaper published in the city. When upon proper advertisement no bid is received, the board of aldermen may proceed as provided herein. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-21) 
12.08.050 - Street repairs-Cost. 
    No formality shall be required to authorize the repairing of sidewalks, or of street or other paving, curbing, guttering, macadamizing or part thereof, or reconstructing the same, and making assessments therefor; but the proper officer or committee on improvements may, without notice, cause such work to be done, keeping an account of the cost thereof, and reporting the same to the board of aldermen for assessment; and each lot or piece of ground abutting on such sidewalk, street, avenue or alley, or part thereof, shall be liable for its part of the cost of any work or improvement provided for herein, done or made along or in front of such lot or piece of ground as reported to the board of aldermen, and all lands, lots and public parks owned by any county or city, and all other public lands, all cemeteries, owned by public, private or municipal corporations; provided, that nothing in this section shall be construed to authorize any assessment against any cemetery lot, and all railroad rights-of-way fronting or abutting on any of such improvements shall be liable for their proportionate part of the cost of such work and improvements, and tax bills shall be issued against such property as against other property, and any county or city that shall own any such property shall out of the general revenue funds pay any such tax bill, and in any case where any county or city or railroad company shall fail to pay any such tax bill, the owner of the same may sue such county, city or railroad company on such tax bill and be entitled to recover a general judgment against such county, city or railroad company. Any of the improvements to be paid for by such city may be paid for by the city out of the general revenue funds if the council so desires, but all such work and improvements shall be paid for with special tax bills unless the proceedings of the city for the same specify that payment will be made out of the general revenue funds of the city. The board of aldermen may provide a penalty for failure to pay such special tax within a given time, and any tax bills issued in payment of such repairs shall constitute a lien upon the property liable therefor until paid. All costs for building and constructing sidewalks shall be paid to the contractor therefor, in special tax bills assessed against the abutting property liable therefor, and such tax bills shall constitute a lien upon such property until paid, and shall bear interest at eight percent per annum from the date of issue. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-22) 
12.08.060 - Certain street improvements-Protest. 
    When the board of aldermen of any city of the fourth class shall deem it necessary to pave, macadamize, gutter, curb, grade or otherwise improve the roadway of any street or avenue for a distance not more than one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet in length so as to connect at both ends with paving, macadamizing, guttering, curbing, grading or other improvements either on the same street or avenue or other streets or avenues, or on the same street or avenue and another street or avenue, the board of aldermen shall declare such work to be necessary to be done and shall cause the same proceedings to be had as are provided herein, except no protest may be filed. The resolution passed and published shall state the fact that anyone desiring to do so may appear before the board of aldermen at a time stated therein and be heard on the question of the necessity of the work sought to be done, and if anyone does not appear he shall be heard, and the board of aldermen shall, by resolution, state the result of such hearing to be a reaffirmance of the necessity for the doing of such work or the contrary, as the board of aldermen may then decide. If no one appears, or if the board of aldermen reaffirm the necessity of the doing of such work and improvement, then it shall proceed with such work and improvement in the manner in this chapter provided for such work and improvement when no sufficient protest against such improvement is filed within the time limited therefor. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-23) 
12.08.070 - Special assessments for improvements. 
    Assessments made for constructing and repairing sidewalks and sidewalk curbing, and for sewers, and for grading, paving, excavating, macadamizing, curbing and guttering of any street, avenue, alley, square or other highway, or part thereof, and repairing the same, or for any other improvement authorized by this code or state law shall be known as "special assessments for improvements," and shall be levied and collected as a special tax, and a special tax bill shall issue therefor and be paid in the manner provided by ordinance. The board of aldermen shall cause plans and specifications for all projects, together with an estimate of the total cost for the projects, including construction, construction contingency and fees and other expenses, and an estimate of the portion of the total cost to be assessed against each property to be benefitted by the project, to be prepared by the city engineer or other proper officer, and filed with the city clerk, subject to the inspection of the public, and shall cause notice thereof to be published in some newspaper printed in the county for two consecutive insertions in a weekly paper. A public hearing shall be had before the board of aldermen upon the request of three or more citizens of the city, at which hearing citizens may express their assent or objection to such project. These special tax bills may include a reasonable construction contingency and an amount not to exceed twenty (20) percent of the total cost of the improvement to be used for payment of fees and other expenses, and tax bills may bear interest not to exceed the rate on ten-year United States treasury notes as established at the most recent auction; all the tax bills shall become due and payable sixty (60) days after the date of issue thereof, except in the case of tax bills payable in installments as herein provided; and, every special tax bill shall be a lien against the lot or tract or parcel of land described in the special tax bill for a period of ten years after date of issue, unless sooner paid, except in the case of special tax bills payable in installments, the lien of which shall not expire until one year after the date of maturity of the last installment, and except in any case where it becomes necessary to bring a suit to enforce the lien of any special tax bill, the lien of which shall continue until the expiration of the litigation. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-24) 
12.08.080 - Tax bills payable in annual installments-Effect of default on installment. 
    The total cost of constructing and repairing sidewalks and sidewalk curbing, and for grading, paving, excavating, macadamizing, curbing and guttering of any street, avenue, alley, square or other highway, or part thereof, and repairing the same, or for any other improvement whatsoever authorized by this code or state law, wherein a special tax bill shall issue therefor, may be paid in ten annual installments. In such case the tax bills shall be payable in annual installments as follows: one-tenth in one year, one-tenth in two years, one-tenth in three years, one-tenth in four years, one-tenth in five years, one-tenth in six years, one-tenth in seven years, one-tenth in eight years, one-tenth in nine years and one-tenth in ten years after the date of their issue, and tax bills may bear interest not to exceed the rate on ten-year United States treasury notes as established at the most recent auction, payable annually, from sixty (60) days after the date of issue until paid, and shall provide that if any annual installment, or the interest thereon, is not paid when due, then all of the remaining installments shall, at the option of the holder of the tax bill, become immediately due and payable; provided, that the owner of property charged with the payment of the tax bill, or the owner of any interest therein, shall have the privilege of paying the whole of any tax bill in full at any time, or on any annual installment payment date of paying in full one or more of the remaining installments not of maturity date. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-25) 
12.08.090 - Record of tax bills-Payment to owner or city. 
    The city clerk shall on completion of all special tax bills enter an abstract thereof in a special book provided for that purpose. The abstract shall recite the date of the tax bill, the name of the property owner and of the person in whose favor it is issued, and a description of the property subject to the lien, and the street upon which it abuts, amount of the tax bill, and the character of the improvement for which it is issued. When any tax bill is assigned, the assignment shall be noted thereon, and the assignee shall exhibit the same to the city clerk who shall, on the margin of the tax bill, appropriately note the assignment. The party liable to pay the tax bill may either pay the owner of the tax bill or he may pay the amount of the tax bill to the city clerk who shall accept the money and make out duplicate receipts therefor, one of which he shall deliver to the person so paying the tax bill and the other he shall file with the city clerk. Thereupon the city clerk shall note the filing of the receipt on the margin of the abstract of the tax bill and shall mark the latter 'canceled' and shall affix his name to the cancellation with the date thereof. The cancellation shall have the effect to extinguish all liability or right of action on the tax bill. The city clerk, on the presentation to him of the tax bill by its owner, shall pay to him the amount thereof, taking duplicate receipts therefor, one of which he shall file with the city clerk who shall note it on the margin of the abstract of the tax bill and the other the city clerk shall retain. The city clerk shall be liable on his bond for the collections. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-26) 
(Ord. No. 5748, § 26, 4-19-16) 
12.08.100 - Apportionment of costs of improvement and issuance of tax bills-Contents. 
    After the city has entered into a contract for construction of the improvements, in accordance with the contract for same, the engineer or other official in charge of the improvement shall compute the cost thereof, and apportion the cost among the tracts of land chargeable therewith, charging each tract of land with its proportionate part of the costs, and shall make a written report to the governing body of the municipality describing each tract of land chargeable with a part of the cost of the improvement, and the amount with which it is chargeable. If the board of aldermen approves the report, which approval may be made by a motion duly adopted, then the clerk shall immediately thereafter issue and deposit the special tax bills into a special fund as authorized by this code or state law, or, if appropriate, shall hold such special tax bills for delivery to the contractor upon completion of the project in payment for the work in accordance with the engineer's report, which tax bill shall be signed by the clerk and under the corporate seal of the city. Each tax bill shall in substance contain a brief general statement of the facts authorizing its issue, the amount for which it is issued, a description of the land against which it is issued, the name of the contractor to whom it is issued, the rate of interest which it bears, and when it begins to bear interest, and shall state that it is a special lien against the land therein described, and give the time that the lien continues. It need not give the name of the owner of the land against which it is issued. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-27) 
12.08.110 - Costs of improvement to be estimated-Contracts not to exceed estimate. 
    Before the governing body of the municipality shall make any contract for building bridges, sidewalks, culverts, or for paving, macadamizing, curbing, guttering or grading any street, avenue, alley or other highway, or building any other improvements authorized herein, an estimate of the cost thereof shall be made by the engineer or other proper officer or person designated by ordinance and submitted to the board of aldermen, and no contract shall be entered into for any work or improvement for a price exceeding the estimate; provided, that no estimate shall be required for the making of any local or special repairs. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-28) 
12.08.120 - Construction of street and sidewalk improvements by city-Special tax bills. 
    Whenever the board of aldermen shall advertise for bids for the construction of any new sidewalk of any kind, or for the construction of new sidewalks in the place of sidewalks condemned, or whenever the city shall advertise for bids for paving, macadamizing, guttering, curbing or otherwise improving any street, avenue, alley or other highway or any part thereof, and shall receive no bids therefor, the city may proceed to construct or reconstruct any sidewalks, or pave, macadamize, gutter, curb or otherwise improve any street at its own expense, and shall keep an accurate account of the amount expended for labor and material, including grading and filling, opposite each lot or piece of ground, and present the same to the board of aldermen for assessment, and each lot or piece of ground abutting on the sidewalk, constructed or reconstructed, or other street improvement made, shall be liable for the costs thereof, as reported to the board of aldermen by the officer or committee having charge of the matter, and special tax bills shall be issued for the amount thereof, payable to the city, against each lot or piece of ground for the amount for which it is liable. In making the assessment there may be as many assessments included in one ordinance as there are lots or pieces of ground reported as having received resulting benefits from the improvement. The special tax bills payable to the city shall be as valid in all respects as other tax bills provided herein, and where any tax bill has been assigned the city shall not in any event be liable for any cost that may accrue in any court action brought in the name of the city to the use of the holder thereof, nor shall the city be liable for the amount of any tax bill after the same is so assigned. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-29) 
12.08.130 - Bringing street to grade-Cost included in special assessment for surfacing. 
    The board of aldermen may, by ordinance, include in the special assessment for the paving, macadamizing or constructing sidewalks on any street, avenue or alley the cost of bringing to the established grade said street, avenue or alley, or part thereof, proposed to be improved; provided, that the resolution declaring the paving and macadamizing necessary to be done shall also declare that the street, avenue or alley, or part thereof, shall be brought to the established grade, and that the cost thereof shall be included in the special assessment for paying for the paving or macadamizing. 
(Ord. 3663 § 2 (part), 1998: prior code § 24-30) 
Chapter 12.12 - SURFACE WATER RUNOFF 

12.12.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter: 
    "Sinkhole" means any opening, crevice or other depression in the surface or below the surface of the earth. 
    "Stormwater" means that portion of the rainfall or other precipitation which runs off over the surface during a storm and for such a short period following a storm as the flow exceeds the normal or ordinary runoff. 
    "Surface water" means that portion of rainfall or other precipitation which runs off over the surface of the ground. 
    "Watercourse" means land which has a conformation so as to give surface water flowing from one tract of land to another tract of land a fixed and determinate course so as to uniformly discharge it upon the servient tract at a fixed and definite point. It includes, but is not limited to, ravines, swales, sinkholes or depressions of greater or lesser depth, extending from one tract and so situated as to gather up the surface water flowing upon dominant tract, and to conduct along a definite course to a definite point of discharge upon servient tract. It shall not be deemed to be important that the force of the water flowing from one tract of land to another has not been sufficient to wear out a channel or canal, having definite or well-marked sides or banks. If the surface water, in fact, uniformly or habitually flows over a given course having reasonable limits as to the width of the line of its flow, it shall be considered to have a definite course. 
(Prior code § 241/2-1) 
12.12.020 - Obstruction of watercourses and sinkholes prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to block, obstruct, destroy, cover, fill or alter in any way a watercourse or sinkhole, or any part thereof, so as to cause damage to the property of other persons from surface water. 
(Prior code § 241/2-2) 
12.12.030 - Violation-Public nuisance. 
    A violation of Section 12.12.020 shall be deemed to be a public nuisance as well as a misdemeanor. Whenever the city engineer or city administrator has determined that a person has blocked, obstructed, destroyed, covered, filled or altered in any way a watercourse or sinkhole so as to cause surface water damage to the property of others, the city engineer or city administrator is authorized to proceed in accordance with Chapter 8.20, so as to abate the public nuisance. The city engineer or city administrator shall proceed in accordance with the authority granted to and as though the city engineer or city administrator was the city health officer under Chapter 8.20 in ordering such nuisance abated. 
(Prior code § 241/2-3) 
12.12.040 - Building permits-Issuance. 
    Whenever the zoning administrator, building inspector, or city engineer of the city has reason to believe that work performed pursuant to a building permit may be in an area defined as a watercourse or sinkhole, or that work performed pursuant to a building permit may in some way interfere with the use and operation of a watercourse or sinkhole, or may violate the provisions of Section 12.12.020, the zoning administrator, building inspector or city engineer, before issuing or consenting to a building permit, shall refer the request for a building permit to the city administration for approval. Upon the matter being referred to the city administrator, the city administrator shall determine whether or not the work performed pursuant to the building permit will interfere with the use and operation of the watercourse or sinkhole. The city administrator may require the person requesting the building permit to submit information to the city administrator concerning the capacity of the watercourse or sinkhole, the amount of surface water runoff in the drainage area, and the amount of surface water runoff that would be caused by the issuance of the building permit. The city administrator, before approving the request, shall determine whether or not the applicant has made adequate provisions for surface water runoff so that the project will not interfere with the use and operation of a watercourse or sinkhole, except nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit the altering of a watercourse so long as it is done pursuant to a permit and provided the change does not cause damage to others or creates a condition which could cause damage to others in the opinion of the administrator. The permit may be conditioned upon compliance with standards established by the administrator so as to protect public health, safety and welfare so as to insure the project will not interfere with the use of the watercourse or sinkhole and that adequate provisions are made to protect the watercourse or sinkhole from any work being performed pursuant to the building permit. 
    In the event the city administrator determines that the permit cannot be issued because the city administrator has determined that the applicant cannot meet the condition, or has refused to meet the condition, the applicant shall be notified in writing and given an opportunity to present alternative plans to protect the watercourse or sinkhole, or to guarantee that the work will not interfere with the use of the watercourse or sinkhole. In the event the applicant is aggrieved by the decision of the city administrator, the applicant shall have the right to appeal the city administrator's decision to the board of aldermen, except no permit shall be issued unless the applicant can show that the provisions of Section 12.12.020 of this chapter will not be violated. The permit shall also provide that the applicant cannot block, obstruct, destroy, cover, fill or alter in any way whatsoever a watercourse or sinkhole so as to cause damage to adjoining property from surface water and that in the event it is determined that adjoining property is damaged, the authority to perform work pursuant to the building permit shall be null and void. 
(Prior code § 241/2-4) 
12.12.050 - Posting of land. 
    It is unlawful for any person to block, obstruct, destroy, cover, fill or alter in any way a watercourse or sinkhole when the watercourse or sinkhole has been posted by the city in accordance with the procedures established in this chapter. When the city administrator has determined that a person is blocking, obstructing, destroying, covering, filling or altering a watercourse or sinkhole which, in the opinion of the city administrator, will now or in the future cause damage to adjoining property, the city administrator is authorized to post private property, which posting shall clearly designate that the blocking, obstructing, destroying, covering, filling or altering in any way is prohibited.
