The city administrator shall give notice to the owner of the property, pursuant to the provisions set forth in Chapter 8.20, that it is unlawful for any person to fill, block, obstruct, cover, destroy or in any way alter the watercourse or sinkhole when the city administrator has determined that the damage to adjoining property might reasonably be caused now or in the future by such actions. The owner of the property may request a hearing before the city administrator, at which time the owner shall submit information pertaining to drainage as described in Section 12.12.040. The owner may request a hearing in front of the city administrator, and the owner shall at that time submit evidence concerning the surface water runoff in the area and his plans for the watercourse. In the event the city administrator determines that the owner's plans for the watercourse will not cause damage to adjoining property owners, the city administrator shall cause the order prohibiting the blocking, obstructing, destroying, filling, covering or altering to be removed. Adjoining property owners shall be notified of any hearing held in front of the city administrator, and such property owner may appear in the matter to be heard. In the event the city administrator determines that no further blocking, obstructing, filling, covering or altering of the watercourse can be permitted, the city administrator shall enter into an order so stating. The owner of the property for which a notice has been issued may appeal the decision of the city administrator under this section pursuant to the provisions of the administrative procedure act. 
(Prior code § 241/2-5) 
12.12.060 - Obstructing drainage. 
    Any person who shall destroy, tear up or otherwise injure, or fill up or otherwise obstruct any sewer, gutter, trench or channel dug, made or used for the purpose of carrying off water from or draining any street within the city shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 241/2-6) 
12.12.070 - Sinkhole remediation and management. 
A.  Remediation and Management. The city shall accept responsibility for the remediation and management of sinkholes for which it has been granted a permanent easement by the property owner under the terms and conditions set forth in this section. 
B.  Developed Property. The owner of a developed lot may apply to the city and request that the city accept responsibility for remediation and management of the sinkhole on said developed lot. If the city accepts said responsibility, then it shall design and construct the sinkhole improvement features. The property owner shall grant to the city an easement of a size no less than fifty (50) feet by fifty (50) feet square centered on the center of the sinkhole or the standpipe designed by the city. The property owner shall also grant an easement for ingress and egress to the sinkhole easement. The city shall only be responsible for the maintenance of the sinkhole utility designed and installed by it; all mowing, surface debris removal, and other aesthetic maintenance shall be the responsibility of the property owner. 
C.  Undeveloped Property. The owner of any undeveloped property shall be responsible for constructing sinkhole improvement features in a manner approved by the city prior to the development of the property. After the sinkhole improvement is constructed and installed, the owner of the undeveloped property may apply to the city and request that the city accept responsibility for remediation and management of the sinkhole on said undeveloped property. If the city accepts said responsibility, the property owner shall grant to the city an easement of a size no less than fifty (50) feet by fifty (50) feet square centered on the center of the standpipe constructed and installed unless the city determines that the property is used for agricultural purposes. In that event the minimum easement size shall be one hundred (100) feet by one hundred (100) feet square centered on the center of the standpipe constructed and installed. The property owner shall also grant an easement for ingress and egress to the sinkhole easement. The city shall only be responsible for the maintenance of the sinkhole utility constructed by the property owner and accepted by the city; all mowing, surface debris removal, and other aesthetic maintenance shall be the responsibility of the property owner. 
D.  Partially Developed Property. Upon being notified that a sinkhole exists on what the city determines to be a partially developed property, the city may agree to enter into a cost share agreement with the property owner in order to construct sinkhole improvement features. If the city accepts said responsibility, the city shall provide the design of the sinkhole improvement and the labor and equipment necessary to improve the sinkhole. The property owner shall pay for all materials necessary to construct the sinkhole improvement. The city may in its sole discretion determine that the sinkhole improvement will be constructed by private contractors. In that event, the property owner shall pay fifty (50) percent of the cost of constructing the sinkhole improvement. At the city's sole discretion the property owner's share of the cost of constructing the sinkhole improvement may be covered by the issuance of a special tax bill against the property upon which the sinkhole improvement is made and such special tax bill shall become a lien on the property in the same manner as provided elsewhere in this code for special tax bills. The property owner shall grant to the city an easement of a size no less than fifty (50) feet by fifty (50) feet square centered on the center of the standpipe constructed and installed unless the city determines that the property is used for agricultural purposes. In that event the minimum easement size shall be one hundred (100) feet by one hundred (100) feet square centered on the center of the standpipe constructed and installed. The property owner shall also grant an easement for ingress and egress to the sinkhole easement. The city shall only be responsible for the maintenance of the sinkhole utility constructed; all mowing, surface debris removal, and other aesthetic maintenance shall be the responsibility of the property owner. 
(Ord. No. 5437, § 1, 6-25-13) 
12.12.080 - Sinkhole improvement plan. 
A.  Policy Statement. Sinkholes provide a vital stormwater function within the city of Perryville. The Karst topography of the area is very prone to sinkholes and it is the responsibility of the city to enforce proper sinkhole maintenance and development to best protect the citizens, property and environment. The goal is not to develop every sinkhole within the city but only those deemed necessary by the city. This policy shall serve to guide that improvement. 
B.  Preferred Sinkhole Improvement Method. The city's typical sinkhole improvement process consists of excavating the depression and removing any debris (e.g. trash, soil, mud, gravel, etc.) present to expose the crevice or opening in the bedrock of the Karst subsurface system. Ideally, the crevice is excavated completely and a vertical standpipe (a forty-eight (48) inch diameter pre-cast concrete manhole preferred) is installed over the crevice. Any portions of the crevice that extend beyond the edge of the standpipe are grouted with low-slump concrete to effectively prevent groundwater from penetrating the crevice except through the opening within the standpipe. The standpipe is extended to the existing or proposed final ground elevation and the structure backfilled with graded crushed rock and compacted earth. The area around the standpipe is graded to allow surface runoff to drain into the standpipe opening. The standpipe shall be covered with a trash rack or other suitable grated intake to help ensure safety and prevent larger debris from entering the standpipe. Wherever possible, the area immediately surrounding the improved sinkhole is established as a vegetated buffer as a means of filtration to prevent sediment and other contaminants from entering the standpipe. The city shall acquire a permanent easement for perpetual maintenance of the improved sinkhole as set forth in Section 12.12.070. In general, the agricultural areas within the city limits will minimally require a 50-foot easement, measured from the center of the standpipe, to be used as a vegetative buffer area. In other areas within the city limits, the preferred easement and vegetative buffer area will minimally be a 25-foot radius measured from the center of the standpipe. It may be possible to reduce this vegetative buffer provided property owners apply herbicide in strict accordance with the instructions found on the label, maintaining appropriate set back requirements while also keeping in mind any aquatic life restrictions. (sinkhole improvement details at Section 12.12.080.F). 
C.  Alternative Sinkhole Improvement Methods. Each sinkhole improvement is unique due to variables such as the crevice depth and geometry, surface runoff drainage area, and the location of the sinkhole relative to existing and proposed developments. It may be necessary to take a customized approach on a specific sinkhole improvement and assess various design alternatives. These alternate approaches to improving the sinkhole may include, but are not limited to, the following: 
1.  Using a smaller diameter standpipe if the surface drainage area is small and/or if access to the crevice by a person is not necessary. 
2.  If the sinkhole location does not allow for the preferred buffer, and with the approval of the city, storm water runoff can be directed to a sedimentation or detention basin upstream of the sinkhole standpipe, mechanical filters upstream of the piping connection to the standpipe may be utilized, or other suitable methods to improve surface runoff water quality may be used with the approval of the city. 
D.  Temporary Best Management Practices. Prior to, during, and after sinkholes are improved it is important that any necessary best management practices (BMP's) are utilized when construction or land disturbance activities are performed within the watershed of a particular sinkhole. When any activities are performed upstream of the sinkhole that may induce sedimentation and pollution of surface water runoff, siltation and erosion control methods shall be installed. Additionally, any work on or in the immediate vicinity of the sinkhole shall be performed with siltation and erosion control measures in place and shall be timed with concern for weather conditions to minimize the possibility of sedimentation and polluted runoff from entering the sinkhole. 
E.  Permanent Best Management Practices. After sinkholes are improved it is important that any necessary best management practices (BMP's) are implemented. The primary BMP for surface water runoff quality shall be the vegetated buffer, or alternatively a sedimentation or detention basin, mechanical filters, or other method as approved by the city. Sinkholes will be inspected regularly and vegetated buffers shall be maintained by mowing or trimming methods rather than using chemical treatment. Grass clippings or other debris shall be kept clear from the standpipe opening. 
F.  Sinkhole Development Details. 
Editor's note- On following page. 

(Ord. No. 5889, § 1, 5-27-17) 
Chapter 12.16 - CITY PARKS 
Sections: 

12.16.010 - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words shall have the following meanings: 
    "City park" means all city-owned or county-owned real estate located within the city limits which is available for public use for recreational or leisure activities. 
    "County park" means all county-owned real estate located within the city limits which is available for public use for recreation or leisure activities. 
    "City neighborhood parks" means all city-owned parks other than the primary city park located in an area generally bordered by Kingshighway, Huber Road, Ste. Marie Street and North Street. 
(Ord. 4181 §1, 2001; Ord. 3986 § 1 (part), 2000; prior code § 21-15) 
12.16.020 - Littering prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to throw bottles, beer cans, melon rinds or other refuse and leave the same on any part of the city park. 
(Prior code § 21-16) 
12.16.030 - Damaging city property prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to injure, damage or deface any flowers, shrubbery, lawn, benches, tables or other city property in the city park. 
(Prior code § 21-17) 
112.16.040 - Glass beverage containers prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person or persons to use glass beverage containers in the city parks. For the purposes of this chapter, "glass beverage containers" means any glass container used by an individual for the immediate consumption of liquid which shall include, but not be limited to, soda bottles, beer bottles, whiskey bottles, wine bottles and soft drink bottles. 
(Prior code § 21-18) 
12.16.050 - Vehicles in park and horseback riding. 
    No person shall drive or operate any self-propelled motor vehicle, except automobiles and pickup trucks, on and along any drive in the city park except for the purpose of delivering or removing products or materials incidental to the operating of the park or to or from any organizational activity which is being carried on in the park. There shall be no horseback riding in the park. 
(Ord. 3986 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 21-19) 
12.16.060 - Camping. 
    There shall be no overnight camping in the city park, except if written permission is granted by the park board. 
(Prior code § 21-25) 
12.16.070 - Speed limit. 
    No motor vehicle shall travel on any street or road in the park at a rate of speed in excess of twenty (20) miles per hour. 
(Prior code § 21-20) 
12.16.080 - Exits from park. 
    All street exits from the park onto any state highway, county road or city street shall be considered a stop intersection, and when stop signs are in place the motor vehicle shall come to a full stop before proceeding onto any state highway, city street or county road. 
(Prior code § 21-21) 
12.16.100 - Parking-Parking on grass. 
A.  Any person driving a motor vehicle shall not be allowed to drive or park on any part of the city park grounds other than park roads, driveways or parking lots. 
B.  No person shall park a motor vehicle on the grass except in temporarily designated parking areas established by the parks director. 
(Ord. 3986 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 21-23) 
12.16.110 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5904, § 1, adopted June 20, 2017, repealed § 12.16.110, which pertained to tennis courts and derived from Ord. No. 5755, § 1, adopted May 3, 2016. 
12.16.120 - Park hours-Penalty for violation-Exemptions. 
A.  The city park and its roadways shall be closed to all persons and all vehicular traffic between the hours of one a.m. and five a.m. every day, including weekends and holidays, except as specifically exempted in subsections C and D of this section. 
1.  It is unlawful for any person or group of persons to enter, wander in, walk through, congregate, loiter or remain in the city park between the hours of one a.m. and five a.m. 
2.  It is unlawful for an operator of any vehicle, motorized or nonmotorized, and any bicycle rider to drive or ride into or through, park in, stop in, or remain in the city park between the hours of one a.m. and five a.m. 
B.  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall, upon being found guilty, be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by confinement in jail not exceeding ninety (90) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
C.  This section does not apply to city authorized personnel and employees while they are performing their functions as such employees and personnel. 
D.  Nothing in this section is to be construed so as to be in conflict with the curfew and other restrictions placed on the controlled area of city park as set out in Section 12.16.110. 
(Ord. 3986 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 21-27) 
12.16.121 - City Neighborhood Park-Park hours-Penalty for violation-Exemptions. 
A.  The city neighborhood parks and their roadways shall be closed to all persons and vehicular traffic between the hours of ten p.m. and five a.m. every day, including weekends and holidays, except as specifically exempted in subsection C of this section. 
1.  It is unlawful for any person or group of persons to enter, wander in, walk through, congregate, loiter or remain in the city neighborhood parks between the hours of ten p.m. and five a.m. 
2.  It is unlawful for an operator of any vehicle, motorized or nonmotorized, and any bicycle rider to drive or ride into or through, park in, stop in or remain in the city neighborhood parks between the hours of ten p.m. and five a.m. 
B.  Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this section shall, upon being found guilty, be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by confinement in jail not exceeding ninety (90) days or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
C.  This section does not apply to city authorized personnel and employees while they are performing their functions as such employees and personnel. 
(Ord. 4181 § 2, 2001) 
12.16.130 - Festivals in the city park prohibited-Exceptions. 
A.  As used in this chapter, unless the context clearly indicates otherwise, the word "festival" means any musical festival, dance festival, rock festival or similar musical activity likely to attract twenty (20) or more people at such an activity, at which music is provided by paid or amateur performers or by prerecorded means, and which is held in any city or county park within the city. 
B.  Prohibition. It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate, maintain, conduct, advertise, encourage, sell or furnish tickets for a festival in any city or county park within the city limits. 
C.  Exceptions. Upon application to the board of aldermen, the board of aldermen may allow exceptions to the provision of this section and provide such restrictions, guidelines or regulations as the board may in its sole discretion determine necessary or proper. 
(Prior code § 21-28) 
12.16.140 - Fund raising and commercial activities prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate, maintain, conduct, advertise, provide, sponsor or otherwise encourage any fund-raising, commercial or money-making activities in any city or county park in this municipality without specific written permission of the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 21-29) 
12.16.150 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person or persons violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall, upon being found guilty, be punished by a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. 3986 § 1 (part), 2000: prior code § 21-26) 
12.16.151 - Specific waiver. 
    The city administrator or his designate may waive in writing any specific provision of this chapter to accommodate special park activities. 
(Ord. 3986 § 1 (part), 2000) 
Chapter 12.20 - MUNICIPAL AIRPORT 
Sections: 

12.20.010 - Consent to ordinances. 
    Any person making use of the Perryville Municipal Airport or grounds owned by the city adjacent thereto, or found thereon, or being thereon, shall be held to have consented to all ordinances of a general nature as being applicable to his conduct in or over the airport, just as they are applicable to persons within the city limits. 
(Prior code § 3-26) 
12.20.020 - Jurisdiction of board of aldermen. 
    The board of aldermen of the city shall have jurisdiction over the airport and persons in, on, or over it. The board of aldermen may delegate their authority to enforce city ordinances and rules and regulations at the airport to the city administrator or his designate. 
(Prior code § 3-27) 
12.20.030 - Scope of general ordinances. 
    All general ordinances of the city pertaining to the conduct of persons in the establishment of businesses shall be in full force and effect at the airport and its property adjacent to it owned by the city. 
(Prior code § 3-28) 
12.20.040 - Promulgation of rules and regulations. 
    The city administrator or his designate, with the approval of the board of aldermen, shall promulgate such rules and regulations as necessary to insure the orderly conduct of the affairs of the airport. Such rules and regulations, when adopted, shall be printed and copies of the rules and regulations be put in prominent places throughout the airport. A copy of the regulations shall be given to all persons leasing, buying any real property, or operating any business within the airport, at the time the lease is entered into, purchase made or business operated. 
(Prior code § 3-29) 
12.20.050 - Construction permits and business licenses. 
    Any person conducting any business for which a license would be required if it were located within the city or constructing any building for which a building permit would be required if it were located within the city shall secure a license and/or building permit and pay the fees required. The city clerk, or the person authorized to issue such licenses and/or building permits, may designate a deputy for the purposes of issuing such licenses and receiving said fees therefore. 
(Prior code § 3-30) 
12.20.060 - Airport operations established. 
    There are established airport operational ordinances. These ordinances shall be enforced by the city administrator or his designate, any and all deputized police officers, and the fixed-base operators located at the Perryville Municipal Airport. 
(Prior code § 3-36) 
12.20.070 - Prohibited conduct. 
    It is unlawful for any person, except fixed base operators appointed by the city, to: 
A.  Operate any ground vehicle on any taxiway or runway of the Perryville Municipal Airport; 
B.  Store fuel or provide fuel for sale at the Perryville Municipal Airport; 
C.  Obstruct any designated access way to the Perryville Municipal Airport; or 
D.  Violate the rules and regulations of the Federal Aviation Administration. 
(Prior code § 3-37) 
12.20.080 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person violating the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be adjudged guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be punished as provided in Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 3-38) 
12.20.090 - Violation-Revocation of rights and privileges. 
    Any violation of the provisions of this code or the airport rules and regulations shall be sufficient cause for revocation of any and all rights or privileges relative to the use and rental of hanger space and/or use of the Perryville Municipal Airport. 
(Prior code § 3-39) 
12.20.100 - Certain ordinances saved from repeal. 
    The following ordinances pertaining to the municipal airport are expressly saved from repeal: 
A.  Ordinance No. 812, enacted on June 24, 1946, which provides that the city accept the guarantee by the Chamber of Commerce of Perryville to keep the city free from any financial loss resulting in the operation of Chester Field as a municipal airport. 
B.  Ordinance No. 813, enacted on June 24, 1946, entitled "An ordinance to enable the City of Perryville, Missouri to secure an airport for public use by purchase, grant and lease." 
C.  Ordinance No. 1247, enacted on September 2, 1971, entitled "An ordinance entering into a lease agreement with Aviation Services Division, North American Rockwell Corporation, on the Perryville Municipal Airport; authorizing the mayor to execute said lease in behalf of the city, stating when this ordinance shall take effect; and repealing all ordinances in conflict therewith." 
(Prior code § 3-16) 
Title 13 - PUBLIC SERVICES 
Chapters: 
Chapter 13.02 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
Sections: 

13.02.010 - Excavations notification required. 
A.  Except as otherwise provided by the laws of the state of Missouri, it shall be unlawful for any person to begin any excavation in or on any privately held property within the limits of the city, any public or private street, road or alley, right-of-way dedicated to the public use, utility easement of record or prescriptive easement without first giving notice of intent to excavate. An excavator shall serve notice of intent to excavate in the manner and form required by Section 319.026, RSMo, and any amendment thereto. 
B.  For the purpose of this chapter, excavation shall mean any operation in which earth, rock or other material in or on the ground is moved, removed or otherwise displaced by means of any tools, equipment or explosives and includes, without being limited to, backfilling, grading, scraping, cable or pipe plowing, plowing-in; pulling-in, ripping, driving and demolition of structures, except that the use of mechanized tools and equipment to break and remove pavement and masonry down only to the depth of such pavement or masonry, the use of high-velocity air to disintegrate and suction to remove earth, rock and other materials and the tilling of soil for agricultural or seeding purposes shall not be deemed excavation. Backfilling or moving earth on the ground in connection with other excavation operations at the same site shall not be deemed separate instances of excavation. 
C.  Any violation of this section is unlawful and shall be punished under Chapter 1.16 of this code. 
D.  In addition to any criminal penalty, any individual, firm, corporation or entity that violates the provisions of this section shall be liable to the owners of any underground facility damaged by the unlawful excavation for the fair and reasonable expenses incurred in repairing or replacing the damaged facilities. In addition, they shall be liable to the owners of any other underground facilities for the costs incurred incidentally due to repair of the damaged facilities including, without limitation and by way of example only, emergency locates, overtime compensation and excavation. An action for damages under this section may be filed in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Ord. No. 5145, § 1, 9-7-10) 
13.02.015 - Underground facility safety and damage prevention. 
    The state of Missouri has implemented the "Underground Facility Safety and Damage Prevention Act" and has codified that in Sections 319.010 through 319.050 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. In order to protect its citizens and in order to provide for facility safety and damage prevention, all property owners and contractors or other individuals doing work within the city shall: 
A.  Complete an application for service on the form supplied by the city prior to any water, sewer, or natural gas installation regardless of whether said installation is to be completed by the contractor or the property owner. Precise location coordinates and as-built drawings for all underground facilities shall be provided to the city by the person performing the installation. 
B.  The installer shall furnish and install a coated solid copper trace wire on all non-conductive water, sewer, and natural gas service lines in the trench alongside the pipe. The trace wire shall be in accordance with the city's trace wire specification document. 
C.  The trace wire shall be twelve (12) gauge minimum and run continuously without splices for the full length of the service line from the building to the water, sewer, or natural gas main. If splicing is necessary, a direct bury splice kit is required in accordance with the city's trace wire specification document. 
D.  The trace wire shall daylight at the point of entry at the foundation of the building through PVC conduit and be permanently attached to a test station as a future contact point to locate the service. The test station shall be in accordance with the city's trace wire specification document. 
E.  The trace wire shall be installed on all new water main installations in the street/roadway and shall come to the surface at every fire hydrant for termination in accordance with the city's trace wire specification document. 
F.  In some circumstances the public works department and/or building official may also require trace wire be extended to curb boxes, clean-outs, gutter drains, fire hydrants, or other similar underground infrastructure in accordance with the city's trace wire specification document. 
G.  All other ordinances concerning the water, sewer, and natural gas systems of the city will be complied with. 
H.  Any violation of this section is unlawful and shall be punished under Chapter 1.16 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 5602, § 1, 1-6-15) 
13.02.020 - Obstructions to utility equipment. 
A.  Vegetation shall not be planted, maintained or permitted to grow in any location where the vegetation hinders access to utility equipment or damages underground service utilities. 
B.  Obstructions shall not be placed in a location where they hinder access to utility equipment. 
C.  In addition to any other remedy available to the city, the city may remove any vegetation or obstruction at the cost to the property owner and tax bill the property owner for the cost of the removal. 
D.  Any violation of subsections A or B of this section is unlawful and may be punished under Chapter 1.16 of this code. 
(Ord. No. 5149, § 1, 9-21-10) 
13.02.030 - Excavations in or on city right-of-way. 
A.  No person shall make or cause to be made any excavation in; encroachment on; lay, locate, erect, remove, maintain, or repair any conduit, pole, pole line, wire, main, pipe, conductor, sewer, tramway, or drain within, upon, over or across; or move any building or other structure upon, over, or across any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk, or public easement without first having filed an application with and obtained a permit therefor from the city clerk. No permit required under this section shall be issued without the approval of the public works director. 
B.  All applications for permits required under this section shall be referred to the public works director for his review and recommendation. If the public works director finds that the applicant has complied with all the requirements of this section and all other ordinances, laws, and regulations of the city, he shall recommend to the city clerk that the permit be issued. 
C.  The city clerk shall collect for the granting of each permit required under this section a fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to cover the city's administrative, inspection, and other costs. 
D.  No person shall receive any permit to excavate in or under any street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk, or public easement until such person shall have first submitted a performance bond in the amount of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00) guaranteeing payment for all restoration and repair of damages to any facility on the city right-of-way. Said bond shall be in a form approved by the city and obtained from duly licensed or authorized companies. The bond shall stay in effect for three years after the completion of the work. 
E.  If the person making an excavation under a permit issued under this section shall delay or refuse, after due notice from the city, to restore such street, avenue, boulevard, road, alley, highway, sidewalk, or public easement in or under which such excavation has been made to as good a condition as it was prior to such excavation, it shall be the duty of the public works director to make such restoration. The expense of the restoration or repair shall be paid to the city from the bond referred to in subsection D of this section. 
(Ord. No. 6076 , § 1, 10-2-18) 
Chapter 13.04 - WATER AND SEWER SERVICE SYSTEMS GENERALLY 
Sections: 

13.04.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter, the following words and phrases shall, unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section: 
    "Act" or "the Act" means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act, also known as the Clean Water Act, as amended, 33 USC 1251 et seq. 
    "Approval authority" means the state of Missouri, Department of Natural Resources, Clean Water Division. 
    Authorized Representative of the Industrial User. 
1.  If the industrial user is a corporation, "authorized representative" means: 
a.  The president, secretary, treasurer, or a vice president of the corporation in charge of a principal business function, or any other person who performs similar policy or decision-making functions for the corporation, 
b.  The manager of one or more manufacturing, production, or operation facilities employing more than two hundred fifty (250) persons or having gross annual sales or expenditures exceeding twenty-five million dollars ($25,000,000.00) (in second quarter 1992 dollars), if authority to sign documents as been assigned or delegated to the manager in accordance with corporate procedures; 
2.  If the industrial user is a partnership, or sole proprietorship, "authorized representative" means a general partner or proprietor, respectively; 
3.  If the industrial user is a federal, state or local governmental facility, "authorized representative" means a director or highest official appointed or designated to oversee the operation and performance of the activities of the government facility, or his/her designee; 
4.  The individuals described in subdivisions (1) through (3) above may designate another authorized representative if the authorization is in writing, the authorization specifies the individual or position responsible for the overall operation of the facility from which the discharge originates or having overall responsibility for environmental matters for the company, and written authorization is submitted to the city. 
    "BOD (biochemical oxygen demand)" means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure in five days at twenty (20) degrees centigrade, expressed in parts per million by weight. 
    "Box (meter)" means any approved box or vault for housing of water meters. 
    "Building" means a structure constructed for permanent use, such as, but not limited to, a house, apartment or factory. 
    "Building inspector" means an individual appointed by the city to administer and enforce the building code, plumbing code, electrical code, mechanical code, zoning ordinances, and subdivision regulations of the city. 
    "Categorical industry" means an industrial subcategory for which the U.S. EPA has set or will establish national pretreatment standards specifying the quantities or concentrations of pollutants or pollutant properties that can be discharged to POTW. 
    "Categorical pretreatment standard" or "categorical standard" means any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the U.S. EPA in accordance with Sections 307(b) and (c) of the Act (33 USC 1317) which apply to a specific category of industrial users and which appear in 40 CFR Chapter I, Subchapter N, Parts 405 through 471. 
    "Cesspool" means a pit for the reception or detention of sewage. 
    "City" means the city of Perryville, Missouri, or its authorized agent. 
    "Color" means the optical density at the visual wavelength of maximum absorption, relative to distilled water. One hundred (100) percent transmittance is equivalent to zero optical density. 
    "Combined sewer" means a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage. 
    "Commercial user" means an individual owner or operator of a commercial or business-related establishment that discharges domestic or sanitary wastewater to the city's wastewater collection system. 
    "Composite sample" means the sample resulting from the combination of individual wastewater samples taken at selected intervals based on an increment of either flow or time. 
    "Consumer" or "customer" means the person being served by or legally using water supplied by the city or using the sanitary sewerage facilities of the city. 
    "Corporation stop" means a valve which is inserted into the main for the connection of the water supply service pipes in sizes up to and including two inches in diameter. 
    "Department of Natural Resources" means the department of the Missouri government under which the rules, regulations and objectives related to environmental quality are developed, administered and enforced. The Division of Environmental Quality is the body of the department specifically responsible for water quality and water pollution control. 
    "Division of Health" means the Division of Health of the state Department of Public Health and Welfare of Missouri or its authorized representative. 
    "Domestic or sanitary wastewater" means the liquid waste from any residence, business, institution or other facility which is related directly to human habitation or occupancy. 
    "Drain" means a sewer or other pipe or conduit used for conveying ground, surface or stormwater. 
    "Environmental Protection Agency" or "EPA" means the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, or where appropriate, the term may also be used as a designation for the Regional Water Management Division Director or other duly authorized official of said agency. 
    "Existing source" means any source of discharge, the construction or operation of which commenced prior to the publication of proposed categorical pretreatment standards which will be applicable to such source if the standard is thereafter promulgated in accordance with Section 307 of the Act. 
    "Garbage" means solid wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food, and from the handling, storage and sale of produce. 
    "Grab sample" means a sample which is taken from a waste stream on a one-time basis without regard to the flow in the waste streams and without consideration of time. 
    "Groundwater" means the water in the zone of saturation found in voids and interstices below the ground surface. 
    "Indirect discharge" or "discharge" means the introduction of (nondomestic) pollutants into the POTW from any nondomestic source regulated under Section 307(b), (c) or (d) of the Act. 
    "Industrial user" or "user" means a source of indirect discharge. 
    "Industrial user surcharge" shall be the charge levied on significant industrial dischargers based on the quantity of BOD5 and TSS discharged to the city sewer system. 
    "Industrial wastewater" means the liquid waste from industrial processes as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastewater. 
    "Instantaneous maximum allowable discharge limit" means the maximum concentration (or loading) of a pollutant allowed to be discharged at any time, determined from the analysis of any discrete or composite sample collected, independent of the industrial flow rate and the duration of the sampling event. 
    "Interference" means a discharge which alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources: (1) inhibits or disrupts the POTW, its treatment processes or operations or its sludge processes, use or disposal; and (2) therefore is a cause of a violation of the city's NPDES permit or any of the prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal in compliance with any of the following statutory/regulatory provisions or permits issued thereunder (or more stringent state or local regulations): Section 405 of the Clean Water Act; the Solid Waste Disposal Act (SWDA), including Title II commonly referred to as the Resource Conservation and Recovery Act (RCRA); any state regulations contained in any state sludge management plan prepared pursuant to Subtitle D of the SWDA; the Clean Air Act; the Toxic Substances Control Act; and the Marine Protection, Research and Sanctuaries Act. 
    "Mains or lines (city or public)" means the system of pipes, valves, fittings and equipment used to distribute water or collect sewage throughout the area. 
    "Mains (private)" means any system of pipes, valves, fittings and equipment used to distribute water or collect sewage within the area served by the city water and sewer system but owned privately by any person. 
    "Manufacturing waste" means the liquid wastes from manufacturing processes as distinct from domestic or sanitary wastes. 
    "Medical waste" means isolation wastes, infectious agents, human blood and blood byproducts, pathological wastes, sharps, body parts, fomites, etiologic agents, contaminated bedding, surgical wastes, potentially contaminated laboratory wastes and dialysis wastes. 
    "Missouri Clean Water Commission" means the six-member, governor-appointed commission responsible for carrying out the state water conservation and water quality objectives. The Division of Environmental Quality under the state Department of Natural Resources is the working body of the commission. 
    "Natural outlet" means any outlet into a watercourse, pond, ditch, sinkhole, lake or other body of surface or groundwater, or any outlet not connected to a sanitary or public sewer. 
    "New source" means: 
1.  Any building, structure, facility or installation from which there is or may be a discharge of pollutants, the construction of which commenced after the publication of proposed pretreatment standards under Section 307(c) of the Act which will be applicable to such source if such standards are thereafter promulgated in accordance with that section, provided that: 
a.  The building, structure, facility or installation is constructed at a site at which no other source is located, or 
b.  The building, structure, facility or installation totally replaces the process or production equipment that causes the discharge of pollutants at an existing source, or 
c.  The production or wastewater generating processes of the building, structure, facility or installation are substantially independent of an existing source at the same site. In determining whether these are substantially independent, factors such as the extent to which the new facility is integrated with the existing plant, and the extent to which the new facility is engaged in the same general type of activity as the existing source, should be considered; 
2.  Construction on a site at which an existing source is located results in a modification rather than a new source if the construction does not create a new building, structure, facility or installation meeting the criteria of subdivision (1)(b) or (c) above but otherwise alters, replaces or adds to existing process or production equipment; 
3.  Construction of a new source as defined under this paragraph has commenced if the owner or operator has: 
a.  Begun, or caused to begin as part of a continuous on-site construction program: 
i.  Any placement, assembly or installation of facilities or equipment, or 
ii.  Significant site preparation work including clearing, excavation or removal of existing buildings, structures or facilities which is necessary for the placement, assembly or installation of new source facilities or equipment, or 
b.  Entered into a binding contractual obligation for the purchase of facilities or equipment which are intended to be used in its operation within a reasonable time. Options to purchase or contracts which can be terminated or modified without substantial loss, and contracts for feasibility, engineering and design studies do not constitute a contractual obligation under this subsection. 
    "Noncontact cooling water" means water used for cooling which does not come into direct contact with any raw material, intermediate product, waste product, or finished product. 
    "Nonsignificant industrial discharger" means any industrial user not classified as a significant industrial discharger. 
    "Operation and maintenance costs" means those costs including, but not limited to, administration, personnel, utilities, chemicals, repair parts, equipment, supplies, vehicles and replacement funds for the entire sewage system. 
    "Pass through" means a discharge which exits the POTW into waters of the U.S. in quantities or concentrations which, alone or in conjunction with a discharge or discharges from other sources, is a cause of a violation of any requirement of the city's NPDES permit (including an increase in the magnitude or duration of a violation). 
    "Penalties" means fines assessed any person, firm or corporation for the violation(s) of the city's of code related to the operation of the water and sewer systems. 
    "Perryville pretreatment program" means the written program and subsequent implementation/operation procedures developed pursuant to the federal general pretreatment regulations (46FR9404) for the purpose of identifying, monitoring and controlling the discharge of industrial wastewater to the city's sewer system. 
    "Person" means any individual, partnership, copartnership, firm, company, corporation, association, joint stock company, trust, estate, governmental entity or any other legal entity, or their legal representatives, agents or assigns. This definition includes all federal, state or local governmental entities. 
    "pH" means a measure of the acidity or alkalinity of a substance, expressed in standard units. 
    "Plumber" means a plumber who is qualified to perform work required for the installation of the necessary piping and fittings for service connections and who is licensed by the city. 
    "Pollutant" means any dredged spoil, solid waste, incinerator residue, sewage, garbage, sewage sludge, munitions, medical wastes, chemical wastes, industrial wastes, biological materials, radioactive materials, heat, wrecked or discharged equipment, rock, sand, cellar dirt, agricultural and industrial wastes, and the characteristics of the wastewater (i.e., pH, temperature, TSS, turbidity, color, BOD, chemical oxygen, (COD), toxicity, odor). 
    "Pollution" means the addition of sewage, industrial wastes or other harmful or objectionable materials to water. 
    "Potable water" means water which is safe for drinking or other sanitary purposes and is also suitable for domestic use. 
    "Premise" or "premises" means a property which cannot be completely divided in its present utilitarian condition through sale, such as: 
1.  A building under one roof owned, leased or occupied by one person as one business or residence; 
2.  A combination of residential or commercial buildings, leased or occupied by one person in one common enclosure; 
3.  The one side of a double house having a solid vertical partition wall; 
4.  A building owned by one person having more than one internal division, such as but not limited to, an apartment, office or store and which may have a common or separate entrance. 
    "Pretreatment" means the reduction of the amount of pollutants, the elimination of pollutants, or the alteration of the nature of pollutant properties in wastewater prior to or in lieu of introducing such pollutants to the POTW. This reduction or alteration can be obtained by physical, chemical or biological processes, by process changes or by other means, except by diluting the concentration of the pollutants unless allowed by an applicable pretreatment standard. 
    "Pretreatment requirements" means any substantive or procedural requirement related to pretreatment imposed on an industrial user, other than a pretreatment standard. 
    "Pretreatment standards" or "standards" means prohibitive discharge standards, categorical pretreatment standards, and local limits. 
    "Process wastes" means process water, industrial wastes, manufacturing wastes, toxic pollutants or any combination thereof. 
    "Process water" means water that comes in contact with an end product or materials incorporated in an end product. 
    "Prohibited discharge standards" or "prohibited discharges" means absolute prohibitions against the discharge of certain substances; these prohibitions appear in Section 13.20.020. 
    "Properly shredded garbage" means the wastes from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of food that has been shredded to such a degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle greater than one-third inch in any dimension. 
    "Public works director" means an individual appointed by the city to be responsible for planning, directing, and managing the administration of the city's public works operations department, which includes, but is not limited to, managing natural gas, water production, treatment and distribution, sewer collection, wastewater treatment, street maintenance, pavement management, street lighting, and refuse. 
    "Publicly owned treatment works" or "POTW" means a "treatment works" as defined by Section 212 of the Act (33 USC 1292), which is owned by the state or municipality. This definition includes any devices or systems used in the collection, storage, treatment, recycling and reclamation of sewage or industrial wastes and any conveyances which convey wastewater to a treatment plant. The term also means the municipal entity having jurisdiction over the industrial users and responsibility for the operation and maintenance of the treatment works. 
    "Public user" means any governmental, religious or educational facility or institution that discharges domestic or sanitary wastewater to the city's sewer system. 
    "Residential user" means individual homeowners or individuals that reside in residential housing that discharge domestic or sanitary wastewater to the city's sewer system. 
    "Revenue bond retirement" means the cost of all revenue bonds approved by the city and sold for sewage system improvements shall be included in the user's service charge for maximum retirement period of twenty (20) years. 
    "Roof drain" means a conduit for conveying the storm or rainwater from a roof. 
    "Sanitary sewer" means a sewer intended to receive sanitary sewage with or without industrial wastes and without the admixture of surface or stormwater. 
    "Segregated domestic wastes" means wastes which come solely out of restroom facilities and other sanitary conveniences. 
    "Septic tank" means a tank through which sewage flows and which permits solids in the sewage to settle in order that portions of such solids may be disintegrated by biological action. 
    "Septic tank waste" means any sewage from holding tanks such as vessels, chemical toilets, campers, trailers and septic tanks. 
    "Service control valve" means a valve for installation in water service pipes located at or near the main. 
    "Service control valve box" means a box or metal housing which encloses, protects and provides access to the service control valve. 
    "Service lateral" means the conduit or pipe from the sewer line to the building served. 
    "Sewage" means the water-carried waste products or discharges from human beings or animals or chemicals or other wastes from public or private buildings, swimming pools or industrial establishments together with such ground, surface or stormwater as may be present. Sewage is synonymous with, and typically called, wastewater. 
    "Sewerage system" means and includes any or all of the following: 
1.  Sewerage systems and sewage treatment plants, with all appurtenances necessary for the useful and convenient collection, treatment, purification and disposal in a sanitary manner of the liquid and solid waste, sewerage and domestic and industrial waste of the city; 
2.  Storm, water and sanitary systems, or any combination thereof; 
3.  The present system and all additions and extensions that may be acquired and constructed in the future. 
    "Sewage treatment plant" means any arrangement of devices and structures used for treating sewage. Sewage treatment plant is synonymous with, and typically called, wastewater treatment plant. 
    "Significant industrial user" applies to: (a) industrial users subject to categorical pretreatment standards; and (b) any other industrial user that: (i) discharges an average of twenty-five thousand (25,000) gpd or more of process wastewater, (ii) contributes a process wastestream which makes up five percent or more of the average dry weather hydraulic or organic capacity of the treatment plant, or (iii) is designated as significant by the city on the basis that the industrial user has a reasonable potential for adversely affecting the POTW's operation or for violating any pretreatment standard or requirement. 
    "Significant violation" means a violation of the national pretreatment standards or general pretreatment requirements that remains uncorrected forty-five (45) days after notification of noncompliance, is part of a pattern of noncompliance over a twelve (12) month period, involves a failure to accurately report noncompliance, or results in a penalty under the provisions of Section 13.20.110. 
    "Sinkhole" means any opening, crevice or other depression in the surface or below the surface of the earth. 
    "Slug load" means any discharge at a flow rate or concentration which could cause a violation of the prohibited discharge standards in Section 13.20.020 or any discharge of a nonroutine, episodic nature, including but not limited to, an accidental spill or a noncustomary bath discharge. 
    "Standard industrial classification (SIC) code" means a classification pursuant to the Standard Industrial Classification Manual issued by the U.S. Office of Management and Budget. 
    "Stop and waste valve" means a valve installed at the termination of the water supply service pipe of three-fourths inch and one-inch sizes, and at the beginning of the consumer's plumbing system. 
    "Stormwater" means any flow occurring during or following any form of natural precipitation, and resulting therefrom, including snowmelt. 
    "Superintendent" means the superintendent of the waterworks and sewerage works system of the city, or his authorized deputy, agent or representative. 
    "Surface water" means that portion of rainfall or other precipitation which runs off over the surface of the ground. 
    "Suspended solids" means solids that either float on the surface of or are in suspension in water, sewage or other liquids and which are removable by laboratory filtering. 
    "Tap" means the drilling of an opening in any main or line for insertion of a corporation stop. 
    "Tile (meter)" means a vitrified tile especially made for the housing of water meters. 
    "TSS (total suspended solids)" means the quantity of suspended matter in a water or wastewater expressed in parts per million by weight. 
    "Toxic pollutant" means one of one hundred twenty-six (126) pollutants, or combination of those pollutants, listed as toxic in regulations promulgated by the EPA under the provision of Section 307 (33 USC 1317) of the Act. 
    "Treatment plant effluent" means any discharge of treated wastewater from the POTW into waters of the state. 
    "User service charge" means the charge levied on all users of the city sewer system for the cost of operation, maintenance, replacement and debt retirement. 
    "Violation surcharge" means the surcharge applicable to any user of the city's sewer system that violates any provision of Chapter 13.16, regarding prohibited discharges. 
    "Wastewater" means liquid and water-carried industrial wastes, and sewage from residential dwellings, commercial buildings, industrial and manufacturing facilities, and institutions, whether treated or untreated, which are contributed to the POTW. 
    "Wastewater treatment plant or treatment plant" means that portion of the POTW designed to provide treatment of sewage and industrial waste. 
    "Watercourse" means a channel in which a flow of water occurs, either continuously or intermittently. 
    "Waterworks system" means and includes the entire water distribution system of the city, including pumping plants, lift stations, distribution mains and pipes, and all auxiliary machines and equipment in connection therewith of the city. 
    "Shall" is mandatory; "may" is permissive or discretionary. 
    The use of the singular shall be construed to include the plural and the plural shall include the singular as indicated by the context of its use. 
    Abbreviations. The following abbreviations shall be the designated meanings: 
    BOD-Biochemical oxygen demand; 
    CFR-Code of Federal Regulations; 
    COD-Chemical oxygen demand; 
    EPA-U.S. Environmental Protection Agency; 
    gpd-Gallons per day; 
    l-Liter; 
    mg-Milligrams; 
    mg/l-Milligrams per liter; 
    NPDES-National Pollutant Discharge Elimination System; 
    O&M-Operation and maintenance; 
    POTW-Publicly owned treatment works; 
    RCRA-Resource Conservation and Recovery Act; 
    SIC-Standard industrial classifications; 
    SWDA-Solid Waste Disposal Act (42 USC 6901 et seq.); 
    TSS-Total suspended solids; 
    USC-United States Code. 
(Prior code § 28-1) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 1, 8-2-11) 
13.04.020 - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this title is to provide for better water and sewer service, to protect the public health and welfare by abating the pollution of water, to create means for a continued supply of wholesome water and to meet the demands of an expanding city as authorized and directed by the laws of this state and the rules and regulations of the United States Department of Health and Welfare and the Division of Health of Missouri. 
(Prior code § 28-2) 
13.04.030 - Waterworks and sewerage system combined. 
    The waterworks system and the sewerage system owned and operated by the city are combined and declared to be one municipal utility, together with all future improvements or extensions, whether to the waterworks or to the sewerage system, or to both, and shall be operated and maintained as one unit, as provided by state law. 
(Prior code § 28-3) 
13.04.040 - Financing cost of combined system. 
    The cost to the city for acquiring, constructing, improving or extending its combined waterworks and sewerage system may be met as follows: 
A.  Through the expenditure of any city funds available for that purpose; 
B.  From the issuance of bonds for that purpose, payable from taxes to be levied by the city; 
C.  From the proceeds of special assessments levied and collected according to state law; 
D.  From any other funds which may be obtained under any law of this state or of the United States for that purpose; 
E.  From the proceeds of revenue bonds of the city, payable solely from the revenues to be derived from the operation of the combined waterworks and sewerage system, or from any combination of any or all of such methods of providing funds. 
(Prior code § 28-4) 
13.04.050 - Charges to be made in relation to combined system. 
    Rates authorized to be fixed and charged by this title shall be fixed and charged to all parts of the combined waterworks and sewerage system regardless of whether or not the services of the system shall previously have been rendered without charge therefor by the city's previously existing waterworks system, sewerage system or combined waterworks and sewerage system and regardless of how the acquisition of such system shall have been financed, whether by taxation, special assessment, the issuance of bonds or otherwise. 
(Prior code § 28-5) 
13.04.060 - Ownership of equipment installed by city. 
    All equipment furnished or installed by the city at its own expense shall remain the property of the city. 
(Prior code § 28-6) 
13.04.070 - Service installations and apparatus-Consumer responsibility. 
    Customers utilizing a one-inch meter or less shall be responsible for the installation of the service line from the city main to the premises of customer. The city assumes ownership of said service line from the city main to a point one foot past the meter box. Repair and maintenance of the service line from that point to the premises is the responsibility of the customer. Customers utilizing a meter greater than one inch shall be responsible for the installation, repair, and maintenance of the service line commencing at the city main to and through customer's premises. 
(Prior code § 28-7) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 2, 8-2-11; Ord. No. 5556, § 1, 8-19-14; Ord. No. 5571, § 1, 10-7-14) 
13.04.080 - Vacation of premises or change in occupancy-Notice to city. 
    When premises are to be vacated or there is a change of owner, occupant or agent, prompt notice shall be given the city. 
(Prior code § 28-8) 
13.04.090 - Discontinuance of service by customer-Payment of bills. 
    Service may be discontinued by the customer by giving not less than seventy-two (72) hours' notice to the city during its regular office hours unless a shorter time is allowed by the city. Final bills for service shall become due and payable upon issuance of bill. 
(Prior code § 28-9) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 3, 8-2-11) 
13.04.100 - Unpaid charges-Property owner liable-Termination of service. 
    Every property owner shall be held responsible for any charges or rentals left unpaid by any tenant of the premises serviced by water or sewer service and the city reserves the right to shut off any water service where the delinquent charges or rentals are not paid by the owner. 
(Prior code § 28-10) 
13.04.110 - Tampering with system. 
    No unauthorized person shall maliciously, wilfully or negligently break, damage, destroy, uncover, deface or tamper with any structure, appurtenance or equipment which is a part of the municipal water and sewerage system. 
(Prior code § 28-11) 
13.04.120 - Indemnification of city by consumer. 
    The consumer shall indemnify, save harmless and defend the city against all claims, demands, cost or expense, for loss, damage or injury to persons or property in any manner directly or indirectly growing out of the use of the water and sewer system by the consumer from the consumer's service pipes or installation. 
(Prior code § 28-12) 
13.04.130 - Discharge of sewage, wastes and polluted waters into natural outlet. 
    It is unlawful to discharge to any natural outlet within the city, or in any area under the jurisdiction of the city, any sewage, industrial wastes or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 28-13) 
13.04.140 - Pollution of groundwater sources. 
    It is unlawful for any person to pollute groundwater sources by discharging sewage into any well, cistern, spring, sinkhole, cave, mine shaft, tunnel, pit, quarry or other excavation, or into any fissure or crevice leading to underground waterbearing strata. 
(Prior code § 28-14) 
13.04.150 - Consumer questions and complaints. 
    All questions and complaints within the scope of this chapter, including any disrespect or unwarranted act of employees of the waterworks and sewerage system shall be reported promptly to the water and sewerage department of the city in order that an investigation can be made and information can be properly given. The city shall make a full report to the consumer in all such cases. 
(Prior code § 28-16) 
13.04.160 - Acceptance of tips by employees. 
    All employees of the waterworks and sewerage system are strictly forbidden to demand or accept any tip, gratuity or other personal compensation in the performance of their duties. 
(Prior code § 28-17) 
13.04.170 - Water, sewer and stormwater manhole standardization. 
A.  All manholes which are or may become a part of the city water, sewer and stormwater systems within or without the city shall conform to the standardized specifications for manholes as prepared by the city engineering department and as adopted and approved by the board of aldermen in Ordinance No. 1648. 
B.  A copy of the standardized specifications shall remain on file at the office of the city clerk for public inspection and is incorporated by reference in this section. 
C.  The city engineer may vary said specifications in the event the same create an undue hardship; provided, however, said variance is requested in writing and does not jeopardize the city water, sewer and stormwater systems or maintenance thereof. 
(Prior code § 28-18) 
13.04.180 - Sanitary sewer and storm sewer plans and specifications adopted by reference. 
A.  The mayor and board of aldermen have reviewed the sanitary sewer and storm sewer plans and specifications attached to Ordinance No. 1792, and do adopt same for use by the city engineer when planning the construction and reconstruction of sanitary sewers and storm sewers in the city. 
B.  Copies of the plans and specifications shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and made available for public view, inspection and copying. 
C.  A copy of the plans and specifications shall be kept on file in the office of the city engineer and made available for public view, inspection and copying; and when requested, the city engineer should make a copy of the plans and specifications available to contractors, developers, subdividers and other persons interested in the plans and specifications for sanitary and storm water drainage systems in the city. 
D.  All construction, reconstruction and repair of sanitary sewer and storm drainage systems in the city shall be in compliance with the plans and specifications; provided, however, that the city engineer, in his sole discretion, may vary plans and specifications for good reason shown if, and only if, variations are approved in writing from the office of the city engineer. 
(Prior code § 28-19) 
13.04.190 - Inspectors-Credentials-Access to premises. 
A.  All city inspectors shall present proper city credentials when performing any inspection or other duty required by this chapter. 
B.  The city shall have access to all portions of any premises connected or proposed to be connected to the public water or sewer system at any reasonable time for inspection of the water or sewer service connections, building pipes, fixtures, plumbing and other apparatus. 
(Ord. 4011 § 2, 2000: prior code § 28-28) 
13.04.200 - Right of city to demand repairs, charges and removal of apparatus. 
    The city shall have the right and option to demand charges or stopping of use of water or to require any repair, change, removal or improvement of any pipe, fixture, plumbing or other apparatus that would in any manner affect the satisfactory operation of the water or sanitary sewer system and treatment facilities. 
(Prior code § 28-29) 
13.04.210 - Right of city to shut off water in main. 
    The city reserves the right at all times, without notice to any customer, to shut off the water in a main for the purpose making repairs or extensions or for any other necessary purpose. All persons having boilers or tanks within their premises depending on the pressure from the main to keep them filled are cautioned against the danger of collapse. It is the intention of the city to notify its customers of the necessity of shutting off the main supply, but an emergency may at times, not permit taking the time to do so. 
(Prior code § 28-30) 
13.04.220 - Right of city to refuse or discontinue water service when system endangered-Repair and removal of apparatus. 
    The city shall have the right to refuse or to discontinue water service, without notice at any time to any consumer, if the city finds any apparatus or appliance which will be detrimental to the water system of the city or to any or all of its consumers. Standpipes, hydrants, gate valves and any other apparatus that cause any danger to the water system or any other customer's plumbing shall be immediately repaired or removed upon notice from the city or, at its option, the city may immediately discontinue service without notice and without any liability for direct or resulting damages therefrom. 
(Prior code § 28-31) 
13.04.230 - Right of city to discontinue service upon violation. 
    Upon violation of any provision of this chapter or any other rule and regulation of the city by a consumer, the right is reserved by the city, after due notice has been given, to discontinue service to such consumer. 
(Prior code § 28-32) 
13.04.240 - Contractor protest-Procedure. 
    The board of aldermen establishes the following procedures for prompt consideration of initial protests filed by contractors or subcontractors concerning the solicitations or contract awards for construction of city projects including public water system improvements, as follows: 
A.  A protest is a written complaint concerning the city's solicitation or award of a subagreement or contract which must be filed in writing with the city clerk by a party with a direct financial interest adversely affected by the city's procurement action for construction of public water supply improvements. 
B.  A party with a financial interest which believes it is adversely affected by a procurement action by the city must file a written protest stating the basis for such protest with the city clerk as early in the procurement process as possible. A protest must be received by the clerk within seven days after the basis for the protest is known or reasonably should have been known. The board of aldermen, upon receipt of such protest, shall hold a hearing as soon as reasonably possible or proper and legal notification to the party with the financial interest which is allegedly adversely affected by the action of the city and that such protestant shall be accorded a complete hearing and shall have the right to adduce evidence, both verbal and documentary, to the board of aldermen and upon conclusion of the hearing and the evidence adduced as submitted, the board of aldermen shall announce and issue its written decision and order making disposition of the issues raised in such protest. A written copy of the decision of the board of aldermen shall be served upon the protestant within seven days after the hearing. 
C.  The provisions of this section shall be incorporated in any solicitations, contract awards or subagreements entered into by the city. 
(Ord. 4010 § 1, 2000) 
Chapter 13.08 - WATER AND SEWER RATES AND CHARGES 
Sections: 

13.08.010 - Water service rates. 
A.  Rate schedules for the cost of water to city water customers shall be established as needed in accordance with the provisions of this code. The rate schedule shall be approved by the board of aldermen after receiving input from the city budget officer and the city's consulting water engineer. 
B.  Rates shall be published by posting same in City Hall in a format approved by the board. No rate shall be effective unless posted and made available to the public as provided herein. The rate schedule shall also be available to the general public in the office of the city clerk during regular business hours. 
C.  In order to provide a self-sufficient, stable water system and to provide for system deficit reduction; infiltration and inflow repairs; operation, maintenance and inflation; establishment of reserve account for replacement of equipment; and waterline replacement and restoration, the board may establish a separate capital improvement charge and/or supplement the water rate. Such supplemental rates shall be established separately or together and in conjunction with regular water rates for the city. If the supplemental rates are established separately from standard water user rates, they shall be separately published in a format approved by the board. 
D.  The city shall review the rate schedule annually and revise the rate as necessary to ensure that the system generates adequate revenues to pay the cost of operation and maintenance, including replacement, and that the system continues to provide for the proportional distribution of operation and maintenance, including replacement cost, among users. 
E.  The city will notify each user at least annually, in conjunction with a regular water bill, of the rate being charged for operation and maintenance, including the replacement of the treatment works and other components of the water system. 
F.  The city shall review the user service charge annually and revise the rate as necessary to ensure that the system generates adequate revenues to pay the cost of operation and maintenance, including replacement, and that the system continues to provide for the proportional distribution of operation and maintenance, including replacement cost, among users. 
G.  The city shall utilize the "city of Perryville water rate and supplemental water rate derivation formulae" in establishing water rate increases required as provided for in subsection F of this section. Said formulae shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available for public inspection during normal business hours. 
(Ord. 4009 § 1, 2000; Ord. 3665 § 1, 1998: prior code § 28-38) 
(Ord. No. 5241, §§ 4, 5, 8-2-11) 
13.08.020 - Water service-Contract with one person for payment-Master meter. 
A.  Where water is to be supplied to several persons in a two-family dwelling, a multi-family dwelling, offices, or stores, all located in a single building, the city shall require a single meter and contract with only one person for the supply of water and said person shall be responsible to the city for the payment of water bills. Two-family dwellings, multi-family dwellings, offices, or stores located in a single building hereafter constructed or converted must be master metered. 'Master meter' is defined as a single meter serving multiple tenant spaces. 
B.  In accordance with Section 250.140 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, where water is to be supplied to several persons by way of a privately-owned water line main in a mobile home park or several persons or corporations occupying multiple commercial units located on a single property, the city shall contract with only one person for the supply of water and said person shall be responsible to the city for the payment of water bills. Such units shall hereafter be converted to a master meter. "Master meter" is defined as a single meter serving multiple tenant spaces. 
C.  Any mobile home, mobile home park, two-family dwelling, a multi-family dwelling, offices, or stores which are subject to the master meter requirement of this section shall be given no less than six months to prepare for the conversion to master meter upon notification of the property owner by the city. The city will install the master meter at the city's cost. The existing meters will be abandoned in place by the city and the property owner may utilize said meters at no cost or expense to the city and the city shall have no obligation to replace or maintain the abandoned meters. The city will refund the water deposits for all abandoned meters upon payment of the water deposit for the new master meter. 
(Ord. 4805 § 1, 2006: prior code § 28-40) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 6, 8-2-11; Ord. No. 5827, § 1, 12-6-16; Ord. No. 5998 , § 1, 1-23-18) 
13.08.030 - Sewer service rates-Annual review. 
A.  Sewer service charges for the cost of maintaining the city sewer system shall be billed to the city water customers and shall be established as needed in accordance with the provisions of this code. The sewer service charges shall be approved by the board of aldermen after reviewing input from the city budget officer and city's consulting sewer engineer. 
B.  The sewer service charges shall be published by posting same in City Hall in a format approved by the board. No sewer service charge shall be effective unless posted and made available to the public as provided in this chapter. The sewer service charges shall also be made available to the general public in the office of the city clerk during regular business hours. 
C.  The purpose of the sewer service charge is to distribute the costs of operating, maintaining and financing the system to all contributors to the system. The total sewer service charge will equal the total cost of the sewer system, minus the funds collected by way of industrial user charge (see Section 13.20.140). The sewer service charge to each established customer shall be based on the monthly metered water use for each customer. However, the sewer service charge for customers during the months billed on July 1st, August 1st, and September 1st shall be charged at ninety (90) percent of the rates established by the mayor and board of aldermen. If it is determined that a customer had a water leak during any given month, then the customer's sewer charge for the month(s) affected shall be based on the average of the three months closest to the month when the water leak occurred. If a new residential customer has a water leak before a normal usage is established, the city will charge an average of no more than six thousand (6,000) gallons of water for the month in which the leak occurred. 
D.  The sewer service charge shall be the rate established by the board of aldermen from time to time and published in accordance with this section. 
E.  The city shall review the sewer service charge annually and revise the rate as necessary to ensure that the system generates adequate revenues to pay the cost of operation and maintenance, including replacement, and that the system continues to provide for the proportional distribution of operation and maintenance, including replacement cost, among users. 
F.  Customers not using city water may be required to install an appropriate water meter or to use the water meter supplied by the water district. In that event, sewer usage shall be charged based on actual metered water usage as set forth in this section. In the event the customer is not required by the city to meter said customer's water usage, then the customer shall be charged for sewer usage based on a minimum set use of six thousand (6,000) gallons of water per month. 
G.  The city will notify its customers at least annually of the rate being charged for operation and maintenance, including the replacement of the treatment works and other components of the sewer system, by posting said notice in the City Hall. 
(Ord. 4803 § 1, 2006: Ord. 4706 § 1, 2005: Ord. 3666 § 1, 1998: Ord. 3567 § 1, 1997; prior code § 28-41) 
(Ord. No. 5311, § 1, 3-6-12; Ord. No. 5540, § 1, 7-15-14) 
13.08.040 - Use of noncity water-Charges. 
    In the event a person, firm or corporation: 
A.  Obtains potable water from a source other than the city waterworks; and 
B.  Has failed to meter their potable water source as provided in Section 13.12.520; or 
C.  Has failed to make connection to an available city sewer as provided in Section 13.16.190; then, and in that event, such person, firm, or corporation shall be charged the average monthly residential user service charge (see section 13.08.030, subsection F) per residential dwelling in use and located on his or its property until the person, firm, or corporation shall have complied with this code. 
(Prior code § 28-42) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 7, 8-2-11) 
13.08.050 - Billing-Customer responsibility. 
    All bills for water and sewer service shall be rendered by the city to the customer monthly in accordance with the applicable rate established in this chapter.
