The failure of a customer to receive such bill shall not, however, relieve him from the obligation of paying the amount owed by him to the city nor shall it be necessary for the city to set aside any penalty or discount rule on account of the failure of a consumer to receive such bill, as it is the intent of this chapter that customers shall call at the office of the city clerk for such bill when not receiving the same. 
(Prior code § 28-43) 
13.08.060 - Billing-Payment to city. 
    All bills for water and sewer service charges and rates shall be payable at the office of the city clerk. 
(Prior code § 28-44) 
13.08.070 - Delinquent bills. 
A.  The city of Perryville will notify each customer of the date that services will be discontinued for non-payment via their monthly utility bill. In addition, the city will take reasonable measures to notify customers by electronic telephone calls at least one day prior to the date their utilities are scheduled for disconnection. Water service shall be discontinued to any customer who is delinquent in the payment of the charges or rates for water or sewer service by the date established on the monthly utility bill. Water service shall not again be turned on until all delinquent charges due the city for water or sewer services, including penalties and a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for discontinuing the water service and a charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for turning on the water service, have been paid. 
B.  If it becomes necessary to refer a delinquent account to the city attorney for collection, the customer shall be responsible for a reasonable attorney's fee as well as court costs for the collection of such delinquent billings. 
C.  In addition to all other fees charged in this chapter, in the event that any bill is delinquent, then the city shall charge a penalty on such delinquent bill at the rate of ten (10) percent of such bill or five dollars ($5.00), whichever is greater. 
(Ord. 4558 § 1, 2004: prior code § 28-45) 
(Ord. No. 5434, § 1, 6-25-13) 
13.08.080 - Civil tampering penalty. 
    No person shall tamper with any city water meter. Nothing in this section shall limit the city's ability to engage in the criminal prosecution of any person tampering with a city water meter as set forth elsewhere in this Code. The provisions of this section shall be in addition to and separate from any criminal prosecution. Any city water meter on which any seal to the city water meter or any connection or disconnection of the city water meter has been changed or tampered with so as to disturb or change the action or regulation of the city water meter shall be subject to an additional city water meter tampering fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) which shall be assessed and added to the customer's bill which must be paid prior to the city connecting or reconnecting the city water meter. 
(Ord. No. 5760, § 1, 5-17-16) 
Chapter 13.12 - WATER SERVICE SYSTEM 
Sections: 
Article 1. - Generally 

13.12.010 - Tap or service connection-Application. 
    Any person desiring to make a water tap or service connection with the waterworks system shall first file a written application therefor in the office of the city clerk upon blank forms to be provided by the city for such purposes. Such application shall be signed by a licensed plumber acting on behalf of the owner for which such tap or service connection is desired. 
(Prior code § 28-88) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 8, 8-2-11) 
13.12.020 - Plans and specifications to accompany application for tap. 
    Plans and specifications shall accompany an application for a tap when requested by the city. 
(Prior code § 28-89) 
13.12.030 - Tap to be made by city. 
    All water taps onto the waterworks system shall be made by the city except as provided elsewhere in this chapter. 
(Prior code § 28-90) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 9, 8-2-11) 
13.12.040 - Specifications for tapping. 
    The main shall be exposed at the tapping point, and the tap excavation shall be of sufficient size to allow the tapper to attach and operate the tapping machine and shall be free from mud and water. It shall be so located that the corporation stop can be inserted at a point in the pipe approximately forty-five (45) degrees from the top of the pipe on the side nearest to the premises to be supplied. If the tapper finds the main not ready when he calls to make the tap, the city shall be notified again of readiness before the tapper makes another trip to make the tap. 
(Prior code § 28-91) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 10, 8-2-11) 
13.12.050 - City to be notified in advance of tapping. 
    The city shall be given, during regular office hours, at least forty-eight (48) hours' notice in advance of the time a tap is to be made. 
(Prior code § 28-92) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 11, 8-2-11) 
13.12.060 - Meter and security deposits. 
A.  If any applicant for water service is the owner of any premises within the city limits for which a water service connection with the waterworks system is desired, the applicant shall not be required to pay a meter deposit fee unless required to do so elsewhere in the Code of Ordinances of the city. Any owner of any premises within the city limits who paid a meter deposit fee prior to September 21, 2004, may contact the utility billing department and request that the deposit be refunded as a credit on their utility bill. This request shall be granted if the deposit has not previously been credited on a utility bill and is still carried on the records of the city. 
B.  If an applicant for water service is not the owner of any premises within the city limits for which a water service connection with the waterworks system is desired, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a meter deposit fee in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
C.  If an applicant for water service is the owner of any premises outside the city limits for which a water service connection with the waterworks system is desired, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a meter deposit fee in the sum of fifty dollars ($50.00). 
D.  If an applicant for water service is not the owner of any premises outside the city limits for which a water service connection with the waterworks system is desired, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a meter deposit fee in the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
E.  Upon disconnection of city water service to the depositor, the deposit shall be applied to any charges incurred and then any balance of such deposit shall be returned to the depositor without interest. 
F.  In addition to the aforesaid meter deposit fee, the applicant shall also deposit with the city clerk a security deposit in the amount of one hundred dollars ($100.00). This security deposit may be waived by the city clerk or his designate for applicants whose prior or current accounts with the city have been promptly paid and are not in arrears. For new applicants, the security deposit may be waived by the city clerk or his designate if the applicant requests and agrees to consent to a credit check and that credit check indicates the applicant is a good risk. If the credit check reveals unfavorable credit information or if the applicant does not request a credit check, then the aforesaid security deposit shall be required prior to utility connection. There shall be a one time ten dollar ($10.00) charge for each credit check which shall be paid at the time applicant is requesting the credit check. 
G.  If the applicant for water service is a commercial user, then, in addition to all other deposits or fees set forth herein, the applicant shall pay a security deposit sufficient to secure two months of water billing for the business. The city shall establish said amount by comparing the usage amounts of similar businesses within the city or, if none, then within two hundred (200) miles of the city. The applicant may request to have the deposit reduced to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) if the applicant is a resident of the city who has a twenty-four (24) month utility payment history with no late fees assessed. After sixty (60) months of usage during which the applicant has no late utility payments, the applicant may request a return of fifty (50) percent of any deposit in excess of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(Ord. 4897 § 1, 2007; Ord. 4558 § 2, 2004: prior code § 28-93) 
(Ord. No. 4991, § 1, 10-21-08; Ord. No. 5679, § 1, 8-18-15) 
13.12.070 - Service connection or tap-Charges. 
A.  The charges for connecting any premises within the city limits to the waterworks system shall be as follows: 
1.  For each three-quarter-inch or one-inch service connection, the applicant therefor shall pay a charge as set forth in the yearly rate schedule which shall be payment in full for the furnishing by the city of tools, parts, and labor to tap the main and install a saddle and corporation stop. The city shall furnish and install a five-eighths-inch or one-inch meter. Said yearly rate schedule shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk and shall be available for public inspection during normal business hours. 
2.  All service connections in excess of one inch shall be 'hot taps' performed by an approved contractor under the supervision of the public works department. 
3.  When performing a hot tap on the city's main, the contractor shall be responsible for any damages and any cost incurred by the city in repairing the line. 
4.  All excavations, pipes, fittings, labor, and other materials required for service connections, other than those specified in this chapter to be furnished by the city, shall be furnished and paid for by the applicant. 
5.  The board of aldermen reserves the right to make special charges for service connections to properties not covered by this subsection, or which, in the judgment of the board, should pay special charges. 
B.  For all service connections outside the city limits there shall be an additional charge of four hundred dollars ($400.00) over and above all other charges provided for in subsection A of this section. 
(Prior code § 28-94) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 12, 8-2-11) 
13.12.080 - Charge when main not ready for tapping. 
    If the main is not found ready for the tapper after being notified to make the tap, an additional charge of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) shall be made for each additional trip required. 
(Prior code § 28-95) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 13, 8-2-11) 
13.12.090 - Agreement of board needed for certain taps. 
    Taps shall not be made for vacant lots or in advance of building requirements unless required elsewhere in this code or unless by special agreement with the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 28-96) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 14, 8-2-11) 
13.12.100 - Required connection-Distance-Location-Service line. 
A.  All properties within one hundred (100) feet of any existing city water line shall be required to connect to the city water system. 
B.  Water shall be furnished for consumption by the customer only at a point designated by the city. 
C.  Service Line. 
1.  Customers utilizing a one-inch meter or less shall be responsible for the installation of the service line from the city main to the premises of customer. Upon proper installation, the city shall assume ownership of said service line from the city main to a point one foot past the meter box. Repair and maintenance of the service line from one foot past the meter box to the premises is the responsibility of the customer. Customers utilizing a meter greater than one inch shall be responsible for the installation, repair, and maintenance of the service line commencing at the city main to and through customer's premises. 
2.  In the event the city becomes aware of a leak or other damage to a customer service line, the city shall notify customer immediately and customer shall, within three business days from receipt of notice repair said leak or damage. 
3.  In the event the customer does not repair said leak or damage to the service line as defined in Section 13.12.100(C)(1) within three business days and the leak or damage present has an adverse impact on city infrastructure, the city may, at its sole discretion, disconnect the meter until the repairs are completed or repair the same and bill the customer for the actual costs of the repair plus an equal amount to cover administrative expenses. Unpaid bills shall constitute a lien on the property and may be tax billed accordingly. 
(Ord. 4011 § 1, 2000: prior code § 28-97) 
(Ord. No. 5556, § 2, 8-19-14; Ord. No. 5571, § 2, 10-7-14) 
13.12.110 - Separate premises to have separate service. 
    Every separate premises shall have a separate service pipe installation and shall be separately metered. In no case shall a consumer extend his service pipes or plumbing across a street or alley or to an adjacent property in order to furnish service to such adjacent property even though such adjacent property is owned by the same party. 
(Prior code § 28-98) 
13.12.120 - New construction-Water main extensions. 
    Upon the application of any person desiring the extension or upgrade of the existing water system, such person shall comply with the provisions of this code and the following regulations: 
A.  Generally. 
1.  All new construction, extension or upgrades to the existing city water system shall receive a permit to construct from the Missouri Department of Natural Resources, Public Drinking Water Program, and a city building permit prior to the commencement of construction. 
2.  Any new construction, extension or upgrade of the existing city water system shall include only those materials required by the most recent edition of the Missouri Department of Natural Resources, Public Drinking Water Program, "Design Guide for Community Public Water Supplies." 
3.  No extension of any water main shall be made using pipe smaller than eight inches in diameter, but in those locations where a larger size pipe than exists at the present time would serve no useful purpose a smaller main may be used; however, actual size of the main required shall be determined by the public works director according to sound engineering practice, which shall be final and binding. 
B.  Within the City Limits. All extensions required within the city limits shall be governed by the subdivision regulations or by subsection D of this section. 
C.  Outside City Limits. All extensions required outside the city limits shall be made on the basis that any portion of the extension lying within the city limits shall be considered as a necessary part of the extension. Such extensions shall be made by the city upon receipt from the applicants of the estimated cost of the extension, such costs to include engineering, supervising and inspection. Upon completion of the construction of the extension, the applicants shall be either refunded the difference between the amount of their prepayments and actual construction cost or shall pay the additional amount if the extension costs exceeded the amount of the prepayment, the additional amount to be paid to the city prior to placing the extension into service. 
D.  Special Conditions. The board of aldermen, after consultation with the public works director, shall have the right to enter into agreements which would cover special conditions not covered by this section, such as subdivisions, housing, and industrial developments. The board of aldermen shall also have the right to authorize extensions to be constructed by persons at their own expense or with their own employees providing that the materials and workmanship meet the requirements of this chapter. Such extensions shall be subject to the inspection and acceptance of the city and no water service shall be furnished to any main or service which has not been inspected and accepted. 
(Ord. 4011 § 3, 2000; prior code § 28-100) 
(Ord. No. 5241, §§ 15-17, 8-2-11) 
13.12.130 - Resale of city water. 
    It is unlawful for any person to resell any city water unless: 
A.  That person has purchased the water at an appropriately metered location and paid all water and sewer charges therefor; or 
B.  That person has purchased the water at a location provided by the city for the direct bulk sale of water and paid all city charges therefor. Nothing herein shall compel the city to provide a location for the direct bulk sale of water. 
(Ord. 4950 § 1, 2008: prior code § 28-101) 
13.12.140 - Use of service cocks and gate valves. 
    No person shall use any meter service cock or any gate valve in the street, belonging to the city, to shut off or turn on the city water supply. 
(Prior code § 28-102) 
13.12.150 - Corporation stops and gate valves. 
A.  Single or multiple corporation stops shall be used to supply services or private mains up to and including two inches in diameter. 
B.  Gate valves shall be used to supply services or private mains over two inches in diameter. 
C.  Connection or service between one and one-quarter inches and two inches to the city main shall be through one-inch corporation stops with branch connections making an angle of forty-five (45) degrees to the main; on one and one-quarter-inch services, one-inch corporation stop shall be required; on one and one-half-inch services, two one-inch corporation stops shall be required; on two-inch services, three one-inch corporation stops shall be required; on three-inch services, a four-inch connection at the main and a four-inch valve shall be required; services four inches and over shall have the same size connection as the service. 
(Prior code § 28-103) 
13.12.160 - Service control valves. 
    Service control valves may be nonrising stem gate valves, meter stop, or plug-type. Such valves shall be of approved standard make and shall be housed in approved-type service or roadway valve boxes. 
(Prior code § 28-104) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 18, 8-2-11) 
13.12.170 - Disinfection of lines and mains. 
A.  All new or repaired pipelines shall be flushed and disinfected before being placed in use. Water containing at least fifty (50) ppm of chlorine shall be allowed to stand in the line for eight hours after which there shall be at least twenty-four (24) ppm residual chlorine remaining. 
B.  The "recommended specifications for disinfection of potable water mains" shall be in accordance with the Missouri Department of Natural Resources. 
(Prior code § 28-105) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 19, 8-2-11) 
13.12.180 - Fluoridation. 
    The public works director is authorized and directed to provide the means and to proceed with the addition of approximately one and not more than one and five-tenths parts of fluoride to every million parts of water being distributed in the waterworks system. 
(Prior code § 28-106) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 20, 8-2-11) 
13.12.190 - Corrupting or diverting water supply. 
    Whoever wilfully or maliciously poisons, defiles or in any way corrupts the water of a well, spring, brook or reservoir used for domestic or municipal purposes, or whoever wilfully or maliciously diverts, dams up and holds back from its natural course and flow any spring, brook or other water supply for domestic or municipal purposes, after such water supply shall have once been taken for use by any person or the city for their use, shall be adjudged guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Prior code § 28-107) 
13.12.200 - Charge to turn water supply on or off at request of customer. 
    If any person desires to have the city shut off or turn on his city water supply, he shall pay to the city the sum of one dollar ($1.00) for each trip required therefor, plus the bill for any water that may be used or wasted. 
(Prior code § 28-108) 
13.12.210 - Water services installed for fire protection. 
    Water services installed to supply standpipes and sprinkler systems for fire protection only shall not be subject to metering. Complete specifications for such proposed work shall be submitted to the city before connection to the water distribution system is made. Unmetered fire protection services shall be installed in such a manner that all outlets subject to sealings are exposed and easily accessible for inspecting seals at any time. No connections for any other purpose whatever shall be permitted to unmetered fire services. 
(Prior code § 28-109) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 21, 8-2-11) 
13.12.220 - Fire hydrants. 
A.  All public fire hydrants with gate valves, teels and connections from the main, inside the city limits, shall be owned, maintained and used only by the city, which shall be solely responsible for the same. No person shall use any water from any such fire hydrant unless application is first made to the city therefor and written permission is secured for such use. 
B.  All public fire hydrants outside the city limits owned by the city shall be maintained in as good order as reasonably possible, but the city shall not undertake or assume any responsibility or liability for their condition or use or abuse. Such public fire hydrants shall be used only for the purpose of extinguishing fires except when the city issues a special permit for their use to contractors, who shall then be responsible for the hydrants and the use of water from them. 
C.  The city shall not be held liable nor assume any responsibility for the condition of any fire hydrant inside or outside the city limits, or the pressure or amount of water obtainable therefrom, or any damage either direct or resultant because of the condition, pressure or amount of water available at any fire hydrant. 
(Prior code § 28-110) 
13.12.230 - Tampering with main or pipe. 
    No person shall, without written permission from the city, make any connection, addition or change to any main or pipe belonging to the city. 
(Prior code § 28-111) 
13.12.240 - Electric ground wires. 
    Metal water piping shall be bonded to the grounding electrode as per the National Electrical Code. 
(Prior code § 28-112) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 22, 8-2-11) 
13.12.250 - Damages-Liability of city. 
    The city shall not be held responsible or in any manner liable to any person for any claim or damage, either direct or resultant, because of any shortage of water supply, any shutoff of water, any bursting or leakage of the city's mains, pipes and fixtures, any pollution or impurity in the water supply, or any fire or water damage. 
(Prior code § 28-113) 
13.12.260 - Backfilling service line trench. 
A.  All service line trenches on or across any street, alley, public thoroughfare, or driveway shall be backfilled in the following manner: 
1.  All trenches on or across any improved or surfaced street, alley, public thoroughfare, or driveway shall be kept to the narrowest width practical for the installation of the service line. All excavated material shall be removed and disposed of and the trench shall be backfilled with an approved granular material. The backfill material shall be thoroughly compacted in a manner approved by the public works director. The area excavated shall be replaced with the same type of material as the pre-existing surface. If the surface is bituminous material, it shall be replaced with a minimum thickness of four inches of an approved bituminous patch material, thoroughly compacted so as to provide a smooth surface. 
2.  All that portion of the trench outside the surfaced area of any street, alley, thoroughfare, or driveway shall be backfilled with the excavated material, being thoroughly compacted in a manner approved by the public works director. After such trench has been completely backfilled, all excess and unsatisfactory material shall be disposed of and the area of operations shall be cleaned and dressed. Approved granular material may be used for backfilling this area without tamping to within six inches of the surface, the balance of the trench to be backfilled with earth in the parkway and grassway areas and with crushed stone or earth in the other areas. 
B.  No service line trench shall be backfilled until after the tap has been completed and the installation has been approved by the city. 
(Prior code § 28-114) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 23, 8-2-11) 
13.12.270 - Excavations to be guarded. 
    All excavations for water service connections shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. 
(Prior code § 28-115) 
13.12.280 - Water wells regulated-Penalty for violation. 
A.  No person shall drill, construct, or otherwise provided a water well or water system within the city limits of the city without prior permission of the board of aldermen. Upon special request, the board of aldermen may grant special permission for the drilling, construction or establishment of a water well, provided, however, that any water well designed or intended to provide potable water shall be in full compliance with the rules and regulations of the Department of Natural Resources, Clean Water Division, of the state of Missouri, and approved by the office of the city engineer. 
B.  Any violation of this section shall be punishable as made and provided in Section 1.16.010, and each day of operation in violation of this section shall be deemed a separate and distinct offense. 
(Prior code § 28-116) 
Article 2. - Service Pipes 

13.12.290 - Installation to comply with city regulations. 
    The service line from the main to the property line shall be installed in accordance with city regulations. 
(Prior code § 28-121) 
13.12.300 - Diameter restrictions and type of pipe required. 
A.  No service pipe shall have an inside diameter less than three-quarter inch. 
B.  All service pipes of one inch or less in diameter shall be of U. S. Government specification Type K copper tubing or polyethylene (PE) plastic tubing conforming to ASTM D 2737. Polyethylene tubing shall be installed with a number 12 gauge copper tracer wire. If the polyethylene tubing is connected to a plastic water main, the tracer wire shall be soldered to the tracer wire on the water main or connected to the tracer wire on the water main using a testing agency listed direct burial splice kit. If the polyethylene tubing is connected to a ductile iron water main, the tracer wire shall be soldered to the tapping saddle or connected to the tapping saddle using a testing agency listed direct burial splice kit. Polyethylene tubing shall be blue in color and suitable for potable water. 
C.  All service pipes over one inch in diameter to two inches in diameter shall be ductile iron meeting the latest accepted specifications of the American Waterworks Association, Class 150, or U. S. Government specification Type K copper tubing or polyethylene (PE) plastic tubing conforming to ASTM D 2737. Polyethylene tubing shall be installed with a number 12 gauge copper tracer wire. If the polyethylene tubing is connected to a plastic water main, the tracer wire shall be soldered to the tracer wire on the water main or connected to the tracer wire on the water main using a testing agency listed direct burial splice kit. If the polyethylene tubing is connected to a ductile iron water main, the tracer wire shall be soldered to the tapping saddle or connected to the tapping saddle using a testing agency listed direct burial splice kit. Polyethylene tubing shall be blue in color and suitable for potable water. 
D.  All service pipes greater than two inches in diameter shall be ductile iron meeting the latest accepted specifications of the American Waterworks Association, Class 150, or Type K hard copper tubing or polyvinyl chloride (PVC), Class 900, 905 or 909. 
E.  All pipe described herein shall be rated at one hundred fifty (150) PSI or greater. 
(Prior code § 28-122) 
(Ord. No. 5015, § 1, 3-3-09) 
13.12.310 - Copper service pipe specifications. 
A.  The specifications for the installation of copper service pipe shall be as follows:

No coupling of any type will be permitted between the corporation stop and the meter yoke where the distance is less than sixty (60) feet. 
(Prior code § 28-123) 
13.12.320 - Depth of installation. 
    All service pipes shall be placed with at least thirty (30) inches' cover above the service pipes. 
(Prior code § 28-124) 
13.12.330 - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5241, § 24, adopted August 2, 2011, repealed § 13.12.330, which pertained to angle to building and derived from prior code § 28-125. 
13.12.340 - Cross-connections. 
    No physical connection shall be made between a service line from the mains of the city and any private water system, pipe, or tank which has contents of a polluted or otherwise questionable character or which is another water supply approved by the state Division of Health or the State Water Pollution Board other than the city. If such a cross-connection is found, the city shall discontinue service to the consumer in question unless all physical connections between the two water supplies have been severed. 
(Prior code § 28-126) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 25, 8-2-11) 
13.12.350 - Backflow prevention on service lines. 
    When any premises is supplied through two or more interconnecting water service pipes, each pipe shall be equipped with a backflow-prevention device near the meter outlet so set that the water can flow into the premises, but no water can flow out. 
    All water service lines shall be equipped with a backflow-prevention device near the meter outlet so set that the water can flow into, but no water can flow out. 
(Prior code § 28-127) 
13.12.360 - Leaks in consumer's installation. 
    The consumer shall keep his service pipes free from leaks at all times. Where a leak appears in a consumer's installation allowing water to escape that does not register, the city shall give the consumer written notice thereof, and the consumer shall immediately proceed to repair such service pipe. If the same is not repaired within forty-eight (48) hours after written notice has been given to the consumer, the city may discontinue the service by closing the corporation stop. The cost of excavating and shutting off such service shall be paid by the consumer or by the owner of the property on which the service pipes are located before the service shall be restored by the city. If, in the judgment of the city, any leak on the consumer's installation is of such nature as to endanger public safety or constitute a nuisance or is the source of the waste of any considerable amount of water, the city may cut off or discontinue such service without previous notice to the consumer and shall not restore service until such leak is repaired. 
(Prior code § 28-128) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 26, 8-2-11) 
13.12.370 - Abandoned service pipes. 
    Should an owner desire to abandon the service pipes, the owner shall uncover and expose the corporation stop so that employees of the city may either turn it off and, if deemed advisable, saw off the outlet threads; or the owner may leave for future use that portion of the service from the meter box to the main provided the meter is removed and the line to the building is severed or removed. 
(Prior code § 28-129) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 27, 8-2-11) 
13.12.380 - Protection by customer. 
    All customers shall take the necessary precautions to prevent their water pipes, meters, and fittings from freezing in cold weather. 
(Prior code § 28-130) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 28, 8-2-11) 
Article 3. - Meters 

13.12.390 - City to furnish meter. 
    All water meters one inch or less which are to be used for the measuring of water consumed shall be furnished by the city. All meters larger than one inch shall be furnished by the customer after approval by the city. 
(Prior code § 28-136) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 29, 8-2-11) 
13.12.400 - Type. 
    Unless otherwise determined, water meters with inlet and outlet openings up to two inches inclusive may be of the disc-type. When water meters with openings two inches or larger are required, the city shall determine the type to be used. 
(Prior code § 28-137) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 30, 8-2-11) 
13.12.410 - Installation. 
A.  When requesting the installation of any water meter, the consumer shall furnish information as to the amount of his contemplated water demand and the city shall then determine the proper type and size of the meter to be installed. 
B.  All water services one and one-half (11/2) inches and larger shall be installed with a full size meter bypass, equipped with a lockable valve approved by the city, equipped with a test port, and equipped with meter control valves at the inlet and outlet of the water meter. All new and replacement meters must be compatible with the city's meter reading system. 
C.  A permanent meter box of plastic or concrete shall be installed according to the following requirements:

13.12.420 - Recording of water supply. 
    Except in special cases, the supply of water through each water service shall be recorded through one meter. 
(Prior code § 28-139) 
13.12.430 - Location of meter tile and meter. 
    All water meter boxes for one- and two-family dwellings shall be placed no less than six feet or more than ten feet off of the property line unless permission is granted by the public works director. Multi-family, commercial, and industrial metering devices may be installed within the customer's building provided the city has access during business hours. 
(Prior code § 28-140)

13.12.440 - Yoke. 
    An iron meter yoke with a lockable shut-off valve and check valve shall be installed in the meter tile which shall be located at or near the customer's property line. Such yoke is to be furnished and installed by the customer's plumber and shall be an approved type. 
(Prior code § 28-141) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 33, 8-2-11) 
13.12.450 - Meter reading conclusive-Exceptions. 
    All customers shall be liable for the water consumption as shown by the meter, whether used, wasted, or caused by leakage or otherwise; provided, however, that whenever the city finds any meter not registering, an average bill may be rendered at the sole discretion of the city. This average bill shall be based upon a timeframe that most accurately reflects recent usage patterns and/or previous usage history. Whenever the city has reason to believe that any water meter is not registering correctly, such average bill may be rendered and the meter removed for testing; if such average bill proves to be incorrectly estimated, either by actual test or by actual water consumption after being replaced by a correct meter, such average bill so rendered shall be revised to conform to the same. 
(Prior code § 28-142) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 34, 8-2-11) 
13.12.460 - Moving of meters. 
A.  Any customer may make arrangements to move their water meter to a location which shall comply with Section 13.12.430. Such customer shall file, in writing, with the city a request for moving the meter, which request shall designate the location to which the meter is to be moved. Upon the receipt of such a request, the building inspector shall examine the proposed location and, if found to comply with this article, shall issue a written permit for the meter relocation and shall furnish the applicant with a meter yoke, meter tile, and cover without charge. Such applicant shall furnish all other labor, material, and equipment required for moving the meter and, when all of the necessary piping has been completed for the actual installation of the meter at its new location, he shall notify the city, which will arrange to move the meter to its new location and inspect the piping and work. The city's authorized representative who moves the meter and inspects the piping and work shall make a notation on the request which has been filed by the applicant of the date the meter was moved and comments on his inspection. 
B.  The charge for making the inspection required by subsection A of this section shall be twenty dollars ($20.00); provided however, that if the service line or piping is not ready for moving the meter, or is found unsatisfactory upon inspection, there shall be an additional charge of twenty dollars ($20.00) for each additional service call required. 
(Prior code § 28-143) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 35, 8-2-11) 
13.12.470 - Testing of meters. 
A.  In the event a customer requests an accuracy test of a meter one inch or smaller, the customer shall be required, prior to making such test, to deposit with the city an amount listed on the yearly rate schedule to cover the cost of removing, testing, and replacing such meter. In the event such meter is found to register incorrectly by more than two percent, an accurate meter shall be substituted and the test deposit shall be refunded. Past water bills shall be adjusted by refund or credit of such percentage of the amount of the water bills for a period of not more than two months previous to such tests. In the event such meter is found to be registering correctly, the customer shall forfeit the test deposit and such funds shall be deposited in the water operating funds of the city. 
B.  The city shall perform accuracy tests on meters greater than one inch every five years at the city's expense. If the meter falls within a five percent failure rate, the customer must replace or repair the meter at customer's expense. 
(Prior code § 28-144) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 36, 8-2-11) 
13.12.480 - Reserved.

13.12.490 - Plumber to notify city before breaking seal. 
    Plumbers shall notify the city whenever it is necessary to break any seal attached to a water meter or water service. 
(Prior code § 28-146) 
13.12.500 - Tampering prohibited. 
    No person, without permission from the city, shall tamper with any seal attached to a water meter or connect, disconnect, take apart, or in any manner change or interfere with the action, regulation, or registration of a water meter, or disturb any piping between any meter and the city's distributing system after such meter has been set. Any water meter so tampered with shall be removed for tests and repairs at the expense of the consumer or the owner of the property on which the meter is located. 
(Prior code § 28-147) 
13.12.510 - Repairs. 
    The city shall maintain and repair its water meters at its own expense, except that if any water meter is damaged by freezing, hot water or otherwise, due to the negligence of any customer, the cost of such repair shall be charged to the customer. 
(Prior code § 28-148) 
13.12.520 - Metering of private water supplies. 
    Upon all private water supplies of sewage system customers, there shall be required the installation of water meters on said supplies. Where the installation of a water meter is not feasible, a meter shall be required to be placed on the sewer of the customer. These meters shall be installed in compliance with Sections 13.12.390 through 13.12.510 dealing with meter installation. 
(Prior code § 28-149) 
Article 4. - Cross-Connections 

13.12.530 - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    "Cross-connection" is any physical connection between a potable water supply and any waste pipe, soil pipe, sewer, drain or any unapproved source or system. Furthermore, it is any potable water supply outlet which is submerged or can be submerged in wastewater and/or any other source of contamination and any source or system that is, in the opinion of the building inspector, based on the standards of the Missouri Department of Natural Resources, nonpotable and through which backflow can occur to contaminate the city's system. Bypass arrangements, jumper connections, removable sections, swivel or changeover devices and other temporary or permanent devices through which or because of which backflow can occur are to be considered as cross-connections. Cross-connections may be considered as direct or indirect. 
    "Direct cross-connection" is where the city's water system is physically joined to a system containing unsafe water, sewage or other waste that could contaminate the safe water system. 
    "Indirect cross-connection" may be a condition where a source of contaminated water may be blown across, sucked or diverted into the city's system. 
(Prior code § 28-156) 
13.12.540 - Violations-Discontinuance of service. 
    Cross-connections in the customer's water installation are not permitted. If a cross-connection is discovered, the building inspector, after giving the customer no less than fifteen (15) days' notice of its intention, will discontinue service, unless the condition is corrected or an approved backflow prevention device is installed by and at the expense of the customer. If, in the opinion of the building inspector, a real and serious threat to public health is posed, the building inspector may discontinue service without notice. 
(Prior code § 28-157) 
13.12.550 - Hazardous conditions. 
    Service connections will neither be made nor allowed to continue where there is, in the opinion of the building inspector, a strong potential for hazardous cross-connections, unless the customer will install and maintain at his own expense a backflow prevention device approved by the building inspector. 
(Prior code § 28-158) 
13.12.560 - Backflow prevention devices-Where required. 
    Approved backflow prevention devices are required for the following facilities: 
Beverage bottling plants ..... A.G., R.P.D. or D.C.A.* Packinghouses ..... A.G. or R.P.D. Cold storage plants ..... A.G. or R.P.D. Dairies ..... A.G., R.P.D. or D.C.A. Film laboratories ..... A.G. or R.P.D. Hospitals, medical buildings, sanitariums, morgues, autopsy facilities ..... A.G. or R.P.D. Nursing or convalescent homes and clinics ..... D.C.A. Irrigation systems, separate from domestic systems, such as parks, playgrounds, cemeteries, golf courses, schools, estates ..... A.G. or R.P.D. Lawn sprinkling systems adjunct to domestic systems ..... D.C.A. Sewage treatment plants ..... A.G. or R.P.D. Power plants ..... R.P.D. Laundries;lf.; R.P.D. Carwashes ..... R.P.D. Water loading stations ..... A.G. or D.C.A. Industries using toxic substances ..... R.P.D. Stockyards ..... R.P.D.  
* A.G. refers to air gap; R.P.D. refers to reduced pressure backflow device; D.C.A. refers to double-check valve assembly. 
    The building inspector, at his discretion, may require a device at other facilities dangerous to public health. 
(Prior code § 28-159) 
13.12.570 - Backflow prevention devices-Approval and installation inspection. 
    Backflow prevention devices shall be approved by the building inspector before installation by the customer and shall have been acceptable to the building inspector. Installation shall be inspected and approved by the building inspector. 
(Prior code § 28-160) 
13.12.580 - Backflow prevention devices-Maintenance. 
    The customer shall be responsible to maintain all backflow prevention devices in good working order and to make no piping or other arrangements for bypassing the devices. 
(Prior code § 28-161) 
13.12.590 - Backflow prevention devices-Periodic inspection-Testing. 
    Periodic testing and inspection schedules shall be established by the building inspector for all backflow prevention devices. Inspection intervals will not exceed one year; more frequent intervals may be established in accordance with the age and condition of the device. Testing and inspection will be performed by a certified backflow prevention technician, with cost to be borne by the customer. 
(Prior code § 28-162) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 38, 8-2-11) 
13.12.600 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Violation by a customer of the provisions of this article may be deemed a misdemeanor, punishable under the provisions of Section 1.16.010. 
(Prior code § 28-163) 
Chapter 13.16 - SEWER SERVICE SYSTEM 
Sections: 

13.16.010 - Sewer connection requirement. 
    Every owner of a house, building or structure used for human occupancy, business, employment, recreation or any other purpose, situated within the city on property abutting on any street, alley or right-of-way in which there is located a public sanitary sewer of the city within two hundred (200) feet of the property line, is hereby required, at his expense, to install suitable toilet facilities therein and to connect such facilities, as well as all other facilities which discharge domestic wastewater to such sewer in accordance with the provisions of this chapter within ninety (90) days of the date of an official notice to do so. 
(Prior code § 28-200) 
13.16.020 - Connection permit requirement. 
    Any person, organization, company, or corporation required to connect, or desiring to make connection, to the city sewer system (see Section 13.16.010) shall first obtain a connection permit authorizing the construction of such connection. No person, organization, company, or corporation shall uncover, alter, or disturb any public sewer or appurtenance thereon without first obtaining a connection permit. 
(Prior code § 28-201) 
(Ord. No. 6028 , § 1, 5-1-18) 
13.16.030 - Industrial discharge permit requirement. 
    Any discharger to the city sewer system classified by the city as an industrial user shall obtain an industrial discharge permit, in addition to the connection permit, in order to discharge industrial wastewater to the city sewer system. See Section 13.20.020 for specific requirements for obtaining/using an industrial discharge permit. 
(Prior code § 28-202) 
13.16.040 - Connection fees; inspection fees; procedure. 
A.  Sewer Connection Fee. 
1.  The purposes of providing funds for the extension, enlargement and improvement of the trunk, interceptor or outfall collection system associated with the sewerage system of the city and for the purpose of providing funding, in full or in part, for the construction of such sewage lines, and for the purpose of providing local matching funds for state and federal grant, there is hereby authorized and directed to be charged and collected a sewer connection fee for every new facility, whether residential, commercial or industrial, hereafter connected, directly or indirectly, through other sewers, to the sanitary sewer system of the city. 
2.  This sewer connection fee is in addition to the users service charge set out in Section 13.08.030 of this title. 
3.  Sewer connection fees for new facilities will be based on the size of the water tap serving such facility as follows: 
Water Tap Size Amount 3/4-Inch Water Service $845.00 1-Inch Water Service $1,265.00 11/2-Inch Water Service $2,335.00 2-Inch Water Service $3,618.00 3-Inch Water Service $6,605.00 4-Inch or Larger Water Service $13,005.00  
4.  A new facility is defined as any facility which makes a new connection to the city sewers, either directly or indirectly, or which increases its water tap size after March 1, 1997. 
5.  Such sewer connection fees as established by this ordinance shall be payable for each water tap and collected in advance of the issuance of any permit to construct any building or facility which will be connected to the combined water and sewerage system (CWSS). 
6.  Any new facility that pays a sewer connection fee pursuant to this ordinance after January 1, 1997 and later increases its water tap size or number of taps will be subject to the appropriate fee as established herein for its new water tap size except that it shall receive credit for sewer connection fees previously paid pursuant to this ordinance for the smaller water tap size. 
7.  The fees established herein shall be reviewed by the mayor and board of aldermen of the city on an annual basis and adjusted based upon the formula utilized by the city in its adoption of this ordinance, which formula has been heretofore established by Burns and McDonnel engineering firm, and which formula and study are available for public inspection in the office of the city clerk during regular business hours. 
B.  Permit Application Fee. Every person desiring a connection permit required by this division shall pay the connection fee set out above. All connection fees shall be paid in advance and shall be in addition to any charge made by the city for street openings and repairs. 
C.  Sewer Connection Fee/Restricted Account. The sewer connection fee referred to in subsection A of this section shall be deposited by the city clerk in a fund established pursuant to the provisions of Section 602(e)(2) of Ordinance Number 3355 and Ordinance Number 3354 authorizing the issuance of CWSS revenue bonds. Such account shall be designated "surplus account/plant system development charge/connection fee" and shall be designated a separate "surplus account" under the provision of Section 602(e)(2) of the aforesaid ordinances. Such account shall be restricted in that it shall not be used in any manner whatsoever other than as provided in subsection A of this section. The inspection fee set out above shall be deposited by the city under its normal operating procedures for costs of city personnel in inspection of sewer connections. 
(Ord. 3496 § 1, 1997: prior code § 28-203) 
(Ord. No. 5599, § 1, 12-16-14; Ord. No. 6028 , § 2, 5-1-18) 
13.16.045 - Private sewer mains prohibited. 
A.  "Private sewer main" is defined as service lines with multiple customers connected to it. Private sewer mains are prohibited and shall be repaired or replaced as set forth in this section. 
B.  Existing private sewer mains that are discovered by the city to be in poor repair or are found to be creating or causing environmental problems such as leaking sewage, infiltration and inflow, or related problems shall be replaced in the manner set forth in this section. Private sewer mains that are not yet creating or causing environmental problems shall be maintained by the property owners at no cost to the city until such time as the city determines that the private sewer main is in poor repair or creating or causing environmental problems. 
C.  Upon notice of environmental problems originating from or caused by a private sewer main, the city shall notify all property owners using said private sewer main and shall require the property owners to submit engineering plans to the city for the repair and replacement of the private sewer main within six months of notification by the city. The property owners shall be responsible for obtaining all needed easements and the property owners shall complete all construction of the appropriate sewer repair within one year of the notification by the city as set forth herein. If the city administrator or his designee determines that just cause exists for the extension of time, then an extension of time may be granted. 
D.  In the alternative, property owners who are required to replace or repair a private sewer main may form a cost-share agreement with the affected property owners and may enter into a contract with the city to replace the existing private sewer main with new sewer lines engineered to meet the city's requirements. If the city and the affected property owners utilize this alternative method, then the city shall pay all of the engineering design and inspection costs for the project. The property owners shall pay all of the remaining costs in the manner agreed to by the property owners and approved by the city by the formation of a Neighborhood Improvement District as set forth in the Revised Statutes of Missouri (see e.g. Sections 67.457 and 88.836.1, RSMo). 
E.  In the event the affected property owners do not repair or replace the private sewer main as required by the city, then the private sewer main shall be discontinued and the appropriate sewer lines installed with the full cost of the project being paid equally by the affected property owners by formation of a sewer district (see e.g. Sections 88.834, 88.836, and 88.838, RSMo). 
F.  After construction is completed to the city's satisfaction and standards, the city shall accept any new sewer mains constructed with the property owners being responsible for the service lines and the city shall pay all future maintenance costs for sewer mains. 
(Ord. No. 5828, § 1, 12-6-16) 
Article 2. - Sewer District 

13.16.050 - General sewer system. 
    The board of aldermen shall have the power to cause a general sewer system to be established which shall be composed of four classes of sewers: public, district, joint-district and private sewers. Public sewers shall be established along the principal courses of drainage, at such time, to such extent of such dimensions, and under such regulations as may be provided by ordinance. These may be extensions or branches of sewers already constructed or entirely new throughout, as may be deemed expedient. The city may levy a tax on all property made taxable for state purposes over the whole municipality to pay for the constructing, reconstructing and repairing of the work, which tax shall be called special public sewer tax, and shall be of the amount as may be required for the sewer, provided by ordinance to be built; and the funds arising from the tax shall be appropriated solely to the construction, reconstruction and reparation of the sewer. 
(Prior code § 28-600) 
13.16.060 - Creation of districts-Amendment-Construction generally. 
    District sewers shall be established for districts created and to be prescribed by ordinance and connect with public or other district or joint-district sewers, or with a natural course of drainage, as each case may be, and may be constructed with the main branch or discharge pipe wholly within or beyond the boundary of the district as the board shall determine. The district may be subdivided, enlarged or changed by ordinance at any time previous to the construction of the sewer therein; and more than one district sewer may be laid in a sewer district, if deemed necessary by the board of aldermen for sanitary or other purposes. The board of aldermen shall cause sewers to be constructed in each district whenever a majority of the property holders or residents shall petition therefor, or whenever the board of aldermen shall deem the sewers necessary for sanitary or other purposes, and the sewers shall be of such dimensions and materials as may be prescribed by ordinance and may be changed, enlarged or extended, and shall have all the necessary laterals, inlets, catch basins, manholes and other appurtenances. 
(Prior code § 28-601) 
13.16.070 - Apportionment of costs of district sewers-Levy of tax-Tax bills. 
    As soon as any district sewer shall have been completed, the engineer or other officer having charge of the work shall compute the whole costs thereof and shall apportion the same against the lots or tracts of ground in the district, exclusive of public highways, and the officer shall report the same to the board of aldermen by bill or otherwise, and the board of aldermen shall, therefore, levy and assess a special tax by ordinance against each lot or piece of ground within the district; whereupon, the city clerk shall make out a certified tax bill under the seal of the city of the assessment against each lot or piece of ground within the district in the name of the owner thereof. The certified tax bills shall be signed by the mayor and attested and recorded by the city clerk and shall be delivered to the contractor in payment for the work. 
(Prior code § 28-602) 
(Ord. No. 6028 , § 3, 5-1-18) 
13.16.080 - Special tax bills for sewers. 
    All special tax bills issued under the provisions of this chapter for sewers shall be as valid in all respects as other special tax bills provided for by state law, and collected in the manner and under the provisions as provided by Chapter 88 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(Prior code § 28-603) 
13.16.090 - Special assessments for improvements. 
    The procedure, levy and implementation of special assessments for improvements and district sewers generally shall be made in accordance with Chapter 88 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, and shall conform in all respects to Section 12.08.060. 
(Prior code § 28-604) 
13.16.100 - Connections to public sewers in districts from outside district boundaries. 
A.  Any person owning a lot or parcel of land lying outside the boundaries of a sewer district in which a sanitary or storm sewer has been constructed may, upon written application to the board of aldermen, be permitted to connect such lot or parcel of land with such sewer upon payment to the city clerk of a sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) plus the standard sewer connection fee for each connection of one building. In the case where several buildings are to be connected to a public sewer, with a line of such size as is approved by the city engineer and city superintendent of sewer and water, the fee shall be one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) plus the standard sewer connection fee for each building served. In the case of industrial buildings for which application to connect to the public sewer is made, the board of aldermen shall determine the amount of payment to be made, and it may further place certain restrictions on the use of such connection as concern the volume and character of the sewage to be discharged into the public sewer. 
B.  The person making the application and obtaining a permit to proceed with a connection shall pay the entire cost of labor, materials and all else required for such connection. 
C.  The fee paid for the authority to make such connection shall in no way be taken as the purchase price of any vested right in such public sewer, but the same shall be deemed and held as rental money for the sewer to which the connection has been made until such time as sewers shall be constructed in the district in which such connecting property lies, at which time the property shall be assessed its proportionate share of the cost of such construction as if the previous connection outside the district did not exist. Also, at the time such sewers are constructed, no refund of the fee collected by the city shall be made as the same shall be used in the maintenance of the sewer system in which the connection was made. 
D.  The city clerk shall keep a special record showing all receipts and connections so made. 
E.  The connections above described shall conform to all the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 3926 § 1, 1999; prior code § 28-605) 
(Ord. No. 6028 , § 4, 5-1-18) 
13.16.101 - District sewers special assessment fees on property not assessed in original district-Requirements generally. 
A.  For each district sewer which is financed by special assessments against land within the district, there should be established a special assessment fee. Any property owner who annexes to or is annexed by the city, or any property owner who connects to the sewers in a district for which such property has not previously been assessed, shall pay an assessment equal to the square foot assessment, or if assessed by lot or potential connection, the assessment therefor, for district sewers established at the time of levy of the assessment against the real estate reasonably served by such district in the same portion as other similarly situated properties within the district at the time of levy of the assessment. 
B.  The special assessment fee shall be established at the time of levy of the original special assessments, and shall remain on file in the office of the city clerk. The special assessment shall bear interest at the same percentage as the special assessment tax bills issued for the original district. Such special assessments shall be paid no later than the time at which the unassessed property or any part thereof is connected to the sewer system as annexed by the city. 
C.  This fee shall be levied only upon real estate which was included in the original district boundaries but was not assessed therefor because the same was not within the city limits or excluded by the property owner, and shall be levied only upon real estate within the district. 
D.  No sewer tap to the district sewer line shall be permitted prior to the payment in full of the fee established herein, compliance with regulations of the city, and payment of any fee otherwise required by city ordinance. 
E.  The fees provided for herein are for the purpose of reimbursing the city for its payment of the proportionate share of the total district not originally assessed against benefitted property. 
F.  Contemporaneous with the levy of the special assessment, the city shall establish the amount of special assessment for the property not assessed within the boundary of the district by preparation of a special assessment tax bill for said property, and same shall be kept on file in the office of the city clerk. Such special assessment tax bill shall not be levied, however, until the property is annexed or sewer system is accessed as set forth hereinabove. 
(Ord. 3927 § 1, 1999) 
Article 3. - Prohibited Discharges 

13.16.110 - General prohibition. 
    No person shall discharge any of the substances or substances having the conditions described in this article into any public sanitary sewer in the city, into any sewer flowing into any public sanitary sewer in the city or into any sewer flowing into any wastewater treatment plant owned or operated by the city (see also Sections 12.12.060 and 9.12.020). 
(Prior code § 28-250) 
13.16.120 - Waters. 
    No person shall discharge any stormwater, groundwater, roof runoff, subsurface drainage ponds, sump pumps, septic tanks or lawn sprays into any city sanitary sewer. Water from swimming pools, boiler drains, blowoff pipes or cooling water from various equipment may be discharged into the city sanitary sewer by an indirect connection where such discharge is cooled, if required, and flows into the sewer at a rate not to exceed the capacity of the sewer provided the waste does not contain materials or substances in suspension or solution in violation of the terms of this chapter and provided further than cooling water from any air-conditioning unit or other cooling unit shall in no event exceed one-tenth of a gallon per minute per ton capacity of the air conditioner or cooling unit. Dilution of any water discharged into the city sanitary sewer system is prohibited whether accomplished by combining two or more streams or by adding other liquids solely for the purpose of diluting the discharge. 
(Prior code § 28-251) 
13.16.130 - Wastewater. 
    No person shall discharge any of the following wastewater into any city sewer: 
A.  Any liquid or vapor having a temperature of more than one hundred eighty (180) degrees Fahrenheit that would elevate the wastewater treatment plant influent to a temperature above one hundred four (104) degrees Fahrenheit; 
B.  Any wastewater which contains wax, grease, oil, plastic or other substances that will solidify or become discernibly viscous at temperatures between thirty-two (32) degrees Fahrenheit and one hundred fifty (150) degrees Fahrenheit or that contain more than one hundred (100) parts per million by weight of fat, oil or grease; 
C.  Any wastewater containing flammable or explosive liquids, solids or gases; 
D.  Any wastewater containing solid or viscous substances in quantities capable of causing obstruction to the flow of the city sewer or interference with the operation of the wastewater treatment plant. Such substances include, but are not limited to, acids, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, whole blood, manure, hair, animal wastes, parts of bodies of animals, lime slurry, lime residue, paint residues, fiberglass or bulk solids; 
E.  Any wastewater containing garbage, except properly shredded garbage; 
F.  Any wastewater containing a noxious or malodorous substance which can form a gas, which, singly or by interaction with other wastes in the sewage system, is capable of causing objectionable odors or hazards to health, life or property or which can by itself or in combination with other substances in the sewage system form solids and concentrations exceeding the limits established in this article or any substance which creates any other condition harmful to the structure of treatment processes of the waste-water treatment plant; 
G.  Any industrial discharge containing pollutant or pollutant parameters exceeding the national pretreatment standards (40 CFR 403) or standards modified in accordance therewith. 
(Prior code § 28-252) 
13.16.140 - Substances. 
    No person shall discharge any of the following into the city sanitary sewer system: 
A.  Free or emulsified oil and grease exceeding an average of one hundred (100) mg/l or eight hundred thirty (830) pounds per million gallons of either oil or grease or any combination of oil and grease if it appears that the amounts of oil and grease can do any of the following: deposit grease or oil in the sewer in such a manner as to clog or interfere with the flow, overload the grease handling equipment of the wastewater treatment plant or have any harmful effect on the treatment process or the treatment equipment due to the nature and quantity of the substance; 
B.  Acids or alkalis having a pH value lower than 5.0 or higher than 9.0; 
C.  Salts or heavy metals in solution or suspension in concentrations toxic to biological wastewater treatment processes or in concentrations sufficient to adversely affect sludge digestion or any other biochemical, biological or other wastewater treatment process or harmful to the biology of the receiving stream to which the flow of the wastewater treatment facility discharges, or exceeding any limits established and identified in the Perryville pretreatment program; 
D.  Any other elements which will damage the city sewer system or be detrimental to the treatment processes or to the receiving stream to which the effluent of the wastewater treatment plant discharges. In enforcing this chapter the volume of a particular industrial user shall be considered not only by itself, but also in connection with other industrial users. All federal and state laws and regulations relating to the discharge of effluent streams shall be followed; 
E.  Cyanide or cyanogen compounds of liberating hydrocyanic gas or acidification in excess of two mg/l as Cx; 
F.  Radioactive materials defined as hazardous materials under federal laws and applicable regulations, including any substance required by the United States Department of Transportation to have Type A packaging or Type B packaging under regulations found in 49 CFR 173.426; 
G.  Any phenols or other odor-or taste-producing substances in such amounts as to produce a detectable odor or taste in the stream receiving the effluent from the wastewater treatment plant; 
H.  Materials which cause unusual concentrations of inert solids such as fuller's earth or other solids such as sodium chloride, calcium chloride or sodium sulfate. Materials which cause excessive discoloration. Materials which cause unusual biochemical oxygen demand or an immediate oxygen demand. Materials with a high hydrogen sulfide content. Materials with unusual flow and concentration; 
I.  Any toxic substances which are not amenable to treatment or reduction by the wastewater treatment plant; 
J.  Any water, wastewater or substance of any type which causes the city to violate its NPDES permit or interfere with its sludge use or disposal methods. 
(Prior code § 28-253) 
13.16.150 - Measurement of waters, wastewaters and substances discharged to the city sewer. 
    All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of water and wastewater to which reference is made in this article shall be determined in accordance with standard methods for the examination of water and wastewater accepted by the department of natural resources. 
(Prior code § 28-254) 
13.16.160 - Violations-City action. 
    Upon any violation of any provision of this article, the superintendent may take any or all of the following actions: 
A.  Discontinue sewer service and water service to the offending premises; 
B.  Apply for appropriate court action, with the assistance of the city attorney; 
C.  Require pretreatment of the discharge or other action to end the violation forthwith; 
D.  Require the user to pay a violation surcharge equal to the cost to the city of dealing with the offending matter; 
E.  Apply to the court for the levy of a fine for violation of this article. 
(Prior code § 28-255) 
13.16.170 - Violation surcharge. 
    Any user of the city sewer system that violates any provision of this article shall be subject to a violation surcharge equal to the cost incurred by the city in dealing with any problems resulting from the violation. The surcharge shall be as determined by the superintendent and approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 28-256) 
13.16.180 - Violation-Penalty. 
    Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than five dollars ($5.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Prior code § 28-257) 
Article 4. - Connection Specifications 

13.16.190 - Separate connection required for each building-Exception. 
    A separate and independent building sewer service connection shall be provided for every building except where a separate connection is not feasible. Each multiple connection shall be approved by a resolution of the board of aldermen. 
(Prior code § 28-300) 
13.16.200 - Use of old service connections. 
    Use of abandoned building sewer service connections is prohibited. 
(Prior code § 28-301) 
(Ord. No. 6028 , § 5, 5-1-18) 
13.16.210 - Inspection. 
    Every applicant receiving a building sewer connection permit shall give the city twenty-four (24) hour notification prior to the building sewer being ready for connection to the public sewer. The connection shall be made by city crews, using INSERTA TEE service connection system provided by the city. 
(Prior code § 28-302) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 39, 8-2-11; Ord. No. 6028 , § 6, 5-1-18) 
13.16.220 - Service connections and mains-Size, material, grade, location and alignment. 
A.  Mains. All extensions of sewer mains shall be of a diameter of not less than eight inches and a minimum grade of one-sixteenth inch per foot. All sewer mains shall be laid at a uniform grade and alignment. Changes in direction shall only be made with approved manholes per DNR construction specifications. 
B.  Sewer Service Connections. The size of every sewer service connection will be determined by the superintendent and installed by the city. Schedule 40 PVC pipe shall be used from the tapping point to the point the pipe reaches the property to be served. At the point the service line reaches private property, Schedule 35 pipe may be used by the contractor installing the line. Twelve (12) gauge solid copper/steel coated tracer wire shall be installed on the service line from the tapping point on the main to the cleanout closest to the foundation. The city will only supply the tee; it is the contractor's responsibility to supply the correct piping and tracer wire according to the specifications above. 
1.  A single-family dwelling connection shall be of a diameter of not less than four inches with a minimum grade of one-half inch per foot. 
2.  A multifamily, commercial or industrial connection shall be of a diameter of not less than six inches and a minimum grade of one-eighth inch per foot. 
3.  Whenever possible, every sewer service connection shall be brought into a building at an elevation below the basement floor. No service lines shall be laid parallel or within three feet of any bearing wall which might thereby be weakened. Service connections above the basement floor must be approved in writing by the superintendent. All sewer pipes shall be laid at a uniform grade and alignment and shall not vary more than one-half of the diameter of the pipe. Changes in directions shall only be made with approved manholes per DNR construction specifications. 
(Prior code § 28-303) 
(Ord. No. 6028 , § 7, 5-1-18) 
13.16.230 - Connection to be made where-Joints. 
A.  The connection of a building service to the city sewer shall be made by the city. 
B.  The invert of the sewer service connection at the point of connection shall be at the same or at a higher elevation than the invert of the city sewer. A smooth, neat joint shall be made with the opening machine cut only as approved by the superintendent, and the connection made secure and water tight by encasement of same in concrete. 
C.  No excavation for a sewer line connection, whether it be to a collector, lateral, or other city sewer line, shall be covered without the superintendent first inspecting and approving the connection. 
D.  No connection of a residential or industrial sewer service line shall be made into a manhole without the written approval of the superintendent. 
(Prior code § 28-304) 
(Ord. No. 6028 , § 8, 5-1-18) 
13.16.240 - Pipe joints. 
    All joints and connections shall be made gas tight and water tight. 
(Prior code § 28-305) 
(Ord. No. 6028 , § 9, 5-1-18) 
13.16.250 - Excavation and backfill. 
    All excavations required for the installation of a sewer service connection shall be open-trench work. Pipe laying and backfill shall be performed in accordance with ASTM specifications D2321 for plastic pipe except that no backfill shall be placed until the work has been inspected by the superintendent. If the trench is located in filled or unstable ground or in a trench greater that forty-eight (48) inches deep, proper trench protection shall be installed prior to city crews entering the trench to install the sewer tap. In cases of filled or unstable ground, the sewer service connection shall be constructed in such a manner as to assure proper grade and alignment. All excavations for sewer service connections shall be adequately guarded with barricades and lights so as to protect the public from hazard. Streets, sidewalks, parkways and other public property disturbed in the course of the work shall be restored in a manner satisfactory to the city. The backfill, to a point extending six inches above the pipeline, shall be made by hand and sand backfilled to ensure uniform support of the pipe. The balance of the backfill may be made with equipment but must be water jetted or tamped to ensure maximum settlement. Excess excavation shall be removed and the surface of the street or alley shall be left in as reasonably near the same condition as existed prior to the excavation. 
(Prior code § 28-306) 
(Ord. No. 6028 , § 10, 5-1-18) 
13.16.260 - Alteration of sewage/wastewater disposal method-Cost constitutes tax bill. 
    If the city makes any alteration in the method of disposal of sewage, the cost thereof shall be provided for and defrayed by a special tax bill to be assessed in favor of the city against the property on which the improvements are made and such special tax bill shall become a lien on the property. 
(Prior code § 28-307) 
Article 5. - Pretreatment of Sewage 

13.16.270 - Pretreatment requirements-Generally. 
    Any user of the city sewer system shall be required to pretreat the user's wastewater discharge before release to the city sewer if in the opinion of the superintendent: 
A.  The user is an industrial discharger and the wastewater being discharged contains constituents or characteristics that exceed federal national pretreatment standards. 
B.  The wastewater will be harmful to the structure, process or operation of the city sewer system, wastewater treatment plant or sludge management practice. 
(Prior code § 28-450) 
13.16.280 - Pretreatment standards. 
    Any user of the city sewer system that is required by the superintendent to pretreat the discharge before release shall, at the user's expense, provide such treatment as may be necessary to: 
A.  Reduce the five-day BOD to three hundred (300) parts per million and the suspended solids to three hundred fifty (350) parts per million by weight; 
B.  Reduce objectionable characteristics or constituents to within the maximum limits provided for in Article 3 of this chapter; 
C.  Control the rate of discharge of such waters and wastewaters. 
(Prior code § 28-451) 
13.16.290 - Grease, oil and sand interceptors. 
    Grease, oil and sand traps or interceptors shall be provided for any discharge to the city sewer containing grease or flammable wastes, sand and other harmful materials. Such interceptors shall not be required for private living quarters or dwellings. All such interceptors shall be subject to inspection by the superintendent, and they shall be located so as to be readily accessible for easy cleaning and inspection. Grease and oil interceptors shall be constructed of impervious materials capable of withstanding abrupt and extreme changes in temperature. They shall be of substantial construction, watertight and equipped with easily removable covers which when bolted in place shall be gastight and watertight. Where installed, all grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be maintained by the user, at the user's expense, in continuously efficient operation at all times. Materials removed from these facilities shall be either recycled by the user or disposed of in accordance with all applicable laws and ordinances. 
(Prior code § 28-452) 
13.16.300 - Pretreatment facilities-Approval of plans and specifications. 
    Any user of the city sewer system required or desiring to pretreat discharge shall submit to the city a copy of the plans, specifications and other pertinent information relating to the proposed facilities. No construction of such facilities shall begin until the plans and related information are approved in writing by the city. 
(Prior code § 28-453) 
13.16.310 - Pretreatment facilities-Maintenance. 
    Where pretreatment facilities are provided for any waters or wastewaters to be discharged to the city sewer, such facilities shall be maintained continuously in a satisfactory and effective operation by the owner thereof at the owner's expense. 
(Prior code § 28-454) 
Chapter 13.20 - INDUSTRIAL USERS OF SEWER SYSTEM[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5658, § 1, adopted July 7, 2015, amended Chapter 13.20 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Chapter 13.20, §§ 13.20.010-13.20.170, pertained to similar material, and derived from prior code §§ 28-350-28-364 and Ord. No. 5241, adopted August 2, 2011. 

13.20.010 - General provisions. 
A.  Purpose and Policy. This chapter sets forth uniform requirements for users of the publicly owned treatment works for the city of Perryville and enables the city to comply with all applicable state and federal laws, including the Clean Water Act (33 U.S.C. 1251 et seq.) and the General Pretreatment Regulations (Title 40 of the CFR Part 403). The objectives of this chapter are: 
1.  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works that will interfere with its operation. 
2.  To prevent the introduction of pollutants into the publicly owned treatment works that will pass through the publicly owned treatment works, inadequately treated, into receiving waters or otherwise be incompatible with the publicly owned treatment works. 
3.  To protect both publicly owned treatment works personnel who may be affected by wastewater and sludge in the course of their employment and the general public. 
4.  To promote reuse and recycling of industrial wastewater and sludge from the publicly owned treatment works.
