2.  The city administrator shall have the right to set up on the user's property, or require installation of, such devices as are necessary to conduct sampling and/or metering of the user's operations. 
3.  The city administrator may require the user to install monitoring equipment as necessary. The facility's sampling and monitoring equipment shall be maintained at all times in a safe and proper operating condition by the user at its own expense. All devices used to measure wastewater flow and quality shall be calibrated to ensure their accuracy. 
4.  Any temporary or permanent obstruction to safe and easy access to the facility to be inspected and/or sampled shall be promptly removed by the user at the written or verbal request of the city administrator and shall not be replaced. The costs of clearing such access shall be borne by the user. 
5.  Unreasonable delays in allowing the city administrator access to the user's premises shall be a violation of this chapter. 
B.  Search Warrants. If the city administrator has been refused access to a building, structure, or property, or any part thereof, and is able to demonstrate probable cause to believe that there may be a violation of this chapter, or that there is a need to inspect and/or sample as part of a routine inspection and sampling program of the city designed to verify compliance with this chapter or any permit or order issued hereunder, or to protect the overall public health, safety, and welfare of the community, the city administrator may seek issuance of a search warrant from the Circuit Court of Perry County, Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 5658, § 1, 7-7-15) 
13.20.080 - Confidential information. 
    Information and data on a user obtained from reports, surveys, wastewater discharge permit applications, individual wastewater discharge permits, and monitoring programs, and from the city administrator's inspection and sampling activities, shall be available to the public without restriction unless the user specifically requests and is able to demonstrate to the satisfaction of the city administrator that the release of such information would divulge information, processes, or methods of production entitled to protection as trade secrets under applicable state law. Any such request must be asserted at the time of submission of the information or data. When requested and demonstrated by the user furnishing a report that such information should be held confidential, the portions of a report which might disclose trade secrets or secret processes shall not be made available for inspection by the public, but shall be made available immediately upon request to governmental agencies for uses related to the NPDES program or pretreatment program and in enforcement proceedings involving the person furnishing the report. Wastewater constituents and characteristics and other effluent data, as defined at 40 CFR 2.302, shall not be recognized as confidential information and shall be available to the public without restriction. 
(Ord. No. 5658, § 1, 7-7-15) 
13.20.090 - Publication of industrial users in significant noncompliance. 
    The city administrator shall publish annually, in a newspaper of general circulation that provides meaningful public notice within the jurisdictions served by the POTW, a list of the users which, at any time during the previous twelve (12) months, were in significant noncompliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. The term significant noncompliance shall be applicable to all significant industrial users (or any other industrial user that violates this section and shall mean: 
A.  Chronic violations of wastewater discharge limits, defined herein as those in which sixty-six (66) percent or more of all the measurements taken for the same pollutant parameter taken during a six-month period exceed (by any magnitude) a numeric pretreatment standard or requirement, including instantaneous limits as defined in this chapter. 
B.  Technical review criteria (TRC) violations, defined herein as those in which thirty-three (33) percent or more of wastewater measurements taken for each pollutant parameter during a six-month period equals or exceeds the product of the numeric pretreatment standard or requirement including instantaneous limits, as defined in this chapter, multiplied by the applicable criteria (1.4 for BOD, TSS, fats, oils, and grease, and 1.2 for all other pollutants except pH) 
C.  Any other violation of a pretreatment standard or requirement as defined herein (daily maximum, long-term average, instantaneous limit, or narrative standard) that the city administrator determines has caused, alone or in combination with other discharges, interference or pass through, including endangering the health of POTW personnel or the general public. 
D.  Any discharge of a pollutant that has caused imminent endangerment to the public or to the environment or has resulted in the city administrator's exercise of the city administrator's emergency authority to halt or prevent such a discharge. 
E.  Failure to meet, within ninety (90) days of the scheduled date, a compliance schedule milestone contained in an individual wastewater discharge permit or enforcement order for starting construction, completing construction, or attaining final compliance. 
F.  Failure to provide within forty-five (45) days after the due date any required reports, including baseline monitoring reports, reports on compliance with categorical pretreatment standard deadlines, periodic self-monitoring reports, and reports on compliance with compliance schedules. 
G.  Failure to accurately report noncompliance. 
H.  Any other violation(s), which may include a violation of best management practices, which the city administrator determines will adversely affect the operation or implementation of the local pretreatment program. 
(Ord. No. 5658, § 1, 7-7-15) 
13.20.100 - Administrative enforcement remedies. 
A.  Notification of Violation. When the city administrator finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the city administrator may serve upon that user a written notice of violation. Within twenty (20) days of the receipt of such notice, an explanation of the violation and a plan for the satisfactory correction and prevention thereof, to include specific required actions, shall be submitted by the user to the city administrator. Submission of such a plan in no way relieves the user of liability for any violations occurring before or after receipt of the notice of violation. Nothing in this section shall limit the authority of the city administrator to take any action, including emergency actions or any other enforcement action, without first issuing a notice of violation. 
B.  Consent Orders. The city administrator may enter into consent orders, assurances of compliance, or other similar documents establishing an agreement with any user responsible for noncompliance. Such documents shall include specific action to be taken by the user to correct the noncompliance within a time period specified by the document. Such documents shall have the same force and effect as the administrative orders issued pursuant to this section and shall be judicially enforceable. 
C.  Show Cause Hearing. The city administrator may order a user which has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement to appear before the city administrator and show cause why the proposed enforcement action should not be taken. Notice shall be served on the user specifying the time and place for the meeting, the proposed enforcement action, the reasons for such action, and a request that the user show cause why the proposed enforcement action should not be taken. The notice of the meeting shall be served personally or by registered or certified mail (return receipt requested) at least twenty (20) days prior to the hearing. Such notice may be served on any authorized representative of the user as defined in this chapter. A show cause hearing shall not be a bar against, or prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
D.  Compliance Orders. When the city administrator finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the city administrator may issue an order to the user responsible for the discharge directing that the user come into compliance within a specified time. If the user does not come into compliance within the time provided, sewer service may be discontinued unless adequate treatment facilities, devices, or other related appurtenances are installed and properly operated. Compliance orders also may contain other requirements to address the noncompliance, including additional self-monitoring and management practices designed to minimize the amount of pollutants discharged to the sewer. A compliance order may not extend the deadline for compliance established for a pretreatment standard or requirement nor does a compliance order relieve the user of liability for any violation, including any continuing violation. Issuance of a compliance order shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
E.  Cease and Desist Orders. When the city administrator finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, or that the user's past violations are likely to recur, the city administrator may issue an order to the user directing it to cease and desist all such violations and directing the user to: 
1.  Immediately comply with all requirements. 
2.  Take such appropriate remedial or preventive action as may be needed to properly address a continuing or threatened violation, including halting operations and/or terminating the discharge. Issuance of a cease and desist order shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
F.  Administrative Fines. 
1.  When the city administrator finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the city administrator may fine such user in an amount not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). Such fines shall be assessed on a per-violation, per-day basis. In the case of monthly or other long-term average discharge limits, fines shall be assessed for each day during the period of violation. 
2.  Unpaid charges, fines, and penalties shall, after ninety (90) calendar days, be a lien against the real estate where the violation occurred. The lien shall be perfected as a tax bill against the property where the violation occurred. The tax bill shall accrue interest at the same rate as set for the United States Treasury bills on the date when the tax bill is recorded. All tax bills issued under the provisions of this section shall be valid in all respects as other special tax bills provided for by state law and collected in the manner and under the provisions provided by Chapter 88 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
3.  Users desiring to dispute such fines must file a written request for the city administrator to reconsider the fine along with full payment of the fine amount within thirty (30) days of being notified of the fine. Where a request has merit, the city administrator may convene a hearing on the matter. In the event the user's appeal is successful, the payment, together with any interest accruing thereto, shall be returned to the user. The city administrator may add the costs of preparing administrative enforcement actions, such as notices and orders, to the fine. 
4.  Issuance of an administrative fine shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
G.  Emergency Suspensions. The city administrator may immediately suspend a user's discharge, after informal notice to the user, whenever such suspension is necessary to stop an actual or threatened discharge, which reasonably appears to present or cause an imminent or substantial endangerment to the health or welfare of persons. The city administrator may also immediately suspend a user's discharge, after notice and opportunity to respond, that threatens to interfere with the operation of the POTW or which presents, or may present, an endangerment to the environment. 
1.  Any user notified of a suspension of its discharge shall immediately stop or eliminate its contribution. In the event of a user's failure to immediately comply voluntarily with the suspension order, the city administrator may take such steps as deemed necessary, including immediate severance of the sewer connection, to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW, its receiving stream, or endangerment to any individuals. The city administrator may allow the user to recommence its discharge when the user has demonstrated to the satisfaction of the city administrator that the period of endangerment has passed, unless the termination proceedings in this section are initiated against the user. 
2.  A user that is responsible, in whole or in part, for any discharge presenting imminent endangerment shall submit a detailed written statement describing the causes of the harmful contribution and the measures taken to prevent any future occurrence to the city administrator prior to the date of any show cause or termination hearing under this section. 
Nothing in this section shall be interpreted as requiring a hearing prior to any emergency suspension under this section. 
H.  Termination of Discharge. In addition to the provisions in this chapter, any user who violates the following conditions is subject to discharge termination: 
1.  Violation of individual wastewater discharge permit conditions. 
2.  Failure to accurately report the wastewater constituents and characteristics of its discharge. 
3.  Failure to report significant changes in operations or wastewater volume, constituents, and characteristics prior to discharge. 
4.  Refusal of reasonable access to the user's premises for the purpose of inspection, monitoring, or sampling. 
5.  Violation of the pretreatment standards in this chapter. 
Such user will be notified of the proposed termination of its discharge and be offered an opportunity to show cause under this chapter why the proposed action should not be taken. Exercise of this option by the city administrator shall not be a bar to, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against the user. 
(Ord. No. 5658, § 1, 7-7-15; Ord. No. 5888, § 3, 5-27-2017) 
13.20.110 - Judicial enforcement remedies. 
A.  Injunctive Relief. When the city administrator finds that a user has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, the city administrator may petition the Circuit Court of Perry County, Missouri, for the issuance of a temporary or permanent injunction, as appropriate, which restrains or compels the specific performance of the individual wastewater discharge permit, order, or other requirement imposed by this chapter on activities of the user. The city administrator may also seek such other action as is appropriate for legal and/or equitable relief, including a requirement for the user to conduct environmental remediation. A petition for injunctive relief shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a user. 
B.  Civil Penalties. 
1.  A user who has violated, or continues to violate, any provision of this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement shall be liable to the city for a maximum civil penalty of five hundred dollars ($500.00) per day. In the case of a monthly or other long-term average discharge limit, penalties shall accrue for each day during the period of the violation. 
2.  The city administrator may recover reasonable attorneys' fees, court costs, and other expenses associated with enforcement activities, including sampling and monitoring expenses, and the cost of any actual damages incurred by the city. 
3.  In determining the amount of civil liability, the court shall take into account all relevant circumstances, including, but not limited to, the extent of harm caused by the violation, the magnitude and duration of the violation, any economic benefit gained through the user's violation, corrective actions by the user, the compliance history of the user, and any other factor as justice requires. 
4.  Filing a suit for civil penalties shall not be a bar against, or a prerequisite for, taking any other action against a user. 
C.  Criminal Prosecution. 
1.  A user who willfully or negligently violates any provision of this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) per violation, per day, or imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days. 
2.  A user who willfully or negligently introduces any substance into the POTW which causes personal injury or property damage shall, upon conviction, be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be subject to a penalty of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and imprisonment for a period up to ninety (90) days. This penalty shall be in addition to any other cause of action for personal injury or property damage available under state law. 
3.  A user who knowingly makes any false statements, representations, or certifications in any application, record, report, plan, or other documentation filed, or required to be maintained, pursuant to this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or who falsifies, tampers with, or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this chapter shall, upon conviction, be punished by a fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and imprisonment for a period up to ninety (90) days. 
D.  Remedies Nonexclusive. The remedies provided for in this chapter are not exclusive. The city administrator may take any, all, or any combination of these actions against a noncompliant user. Enforcement of pretreatment violations will generally be in accordance with the city's enforcement response plan. However, the city administrator may take other action against any user when the circumstances warrant. Further, the city administrator is empowered to take more than one enforcement action against any noncompliant user. 
(Ord. No. 5658, § 1, 7-7-15; Ord. No. 5888, § 4, 5-27-2017) 
13.20.120 - Supplemental enforcement action. 
A.  Penalties for Late Reports. A penalty of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be assessed to any user for each day that a report required by this chapter on a permit or order issued hereunder is late, beginning five days after the date the report is due. Actions taken by the city administrator to collect late reporting penalties shall not limit the city administrator authority to initiate other enforcement actions that may include penalties for late reporting violations. 
B.  Performance Bonds. The city administrator may decline to issue or reissue an individual wastewater discharge permit to any user who has failed to comply with any provision of this chapter, a previous individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, unless such user first files a satisfactory bond, payable to the city, in a sum not to exceed a value determined by the city administrator to be necessary to achieve consistent compliance. 
C.  Liability Insurance. The city administrator may decline to issue or reissue an individual wastewater discharge permit to any user who has failed to comply with any provision of this chapter, a previous individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, unless the user first submits proof that it has obtained financial assurances sufficient to restore or repair damage to the POTW caused by its discharge. 
D.  Payment of Outstanding Fees and Penalties. The city administrator may decline to issue or reissue an individual wastewater discharge permit to any user who has failed to pay any outstanding fees, fines, or penalties incurred as a result of any provision of this chapter, a previous individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder. 
E.  Water Supply Severance. Whenever a user has violated or continues to violate any provision of this chapter, an individual wastewater discharge permit, or order issued hereunder, or any other pretreatment standard or requirement, water service to the user may be severed. Service will recommence, at the user's expense, only after the user has satisfactorily demonstrated its ability to comply. 
(Ord. No. 5658, § 1, 7-7-15) 
13.20.130 - Affirmative defenses to discharge violations. 
A.  Upset. 
1.  For the purposes of this section, upset means an exceptional incident in which there is unintentional and temporary noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards because of factors beyond the reasonable control of the user. An upset does not include noncompliance to the extent caused by operational error, improperly designed treatment facilities, inadequate treatment facilities, lack of preventive maintenance, or careless or improper operation. 
2.  An upset shall constitute an affirmative defense to an action brought for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards if the requirements of subsection (A)(3) below are met. 
3.  A user who wishes to establish the affirmative defense of upset shall demonstrate through properly signed contemporaneous operating logs or other relevant evidence that: 
a.  An upset occurred and the user can identify the cause(s) of the upset. 
b.  The facility was at the time being operated in a prudent and workmanlike manner and in compliance with applicable operation and maintenance procedures. 
c.  The user has submitted the following information to the city administrator within twenty-four (24) hours of becoming aware of the upset; if this information is provided orally, a written submission must be provided within five days: 
i.  A description of the indirect discharge and cause of noncompliance. 
ii.  The period of noncompliance, including exact dates and times, or, if not corrected, the anticipated time the noncompliance is expected to continue. 
iii.  Steps being taken and/or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent recurrence of the noncompliance. 
4.  In any enforcement proceeding, the user seeking to establish the occurrence of an upset shall have the burden of proof. 
5.  Users shall have the opportunity for a judicial determination on any claim of upset only in an enforcement action brought for noncompliance with categorical pretreatment standards. 
6.  Users shall control production of all discharges to the extent necessary to maintain compliance with categorical pretreatment standards upon reduction, loss, or failure of its treatment facility until the facility is restored or an alternative method of treatment is provided. This requirement applies in the situation where, among other things, the primary source of power of the treatment facility is reduced, lost, or fails. 
B.  Prohibited Discharge Standards. A user shall have an affirmative defense to an enforcement action brought against it for noncompliance with the general prohibitions in this chapter or the specific prohibitions in this chapter if it can prove that it did not know, or have reason to know, that its discharge, alone or in conjunction with discharges from other sources, would cause pass through or interference and that either: 
1.  A local limit exists for each pollutant discharged and the user was in compliance with each limit directly prior to, and during, the pass through or interference. 
2.  No local limit exists, but the discharge did not change substantially in nature or constituents from the user's prior discharge when the city was regularly in compliance with its NPDES permit and in the case of interference was in compliance with applicable sludge use or disposal requirements. 
C.  Bypass. 
1.  For the purposes of this section: 
a.  Bypass means the intentional diversion of wastestreams from any portion of a user's treatment facility. 
b.  Severe property damage means substantial physical damage to property, damage to the treatment facilities which causes them to become inoperable, or substantial and permanent loss of natural resources which can reasonably be expected to occur in the absence of a bypass. Severe property damage does not mean economic loss caused by delays in production. 
2.  A user may allow any bypass to occur which does not cause pretreatment standards or requirements to be violated, but only if it also is for essential maintenance to assure efficient operation. These bypasses are not subject to the provision of this section. 
D.  Bypass Notifications. 
1.  If a user knows in advance of the need for a bypass, it shall submit prior notice to the city administrator at least ten days before the date of the bypass, if possible. 
2.  A user shall submit oral notice to the city administrator of an unanticipated bypass that exceeds applicable pretreatment standards within twenty-four (24) hours from the time it becomes aware of the bypass. A written submission shall also be provided within five days of the time the user becomes aware of the bypass. The written submission shall contain a description of the bypass and its cause; the duration of the bypass, including exact dates and times, and, if the bypass has not been corrected, the anticipated time it is expected to continue; and steps taken or planned to reduce, eliminate, and prevent reoccurrence of the bypass. The city administrator may waive the written report on a case-by-case basis if the oral report has been received within twenty-four (24) hours. 
E.  Bypass. 
1.  Bypass is prohibited and the city administrator may take an enforcement action against a user for a bypass unless: 
a.  Bypass was unavoidable to prevent loss of life, personal injury, or severe property damage. 
b.  There were no feasible alternatives to the bypass, such as the use of auxiliary treatment facilities, retention of untreated wastes, or maintenance during normal periods of equipment downtime. This condition is not satisfied if adequate back-up equipment should have been installed in the exercise of reasonable engineering judgment to prevent a bypass which occurred during normal periods of equipment downtime or preventive maintenance. 
c.  The user submitted notices as required under this section. 
2.  The city administrator may approve an anticipated bypass, after considering its adverse effects, if the city administrator determines that it will meet the three conditions listed in the surcharge costs and billing procedures. 
(Ord. No. 5658, § 1, 7-7-15) 
13.20.140 - Surcharge costs and billing procedures. 
A.  Industrial User Surcharge. 
1.  All industrial users that are allowed to discharge five-day biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) or total suspended solids (TSS) in excess of two hundred fifty (250) milligrams per liter shall be subject to an industrial user surcharge. The surcharge is in addition to the user service charge defined in this chapter. The purpose of the surcharge is to ensure that industrial users pay a proportionate share of the costs of operating, maintaining, and financing the city sewer system. The charge to each industrial user for which the charge is applicable shall be based on the surcharge pounds of BOD plus TSS discharged. 
2.  The following formula shall be used for determining the industrial user surcharge (IUS): 
IUS = A/B 
Where, 
IUS = The charge in dollars per pound of BOD plus TSS for the surcharge pounds of these pollutant parameters. 
A   = Estimated annual costs in dollars to operate, maintain, and finance the city sewer system. 
B   = Estimated annual pounds of BOD plus TSS received at the city wastewater treatment plant. 
3.  The city shall review the industrial user surcharge annually in conjunction with the user service charge and revise the rate as necessary to ensure that the systems generate adequate revenues to pay the cost of operation and maintenance, including replacement, and that the systems continue to provide for the proportional distribution of costs among users. 
4.  The city will notify each industrial user at least annually, in conjunction with a regular sewer bill, of the industrial user surcharge rate. 
B.  Monitoring. All significant industrial users connected to the city sewer system shall be monitored by the city a minimum of once per year or as often as necessary to determine their hydraulic and organic contribution. The results of the monitoring shall be used to calculate the industrial user surcharge amount. 
C.  Billing. All significant industrial users subject to the industrial user surcharge will be billed by the city by the fifteenth (15th) of each month. 
D.  Failure to Pay. If and when any industrial user subject to the industrial user surcharge fails to make payment to the city by the last day of the month, after proper billing by the city by the fifteenth (15th) of the month, the city is directed to recover any sums due to the city under this section and enforce any provisions of this code to effectuate same. 
E.  Inhibitory Pollutants-Service Charge. Any user of the city sewer system that discharges, occasionally or routinely, any inhibitory or toxic pollutants which cause an increase in the cost of managing the effluent or the sludge from the wastewater treatment plant, or any user that discharges any substance which singly or by interaction with other substances causes identifiable increases in the costs of operation, maintenance, or replacement of the wastewater treatment plant, shall pay for such increased costs. The charge to each such user shall be as determined by the city administrator and approved by the board of aldermen. 
F.  Installation and Location of Monitoring Manhole. When required by the city, the owner of any property served by a sewer service connection carrying industrial wastewater shall install, at the owner's expense, a suitable monitoring manhole in the service sewer to facilitate observation, sampling, and measurement of the discharge. Such manhole, when required, shall be accessible and safely located and shall be constructed in accordance with plans approved by the city. 
(Ord. No. 5658, § 1, 7-7-15; Ord. No. 5888, § 5, 5-27-2017) 
13.20.150 - Wastewater treatment rates. 
    (RESERVED) 
13.20.160 - Miscellaneous provisions. 
A.  Pretreatment Charges and Fees. The city may adopt reasonable fees for reimbursement of costs of setting up and operating the city's pretreatment program which may include: 
1.  Fees for wastewater discharge permit applications including the cost of processing such applications. 
2.  Fees for monitoring, inspection, and surveillance procedures, including the cost of collection and analyzing a user's discharge and reviewing monitoring reports and certification statements submitted by users. 
3.  Fees for reviewing and responding to accidental discharge procedures and construction. 
4.  Fees for filing appeals. 
5.  Fees to recover administrative and legal costs (not included in this section) associated with the enforcement activity taken by the city administrator to address IU noncompliance. 
6.  Other fees as the city may deem necessary to carry out the requirements contained herein. These fees relate solely to the matters covered by this chapter and are separate from all other fees, fines, and penalties chargeable by the city. 
B.  Severability. If any provision of this chapter is invalidated by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining provisions shall not be affected and shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 5658, § 1, 7-7-15) 
13.20.170 - Effective date. 
    This chapter shall be in full force and effect on October 1, 2014. 
(Ord. No. 5658, § 1, 7-7-15) 
Chapter 13.24 - NATURAL GAS SERVICE SYSTEM 
Article 1. - Generally 

13.24.010 - Definitions. 
    As used in this chapter the following terms shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them in this section: 
    "Customer" means any person whose premises is connected to the natural gas system of the city. 
    "Meter" means the device used to measure the amount of gas supplied by the natural gas system of the city. 
(Prior code § 15-1) 
13.24.020 - Tap and service connection-Application required. 
    Any person desiring gas service from the natural gas system of the city shall file a written application therefor in the office of the city clerk upon blank forms to be provided for such purpose, signed by the owner of the property for which such tap or service connection is desired, or by a duly authorized agent of such owner. Such application shall be accompanied by payment of the fee prescribed in this chapter to cover the cost of such service connection. In the event such application is made by an agent for the owner, then such application shall also be accompanied by written authority of such owner to the agent for the making of the application. 
(Ord. 3660 § 1, 1998: prior code § 15-2) 
13.24.030 - Order for installation of pipe, tap, meter and service connection. 
    Upon the filing of the application for a gas tap or service connection, with the intent to immediately use gas, if the same is in proper form and the fee required by Section 13.24.040 is paid, an order for the installation of service pipe, tap, meter and service connections shall be issued by the city clerk to the officer or employees of the city having charge of such work, whose duty it shall be to make such installation and connection without unnecessary delay, and to return such order to the city clerk immediately upon completion of such work with an endorsement thereon signed by such officer or employee showing the date, place and manner in which such tap or connections were made. 
(Prior code § 15-3) 
13.24.040 - Tap and service connection fee. 
A.  For all residential gas taps and service connections within the city limits, the city shall furnish and install an excess flow valve, service tee, the first seventy-five (75) feet of service pipe, connection, fittings, regulator, meter, and necessary meter stop for a fee indicated on the city's yearly rate schedule. The city shall own and maintain all equipment furnished under this subsection. 
B.  For all industrial gas taps and service connections within the city limits, the city shall furnish and install an excess flow valve, service tee, the first seventy-five (75) feet of service pipe, connection, fittings, and necessary meter stop for a fee indicated on the city's yearly rate schedule. The city will also install the regulator, meter, and meter set; however, the customer shall reimburse the city for the cost of these items at the purchase price. The city shall own and maintain all equipment installed. In the event an existing industry increases their need for natural gas beyond the capabilities of their current gas meter, the city shall install a new regulator, meter, and meter set capable of handling the industry's needs; however, the customer shall reimburse the city for the cost of these items at the purchase price. The city shall own and maintain all equipment installed. 
C.  In addition to the above, the customer shall pay the city an amount listed on the city's yearly rate schedule per lineal foot of service pipe over seventy-five (75) feet. 
(Prior code § 15-4) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 43, 8-2-11) 
13.24.050 - Applications, orders and reports-Records. 
    All applications for gas taps or service connections and the orders and reports issued and returned thereon, shall be appropriately numbered and kept on file in the office of the public works director as a permanent record. 
(Prior code § 15-5) 
13.24.060 - Time restriction on installation of service line. 
    No gas service line shall be installed by the city more than sixty (60) days prior to its use for service. 
(Prior code § 15-6) 
13.24.070 - Extension of service mains within city limits. 
A.  The city shall extend natural gas mains within the city limits for a distance of one hundred (100) feet per customer. If an extension over one hundred (100) feet is approved by the board of aldermen, the materials for such extension shall be at the cost of the customer according to the city's yearly rate schedule. 
B.  In extraordinary situations which will provide a substantial increase in the natural gas customer base, the city in its sole discretion may elect to extend natural gas mains within the city limits at the city's cost to provide natural gas service for residential, commercial, or industrial developments in order to increase its customer base and secure new development. In such situations, a reasonable rate of return or benefit to the city must occur as determined by the city administrator and approved by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. 3660 § 2, 1998: prior code § 15-8) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 44, 8-2-11; Ord. No. 5439, § 1, 6-25-13) 
13.24.080 - Extension of service outside city limits. 
    The extension of gas mains and service outside the city limits shall be subject to the approval of the board of aldermen and shall also be subject to all of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 15-9) 
13.24.090 - Meter and security deposits. 
A.  If any applicant for gas service is the owner of any premises within the city limits for which a gas service connection with the gas system is desired, the applicant shall not be required to pay a meter deposit fee unless required to do so elsewhere in the code of ordinances of the city. Any owner of any premises within the city limits who paid a meter deposit fee prior to September 21, 2004, may contact the utility billing department and request that the deposit be refunded as a credit on their utility bill. This request shall be granted if the deposit has not previously been credited on a utility bill and is still carried on the records of the city. 
B.  If an applicant for gas service is not the owner of any premises within the city limits for which a gas service connection with the gas system is desired, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a meter deposit fee in the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
C.  If an applicant for gas service is the owner of any premises outside the city limits for which a gas service connection with the gas system is desired, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a meter deposit fee in the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
D.  If an applicant for gas service is not the owner of any premises outside the city limits for which a gas service connection with the gas system is desired, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a meter deposit fee in the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00). 
E.  Upon disconnection of city gas service to the depositor, the deposit shall be applied to any charges incurred and then any balance of such deposit shall be returned to the depositor without interest. 
F.  In addition to the aforesaid meter deposit fee, the applicant shall also deposit with the city clerk a security deposit in the amount of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). This security deposit may be waived by the city clerk or his designate for applicants whose prior or current accounts with the city have been promptly paid and are not in arrears. For new applicants, the security deposit may be waived by the city clerk or his designate if the applicant requests and agrees to consent to a credit check and that credit check indicates the applicant is a good risk. If the credit check reveals unfavorable credit information or if the applicant does not request a credit check, then the aforesaid security deposit shall be required prior to utility connection. There shall be a one time ten dollar ($10.00) charge for each credit check which shall be paid at the time applicant is requesting the credit check. 
G.  If the applicant for gas service is a commercial user, then, in addition to all other deposits or fees set forth herein, the applicant shall pay a security deposit sufficient to secure two months of gas billing for the business. The city shall establish said amount by comparing the usage amounts of similar businesses within the city or, if none, then within two hundred (200) miles of the city. The applicant may request to have the deposit reduced to two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) if the applicant is a resident of the city who has a twenty-four (24) month utility payment history with no late fees assessed. After sixty (60) months of usage during which the applicant has no late utility payments, the applicant may request a return of fifty (50) percent of any deposit in excess of two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00). 
(Ord. 4897 § 2, 2007; Ord. 4558 § 3, 2004: prior code § 15-10) 
(Ord. No. 4991, § 1, 10-21-08; Ord. No. 5679, § 2, 8-18-15) 
13.24.100 - Applications for gas to identify appliances to be used. 
    Every person desiring to be served by the natural gas system of the city shall file an application for gas with the city clerk or her designee, stating the equipment to be connected, and shall file an additional application when any future equipment is added, showing all equipment installed or proposed. 
(Prior code § 15-11) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 45, 8-2-11) 
13.24.110 - City to be notified of any work affecting piping. 
    Any person who performs any work affecting gas piping in any building or grounds shall immediately notify the city of the work performed. 
(Prior code § 15-12) 
13.24.120 - Inspection required before final tie-in of line to meter. 
    Before the final tie-in of the city gas line to any meter is made, it shall be the duty of the city building inspector to make a complete inspection of all work performed under this chapter. 
(Prior code § 15-13) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 46, 8-2-11) 
13.24.130 - Final tie-in of line to meter to be made by the city. 
    The final tie-in of the city gas line to a meter shall be made by the city. 
(Prior code § 15-14) 
13.24.140 - Electrical ground wires. 
A.  No customer shall attach any electrical ground wire to any fixture or piping which is connected to any gas service pipe, meter or main of the city. 
B.  All customers shall remove immediately all electric ground wires which are attached to any fixture or piping connected to any gas service pipe, meter or main of the city and, if such ground wires are not removed by the customer within twenty-four (24) hours after written notice from the city to remove the same, the city, through its officials, shall remove such ground wires and the customer shall pay all costs thereof. 
C.  The city shall hold the owner of the premises upon which an electrical ground wire is attached to any fixture or piping connected to any gas service pipe, meter or main of the city responsible and liable for any injury to city employees or city property caused by such ground wire. 
(Prior code § 15-15) 
13.24.150 - Authority of city to shut off supply. 
    The city shall have the authority to shut off the supply of gas whenever it is necessary to make repairs or improvements, enforce rules or for any other grounds necessary for the safe operation of the natural gas system of the city. 
(Prior code § 15-16) 
13.24.160 - Notice to customers when supply shut off. 
    In all cases when the supply of gas is shut off, where possible, a reasonable notice of the circumstances therefor shall be given to customers, but in an emergency the gas may be shut off without notice. 
(Prior code § 15-17) 
13.24.170 - Repairs to be made rapidly when supply is shut off. 
    All necessary repairs made by the city during the time the gas supply is shut off shall be made as rapidly as may be practical. 
(Prior code § 15-18) 
13.24.180 - Customers not to shut off supply. 
    No customer shall be permitted to use the meter stop of the service connection for shutting off gas while making extensions, additions, or repairs to the pipe or equipment on the premises. Such shutoff or discontinuance or interruption of service will be made only by the city or its properly authorized employees. 
(Prior code § 15-19) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 47, 8-2-11) 
13.24.190 - Right of city to refuse to provide service. 
    The city shall have the right to refuse to provide gas service to any person if the city finds any apparatus or appliance on such person's property which would be detrimental to the efficient operation of the natural gas system of the city. 
(Prior code § 15-20) 
13.24.200 - Discontinuance of service generally. 
    The city reserves the right to discontinue gas service to any premises where the owner or tenant thereof has been found guilty of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or of the following: 
A.  For repairs or because of leaks in any equipment or appurtenances connected with the natural gas system of the city; 
B.  For failure to provide or increase proper security; 
C.  For fraudulent representation in relation to the consumption of gas; 
D.  When the customer has moved from the premises; 
E.  For fraudulent tampering with the meter or connections or for the use of gas through rubber hose or other unsafe appliances; 
F.  For shortage of gas or reason of safety; 
G.  For larceny of gas; 
H.  For any action by the customer to secure through his meter, gas for any purpose other than those contracted for or for any other party without the written consent of the city; 
I.  For failure to comply with the building codes of the city. 
(Prior code § 15-21) 
13.24.210 - Resumption of service. 
    Whenever gas service is disconnected to any premises and the gas therefor is shut off or stopped, whether by order of the city or at the request of the customer, the gas shall not again be turned on or supplied to such premises until all such delinquent charges due the city have been paid and there is no existing default or violation of any of the provisions of this chapter. A written application shall be filed with the city clerk for the renewal of such gas service, which application shall be accompanied by all fees and penalties required by any section of the code of the city, including, but not limited to, Section 13.24.340, for the shutting off and turning on of the gas supplies; provided, however, if the gas supply was shut off at the request of the customer and there were no delinquent charges or violations of this chapter, the charge for renewal of gas service shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) plus the normal deposit for providing gas service as set forth in this chapter. 
(Ord. 4558 § 4, 2004: prior code § 15-22) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 48, 8-2-11) 
13.24.220 - Shutting off supply or discontinuing service-City liability. 
    The city shall not be held responsible or liable for any direct or resultant loss or damage to any person due to shutting off the supply of gas or discontinuing service. 
(Prior code § 15-23) 
13.24.230 - Customers may provide facilities for standby service. 
    Where the nature of a customer's operations are such that an interruption of gas service might create a hazard or large economic loss, such customer may provide facilities for standby service, subject to prior review and approval by the city. 
(Ord. 3660 § 3, 1998: prior code § 15-24) 
13.24.240 - Maintenance of service during street improvements-Liability of city. 
    Whenever mains, pipes, service connections or other facilities of the gas system are taken up, shut off or interfered with by reason of any street improvement by the city, the city shall endeavor to maintain service so far as is reasonably possible but shall not be directly or indirectly liable for any interruption, poor pressure or damage of any kind to the customers adjacent thereto or to other customers affected thereby; provided, however, that direct damage to property due to such operations shall be either repaired or replaced by the city without cost to the customer. 
(Prior code § 15-25) 
13.24.250 - Right of city to require change, removal or replacement of dangerous equipment. 
    The city shall have the right to demand changes, or the removal or replacement of any gas pipe, fixture or apparatus which is faulty, inadequate or hazardous; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to obligate the city in any way or manner. 
(Prior code § 15-26) 
13.24.260 - Inspection of equipment-Repair of defective, noncomplying parts. 
    At all reasonable hours, meters, regulators, fittings, fixtures, and appurtenances connected with the natural gas system of the city and located on private property shall be open for inspection by the proper officers and employees of the city and any part thereof found to be defective or not in compliance with the provisions of this chapter shall be immediately repaired or corrected. If faulty equipment is discovered outside the building, up to and including the meter, the city will repair it at the city's expense. Any repairs to be made past the meter are the responsibility of the customer. 
(Prior code § 15-27) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 49, 8-2-11) 
13.24.270 - Tampering with city equipment unlawful. 
    It is unlawful for any person to break the seal of any meter or in any manner to make any alterations, changes, or repairs on the same or to open any main, lateral, service pipe, meter stop, valve, or any part thereof or otherwise tamper with or attempt to do any work on the same. 
(Prior code § 15-28) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 50, 8-2-11) 
13.24.280 - Damaging equipment prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to willfully or maliciously injure or damage any equipment connected with the natural gas system of the city. 
(Prior code § 15-29) 
13.24.290 - Customers liable for damaged equipment-Adjustment of bill. 
    Whenever a meter, regulator or other equipment of a service connection which has been installed by the city is found damaged for any cause whatsoever, such damages shall become the liability of the customer who shall pay the city the actual cost of removal, repairing and replacing of such damaged equipment. In the event such damage has caused inaccurate metering, then past gas bills shall be corrected in the manner previously provided for in Section 13.24.400. 
(Prior code § 15-30) 
13.24.300 - Disturbing service of other customers. 
    No customer shall use any appliance or device which will in any way modify or disturb the evenness of the gas pressure of other customers in his locality. 
(Prior code § 15-31) 
13.24.310 - Sale of gas by customer. 
    No customer shall sell any gas passing through his meter to another person. 
(Prior code § 15-32) 
13.24.320 - City employees not to accept tips. 
    All employees of the city are strictly forbidden to demand or accept any tips, gratuity or other personal compensation for any service within the scope of this chapter rendered during the hours they are under the employ of the city. 
(Prior code § 15-33) 
13.24.330 - Rules and regulations to be incorporated into contract with customer. 
    All rules and regulations established by the city concerning the use of the facilities of the natural gas system of the city and the consumption of gas therefrom are incorporated into the contract with every customer, and every customer shall be subject thereto and bound thereby. 
(Prior code § 15-35) 
13.24.340 - Delinquent bills. 
A.  Any customer who is delinquent in the payment of charges or rates for gas service for a period of five days shall be notified by the city clerk in writing that, unless such charges are paid within a period of five days, gas service to the customer's premises shall be discontinued and shall not again be turned on until all delinquent charges due the city for gas services, including penalties and a charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) for discontinuing the gas service and a charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) for turning on the gas service, have been paid. 
B.  If it becomes necessary to refer a delinquent account to the city attorney for collection, the customer shall be responsible for a reasonable attorney's fee as well as court costs for the collection of such delinquent billings. 
C.  In addition to all other fees charged in this section, in the event that any bill is delinquent, then the city shall charge a penalty on such delinquent bill at the rate of ten percent of the bill or five dollars, whichever is greater. 
(Ord. 4558 § 5, 2004: Ord. 3660 § 4, 1998: prior code § 15-36) 
13.24.345 - Civil tampering penalty. 
    No person shall tamper with any city natural gas meter. Nothing in this section shall limit the city's ability to engage in the criminal prosecution of any person tampering with a city natural gas meter as set forth elsewhere in this Code. The provisions of this section shall be in addition to and separate from any criminal prosecution. Any city natural gas meter on which any seal to the city natural gas meter or any connection or disconnection of the city natural gas meter has been changed or tampered with so as to disturb or change the action or regulation of the city natural gas meter shall be subject to an additional city natural gas meter tampering fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) which shall be assessed and added to the customer's bill which must be paid prior to the city connecting or reconnecting the city natural gas meter. 
(Ord. No. 5760, § 2, 5-17-16) 
Article 2. - Rates and Charges 

13.24.350 - Rates established. 
    A basic rate schedule for the cost of natural gas to city natural gas customers shall be established as needed in accordance with the provisions of this article. The rates shall be approved by the board of aldermen after receiving input from the city budget officer and consulting gas engineer. The rates shall be published by posting same in City Hall in a form as approved by the board of aldermen. No rate shall be effective unless posted and made available to the public as provided in this chapter. Rate schedules shall also be available to the general public in the office of the city clerk during regular business hours. 
(Ord. 3798 § 1, 1998; Ord. 3664 § 1, 1998: prior code § 15-62) 
13.24.355 - Purchased gas adjustment. 
    The charges stated in this article for natural gas service do not include the city's delivered cost for the purchase of natural gas from its supplier, which cost shall be added to the above-stated charges. The city administrator or his designate is empowered and directed to determine the cost of purchased natural gas on a per thousand cubic feet basis. The cost of natural gas charged by the supplier(s) to the city shall be determined and added to each customer's bill as set forth in Section 13.24.360. Also there shall be correspondingly added to each customer's bill a percentage amount in order to compensate for distribution system losses and city use. The amount for distribution system losses and city use shall be reviewed and updated on or before July 1 of each year as set forth in Section 13.24.360. 
(Ord. 4557 § 1, 2004) 
13.24.360 - Natural gas rate established-Cost of operation considered. 
A.  Any fluctuation in the cost of gas from the city's supplier of natural gas shall be automatically passed on to the gas consumer (fuel cost adjustment). Such fluctuation shall be added to or subtracted from the basic rate schedule established in Section 13.24.350 hereof immediately upon the effective date of the increase or decrease of the cost of gas from the city's natural gas supplier. 
B.  The public works committee or any committee designated by the mayor to supervise the operation of the gas department shall annually study the cost of operation and management of the city's natural gas system and shall file a written report thereof with the mayor and board of aldermen who shall increase or decrease the natural gas rates in the city when necessary for the safe, efficient and financially responsible operation and management of the city's natural gas system. 
(Prior code § 15-64) 
13.24.365 - Natural gas-Budget billing. 
A.  Any residential customer who has not been shut off by the city for nonpayment of a utility bill and who has been a residential customer at the current residence for at least the preceding twelve (12) months may enter into a contract with the city for budget billing of such residential customer's natural gas bill in accordance with the terms and conditions of this section. The purpose of this section is to allow eligible residential customers to pay a reasonably expected amount each month, and nothing in this section shall be construed to be forgiveness by the city of any amount due from the residential customer for actual natural gas use. 
B.  The city may enter into a contract with an eligible residential customer for budget billing under the terms and conditions of this section with the contract stating: 
1.  That the city will add the residential customer's current month's natural gas bill to the previous eleven (11) months' natural gas bills and divide by twelve (12). That result will be the residential customer's budget billing amount due for the month. The city will continue that procedure every month during the duration of the budget billing agreement; 
2.  That the residential customer shall pay the budget billed amount in accordance with this section; 
3.  That the city retains the right to bill the customer for the actual natural gas amount due if the city, in its absolute discretion, has determined that the amount due has become excessive; 
4.  That the contract will be automatically renewed at the end of each twelve (12) month period for an additional twelve (12) month period unless the residential customer requests that the contract not be renewed prior to the end of each year term; 
5.  That the residential customer may reject the renewal of the budget billing contract upon notice to the city at least fifteen (15) days prior to the end of a normal billing cycle; 
6.  That the residential customer shall ultimately be responsible to pay for all natural gas actually used at the actual natural gas rate (as defined in subsection C of this section); 
7.  That in the event the customer fails to pay any utility bill when due, the budget billing contract will be null and void and the customer will immediately owe the city for all natural gas actually used; 
8.  That all other requirements of the code of ordinances of the city must be met by the residential customer; and 
9.  Such other provisions as may be necessary to effect the intent of this section. 
C.  Budget billing will be computed by adding the residential customer's current month's natural gas bill to the previous eleven (11) month's natural gas bill and dividing that sum by twelve (12). That result will be the residential customer's budget billing amount due for the month. The city will continue that procedure every month during the duration of the budget billing agreement. 
D.  In order to implement the budget billing process, the city will determine the amount of "historical natural gas monthly usage" by the residential customer for each month for the twelve (12) months prior to the beginning of the budget billing. The city will determine the "projected natural gas rates" provided by the city's natural gas consultant showing the "projected natural gas rates" for the twelve (12) months of the budget billing cycle. The city will then compute the residential customer's "projected monthly natural gas bill" for each of the twelve (12) months of the budget billing cycle. The residential customer's "projected monthly natural gas bill" for the next twelve (12) months will then be added together and divided by twelve (12) to establish the "base monthly natural gas bill" amount for the budget billing cycle. The residential customer shall then be obligated to pay the "base monthly natural gas bill" plus the "monthly adjustment," which amount shall be the "actual monthly amount due." If in the final month of the budget billing cycle the total amount paid to date is not equal to the total "actual monthly natural gas bill" for the year, the city shall make a final adjustment. 
(Ord. 4814 §§ 1, 2, 2006; Ord. 4705 § 1, 2005) 
13.24.370 - Additional charge for unpaid bills. 
    All bills for natural gas consumed which are not paid within fifteen (15) days after the date of rendition to the customer shall be subject to an additional ten percent charge. 
(Prior code § 15-65) 
13.24.380 - Termination of service for nonpayment of charges. 
    Any customer refusing or neglecting to pay his bill for natural gas consumed for a period of thirty (30) days subsequent to its rendition shall be deprived of the use of gas and the city shall stop all gas supply to such customer until such time that all past-due bills are paid, including all penalty charges. 
(Prior code § 15-66) 
13.24.390 - Nonpayment of charges by tenant-Liability of property owner. 
    Each property owner shall be liable for all charges for natural gas consumed left unpaid by his tenant where such property owner has countersigned the application for gas service on the premises occupied by his tenant and the city reserves the right to shut off any gas service where such delinquent charges are not paid for by the owner. 
(Prior code § 15-67) 
13.24.400 - Average bill may be rendered when meter defective. 
    Whenever the city finds any meter not registering, an average bill may be rendered to the customer, at the option of the city. This average bill shall be based upon a timeframe that most accurately reflects recent usage patterns and/or previous usage history. Whenever the city has reason to believe that a meter is not registering correctly, an average bill, as stated above, may be rendered and the meter removed for testing. If such average bill proves to be incorrectly estimated, either by actual testing or by actual gas consumption after being replaced by a corrected meter, such bill shall be adjusted accordingly. 
(Prior code § 15-68) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 51, 8-2-11) 
Article 3. - Meters 

13.24.410 - Required. 
    All city gas service shall be measured with a meter of adequate size to measure the amount of natural gas consumed. 
(Prior code § 15-79) 
13.24.420 - Location. 
    All meters shall be placed and installed so as to render the same accessible at all times for the purpose of reading and repairing and, wherever practical, shall be set outside of a building. 
(Prior code § 15-81) 
13.24.430 - Venting. 
    All regulators installed indoors shall be vented with an adequate vent extending to the outside. 
(Prior code § 15-82) 
13.24.440 - Separate meter required when. 
A.  No person shall connect any gas service pipe or transmit gas supplied by the natural gas system of the city into two distinct premises from one meter. 
B.  If a natural gas customer is required to have two meters at one address, the city shall provide and install all required equipment, which may include an excess flow valve, service tee, the first seventy-five (75) feet of service pipe, connection, fittings, regulator, meter, and necessary meter stop for a fee indicated on the city's yearly rate schedule. Additionally, the customer shall pay the city an amount listed on the city's yearly rate schedule per lineal foot of service pipe over seventy-five (75) feet. The customer shall be billed for any natural gas that flows through the second meter, but shall not be billed the monthly minimum fee for the second meter. 
C  The board of aldermen shall have the right to establish special services or special connections as may be necessary for large users. 
(Ord. 3660 § 6, 1998; prior code § 15-83) 
(Ord. No. 5312, § 1, 3-6-12) 
13.24.450 - Conclusiveness of meter reading. 
    Except as otherwise specifically provided for in this chapter, all customers shall be liable for all gas consumed, as shown by the appropriate meter, which meter reading shall be conclusive, and waste, leakage or other causes not the liability of the city shall be included under the liability. 
(Prior code § 15-84) 
13.24.460 - Tests. 
A.  In the event a customer requests an accuracy test of a meter, the customer shall be required, prior to making such test, to deposit with the city an amount listed on the city's yearly rate schedule to cover the cost of removing, testing, and replacing such meter. In the event such meter is found to register incorrectly by more than two percent, an accurate meter shall be substituted and the test deposit shall be refunded. Past gas bills shall be adjusted by refund or credit of such percentage of the amount of the gas bills for a period of not more than two months previous to such tests. In the event such meter is found to be registering correctly, the customer shall forfeit the test deposit and such funds shall be deposited in the gas operating funds of the city. 
B.  The city shall perform accuracy tests on industrial meters every year at the city's expense. If the meter falls within a two percent failure rate, the meter shall be replaced as stated in Section 13.24.260 of this chapter. 
(Prior code § 15-85) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 52, 8-2-11) 
Article 4. - Minimum Standards 

13.24.470 - Adoption of certain codes. 
    There is adopted by the city for the purpose of establishing minimum standards for gas installations certain codes, the first one being the "International Fuel Gas Code" published by the International Code Council, being particularly the 2015 Edition; the second one being the "International Plumbing Code" published by the International Code Council, being particularly the 2015 Edition; the third one being the "International Mechanical Code" published by the International Code Council, being particularly the 2015 Edition; and the fourth one being the State Minimum Standards "Transportation of Natural and Other Gas by Pipeline, Parts 191 and 192"; save and except such portions as are hereinafter deleted, modified, or amended. One copy of each of the aforesaid codes are now on file in the office of the city clerk for public use, inspection, and examination, and the same are adopted and incorporated as fully as if set out at length herein and the provisions thereof shall be controlling within the corporation limits of the city. 
(Ord. 4583 § 1, 2004: Ord. 3660 § 7, 1998: prior code § 15-96) 
(Ord. No. 5253, § 1, 8-16-11; Ord. No. 5927, § 1, 7-18-17) 
13.24.480 - Conflict of provisions. 
    In the event of any conflict between the provisions of the codes adopted by this article and any other provisions of this code or other city ordinances, such provisions of this code or other city ordinances shall prevail and be controlling. 
(Prior code § 15-97) 
13.24.490 - Violations of adopted codes-Penalties. 
A.  Any person who violates any provision of any or all of the codes adopted in this article, or who fails to comply with any order made thereunder shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) and costs, or by imprisonment in the city prison not exceeding three months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
B.  The application of the penalty set forth in subsection A of this section shall not be held to prevent the enforced removal of prohibited conditions. 
(Prior code § 15-98) 
13.24.500 - Piping regulations generally. 
A.  The pipe from the outlet of a meter shall be of iron pipe of not less than one inch inside diameter and shall enter the house wall or be securely fastened to the house wall by means of a suitable metal strap or clamp at a point not more than eighteen (18) inches from the outlet connection of the meter and, if extended along the outside walls, shall be fastened to the house wall at intervals sufficient to make the piping rigid throughout. In instances where piping from the meter enters the house wall, the opposite end shall be securely fastened so that the pipe shall not turn when fittings at the meter are put on. 
B.  Gas pipe material and sizing shall be as per the International Fuel Gas Code. 
(Ord. 3660 § 8, 1998; prior code § 15-99) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 53, 8-2-11) 
13.24.510 - Appliances to be vented. 
    All appliances, so designated by the codes adopted and set forth in Section 13.24.470, shall be vented. 
(Prior code § 15-100) 
13.24.520 - Adherence to associations' rules for venting. 
    General rules for venting as prescribed by the codes set forth in Section 13.24.470, as well as those included in the city's building codes, shall be followed. 
(Prior code § 15-101) 
13.24.530 - Installation of vent pipes and draft diverters on gas appliances. 
    An approved type vent pipe and draft diverter shall be installed on all gas-burning space heating and water heating appliances. Such vent pipe shall be installed with not less than one-half inch rise per foot of horizontal run. 
(Prior code § 15-102) 
13.24.540 - Gas appliances to be installed in ventilated location. 
    All gas-burning appliances shall be installed in a location in which the facilities for ventilation permit satisfactory combustion of gas and proper venting under normal conditions of use. 
(Prior code § 15-103) 
13.24.545 - Installation of secondary outside connections. 
    Secondary outside connections for gas-burning appliances may be made to a natural gas meter using a T-connection located behind the meter or other method approved by the superintendent of the natural gas system. The property owner shall submit an application for such connection to the city clerk and the application shall state the maximum BTU load for the property in question. At the city's sole discretion an additional meter may be required based on expected BTU load or service locations. No individual lines to outside lights, grills, or other appliances shall be installed without the permission and supervision of the city. The city in its sole discretion may agree to conduct the installation at the customer's cost or may authorize installation by a private contractor hired by the customer. The installation shall be done in conformance with city codes or, in the absence of such city codes, the International Fuel Gas Code. Actual connections to the appliance or equipment shall be done by a licensed plumber. 
(Ord. No. 5438, § 1, 6-25-13) 
13.24.550 - Chimney to be examined before flue or vent is connected. 
    Before connecting a flue or vent connector into any chimney, the chimney shall be examined to ascertain that it is properly constructed, clear and clean and will freely conduct the products of combustion from the gas-heating appliance in question to the outer air. 
(Prior code § 15-105) 
13.24.560 - Heating plants. 
A.  All designed heating plants shall be of the type approved by the American Gas Association and the manufacturer's recommendations for the installation thereof shall be followed. 
B.  All heating plants of the downdraft type shall be vented by connecting a one-inch black iron pipe from the highest point of the flue passage of the heating plant to the flue pipe. Such one-inch black iron pipe shall be welded or screwed into the furnace in a manner to assure no leakage. 
C.  A high limit control shall be installed on all heating plants. 
(Prior code § 15-106) 
13.24.570 - Service connections to mains. 
    All gas service connections made to the gas mains of the distribution system of the city shall be substantially as follows: 
A.  The connection at the main shall consist of a polyethylene valve service tee three-fourths-inch inside diameter with an excess flow valve. Steel valve tees shall be welded in a workmanlike manner to steel mains. Service lines shall consist of three-fourths-inch approved polyethylene pipe with anodeless riser laid with a #12 coated copper tracer wire, which shall be laid approximately eighteen (18) inches below the ground surface. Approximately one-foot above ground, at or near the building, the service line will be serviced and fitted with a three-fourths-inch black iron or brass meter stop. Prior to drilling the main for gas service, the low pressure service line shall be tested at ninety (90) pounds of pressure and the high pressure side shall be tested at one thousand fifty (1,050) P.S.I. All regulators and meters shall be capable of handling a sufficient volume of gas to service the needs of the customer. 
B.  Wherever it is necessary for service lines to cross under high-type pavements, the service line shall be installed by boring or jacking the service line through underneath the pavement from a point six feet outside of the pavement to six feet beyond the edge of the pavement. 
C.  All lines and fittings shall be capable of withstanding a working pressure of not less than one hundred twenty-five (125) pounds per square inch and shall be so rated by the manufacturer. One fitting of the meter swivel shall be insulated. 
D.  Service connections, where the gas consumption will be in excess of the capacity of the above specifications, shall be made in the manner specified by the engineer or the superintendent of the natural gas system. 
(Prior code § 15-107) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 54, 8-2-11) 
13.24.580 - Connections with house pipe manifold. 
    No connection shall be made with any house pipe manifold that has not been tested for leakage by a licensed plumber. The line must be air tested for a minimum of twenty (20) minutes at twenty (20) pounds per square inch (P.S.I.). Gas services requiring more than one P.S.I. operating pressure shall be tested at ten (10) times operating pressure or maximum pipe rating. All testing must be performed in the presence of the building inspector or gas department personnel. 
(Ord. 3660 § 10, 1998: prior code § 15-108) 
(Ord. No. 5241, § 55, 8-2-11) 
13.24.590 - Conversion burners. 
A.  All gas conversion burners to be installed shall be of the type approved by the American Gas Association. 
B.  No gas conversion burner shall be installed in an old or inefficient warm air furnace or in an old or leaky boiler which is in poor repair. All tests for leakage on warm air heating plants shall be made with oil of wintergreen or a smoke bomb before installing a gas conversion burner. All furnaces shall be reset if found to be leaking. 
(Prior code § 15-109) 
13.24.600 - Installation of hinge pin and spring on firing door. 
    All positive-type catches on any firing door shall be eliminated and a hinge pin and spring shall be installed thereon. 
(Prior code § 15-110) 
13.24.610 - Cutoffs on steam boilers. 
    A low water cutoff control shall be installed on all gas-fired steam boilers. 
(Prior code § 15-111) 
13.24.620 - Installation of gas shutoffs. 
    A gas shutoff, plainly marked, shall be installed in the fuel line directly above the appliance manifold connection. 
(Prior code § 15-112) 
13.24.630 - Connection of gas pilot lines. 
    Every gas pilot line shall be connected to the fuel line ahead of the main shutoff valve. 
(Prior code § 15-113) 
Chapter 13.28 - VIDEO SERVICE REGULATION 
Sections: 

13.28.010 - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known as the "Perryville Video Service Regulation." 
(Ord. 4941 § 1 (part), 2008) 
13.28.020 - Definitions. 
    The words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the meanings as set forth in Section 67.2677 RSMo or, if not defined therein, shall have such meanings as established by the city code. 
(Ord. 4941 § 1 (part), 2008) 
13.28.030 - Franchise fee. 
    Pursuant to Section 67.2689 RSMo, and as partial compensation for use of the city's public rights-of-way, each video service provider or other person providing cable services or video services within the city shall, to the extent permitted by law, pay to the city a fee of five percent of the gross revenues from such video service provider in the geographic area of the city. Such payment shall be made as required by Section 67.2689 RSMo. The city shall have the right to audit any video service provider as authorized by Section 67.2691 RSMo. Late payments shall accrue interest due to the city compounded monthly at one and one-half percent or such other maximum rate as may be established by law. 
(Ord. 4941 § 1 (part), 2008) 
13.28.040 - Customer service requirements. 
    All video service providers providing service within the city shall adopt and comply with the minimum customer service requirements set forth in Section 67.2692 RSMo. Notice or receipt of this chapter by the video service provider shall be deemed notice of the city invoking such customer service requirements. 
(Ord. 4941 § 1 (part), 2008) 
13.28.050 - Rights-of-way-Indemnification-Permits and compliance with other laws. 
    Video service providers shall comply with the requirements of Sections 67.2707 and 67.2709 RSMo and all applicable chapters and regulations consistent with Sections 67.1830 to 67.1846 RSMo relating to use of the city rights-of-way. Each video service provider shall indemnify and hold harmless the city and its officers, employees and agents from any loss or damage, including, but not limited to, attorneys' fees, as provided in such chapters or regulations, but in no event less than the obligation on video service providers set forth in Section 67.2695 RSMo. The city administrator may require documentation of such indemnification by written agreement or other instrument to the extent permitted by law. In addition, video service providers shall be subject to and comply with all supplementary provisions relating to placement, screening and relocation of facilities as may be adopted by the board of aldermen and such other applicable laws of the city except as may be otherwise validly preempted. Notwithstanding any other chapter to the contrary, no facilities to be used for video services shall be installed without obtaining a permit from the city authorizing the location and plans for such facilities; provided that this provision shall not apply to installation of otherwise lawful and authorized poles or wires. 
(Ord. 4941 § 1 (part), 2008) 
13.28.060 - Public, educational and governmental channels. 
    Each video service provider shall designate a number of channels for public, educational and governmental programming consistent with Section 67.2703 RSMo; provided that any greater number of channels, as may be required in the incumbent cable franchise or franchise chapter, shall be required pursuant to Section 67.2703.2 RSMo.
